HEADLINE: Japan Pledges to Open Economy, But Lack of Detail Raises Doubts

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today pledged far-reaching changes in Japan's economic structure and promised a "thoroughgoing deregulation" of the thicket of restrictions that curb just about every aspect of commercial life.
Mr. Hashimoto, who was elected Prime Minister this month, also emphasized in a major speech today to the opening session of Parliament that the relationship with the United States would remain the foundation of Japanese foreign policy. 
 Throughout the speech -- a rough equivalent of an American President's State of the Union address -- Mr. Hashimoto reiterated a pledge for fundamental changes in the way Japan does business. Yet Mr. Hashimoto gave few examples of specific changes he hopes to introduce, and it is far from clear whether much will come of the grand talk of change.
"Reform is Japan's most pressing need today," declared Mr. Hashimoto, a 58-year-old politician with a reputation as a bit more aggressive than most of his predecessors. "Like it or not, there are many changes that must be made in every aspect of Japanese society."
The Government's first priority, Mr. Hashimoto said, is to rebuild the nation's battered economy.
Over the longer term, he said Japan must become more competitive by eliminating regulations that raise the cost of doing business.
"The first structural reform here is that of thoroughgoing deregulation," he declared. "Our basic approach will be to assume that deregulation is appropriate. We will retain regulations only in exceptional cases and we will winnow regulations down to the bare minimum consistent with their original purpose."
But Mr. Hashimoto's reluctance to cite examples inevitably raises questions about his commitment. He has not been known for his passion for liberalization, and just last year, he helped lead the fight against American demands to deregulate the market for repair of cars.
Polls show that the Japanese support the concepts of "economic reform" and "deregulation." But such concepts gather opposition when they take specific form: liberalizing the rice market, allowing the spread of supermarkets, and easing curbs on foreign medicines.
Much of the support for Mr. Hashimoto's party, the Liberal Democrats, comes from farmers and small businesses, who have a great deal at stake in maintaining regulations that protect them from lower-cost competitors.
Ichiro Ozawa, the leader of the New Frontier Party, the main opposition group, immediately complained that Mr. Hashimoto had not been specific in his speech.
"It's quite regrettable that he did not express his exact thinking in his speech," said Mr. Ozawa, who has called for sweeping specific changes that would amount to a revolution in Japanese life. Mr. Ozawa will have the opportunity on Wednesday to grill Mr. Hashimoto in Parliament.

HEADLINE: Is West Slighting Africa's Hot Spots Like Liberia?

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 22

 BODY:
 When the chief American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, stopped here briefly on Wednesday during a tour of several African countries, there were the predictable pledges of assistance from Washington to war-torn Liberia.
But along with the promise of helicopters and trucks to help in the disarming of combatants in a devastating six-year civil war, there was also a stern warning that the international community had little patience for crisis-ridden African countries that failed to settle their own problems. 
 "We have no intention of our logistical support being squandered by anyone's failure of political will," Mrs. Albright said at an airport news conference, straining at times to be heard over a Nigerian transport plane ferrying in new peacekeepers. "Delay," she said, can "no longer be in the vocabulary" of Liberia's political actors.
But for many African leaders and diplomats, the trip by Mrs. Albright -- the highest-ranking American to visit Liberia since Secretary of State George Shultz came here before the war that killed more than 150,000 people -- inadvertently underscored another point: by the time African crises receive this level of outside attention, the moment for averting catastrophe or sealing the peace has all too often passed.
The most critical obstacle to fulfilling the Liberian peace agreement reached last August, these African officials say, has been the delay in getting the kind of international response needed to carry out a disarmament program and remake this country's shattered economy.
In this regard, African officials argue, the handling of the Liberian crisis by the outside world strongly resembles the ambivalent or tardy international response to past crises in other stops on Mrs. Albright's itinerary: Angola, Rwanda and Burundi.
In Liberia, despite widespread skepticism about its prospects, a cease-fire has largely held for months. But recent days have seen the first serious signs of an unraveling of the country's settlement, as unruly fighters of one of the country's several armed factions have killed as many as 50 West African peacekeepers.
Diplomats say the fighting began because of the economic desperation of the militia members, who are often unschooled boys, and add that the conflict nearly flared out of control because of the limited means available to a short-handed and poorly equipped peacekeeping force.
"Last fall, the American Government pledged $75 million to help us," said Wilton S. Sankawulo, the former schoolteacher who is chairman of Liberia's governing Council of State. "But they said go home first and prove that you are serious."
Liberia has been the first instance in which a regional organization, namely the Economic Community of West African States, or Ecowas, has acted with the official sanction of the United Nations to end a civil war. Nigeria has led this effort from the start, spending an estimated $4 billion. But with major political and economic crises at home, diplomats say Nigeria cannot now carry out Liberia's peace agreement without substantially more outside help.
Foreign diplomats say the most critical immediate element is giving the 7,500-man Nigerian-led peacekeeping force -- known as Ecomog, for the Ecowas monitoring group -- the means to deploy throughout the country: the trucks and helicopters pledged but not yet delivered by the Americans, and more troops from poor West African countries, which would require financing from the outside world.
Unlike other crises in which the United Nations sends it own peacekeepers and directly assesses contributions from members, international fund-raising for Liberia has been conducted through voluntary donor conferences that have garnered sparse contributions.
On top of the outside world's reluctance to contribute to an African-led peacekeeping effort, which has embittered many of this region's leaders, there is the additional complication of deeply strained relations between the United States and Nigeria over the latter's human rights situation.
Rather than being turned over to the Nigerian-led peacekeepers, as is the practice in most international efforts of this sort, the troop trucks promised by the United States are leased vehicles that, at Washington's insistence, will be operated only by private contractors to keep them out of Nigerian hands.
"The resources of Ecomog have been stretched to the limit, and it would be wrong and unfair for the international community to expect it to proceed further without getting it more help," said Anthony Nyaki, the United Nations special representative to Liberia. "Because of the unique mandate given by the U.N. to the West Africans, whatever happens here will be precedent-setting.
"In five days as much is spent in Bosnia as was spent in a whole year on Liberia," he said. "If this is allowed to fail, the question will become more pertinent than ever why the outside world cares so little for Africa."
The comparison with Bosnia is one that comes up again and again in conversations with African officials throughout this region, and it is one that inspires cynicism among many.
The international community was slow to act and committed far too few resources to managing crises like the transition to democracy in war-torn Angola or the prevention of a genocidal civil war in Rwanda, African diplomats say. And in Burundi today, where the signs of a possible Rwanda-style civil war are multiplying, the same reluctance to act seems apparent to many.
"Since Somalia ended, I have attended three major conferences on the lessons of that crisis, but these lessons never seem to be learned," said Victor Gbeho, a Ghanaian diplomat who represents the West African economic community here and was the United Nations special envoy to Somalia at the height of that country's crisis.
"For some reason it still takes far too long to get the international community to react to African crises, to realize their pledges of support and work through their bureaucratic mazes," Mr. Gbeho said. "It took the Americans one week to raise $1.8 billion for Bosnia. If I were paranoid, I would say the delays we always face here are due to the fact that we are dealing with Africa."

HEADLINE: Clinton to Ban Contracts to Companies That Hire Illegal Aliens

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton is expected to issue an order barring Federal contracts with companies that illegally hire undocumented foreign workers, Administration officials said today.
The order is part of a stepped-up effort to stop employers from hiring illegal immigrants and to open jobs for American citizens. 
 Congress outlawed the hiring of illegal aliens in 1986, but enforcement has faded in the last six years. Doris M. Meissner, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, said in an interview: "This whole area of employer enforcement has been moribund. There has been a steady decline in effort and resources directed at the workplace."
Immigration is becoming a volatile issue in the Presidential campaign, especially in states like California, Florida and Texas, and Mr. Clinton wants to make sure that Republicans cannot use the issue against him, Administration officials said. In Los Angeles eight days ago, Senator Bob Dole, the front-running candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, criticized Mr. Clinton's record on immigration, saying the President had not helped California cope with the costs of illegal immigrants.
The Administration is already using the armed forces and local law-enforcement agencies to bolster the Border Patrol in Arizona and California. Mexico's economic problems have increased the pressure for illegal immigration. Recognizing that many illegal immigrants are lured to this country by jobs, Congress recently directed the immigration service to double its corps of workplace investigators.
By issuing an executive order, the President can take action by himself, without needing Congress to pass comprehensive legislation to overhaul immigration policy. White House officials say Mr. Clinton will make increased use of such orders to put his imprint on domestic policy and to show that he has not been stymied by Republicans in this election year.
As a condition of doing business with the Government, companies promise to obey Federal immigration and labor laws, but until now, the Government has not had a systematic way to exclude contractors that violate these laws.
The President's order would require all Federal agencies to inform other units when companies are found to have hired illegal aliens and cooperate to bar such companies from doing further work for the Government.
The order is likely to complement the agency's new emphasis on workplace violations. Mrs. Meissner said the enforcement efforts would focus on industries with a history of employing illegal workers, like construction, food processing, hotels, restaurants and agriculture.
Thomas P. Fischer, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Atlanta, said the agency had arrested 34 illegal aliens working on construction of a new Federal office building there in June.
"That building is just 300 feet from my office," Mr. Fischer said. "The illegal workers were Guatemalans, Mexicans and some Canadians also. They were working as carpenters and skilled craftsmen in a union shop. The jobs were later filled by U.S. citizens for wages up to $15 an hour." The case, he said, began with complaints from American citizens at the work site.
Russell A. Bergeron Jr., a spokesman for the immigration service, recalled a similar case in which Mexicans were illegally working on a project to build housing for Army families at Fort Polk, La. The Mexicans were "laying concrete slabs and doing drywall work," Mr. Bergeron said.
The Federal Government buys huge amounts of goods and services, awarding contracts for roughly $200 billion a year. For example, the General Services Administration, the central housekeeping and supply agency for the Government, owns or leases space in more than 7,000 buildings. About 26 million people, accounting for 20 percent of the civilian labor force, work for Federal contractors and subcontractors.
President Clinton declared last year that "border deterrence cannot succeed if the lure of jobs in the United States remains," and he promised to "toughen work-site enforcement and employer sanctions."
Rahm I. Emanuel, a White House aide who works on immigration policy, said the paperwork for the new order had not gone to the President but was being circulated among agencies with an interest in the issue.
Mr. Fischer, the immigration official in Atlanta, said he had tried to persuade the general services agency to crack down on contractors employing illegal immigrants. But "the G.S.A. washes its hands of this," he said in an interview. "They say: 'We just award the contracts. It's up to the contractor or the subcontractor to fulfill legal obligations as to who can work and who can't work.' "
Mr. Fischer said the State of Georgia and local government agencies had taken swift action to correct problems when illegal aliens were found working on their construction projects. But he said: "No one from the G.S.A. has ever called us expressing concern or asking, 'How can we make sure this doesn't happen again?'
"Here's someone in the Federal family, someone we work with and know, the Government's real estate agent. You might think they would have the professionalism and follow-through and wherewithal to say: 'We're embarrassed. We don't want this happening again. How can we prevent it?' "
The Government has elaborate rules specifying how contracts shall be awarded. Under these rules, the Government may disqualify any company found to have committed an "offense indicating a lack of business integrity or business honesty."
Ida M. Ustad, Associate Administrator of the General Services Administration, said "there has been some discussion" of denying contracts to companies found to have employed illegal foreign workers.
"We wouldn't have any objection to it," Ms. Ustad said, "but there's not any systematic way to do it. The I.N.S. does not train its people to consider debarment as an option. As a first step, I.N.S. needs to set up a system to make referrals to other agencies."
The Presidential order would require agencies to work together.
Ms. Ustad said that if the immigration service knew that a Federal contractor was violating the immigration law, it could send the information to the agency that does the most business with that company. Agency officials could then decide whether to bar the contractor from further dealings with the Government, and in an extreme case a contract could be terminated.
The Government publishes a monthly list of thousands of companies ineligible for Federal contracts for various reasons.
Members of Congress from both parties have demanded tougher enforcement of immigration laws,and under a bill signed by Mr. Clinton on Jan. 6, the budget for the immigration service will be increased by 24 percent, to $2.6 billion this year from $2.1 billion in 1995.
Mr. Clinton has already shown that he intends to use the purchasing power of the Government to advance his policies. Under an executive order issued in March, he declared that Federal agencies must not do business with companies that hire permanent replacements for striking workers.
The Chamber of Commerce of the United States filed suit to block it, but Judge Gladys Kessler of the Federal District Court here rejected the challenge. Enforcement of Mr. Clinton's order has been held up while the Chamber of Commerce appeals Judge Kessler's ruling.
The number of employers investigated for possible immigration law violations declined sharply, to 5,963 last year from 14,706 in 1989. While the amount collected in fines rose to $6.2 million in 1992 from $4 million in 1989, it fell to $4.1 million last year.
Congress recently provided $50 million to beef up enforcement of immigration laws in the workplace, allowing Mrs. Meissner to hire 384 new investigators to join the 320 already in the field.
In an example of its new efforts, Mrs. Meissner said, the agency last week arrested 112 illegal aliens in construction, factory and restaurant jobs in Delaware, the District of Columbia, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A Michelangelo in Manhattan?
A stately house on Fifth Avenue may be the home to Manhattan's only sculpture by Michelangelo, a three-foot statue of a naked, curly-haired youth, which is missing its arms and part of its legs. [Page A1.]
 
Schools Move Off Failing List
Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner, announced that he was taking Roosevelt High School and 10 other New York City schools off the failing schools list, the highest number to come off at one time since the list was created in 1989. Mr. Mills said there is no great mystery to turning around failing schools. "Essentially, it's just hard, relentless work to improve performance," he said. [B1.]
 
Takeover of Carting Company
In a move that officials said should lower garbage removal costs for businesses in New York City, one of the country's biggest waste hauling companies, USA Waste Services Inc., said it would take over a carting company that is under indictment for being part of a Mafia-run cartel. [B1.]
 
Nicotine Fix in Exile
Since Mayor Giuliani signed a law a year ago to restrict smoking in public places, smokers have been driven out of offices, restaurants and ball parks -- not to mention hospitals -- in search of nicotine fixes. Not every smoker minds the exile. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Charges of Brutality at Rikers
State and Federal prosecutors are investigating a dozen allegations of brutality by Rikers guards, including a case in which lawsuits charge that two inmates were unjustifiably beaten by officers. [B3.]
 
Police Kill New Jersey Man
A few blocks from the Harlem housing project at which an officer fatally wounded an unarmed man Saturday night, police officers shot and killed a New Jersey man in front of a Washington Heights pool hall. [B3.]
 
Plea Talks in Assisted Suicide
George Delury, who helped his ailing 52-year-old wife, Myrna Lebov, commit suicide, said that his lawyer would be meeting with prosecutors in the next 10 days to discuss a possible plea bargain. [B2.]
 
REGION
 
Helping a Flood-Ravaged Town
With help from emergency services from around the region, the town of Walton, N.Y., began recovery efforts after the worst flash flood there in memory. Governor Pataki flew to Walton by helicopter with pledges of state aid and to announce a request for Federal disaster relief. [A1.]
 
Waters Recede, Losses Mount
Flood waters continued to recede across hundreds of square miles in the Middle Atlantic States, leaving thick layers of mud, terrible human suffering and financial losses that are sure to be staggering. The Federal Emergency Management Agency and insurance companies said it was too early to put a dollar figure on the disaster. [B4.]
 
As the flood waters of Pennsylvania's big rivers receded and thousands of residents returned to their homes, the state said the economic losses could reach $700 million. [B4.]
 
When Offices for Poor Close
The Westchester County Department of Social Services has closed four of its eight offices in the county to save rent. Advocates for the poor said the closings would deprive the most vulnerable and desperate residents of help they needed. [B1.]
 
On-Line Pornography Bill Gains
The New York State Assembly passed a bill that would make it a punishable offense to send pornographic materials to minors over computer networks. An identical bill passed in the Senate and Governor Pataki has said he supports regulating pornography in the booming on-line computer industry. [B5.]
 
Following Giuliani's Lead
Adopting an idea proposed last year by Mayor Giuliani, the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said that parents on welfare should be required to work in the public schools. His proposal drew strong support from the Republican-dominated County Legislature. [B5.]
 
Nassau Approves Smoking Ban
The Nassau County Health Department approved new regulations, which take effect on July 1, that ban smoking in all restaurants except in separately enclosed, separately ventilated rooms comprising no more than 25 percent of a restaurant's seating capacity. [B5.]
 
Sweep of Jail Is Completed
The 160 state corrections officers who temporarily took over the Hudson County jail in Kearny, N.J., last week left the site, except for a small management team that remained to help administer the jail for the county. State officials said they had successfully swept the building for contraband ranging from drugs to homemade weapons. [B5.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Drop on Talk Of a Default

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Investors in the credit markets turned bearish yesterday in response to fresh Republican threats over the weekend to thwart an increase in the Federal debt limit unless it was done on their terms.
Prices also fell as the market weighed the effect of the more than $30 billion of new Treasury notes being sold this week. A weaker dollar also put a drag on prices; a soft dollar makes American investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreigners because the currency movement reduces the gain. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 12/32 in price, to 111 13/32 for a yield of 6.04 percent, up from 5.97 percent on Friday. For investors the loss amounted to a little more than $10 for every $1,000 of bonds held.
The threat made over the weekend by the House majority leader, Dick Armey, to push the nation into default, combined with this week's big Treasury auctions, created an atmosphere in which seemingly no one wanted to buy, traders said. Although the chance of an actual Government default is considered small, market participants would rather see a zero chance.
After the market closed, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told Republican leaders that he had run out of legal options to sidestep the national borrowing limit and could keep the Government from defaulting on its debt after Feb. 29 only through the "completely unacceptable" methods of selling off the national gold reserve or holding up tax refunds.
House Speaker Newt Gingrich said, "We are, quite frankly, at an impasse."
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm with more than $6 billion in bonds under management, said yesterday that in addition to the negative factors in the background, "keep in mind that today's setback in the bond market comes on the heels of the best week for bond market performance since August of last year."
Noting that the yield on the five-year note dropped to about 5.50 percent from about 5.70 percent last week, he said, "it was inevitable that some profit taking would occur today."
"Another negative is that some supply is coming this week, with a two-year note on Tuesday and a five-year note that will be auctioned on Wednesday," he said. "However, the largest one-day negative relates to the continuation of the acerbic debate between the President and Congress with respect to the budget deficit. The bond market at this juncture is simply tired of eating leftovers and tired of being forced to watch reruns."
Mr. Carpenter said the continued political impasse was leading many bond investors to fear that the budget issue would be a fairly long-term matter, persisting through this Presidential campaign year.
"The best-case scenario and probably the scenario for this Friday is that another stop-gap spending measure will be enacted," Mr. Carpenter said, "but the market knows that this, in effect, solves nothing in the sense that no long-term budget is implemented by this action, and secondly, no resolution to the scary debt-ceiling issue is in sight."
Nonetheless, there is "a better-than-even chance we will get another interest rate cut" from the Federal Reserve, he said, adding, "This rally still has legs."
At yesterday's auction, the three- and six-month bills drew good investor demand at an average rate of 4.99 percent and 4.88 percent, respectively. Traders said the ratio of bids to the number of bills actually sold was about 4.8 to 1, but that could be because the size of yesterday's auction was $2 billion less than last week's auction. Bills continued to benefit from a flight of money away from the equity market and from the longer maturities as the budget debate goes on, traders said.
Today, the Government will auction $18.25 billion of new two-year notes and tomorrow, $12 billion of five-year notes. By late in the day in when-issued trading, the notes were offered at a price to yield 5.08 percent for a two-year maturity and 5.34 percent for a five-year.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Good News for President in the Latest Poll

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message tonight, President Clinton will address a public that is suddenly expressing new concerns about the Federal deficit but still gives Mr. Clinton higher marks than the Republican Congress for trying to break the budget impasse, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The survey of public sentiment at the opening of the Presidential campaign shows that the months of turmoil on Capitol Hill over balancing the budget have propelled the deficit to the forefront of the public's agenda. After years of ranking the economy or crime as the most important issue facing the nation, people now put the deficit first. 
 The battle over the budget has also left 3 out of 10 Americans with the view that politics in Washington is more mean-spirited than in the past, and 6 out of 10 expect the budget standoff to drag on for a long time, the poll shows. But more people blame the Republicans: 6 out of 10 surveyed said Mr. Clinton was really trying to find a solution to the budget standoff, while only 4 out of 10 said Republicans in Congress were really trying.
As Mr. Clinton delivers the speech that is intended to serve as the thematic preview of his re-election drive, he can take comfort that the voters in his own party have remained remarkably loyal. Seventy-nine percent of the Democrats polled said they had a favorable opinion of Mr. Clinton, his highest rating ever. His overall job approval rating among all those surveyed remained fairly steady at 47 percent, down only 4 percentage points from December. Nevertheless, approval ratings at this stage of a campaign are rarely a reliable indicator of how a candidate will fare on Election Day.
The poll was done in a telephone survey of 1,076 adults nationwide from Jan. 18 to 20; it has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The poll indicates that Mr. Clinton faces a nation that, while uneasy about the economy, is somewhat less gloomy than four years ago. Sixty-four percent of those polled said they were generally dissatisfied with "the way things are going in the United States at this time."
But the public does not appear to be fixated on a single issue, as when President George Bush was gearing up for his re-election campaign. At this time in 1992, an overwhelming 51 percent of those surveyed cited the economy and jobs as the nation's most pressing problem.
Asked in the current survey to identify the most important problem facing the country, 19 percent cited the deficit, up from only 8 percent in October. While that figure shows that the entire public is not preoccupied with the deficit, 19 percent is a significant number because most other issues scored in only single digits. The surge of interest in the deficit might also reflect heavy news coverage of the issue. Seventeen percent identified the economy and jobs as the most important issue, followed by 13 percent citing crime and violence.
And, in answer to a separate question, 68 percent said balancing the budget was more important than cutting taxes; 27 percent said a tax cut was more important.
In a follow-up interview yesterday, one of the poll respondents, Alexander Dzilvelas of Agoura, Calif., said why he was more concerned about the deficit. "It's been business as usual for too long," said Mr. Dzilvelas, 67, an aerospace consultant. "The interest payments on the debt have become as large as the endowment programs. Whether you're liberal or conservative, you have to be more willing to compromise. The political debate has become increasingly negative, and because of the budget impasse, it's going to continue."
Another respondent, Larry Hoe, 43, a student from Hobart, N.Y., expressed disenchantment with Republicans and Democrats on the deficit issue. He said, "Instead of dealing with the problems, the two parties are spending their time trying to prove which side is better."
With Mr. Clinton fresh from his visit to the troops in Bosnia, his most appreciable gain appears to be in foreign policy. Fifty-percent of those polled approved of the way the President was handling foreign policy, up from 41 percent in December. Specifically, 55 percent approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling the situation in Bosnia.
On the home front, Mr. Clinton's support seems to be holding firm, despite recent spurts of publicity about Hillary Rodham Clinton's involvement in the Whitewater and White House travel office cases. In separate questions, 6 out of 10 people said that the President, as well as Mrs. Clinton, was mostly telling the truth about Whitewater but was still hiding something.
Americans have long been divided about the First Lady, but her image has been further tarnished in recent weeks. Her unfavorable rating was at a high of 40 percent, while her favorable rating was 36 percent. In comparison, another First Lady, Nancy Reagan, often drew criticism, but her favorable ratings were always three times as high as her unfavorable ratings.
Still, many people were sympathetic to what they consider tough treatment of Mrs. Clinton; 78 percent of those polled said Republicans in Congress had criticized her on Whitewater for partisan gain, and 58 percent said the news media had been harder on her than on other First Ladies.
Just three weeks before the Presidential caucuses in Iowa, the survey of registered voters nationwide indicates that Mr. Clinton would beat the leading Republican, Senator Bob Dole, 51 percent to 40 percent. But in what could be a sign of Mr. Dole's possible weakness, Mr. Clinton does not do so well against a generic Republican nominee. The President still wins, but the tally is 46 percent to 39 percent.
One explanation for Mr. Clinton's strength is that many voters view him as a check on the Republican Congress. Forty-nine percent of the respondents said that if the Republicans continued to control Congress after the 1996 election, it would be better to re-elect Mr. Clinton "to limit the power of Republicans in Congress." Just 39 percent said it would be better to elect a Republican President "to increase the power of Republicans in Congress."
Mr. Clinton scored well on other leadership questions. Fifty-three percent of the voters polled said he had strong qualities of leadership, the highest level since 1993. And 51 percent said he had worked hard to bring about change.
But the President is not winning credit for the improvements in the economy, the poll showed. That might be because many people see little economic improvement themselves. For instance, only 51 percent of those surveyed called the condition of the national economy good, down 7 percentage points since December.
When specifically asked whether Mr. Clinton had made progress in significantly improving the economy, only 35 percent said he had, while 57 percent said he had not. In a split that is essentially unchanged from other readings over the past six months, 44 percent approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling the economy, while 48 percent disapproved.
Although Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate who entered the race in September, has doubled his strength since December, the survey shows that Mr. Dole continues to hold a commanding lead over the rest of the Republican Presidential field. Among people who said they would vote in the Republican primaries, 43 percent preferred Mr. Dole, while 12 percent were for Mr. Forbes. Patrick J. Buchanan, the former commentator, and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas each got 7 percent support, and the remaining contenders had 2 percent or less.
These national numbers do not reflect the candidates' strength in the early battleground states of Iowa and New Hampshire, where they have concentrated their campaigning and advertising.
By most measures, Mr. Dole has maintained a strong, positive image. Fifty-four percent approved of the way he is handling his job as majority leader, and 62 percent said he had strong leadership qualities. Even though Mr. Dole, 72, would be the oldest person ever to attain the Presidency, that does not bother most voters. Sixty-two percent said his age would not matter that much; 30 percent said it would be an obstacle to being an effective President, and 6 percent said his age would actually help him.
The poll shows that Speaker Newt Gingrich still has quite a negative image with the public, with 34 percent approving the way he handles his job and 55 percent disapproving. After the first year of Republican control of the Congress, 52 percent of those surveyed said Congress had accomplished less than in past years, and only 32 percent said it had accomplished more.
While Mr. Forbes has made a flat tax the centerpiece of his candidacy, and other Republicans have made their own proposals to streamline the tax system, the issue has yet to catch on with most Republicans or Democrats, according to the survey. While the current tax system taxes wealthier people at higher rates than people with less money, a flat tax would use one tax rate for people of all income levels. Twenty-seven percent of those polled favored that idea, 33 percent opposed it, and 38 percent said they did not know enough about it to comment.
Mr. Forbes's rivals have warned that his flat-tax proposal would hurt the middle class because it would eliminate the deduction for home mortgages. When respondents were asked about eliminating that deduction, the support for a flat tax declined by 10 percentage points, the opposition declined by 4 points, and uncertainty went up by 14 points. Six out of 10 of those polled said the rich would benefit most from a flat tax.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 18 to 20 with 1,076 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of active residential exchanges in the country. The list of more than 36,000 residential exchanges is maintained by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans or independents taken as a group.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Clashing Over Welfare Cuts;
Closing of Westchester Benefits Offices Is Criticized

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Last year, when Frances Gilkes needed to talk to her welfare worker about her benefits, she walked a block and a half from her apartment to the social services office on North Avenue, the main artery in downtown New Rochelle. "It took five minutes at most," said Ms. Gilkes, a 43-year-old mother of three who suffers from a herniated disk, the result of an injury that occurred two years ago when she was doing volunteer work at a senior citizens center.
But a month ago, the Westchester County Department of Social Services closed its New Rochelle office as part of a program that shut down four of eight offices in the county in order to save rent. Now, Ms. Gilkes, who has no car, no money for public transportation and as much trouble walking long distances as some of the elderly people she once helped, says she will have to walk to the office in Mount Vernon, about a mile and a half away. 
 "I pray I'll make it," she said. "But with my back problems, my legs will probably give out."
Westchester officials defend the closings, saying that the four shuttered offices -- in New Rochelle, Ossining, Mount Kisco and Port Chester -- handled only 18 percent of the county welfare cases and were inefficient. All the cases and employees were transferred to other offices, which still leaves Westchester with more welfare offices than most other counties in the state.
"It's economy of scale," said Nancy Shull, the county's Deputy Commissioner of Social Services.
Advocates for the poor, on the other hand, say that the most vulnerable and desperate residents will not get the help they need.
"We're particularly concerned about the elderly," said Rachel Leon, a spokeswoman for Hunger Action Network of New York State. "How are they going to get to these offices? We've asked Social Services to help with transportation, and they've refused. Westchester has one of the worst records in the state when it comes to treatment of clients. This is adding insult to injury."
National welfare experts say that such a reduction in district offices is unusual, and that they have not seen similar cutbacks elsewhere in the country. But they hasten to add that such closings may become a part of a national trend as local governments seek to cut costs in this era of fiscal pruning. On Long Island, the Suffolk County Department of Social Services is to close its Mastic office in two months, leaving the county with five welfare centers instead of six.
Westchester, which has cut welfare costs with a workfare program and strict enforcement of welfare eligibility rules, has already captured the attention of proponents of change in the welfare system. In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has started a workfare program similar to Westchester's that stresses fraud prevention and enforcement. Gov. George E. Pataki has hailed Westchester as a model for state welfare reform, even bringing Mary E. Glass, the county's Commissioner of Social Services, up to Albany to head the state's Department of Social Services, during the early days of his administration.
Westchester's two major reform initiatives have saved about $62 million for the county, state and Federal government, according to Norman Shaw, a spokesman for the county's Department of Social Services. The reduction in welfare offices is expected to save a pittance by comparison, about $900,000 a year in rent, leading some advocates for the poor to question the motive for the closings.
"We're beginning to believe that this is a way to discourage people from accessing services," said Jacquetta Cole, a director of the New Rochelle Community Action Program, an organization that rose out of Lyndon Johnson's "War on Poverty" initiative. Ms. Cole says her organization has offered Social Services free space for a satellite office in New Rochelle, but has not yet received a response. "If they're considering it," she said, "we don't know anything about it."
While acknowledging that the closings would present a hardship for some people, Ms. Shull, the Deputy Commissioner, denied that the action was aimed at trimming the welfare rolls, and she predicted that it would have no such impact. The district office in Ossining closed at the end of September, and "we've seen no reduction in activity or cases from the Ossining-Tarrytown area," she said.
Before the cutback, Westchester had more district offices than any county in the state with the exception of those in New York City, which has 40 welfare centers in the five boroughs. "Most counties in New York only have one," said Dr. Anthony Cupaiuolo, director of the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy at Pace University. He added that he did not expect the office closings to result in a reduction in the welfare rolls.
"Westchester is actually progressive," he said. "It's still providing more access" than most other counties. Nassau County, for example, has only two district offices.
The closings in Westchester would not only save money, Ms. Shull said, but it would also allow Social Services to operate more efficiently and better handle changes in the welfare system being proposed by the state and Federal government.
The centers that were shut down did not offer a full range of benefits, Ms. Shull said, noting that the New Rochelle office did not place the homeless in shelters or help people with foster care needs. And the office in Mount Kisco, which closed on Jan. 8, did not help people with Medicaid benefits or foster care.
The Yonkers office, which manages 49.6 percent of the county's public assistance caseload, was not affected. The three other offices that remain open are in Mount Vernon, Peekskill and White Plains.
But advocates for the poor say that whatever the reasons for the closings, many of the county's 17,800 public assistance recipients, whose nerves are already frayed by what they call an unwieldy bureaucracy, will become more frustrated. At worst, they say, fewer poor people, will apply for help.
Dennis Hanratty, executive director of Mount Vernon United Tenants, which receives about 35 percent of its money from the county's Social Services Department, agreed. He predicted that elderly residents of low-crime areas like Pelham and Mamaroneck, who were formerly assigned to the New Rochelle office, would be apprehensive to venture into Mount Vernon, a city struggling with drug and crime problems. "It's going to be horrible," he said.
But fear of being mugged is not the primary concern of Ursula Greenridge, a 66-year-old New Rochelle resident who is fighting to have her food stamps benefits restored. Ms. Greenridge, a native of Barbados who rarely leaves her apartment except to get dialysis treatments three times a week and to eat dinner at a local soup kitchen, said she feared getting lost in the city.
"I don't know Mount Vernon," she said, tightly clutching her forehead. "I don't know where the place is. I don't know how I'll get there."
Social Service officials say welfare recipients only have to visit their district offices once a year. But that contention was widely disputed by clients and advocates for the poor.
"There are many reasons a client might need to go in," said Jerrold Levy, an attorney with Westchester-Putnam Legal Services. Many public assistance recipients get more than one benefit, and sometimes, they must come in for a separate certification for each benefit. Emergency situations -- an eviction, lack of heat, a broken refrigerator, problems with day care -- might prompt visits.
"Crisis is normalcy for these clients," Mr. Levy said. "At the very least, people will go in twice a year, and many will go in 10 to 15 times a year."
Ms. Gilkes said she visited the New Rochelle center more than two dozen times last year. "You have to bring in this document, then that document," she said.
Although many documents needed to process benefits can be sent through the mail, advocates for the poor say they are often lost through bureaucratic bungling or carelessness.
Ms. Gilkes agreed. "They tell you they never got it," she said.

HEADLINE: A Flood-Torn Village Finds It Has Friends From the City

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WALTON, N.Y., Jan. 22

 BODY:
On one side of the mud-caked street, firefighters from the Bronx unloaded pumps and coils of garden hose. On the other, a dozen firefighters from the Westchester village of Buchanan manned heavy hoses sucking water from the flooded basement of a drugstore.
The men, all more than 100 miles from home, were helping the 6,000 stunned residents of this flood-ravaged town deep in the waterlogged hills of Delaware County recover from the worst flash flood in memory. 
 In two days this weekend, a surge of 25 billion gallons of water from heavy rains and melting snow -- more than 100 times the average amount for two winter days -- poured down the hillsides around Walton into the west branch of the Delaware River and on into New York City's Cannonsville Reservoir.
On its way, the water wreaked havoc. On Friday night, a road collapsed, sending two children, their parents and an uncle to watery deaths, along with another man, whose body was still being sought today. Downtown Walton was inundated. Fire apparently caused by electrical short circuits brought on by the rising waters destroyed two stores.
Gov. George E. Pataki flew to Walton by helicopter today with pledges of state aid and to announce a request for Federal disaster relief. He declined to estimate the damage caused by flooding in New York, as did officials in New Jersey, but authorities in Pennsylvania estimated the damage there at more than $700 million. [Page B4.]
Although it brought tragedy and economic paralysis, the flooding in Delaware County helped cement a newborn partnership with New York City, which draws much of its drinking water from the area. The city sent 50 pumps, 8 highway engineers and more than a dozen trucks to help with the cleanup.
There was plenty of work to be done. Two hundred of Delaware County's 352 bridges were damaged in the flood, with 11 ruined beyond repair, said Ray Christensen, chairman of the County Board of Supervisors. In the village of Margaretville, several stores were washed away. Hundreds of miles of roads were so undercut, cracked or crumbling that the county had run out of orange plastic caution cones.
Jack Kelly, Mayor of the village of Walton, part of the town of the same name, stood in mud today and stared at the charred, icicle-fringed remains of the burned-out clothing and hardware stores on Main Street.
"Everything was starting to go right," Mayor Kelly said. "We'd just finished upgrading our water system, we'd repaved a lot of roads. This has taken the heart out of Walton."
Today, the town and surrounding communities came to life in a rumble of heavy trucks and front-end loaders and in a flurry of volunteerism. Residents whose homes were above the high-water mark helped neighbors shovel muck from living rooms and shop floors.
"The only other time I was up here was to go snowmobiling and such," said Lieut. Donald Scheuber of the Buchanan Fire Department as he oversaw a dozen other Buchanan firefighters sending a stream of water from the Walton drugstore into a storm drain leading back into the river from which the water came three days earlier.
The Buchanan firefighters had left home at dawn in the converted school bus they normally use to travel to parades, Lieutenant Scheuber said. They had not yet worked out where they would spend the next few nights.
"We came up here to work," Lieutenant Scheuber said. "We'll work out where to sleep later."
Towns that were out of harm's way sent firetrucks, front-end loaders, dump trucks and buses to help in cleanups.
In the Annex, a diner 50 feet from the ruins of the hardware store, two customers sipped coffee and listened on a portable radio as a local station interviewed the store's owner, Charles Fiumera. "My store's gone, but I'm still kicking," he said.
At the offices of the local weekly newspaper, The Reporter, Len Govern, a vice president of The Reporter Company, which owns the paper, held up a battered but intact bottle of Bols peppermint liqueur that had washed a quarter of a mile down Delaware Street from a liquor store.
Nearby, 2 of the newspaper's 50 employees, their feet in red mud, were sitting at computer terminals preparing the paper's next issue. "We come out every Wednesday," Mr. Govern said, "and that includes this Wednesday."
Before dawn, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dispatched his Environmental Protection Commissioner, Marilyn Gelber, to survey the damage in towns around the reservoirs and help foster good relations with the people here.
In silence, she stood alone, surveying the gaping chasm in the city-owned road where six people had died. The road had collapsed when a dam holding back an eight-acre pond by a restaurant gave way, she said. Another city water official said the road had stood solidly for 125 years but could not withstand such a massive blast of water.
Ms. Gelber said the flood would have some positive impact. The city, she said, was exploring ways to accelerate a plan to provide economic assistance to Walton and other watershed towns.
Next month, the city is to sign a landmark pact with the watershed communities that will send more than $1 billion to the Catskills and other watershed regions to protect water quality while spurring some development of these economically ailing communities.
But today, New York City was supplying the simple things that Walton residents needed most: 2,000 orange highway cones, truckloads of gravel and many pairs of helping hands.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Flood Losses Could Reach $700 Million

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 22

 BODY:
As the flood waters of Pennsylvania's big rivers receded today from their overflow levels of the weekend, thousands of residents returned to their homes only to find them uninhabitable, and the state said the economic losses could reach $700 million.
From the Susquehanna and Delaware Rivers in the eastern half of the state to the Ohio and Monongahela Rivers out west, Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania blamed the flooding for 14 deaths, damage to 30,000 homes, the closing of 570 roads and the destruction of 8 bridges. 
 Pennsylvania was among the states hardest hit by this month's blizzard, which left some areas under more than 40 inches of snow. Now, its vast system of rivers have made it, so far, the state most affected by the melt.
"We've never had four seasons of weather pushed together in a two-week period of time in the middle of January," Governor Ridge said at a news conference today, citing problems caused by the rapid succession of heavy snowfalls, warming temperatures and rain that flooded scores of communities around the state in the last few days.
Today, the Federal Emergency Management Agency added 26 counties to the list of those in Pennsylvania that have been declared disaster areas, bringing the total number to 32. More are expected. Mr. Ridge has asked for Federal assistance for 58 counties -- all but 9 in the state.
James Lee Witt, the F.E.M.A. director, said at the news conference that the others would be assessed shortly and would probably receive Federal funds. The lag has caused a minor stir between Mr. Ridge, a Republican elected in 1994, and the White House.
After touring damaged areas on Sunday, Mr. Ridge criticized the Administration for not reacting fast enough to help the state, a jab he knew the White House could not ignore, given the state's importance to President Clinton in the 1996 elections.
By Sunday night, after Mr. Ridge spoke by telephone with President Clinton, the controversy had quieted. At the news conference, which followed Mr. Ridge's meeting with Mr. Witt and Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, Mr. Witt assured Mr. Ridge the state would get all the help it deserved, and that seemed to satisfy the Governor.
But Mr. Ridge's remarks drew a sharp response today from Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, who said that Mr. Ridge "ran his mouth instead of getting the work done that would have led to getting their assistance."
"It's the wrong way to do business, to go out and attack the President and the Administration," Mr. McCurry said.
At the news conference, Mr. Ridge said: "I don't want to respond to the President's press secretary. My job is to promote the interests of Pennsylvania citizens."
To assess the damage around the state, Mr. Witt, Mr. Pena and other Federal officials left Washington this morning for a tour of Altoona, Wilkes-Barre, Harrisburg and Pittsburgh. Along the way, they saw all manner of problems caused by the floods.
State officials said that 28 water plants had been destroyed by the floods, well water had been contaminated in countless areas, 150,000 people served by 18 water systems had been told to boil water before drinking and 116 Red Cross shelters had been set up to house people who were forced to evacuate their homes.
In Pittsburgh, where three major rivers -- the Monongahela, Allegheny and Ohio -- converge, cleanup crews struggled with the worst flooding in western Pennsylvania since 1972. Freezing temperatures left huge chunks of ice on roadways and riverbanks throughout the areas after the rivers crested at more than 18 feet above normal levels.
Coal barges were forced to tie up when they were unable to pass through locks, but dozens of barges broke loose and remain wedged against bridge pillars or dam gates.
A 200-foot barge used by the Pittsburgh Wind Symphony ended up on a low-lying city parking lot on top of several automobiles caught by the fast-rising waters.
John Comey, a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency, said that a trailer park had washed away in Williamsport, that 1,300 homes in Scranton had water in their basements and that icy waters were still well above flood level in parts of Bloomsburg, Danville and Harrisburg.
Here in Harrisburg, residents of a historic section of riverfront town houses, who had been evacuated as the Susquehanna rose, suffered another blow this morning when a fire caused serious damage to five homes along Pancake Row that had been built in 1897.
Denise I. Robison, deputy secretary for the State Department of Aging, lives in a house at one end of the row. She said she was not only heartened to find that her house was still standing, but also that the flag she hangs over her balcony was still flying. It says, "Don't Give Up the Ship."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falters Against Mark After Meeting of the Group of 7

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar faltered against European currencies yesterday after a weekend meeting of industrial nations, worrisome headlines from the Federal budget battle and political uncertainty in Italy and Sweden.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 1.4771 German marks, from 1.4810 marks on Friday. The dollar rose to 105.77 yen, from 105.46 on Friday. 
 The Group of Seven industrial nations emerged from their Saturday meeting with little substantive comment on the dollar, in marked contrast with an April 1995 meeting that set the stage for a coordinated effort to pull the dollar up from record lows.
Some dealers had expected the leaders to push for a stronger dollar as a means to revive economic growth in Europe, particularly in Germany.
Bundesbank officials, including the German central bank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, spoke about the merits of a strong dollar, but they also dampened expectations of further reductions in German interest rates.
Dealers took profits from a powerful rally last week when they saw the dollar's surge running out of steam.
"This is pretty much a profit-taking move," said Steven Jury, chief dealer at the Union Bank of Switzerland. "It seems as if the market is unable to get much of a rally at all."
The dollar was weighed down by weakness in the Italian lira and Swedish krona against the German mark, as currency players grew edgy that Rome would not easily resolve political wrangling and that Swedish proposals to increase social security benefits would increase state spending.
The House Republican majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, rattled the financial markets with weekend comments that any bill to raise the United States debt ceiling from $4.9 trillion would be accompanied by Republican conditions, such as scaling back Government departments.
Dealers said the currency market was disturbed by revived talk of a debt default, even though few considered default a likely outcome.

HEADLINE: TREASURY CHIEF WARNS CONGRESS ABOUT DEFAULT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told Republican Congressional leaders today that he has run out of legal options to sidestep the national borrowing limit and cannot keep the Government from defaulting on its debts after Feb. 29 without selling off the national gold reserve or holding up tax refunds.
But Mr. Rubin described those options as "completely unacceptable" to President Clinton, throwing the issue back at the Republicans, who have tried to use the debt limit as a weapon in the war over the Federal budget. 
 As each side tried to force the other's hand, Republican leaders raised the ante today. Speaker Newt Gingrich said the only way for the President to get the authority to pay the nation's bills -- including $30 billion in Social Security, veterans and other retirement payments due on March 1 -- is to accede to much of the Republican agenda.
That is a demand Mr. Clinton has refused to meet, saying he would not be blackmailed by the threat of national default.
"We are, quite frankly, at an impasse," Mr. Gingrich said.
Mr. Rubin has the authority to sell part of America's gold reserve to raise money, but it is a step many have warned against because it could destabilize the American currency. He could also delay sending refunds to the 70 million or so taxpayers who are owed money by the Internal Revenue Service. But as a White House official put it the other day, "I've heard brighter ideas in an election year."
Mr. Rubin's declaration was in a letter to Mr. Gingrich and came after the markets closed, so it was impossible to tell how investors around the world would react to his statement that he could not or would not prevent default if Congress fails to act by the end of next month.
Both Democrats and Republicans have expressed fear that foreign investors in particular would begin to charge a premium for lending money to the United States Government, touching off a rise in interest rates that would quickly affect the cost of home mortgages and other loans. So far the effects on the market have been minimal, apparently because investors have concluded that Mr. Rubin and the Republican leaders are snarling and threatening, but would not actually let the United States go into default for the first time in its history.
"We're in the end game now," one senior Administration official said tonight.
President Clinton was deeply involved in the decision made today, Administration officials insisted, but in public he has stuck to generalities, urging Congress to pass a "clean" extension of the debt limit, one that carries no conditions on the rest of the Republican agenda. "I don't think we should default on the debt," Mr. Clinton told reporters. "I think that would be a terrible mistake."
 Until today, Republican leaders appeared to have assumed that Mr. Rubin would find legal authority to tap other Government trust funds to keep the Government running, even in the absence of an increased debt limit. One option would be to use money from the Social Security Trust Fund, but the President has said publicly he would not do that.
A week ago several Republican leaders, including Mr. Gingrich and the chairman of the House Budget Committee, John R. Kasich of Ohio, suggested that they would find a way to extend the debt ceiling, which allows the Government to borrow money to pay for expenses that exceed its revenues. But this afternoon, Mr. Gingrich seemed to backpedal, moving toward the hard line that his second-in-command, Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, had set on Sunday on NBC News's "Meet the Press."
Mr. Gingrich said that House Republicans would insist on two conditions before they agreed to a new debt ceiling. He said the first was to act "when the President feels there are no more gimmicks" to increase the Government's spending powers -- a condition apparently met today -- and the second was that Mr. Clinton accept a debt ceiling bill that included some of the Republicans' legislative goals.
"The President wants a debt ceiling and we want to know what he is prepared to sign to get that debt ceiling," Mr. Gingrich said at a news conference in his Capitol Hill office. "With the absence of that, we are, quite frankly, at an impasse."
The Speaker said that among the issues that House Republicans want the President to sign off on are some of their proposed changes in entitlement programs. He also said that White House acceptance of the Senate version of a welfare bill would be "a good start" toward negotiating a new debt ceiling bill.
"What we need are clear indications of reforms he will sign," Mr. Gingrich said. "No more promissory notes, no more i.o.u.'s."
By finding ways around the debt ceiling until now, Mr. Rubin has successfully prevented the Republicans from using the threat of default as a lever in their budget negotiations. In the process, he has angered Republicans, some of whom suggested he was stretching his legal authority beyond its proper grounds.
But it was a game with limits, and during a nine-hour meeting at the Treasury on Sunday, shortly after he returned from a meeting of finance ministers in Paris, Mr. Rubin decided he had made his last big move. In the end, he approved some minor steps that will allow him to keep financing the Government between Feb. 15 -- when Treasury estimates its current money will run out -- and Feb. 29, when an interest payment of $5.8 billion is due to holders of Treasury securities.
In the meeting, Mr. Rubin rejected taking a complex but creative step that his lawyers had been examining for weeks: Making use of $75 billion in the Federal Financing Bank, which holds the debt obligations of a number of Federal agencies. "We determined he did not have clear enough authority," one senior Treasury official said.
In his letter today, Mr. Rubin laid out for the first time three short-term steps he will take to get the Government through the month of February. He will suspend the reinvestment of $3.9 billion in Treasury securities held in the Exchange Stabilization Fund, the fund used to keep the dollar's value steady against foreign currencies.
That will exhaust the fund's holdings of dollars, though it will still contain $17 billion in Japanese yen and German marks. Treasury officials concluded that it would be too difficult to convert those holdings to dollars and too risky, because it would leave the United States defenseless if there were a run on the dollar.
Mr. Rubin will also exchange roughly $9 billion in assets held by the Federal Financing Bank. In a complex transaction, the Treasury would be able to cancel some of its own securities held by the bank, giving it additional room to borrow without technically hitting the debt limit.
In a third step, he will also redeem about $6.4 billion in Treasury debt held by the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, exchanging it for an i.o.u. that, in a quirk of accounting, does not count against the debt limit.
After that, he wrote to Mr. Gingrich, "there are no other actions that we will be able or willing to take."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Tax Proposals Flout Equality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Radical reform of the income tax system appears to be a more certain prospect should any of the leading Republican Presidential contenders be elected. What their proposals have in common -- be they versions of a flat tax, a value-added tax or a national sales tax -- is the elimination of the progressivity that remains in the tax system. 
 A tax system that takes a constant share from on all incomes, from $10,000 to $10 million, would raise fundamental concerns about such a system's compatibility with the American ideal of equality. America is becoming an unequal society; the degree of income inequality is the highest in the industrialized world. The steady elimination of progressivity from the tax system has contributed to these outcomes.
A progressive income tax reduces economic instability. Under it, if the economy is booming, a larger fraction of national income is siphoned away through taxes than under a proportional or flat tax system, thus cooling the boom. Conversely, in a recession, significantly less income is taken, thus moderating the recession. A flat tax will make more difficult the task of taming the business cycle.
 
PATRICK M. BOARMAN
San Diego, Jan. 20, 1996
 
The writer is professor emeritus of economics, National University-San Diego.

HEADLINE: An Insurer's Dream, With No Middleman;
ITT Hartford Thrives on Retiree Group

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
In the troubled world of insurance, the news lately has been of mergers and layoffs, record claims and stagnant returns. It is about the last industry where you would expect a company to build a new business of more than $1 billion in revenues in little more than a decade..
But that is what ITT Hartford has done. In 1984 it was selected to sell auto and homeowners insurance to members of the American Association of Retired Persons, and that business soared to about $1.1 billion in premiums last year. That makes it one of the fastest-growing parts of the company, and a standout in an industry not growing much faster than the economy. 
 But the importance of the account to ITT Hartford goes far beyond growth and profits. Creating a division to serve the association's members -- a group whose only common denominator is that they are 50 and over -- was a breath of fresh air that pushed the 186-year-old insurer to adopt new ways of doing business. And it has helped ITT Hartford, now independent after 25 years as a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, keep a competitive edge in a business full of casualties.
The formula exemplifies the direction that analysts say property and casualty insurers must head if they are to shake off their torpor: a clear focus on a distinct group of customers, an emphasis on serving them, and a concerted effort to squeeze costs, notably by cutting out the middleman -- the insurance agent.
Insurers that focus on such "affinity groups" -- from makers of steel storage tanks to florists -- can develop expertise in evaluating risks that other insurers might overlook or exaggerate, and can establish vital connections.
But also crucial to the A.A.R.P. business is the direct link with the customer created by the elimination of agents or brokers to sell policies or handle claims. Not only does that get rid of agents' commissions -- 10 to 20 percent of premiums -- but it makes for a company that can learn about its customers firsthand.
"ITT Hartford has put itself in a position where it is the owner of the customer relationship, not the agent," said B. Joseph Pine 2d, president of Strategic Horizons, a consulting firm in Ridgefield, Conn. By making the most of computers and communications equipment, he said, the company can "learn more about the needs and desires of the A.A.R.P. members -- and then customize products for them that other insurers can't match."
With more than 35 million members now, and 12 million baby boomers turning 50 in the next 12 years, the A.A.R.P. offers a huge pool of potential customers, even bigger than the population of military officers that form the core of the insurance business built by the widely admired USAA. And most important for ITT Hartford, the association membership has enough wealth to own cars and homes that need insuring, and enough income to pay for the insurance.
While no other such group can match the A.A.R.P. for size, ITT Hartford and other insurers are pushing hard to find other pockets of desirable customers. Stephen J. Hasenmiller, senior vice president in charge of all personal insurance lines, noted that employer-sponsored plans were among the company's fastest-growing businesses, and relied on highly efficient customer service centers modeled on the A.A.R.P. program. Companies like United Airlines or the PNC Corporation select ITT Hartford and open their doors to sales agents offering insurance.
Although agents' share of the property-liability business has been shrinking industrywide, ITT Hartford is not scrapping agents. "There will always be people who for one reason or another want to do business with an agent," said Michael H. Hughes, a vice president who heads the A.A.R.P. account.
Even if the A.A.R.P. approach is not suitable for all customers, Mr. Hasenmiller noted that the skills acquired in handling the association's business were helping other parts of the company. Service centers for agent-sold insurance, many of them managed by personnel with experience in the A.A.R.P. program, now handle many routine chores like renewals. The centers are driving costs down rapidly, he said, "leaving the agents more time to sell."
For affinity programs like the A.A.R.P. to work effectively, both the insurer and the customers must think they are getting a good deal.
ITT Hartford is overjoyed at the 94 percent renewal rate for A.A.R.P. customers. The company knows that older drivers are not such high risks as their reputation would indicate because they drive fewer miles and tend to stay off the roads at night and in bad weather. The business consistently operates with lower expenses and claims costs than other insurers. And while ITT Hartford does not publish profits separately for that business, in 1994, for every dollar it collected in premiums, it had $1.026 in operating costs, compared with $1.045 for the industry as a whole. (The company still has a profit because of the interest it earns on premiums.)
For A.A.R.P. customers, the ITT Hartford arrangement offers a policy that is cheaper than average -- but not guaranteed to be the lowest. Beyond price, there are a host of special features and services intended to foster good relations between customers and the 2,000 or so workers who handle their accounts.
Policies, for example, include a promise that car insurance will be renewed despite any number of minor accidents and violations, so long as there are no serious lapses, like a drunken-driving charge.
"The idea that the insurance will be renewed really matters to a lot of people," said Anna Cirielli, a customer service representative. "I get lots of calls from people whose insurance company wouldn't renew, just because they turned 75."
Direct communication between the company and the customer, and a willingness to create a special division were among the requirements set by A.A.R.P. executives in Washington when they selected ITT Hartford in 1983, and again in 1992, when they renewed the agreement. The insurer pays the association a fee of 3 percent of premiums.
"We are comfortable with a direct approach because it allows us to really know what is being communicated to our members," said Susanne Bowman, head of insurance services at A.A.R.P. Not only does the arrangement allow the company to control the training and actions of its workers more closely, but it also makes it easier for the association's officials to monitor phone calls, and even pose as customers, she noted.
The most common complaint, she said, comes from members turned down for insurance because of such special risks as having a home within 1,000 feet of the ocean.
The association declined to make members available to answer questions about their satisfaction with ITT Hartford, and state insurance departments do not break out complaint data on the A.A.R.P. business.
Over all, ITT Hartford has a better than average track record in New York State, with 0.13 valid complaint per $1 million in premiums, compared with a median of 0.21 for all property insurers. In New Jersey, its performance was slightly below par: 0.39 valid complaint per 1,000 vehicles insured, compared with a median of 0.34.
The A.A.R.P. business is run from three buildings set amid gently rolling hills in Southington, a 20-minute drive from "the tower" at the Hartford headquarters. "We started fresh in our own building, and one reason was so that nobody would be around to say, 'But we never did it that way,' " said Trudy Daly, an assistant vice president.
On the surface, the rows of cubicles -- packed with computers, telephones and giant books of minutiae about policies and car parts -- look much like a telephone service center for a credit card company or mail-order house. A big television screen shows workers how many calls are waiting and how close they are to the goal of answering 85 percent of calls within one minute.
 But behind the technology there is a concerted effort to create a "culture," another name for esprit de corps and dedication to a common cause, the A.A.R.P. customer.
About 50 advisers like Matt Nichols are trained to handle the special needs of the more than 10,000 calls a year received from widowed customers -- even to the point of calling social service agencies or helping someone stand up to an overly aggressive car salesman. "I've had people who became distraught at the sight of a renewal notice with the deceased spouse's name on it," he said. "It means a lot for them to have someone who will listen."
By sponsoring a pen-pal program and an open house for customers to visit the office, the company tries to create bonds between workers and customers that make the endless series of calls seem less mind-numbing and more personal.
When Phyllis Sheehan noticed that many applications that had been returned to customers because they were incomplete were being submitted again -- still without the needed information -- she recalled learning in a training class about the deterioration in vision that occurs with age. "Yellow is a color that gets harder to see," she said, "so we stopped using yellow highlighters to mark the missing information, and started using blue."
The staff specialists on aging are a crucial part of training and the design of sales brochures and account statements. Even such simple tasks as training customer service representatives to listen a little longer are important in achieving a high level of service.
"We want to cater to the special needs of the A.A.R.P. customers, but we want to do it in a transparent way, so they never know," said Maureen Mohyde, a gerontologist. That can be tricky, she told a recent class of trainees, "because there are plenty of vigorous 55-year-olds who are aging, but wouldn't be called old by anyone except maybe a teen-ager."
The key is to listen closely for the differences among people, she said, and "remember that the differences between us and them are artificial; our customers have just had more birthdays."
