HEADLINE: Journal;
Calling Ralph Bellamy

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
If this were the 1930's, Steve Forbes, a zillionaire's bespectacled son with a passion for numbers, would be played by Ralph Bellamy and would lose the girl to Cary Grant. But this being the madcap 1990's, we are asked to believe that Mr. Forbes is successfully wooing the country. This week he's starring on the covers of both Time and Newsweek. How long before he's standing before Congress, orating on the State of the Union?
Mr. Forbes is not unappealing. He's smart, he seems as genuine as any fellow you might meet in New Jersey horse country and, unlike his Republican competitors, he doesn't seem driven to outlaw a woman's right to choose, establish school prayer or campaign against homosexuality. But the Forbes boom is less a story about Steve Forbes than about restlessness -- of both the media and the voting public. 
 In a dreary primary season, the press is desperate for a horse race. All it took for Mr. Forbes to be anointed "a major player" (NBC) and to transform the campaign "from a drag into a drama" (ABC) was for him to poll within 20 points of Bob Dole in two primary states. So what if Mr. Forbes has never received a vote for elective office in his life, or if the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll published yesterday shows him the favorite of only 12 percent of Republican primary voters nationwide, vs. Mr. Dole's 43 percent? He's already (ABC again) "either this year's Ross Perot or this year's Ronald Reagan."
As for that 12 percent of Republicans who prefer Mr. Forbes, they are presumably enamored of the flat tax -- since the flat tax is the only policy Mr. Forbes espouses. Like the phantom candidacy of Colin Powell before it -- briefly thought to be an instant panacea for every post-O. J. racial schism in America -- the flat tax is a miracle elixir for our economic future, as simple as filling out a postcard. But aren't the flat-tax fans the same voters who only yesterday placed messianic faith in a balanced budget? Try to find an economist unaligned with the Forbes campaign who says that a middle-class American can have the Forbes flat tax, a tax cut and a balanced budget too.
The press points out this policy conundrum, only to run into Mr. Forbes's filibusters and his nonstop commercials. His relentless advertising might best be countered not by bemoaning it but by making an effort to ferret out his qualifications for the job he seeks. So far only Mr. Forbes's journalistic competitor Fortune shows gusto for the task.
Such is the fog around our would-be President that The Daily News was reduced on Sunday to listing his wife's birthplace as unknown. Despite all Mr. Forbes's bragging about the ad pages he's sold, that alone is hardly a measure of his success in the only executive post he's held -- running the magazine he inherited. As for the tax returns Mr. Forbes refuses to release, they are not the "diversion" he says but an essential capitalist tool for assessing his fiscal citizenship and evaluating his charitable contributions in relation to his wealth. Mr. Forbes prescribes replacing public welfare with private philanthropy -- even as he proposes eliminating the charitable deduction -- without offering hard numbers illustrating how he practices what he preaches. (Nor would his campaign respond to requests for this information by deadline yesterday.)
Thanks to the enterprising Richard Lacayo of Time, we now know that one press certitude about the Forbes campaign -- that the candidate is buying the airwaves with his own cash -- isn't the whole story. Mr. Forbes is actually lending the campaign his money (with interest?) and has campaign contributors like the rest of the pack. Do his fat-cat special interests overlap with Forbes advertisers and story subjects? And how would they benefit from his flat tax?
True, the answers to such questions might dampen the fun. The spectacle of a zillionaire spending money like water is one of the most durable of American entertainments (think of those 30's movies again). The longer Mr. Forbes can get away with robotically flogging a single issue and a mantra of "hope, growth and opportunity," the more the stories of his ascendancy will become self-fulfilling prophecies. At the runaway rate his unexamined media bandwagon is moving, this country could swing from having one of the most scrutinized First Families in its history to a First Family it's never even met.

HEADLINE: 3 Municipal Union Locals Approve 5-Year Contract

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Showing signs that worries about job security are beginning to take hold, three locals in New York City's largest municipal workers' union overwhelmingly approved a proposed five-year contract this week. But several union officials said it was still too close to call whether the agreement would win a majority from the union's 56 locals.
A local representing accountants and auditors working for the city and a local representing computer programmers voted overwhelmingly for the contract, while a large local representing engineers and architects voted in favor by 5 to 3. Those votes more than overcame results announced last week in which workers at the New York City Public Library voted 12 to 1 against the contract. 
 "It's still a cliffhanger," said one official in the 120,000-member union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Even so, the recent votes have come as welcome news to both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37, who was criticized by many rank-and-file members for negotiating a contract that provided no wages increases in its first two years.
But now, Mr. Hill said, members seem to be placing more emphasis on the contract's promises of job security, particularly in light of AT&T's recent announcement of 40,000 layoffs as well as news of a sharp jump in New Jersey's jobless rate.
Mr. Hill pointed to two other anxiety-producing developments that he said would push members to vote for ratification to lock in the contract's job security language. First, several fiscal monitors predicted this week that the city would have to close a $600 million budget gap this year and a $2 billion deficit in the fiscal year beginning July 1. And two weeks ago, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi frightened many workers by suggesting that layoffs might be needed to balance the city budget.
"All this makes it clearer to members how important job security is," Mr. Hill said.
Joseph Vicinanza, president of Local 1407, the accountants' local, said his members voted 497 to 228 in favor of the contract because "they're a little bit fearful for their jobs, and the contract gives them some security."
Mr. Vicinanza told the story of a member of his local's executive board who had been against the contract, but was so shaken by AT&T's layoffs that he changed his mind.
Nonetheless, he added that many members remained unhappy with "the double zeroes," the zero percent wage increases for the first two years.
For Mayor Giuliani, ratification by District Council 37 is important, because if the giant union joins the United Federation of Teachers in rejecting a contract, his strategy for gaining five years of labor peace will have collapsed. But if District Council 37 embraces the agreement, that will isolate the teachers' union and increase pressure on it to reconsider its rejection.
On Monday, Mr. Giuliani predicted that District 37 would ratify the contract, which is roughly similar to the teachers' agreement, promising three years of job security, no wage increase for two years and a 12 percent raise in the last three years of the five-year accord. Many teachers who voted against the contract said they were unwilling to accept such a wage package at a time when the Mayor and other city officials were getting substantial raises.
Sounding markedly more confident about ratification than he did in early January, Mr. Hill said in an interview: "I'm optimistic. I feel comfortable."
Mr. Hill said he expected to announce the cumulative results from the vote of all 56 locals around Feb. 1, once the last mail ballots are counted. Some locals are voting by mail, and others in meetings of the rank and file.
In the other votes announced this week, Local 375, representing architects and engineers, favored the contract by 1,577 to 903. Local 2627, representing computer programmers, voted 783 in favor of the contract and 169 against.
The story was sharply different in Local 1930, which represents workers in the New York Public Library. Last week it announced that its members voted 619 against the contract and 52 in favor.
Raymond Markey, president of the librarians' local, said, "Our members would not agree to accept two years without a pay increase while the Mayor is increasing his salary by 27 percent, from $130,000 to $165,000."
Several other unions that negotiated along with District Council 37 are also voting this month. A teamsters' local representing workers at the New York City Housing Authority has yet to vote, while Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents many municipal computer and communications workers, voted 2,112 against and 347 for.
Arthur Cheliotis, president of Local 1180, said, "There's a strong sentiment out there against the two-year wage freeze because people have been asked to carry a bigger work load and have to pay subway fare increases and pay more tuition for City College and state universities."
Mr. Cheliotis scoffed at the agreement's job security promises, insisting that they could easily be suspended if Mr. Giuliani declared a fiscal emergency.
Mr. Cheliotis predicted that District Council 37 would not ratify the contract. Indeed, ratification has seemed in doubt since late December when Local 420, a large unit representing municipal hospital workers, voted overwhelmingly against the contract by a vote of 4,402 to 34.
That unit voted so overwhelmingly against the agreement because it does not give hospital workers the same job security pledges that it makes to other municipal workers.
But Mr. Hill is counting on his union's largest local -- one representing 22,000 clerical workers -- to help put the contract over the top by delivering a large margin in favor in its mail vote.
Some opponents of the contract criticized Albert Diop, president of the clerical workers' local, saying he stretched out the vote by his local to give him more time to round up votes in favor of the agreement. But local officials said Mr. Diop delayed the vote because of the blizzard.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Stroock & Stroock is moving into space vacated in lower Manhattan when Mudge Rose disbanded.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
WHEN the law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon disbanded in mid-December, it left a large vacancy at 180 Maiden Lane, a 41-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office building in lower Manhattan.
The 126-year-old Mudge Rose, once the legal home of Richard M. Nixon and his Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, had occupied 145,000 square feet of space on the 32d through 36th floors in the 1984 glass tower at South Street. 
 Now, only a month later, the space is spoken for: another downtown law firm, Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, has leased the space for 15 years -- with an option to take another floor -- in a deal valued at nearly $80 million.
The Stroock firm, which has 225 lawyers in New York and a total of more than 300 worldwide, is to relocate in the fall from its current offices a few blocks away at 7 Hanover Square, at Water Street.
The Maiden Lane building, also known as the Continental Center, was once the headquarters of the Continental Corporation, an insurance company. The CNA Financial Corporation, a Chicago-based insurance company whose major shareholder is the Loews Corporation, bought Continental last year for $1.1 billion, and the building now is home to CNA's New York offices.
Stroock still has more than two years left on its Hanover Square lease. John Malino, vice president of real estate at Loews, said that as part of the Stroock transaction, the owner of 180 Maiden Lane -- still officially the Continental Corporation -- had "agreed to get involved with some of the monetary obligations Stroock has to 7 Hanover."
Leonard Boxer, the chairman of Stroock's real estate group, said the Maiden Lane lease was more favorable financially to his firm than was the one at Hanover Square. "Even though our Hanover Square lease expired in 1998, we saw a window to be able to take advantage of the marketplace and make sure we had a deal that brought us into the next century," Mr. Boxer said. "We tried to make a deal with our existing landlord but could not reach an agreement."
The downtown office market has been weak throughout the 90's, and Mr. Boxer said his firm had received some "very attractive proposals" to follow a number of other downtown law firms to midtown. "We had been thinking about midtown for the last year or so," he said, "but we believe in the efforts the city is making to improve things for the downtown community. We decided as a matter of principle that it would be the right thing to stay here."
Another important factor in the decision, he said, was the many amenities available at 180 Maiden Lane, among them a private dining club, a 700-seat restaurant, a 200-seat auditorium and a modern fitness center, "that would improve the quality of life for our people."
Andrew Tisch, chairman of the management committee at Loews, said the deal had taken 29 days to complete, from basic agreement to signed lease, instead of the 4 to 12 months usual in such a transaction. "Stroock saw the space in early December," Mr. Tisch said. "The parties met on Dec. 20 and in about 40 minutes reached agreement on all the economic parameters. We decided to dispose of lawyering the first three drafts and go directly to the final draft."
The deal was signed at 11 A.M. last Thursday. It was brokered by Mort Schrader, John B. Brod and Laura Pomerantz of S. L. Green Real Estate and Mark Weiss of Goldman, Sachs & Company. (Mr. Schrader and Mr. Brod, by the way, were the brokers who originally put Mudge Rose in the space.) Alan Grossman of the Georgetown Company was the consultant for the Continental Corporation.
"Downtown is struggling," Mr. Malino of Loews said. "The fact that a major law firm has decided to stay there is good news."
 
Around the Region
 Props for Today, a supplier of props for theater, movies and television, has signed a 10-year lease for 100,000 square feet on three floors at 330 West 34th Street, an 18-story office building between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. The lease includes 3,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space where originals and replicas of furniture and artifacts used in various productions will be for sale. James D. Kuhn and John Briety of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. brokered the deal . . . E.S. Richard Karson of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company, who represented the building's owner, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, said the 15-year lease had a value of about $15 million. . . . Merchants, NY, a restaurant, has signed a 15-year, $3.6 million lease for 7,500 square feet at 1125 First Avenue, part of a five-story condominium on the southwest corner of 62d Street. The Italian-American nouvelle restaurant has branches at 112 Seventh Avenue, at 17th Street, and 521 Columbus Avenue, at 85th Street. David King of Newmark handled the deal. . . . Information Resources Inc., a marketing research, software and consulting firm with headquarters in Chicago, has leased 50,000 square feet at the 8-story, 250,000-square-foot Merritt View Office Plaza at Route 7 and the Merritt Parkway in Norwalk, Conn. The lease is for 10 years with an aggregate rent of just under $13 million. Jeffrey H. Newman and JoAnn McGrath of W&M Properties of Connecticut represented the building.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Higher, Restrained By Worries Over the U.S. Budget

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar moved slightly higher against most leading currencies yesterday, but its advance was restrained by the continuing Federal budget crisis and uncertainty ahead of the State of the Union address.
Word that the Bundesbank, the central bank of Germany, might consider cutting interest rates drove the dollar higher against the mark. That helped the dollar advance against other European currencies, including the French franc, the Italian lira and the Swiss franc. 
 Against the Japanese yen, the dollar continued its moderate advance from Monday but ran into some technical selling.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4791 German marks, up from 1.4771 on Monday. The dollar ended at 105.84 Japanese yen, up from 105.77 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5138 from $1.5115.
"Over all, it's been a very narrow-range-trading kind of day," said David Glowacki, a senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "There's really a lot of uncertainty going around -- the budget talks, the State of the Union address tonight."
A senior official of the Bundesbank told a gathering of dignitaries that it would consider another cut of key interest rates as long as growth in money supply remained below targets.
The comments echoed recent statements from German monetary officials but still managed to help the dollar, traders said. Lower interest rates tend to make a nation's currency less valuable because investors can find better returns elsewhere.
The budget dispute in Washington continued to weigh on the dollar.
"It's the uncertainty," said Roger Volz, director of technical analysis at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York. He said traders "just do not want to be caught in a situation where we have an unknown."
Increasing concern that the Federal Government would be forced to default on its financial obligations because of the budget impasse also put pressure on the currency.
In trading against the yen, the dollar ran into selling by Japanese exporters as it neared the 106-yen level, Mr. Glowacki said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Budget Fight Hurts Price Of Long Bond

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities dropped again yesterday, as investors fretted over the stalled budget negotiations and faced a large supply of new securities.
The uncertainty, ahead of President Clinton's State of the Union Message, kept buyers at bay, with few venturing to make any large purchases. 
 The 30-year bond fell 21/32, to a price of 110 24/32 to yield 6.09 percent, up from 6.04 percent on Monday. On the shortest maturities, yields were unchanged.
There was scant reaction to the personal income and spending data announced yesterday because the market considered most of the statistics outdated. Bond prices, however, dipped on the release in the morning of the Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim chain store sales index for the week ended Jan. 20. The index rose 1.9 percent from the weak earlier and 5.6 percent from a year earlier.
Economists said that the rebound in sales was not all that surprising given that storms in the East had hurt sales in earlier weeks.
In the afternoon, Johnson Redbook said total sales rose 4.8 percent last week compared with the week a year earlier. It said month-to-date sales declined two-tenths of a percent for the first three weeks in January, which represented an improvement from a drop of nine-tenths of a percent reported a week earlier for three weeks.
Gold rallied on the market's concern about the debt limit and that may be why it has been able to stay above $400 an ounce, analysts said.
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, commented in the afternoon that a balanced budget agreement was now unlikely, and that remark knocked the price of a 30-year bond down nearly a half of a percentage point.
Other data issued in the morning included November personal spending, which rose nine-tenths of a percent, its largest gain since February 1994, when spending was up 1.5 percent. Market participants were looking for spending to rise six-tenths of a percent. October spending was down three-tenths of a percent.
Personal income for November was up only two-tenths of a percent, while many economists had been expecting a gain of seven-tenths of a percent.
But it was the background talk of Government default that caused most of the uneasiness.
Ray Worseck, chief economist and manager at A. G. Edwards & Sons, St. Louis, said the market was focused on Washington developments. "Recent developments," he said, "seem to suggest that the debt market is more concerned about the crisis and fiscal questions as opposed to the economic news."
"The economy on the other hand is not rolling over and playing dead," Mr. Worseck added, "and so that tends to support the hesitancy in the Treasury market to go higher."
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, also said that the news out of Washington was not good for bonds.
"People are worried about setting deadlines that everyone knows will be missed," Mr. Donne said. "But the market, which usually spends its time discounting economic data, now has to digest political speak, and as a result, it is nervous. And when investors are nervous they demand a concession in price."
Mr. Worseck and Mr. Donne said yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes went well and might have been aided by rumors that large hedge funds were in the market to buy two-year securities.
At the Treasury's sale of $18.25 billion in new two-year notes, the high yield was 5.068 percent, down from 5.289 percent last month.
Today the Treasury will sell $12 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the fives were offered at a price to yield 5.37 percent.

HEADLINE: U. of California Postpones Shift In Policy on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
In what proponents of affirmative action hailed as a sign that the University of California may reconsider its ban on the use of race and sex to select students, university officials said today that they would delay starting the new policy by one year.
The officials said that the delay did not signal a retreat from the decision last July to abandon affirmative action. They said there was not enough time to implement new admission guidelines by next year. The postponement means the new policy will apply to freshmen entering in 1998, rather than those entering in 1997. 
 "This is a big change," said Dennis Galligani, assistant vice-president of the university, "and this gives us more time to work with the campuses and explain it to people. But nothing has changed. Materials developed after Jan. 1, 1997, will have no reference to race and gender."
A letter from the university president, Richard C. Atkinson, announcing the delay was sent to the chancellors of the system's nine campuses on Friday, the day after a raucous meeting in which the Regents affirmed their decision to abandon race- and sex-based hiring and admissions. The new standards for hiring took effect in January.
Last July, the Regents banned the use of race, religion, ethnicity, sex and national origin as criteria in hiring faculty, awarding contracts and selecting students.
Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who was behind the drive to abolish affirmative action, made a rare appearance at the meeting and urged the Regents not to back down.
Opponents of the new policy said they believed that the widely organized faculty opposition and several critical newspaper editorials published this week had persuaded the administration to slow down. Roy T. Brophy, a regent from the Sacramento area who voted against the ban, said he would ask the board in the next few months to modify the policy approved in July.
"It gives us a window of opportunity to study and restudy what is fair," Mr. Brophy said.
One faculty member, Lawrence Wallack, a professor of public health at Berkeley, said today that he viewed the delay as a concession that the new policies had been hastily adopted.
"The old policy was dumped without any concept of what it would take to generate a new policy that would assure diversity," Professor Wallack said. "It may be that when enough research is done, they find there is an internal contradiction in the new policy: maintaining diversity is not possible without some consideration of race."
The new admission guidelines, which say that diversity should be pursued by using "social and economic disadvantage" instead of race and sex, must still be approved by the Regents and by each of the system's nine campuses before new applications can be printed.

HEADLINE: Creditors Give Fokker a Month To Plot Survival

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Seeking time to avert collapse, Fokker N.V., the Dutch aircraft maker, said tonight that its main subsidiaries had been granted one month's protection from creditors after the cutoff of financial support from Daimler-Benz A. G., its German benefactor.
The decision appeared to be little more than a stopgap measure, with the announcement on Monday by Daimler-Benz, which holds a controlling stake in Fokker, that it was effectively abandoning Fokker after several years of heavy losses. 
 Analysts said that Fokker's only realistic strategy now was to find buyers for its aircraft-building and other aerospace activities, and that its ability to attract a buyer would probably hinge on how much financial support the Dutch Government was willing to provide, .
Ben van Schaik, Fokker's chairman, said at a news conference in Amsterdam tonight: "If we can find a partner for the companies for which we filed for protection, these companies can be saved. Alone, these companies cannot compete on the world market."
Aerospace companies like Bombardier of Canada, which makes wings for Fokker planes, and British Aerospace, one of Fokker's main rivals in the hotly competitive regional jet market, are likely to take a look at purchasing pieces of Fokker's business, analysts said.
But they also said it was by no means certain that Fokker would attract bids. And it remained unclear how much financial assistance might be forthcoming from the Dutch Government, which rejected Daimler-Benz's demands for high levels of financial aid during restructuring negotiations in recent months.
"The question before us is what is the best way to give Fokker the chance of keeping as much of the company as possible on its feet," Hans Wijers, the Dutch economics minister, said in a television interview.
Daimler-Benz's Deutsche Aerospace unit acquired its stake in Fokker in 1993 as part of a strategy of expanding its European aircraft- building capability into the regional jet market -- planes with 50 to 100 seats flown by airlines on short-haul routes.
But with aircraft sales depressed in recent years by a slump in the airline industry, Fokker, one of the oldest European plane makers, proved to be a substantial drain on Daimler's earnings. In the first half of last year, Fokker lost $400 million.
Analysts said that with British Aerospace, Alenia of Italy and Aerospatiale of France all competing in substantially the same market, a crisis for Fokker was virtually inevitable. Regional jet makers also compete with the smaller aircraft of McDonnell Douglas and the Boeing Company of the United States.
Fokker officials said they wanted to complete planes now under construction, and to win advance financing from the Dutch Government for orders it had placed. Fokker officials said they were working with Daimler-Benz to insure that the company could continue providing technical support to airlines using its planes.
"In the coming four weeks we will try to finish work in progress," Mr. van Schaik said. "We will take all measures to keep as much of the company operating as possible."
Shares of Fokker, which lost more than 40 percent of their value last week, once again did not trade today in the Netherlands. Daimler-Benz stock posted a modest gain in Frankfurt, after also failing to trade on Monday.

HEADLINE: Incomes Rose Only Slightly In November

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Personal incomes edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said today, providing another sign that the economy was slowing.
The report also said consumer spending jumped a surprising nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, its biggest monthly gain since early 1994. But some economists discounted that gain, saying the scant rise in personal incomes, and reports of poor holiday retail sales, suggested consumer spending had weakened since then. 
 Several economists said the sluggish growth in income could increase the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would make another cut in short-term interest rates at a policy meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday whether or not Congress and the Clinton Administration can resolve the budget impasse.
Some estimated that the economy's overall growth rate slid to 2 percent in the last quarter of 1995 from 3.2 percent in the third quarter. They also said the slowdown and disruptions from winter storms might cut economic growth to 1 to 2 percent in the first quarter of 1996.
Joel L. Naroff, chief economist at the First Union National Bank in Philadelphia, said the data in the Commerce report, which was delayed by partial Government shutdowns stemming from the budget fight, were weak enough to imply "a sharp deceleration" in economic growth.
He said the consumer income and spending figures suggested that the Federal Reserve "may have remained too tight for too long" in setting key interest rates, and it "will probably initiate another round of easing" next week.
Mr. Naroff said he expected the Fed's policy committee to cut the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans by one quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent. That would be similar to changes that it made last December and last July after raising the rate seven times between February 1994 and February 1995.
Cheryl R. Katz, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said she also expected the Fed committee to cut that rate by a quarter of a percentage point. She said she believed the Fed might also whittle the rate it charges on its own short-term loans to banks to 5 percent from 5.25 percent.
Noting that the Labor Department released figures last week showing that only half as many new payroll jobs were created in 1995 as in 1994, Ms. Katz said that meant "we will have weak income growth and sluggish consumer spending."
Other economists said top Fed officials might want to wait to see other statistics, including inflation-rate numbers scheduled to be released on Feb. 1, before making any change in interest rates.
But Ms. Katz said it was clear from the latest Commerce Department figures that "things are slowing down, and if they do wait, they'll eventually make another cut" in interest rates.
Indeed, the Commerce Department report said that the increase in personal income of two-tenths of 1 percent in November marked the smallest rise in that measure in three months. The report said personal income, which includes wages and salaries and income from dividends and interest, had increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent in October.
And while consumer spending jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, the report also showed that it declined by three-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Several economists said the increase in November occurred in large part because consumers were making up for unusually weak spending in October.
Mr. Naroff estimated that in real dollars, consumer spending, which represents nearly two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, rose only about 1 percent during the fourth quarter despite the jump in November.
"So when you smooth it out" over October and November, "that was not a lot of demand," he said, "and that was before the disappointing Christmas season."

HEADLINE: Steep Drop in Rate of Student Loan Default

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The percentage of borrowers defaulting on their Federal student loans has sharply dropped and the Government recouped $2 billion in the last fiscal year from those in default, Education Secretary Richard Riley said.
"These numbers reflect real and substantial progress," Mr. Riley said on Monday. "They are the product of several aggressive management decisions that were intended to get the default problem under control." 
 The rate of borrowers defaulting on student loans dropped to 11.6 percent in the 1993 fiscal year, the latest year for which figures are available. That was the lowest rate since official reporting on the default rate began in 1988. The rate has steadily declined since 1990, when it peaked at 22.4 percent.
"The program was hemorrhaging" Mr. Riley said.
Monday's news conference was intended to counter Congressional criticism by showing that the Education Department was improving its management of student loans. Republicans have sought to limit the direct-student-loan program, under which the Education Department bypasses bankers and lends directly to about 2.5 million students at 1,350 colleges and universities. The program has no limit on enrollment; Congressional Republicans would have it constitute no more than 10 percent of all student loans. Other Republicans want to close the department to save money.
Education Department officials have acknowledged that an improving economy helped reduce the default rate and that the Bush Administration deserved some credit. Mr. Riley, who was appointed by President Clinton in 1993, said he had made cutting the default rate his first goal.
Increased collections, combined with the lower default rate, reduced the net cost of defaults to $400 million in the 1995 fiscal year, down from $1.7 billion in the 1992 fiscal year. "Our collections on past defaulted loans are recouping more taxpayer dollars than ever before," Mr. Riley said.
The department reported that it collected $2 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 by suing borrowers in default, tapping their Federal income tax refunds and garnisheeing their wages.

HEADLINE: After Rising Faster Than Inflation for Years, Tuition Begins to Drop at Many Colleges

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
Despite the conventional wisdom that the costs of higher education will keep rising, a once-unthinkable phrase, tuition cuts, has been heard more frequently at America's colleges and universities.
Most of the schools that have announced price cuts have been small, regional colleges and universities looking for an advantage in increasingly competitive markets. But Princeton this week announced its smallest tuition increase in 28 years and such respected institutions as the University of Rochester and Lehigh University have offered tuition reductions or other innovations in the past two years. 
 Few experts on higher education are predicting a dramatic drop in college costs, certainly not at the nation's elite college and universities. But they say that what is happening now is the beginning of a process that could keep college costs down after they have risen at more than twice the rate of inflation for a long time.
What has helped push tuition costs down, they say, has been the increasing competitiveness among schools, a more cost-conscious national attitude and the widespread frustration with the standard practice of discounting prices through scholarships and other forms of aid, while keeping tuition high. Although the average tuition last year for a four-year private college was $18,000, the average student paid about half of that because of various forms of aid.
Some experts say the discounting is so widespread that any tuition cuts are only making official what is already a part of the college pricing structure.
"The price of higher education will be lower two years from now than it is now, and it's lower now than it was two years ago," said Robert Zemsky, director of the Institute for Research in Higher Education at the University of Pennsylvania. "This is going to happen in fits and starts for a while, but after a while if everyone is discounting their prices, no one gains an edge from it. The alternative is to lower the sticker price."
Most experts believe that the very top tier of colleges and universities, perhaps 30 or 35 schools, will remain largely exempt from traditional pricing pressures. Still, even the most elite schools are finding they must hold down price increases. Princeton this week announced the cost of tuition, room and board would increase next year by 4.6 percent to $28,325. It is the lowest rate of increase at Princeton since the 1967-68 school year.
On average, undergraduates will pay about 6 percent more this year on tuition and fees than they did a year ago, according to the annual report from the College Board. That is down substantially from recent years. Prices have risen as high as 12 percent in 1991-92 at public four-year institutions and 9 percent in 1988-89 and 1989-90 at at private institutions.
And in the last few months, a number of schools have announced they were cutting their tuition for next year.
Massachusetts public colleges cut tuition 5 to 10 percent last week. The policy applies to nine state colleges and 15 community colleges, but it is not clear if the University of Massachusetts system will also lower its prices.
Muskingum College in Ohio recently cut tuition by 29 percent. North Carolina Wesleyan College dropped prices by 23 percent. Pine Manor College in Massachusetts this month cut tuition by 38 percent. Other colleges announcing price cuts in the past year include schools like Waldorf College in Iowa, Westfield State College in Massachusetts and United States International University in San Diego.
Michigan State and Rice Universities are among those saying prices will not rise above the inflation rate, and others including the 22 campuses of the California State University system have frozen prices.
Many of these schools say it is fairer and easier to set a realistic sticker price than to bargain over discounts. "Why charge so much in the first place if you have to turn around and give it back in the form of institutionally funded financial aid?" said Bill Hamm, President of Waldorf College, a private institution offering a three-year bachelor's degree, where 95 percent of the students receive some form of financial aid.
Cutting tuition can be part of a smart marketing plan that need not bring in any less revenue.
The University of Rochester last year announced it would cut tuition by $5,000 for in-state students and the children of alumni. The main reason, officials said, was to better compete with less expensive state universities for relatively affluent students.
"We had a $15,000 price differential with the State University of New York and students were voting with their feet and going to SUNY," said Jim Scannell, vice president for enrollments, placement, alumni relations and development. "Families always realized the value here, but at $15,000 difference they voted no. At $10,000, we were much more competitive."
He said applications rose 21 percent from in-state students and 25 percent from the children of alumni, and the university was able to be more selective.
Average Scholastic Assessment Test scores rose 34 percent and the price cuts brought in a higher percentage of middle-class students able to pay the full cost.
As a result, the tuition reduction proved to be "slightly budget positive," bringing in $150,000 more in tuition revenue than in the previous year, Mr. Scannell said.
Many schools that have cut tuition say the move works in favor of middle-class families, who may have trouble getting financial aid but cannot pay ever-rising tuition.
"What's developed over time is a very complicated structure that no one really understands, least of all the parents and students," said Linda Stallone, vice president for development at North Carolina Wesleyan College in Rocky Mount, N.C. "What we've come up with is something that's more equitable, easier to understand, and clearer that will particularly help middle-class students who were reaching the point where tuition was getting so high even they couldn't pay it."
But some experts say this is the start of a process likely to bring real, long-term reductions in the cost of higher education.
In announcing its tuition cut, Muskingum College cited a Gallup Poll showing that by a 4-to-1 ratio, cost is the most important concern parents have about attending a private college.
Thomas D. Parker, a lecturer in education at Boston University, said education is beginning to go through the same process the rest of the economy did in greater price consciousness.
He said just as I.B.M. can no longer build a computer and add in what it wants in profits, universities will increasingly face competitition forcing them to become smarter, more cost efficient and cheaper.
He said the economic insecurity affecting society will increase the pressures on colleges and universities.
But he added that he and others have been predicting for years that the college price spiral has to end, and it has kept on longer than he ever thought it would.
"Having said all this, I have to also say I said the same thing 25 years ago," he said. "I have an old clipping from the Boston Globe from 1956 saying that by 1960, tuition at Harvard would cost $1,000 a year and it can't keep going up like this. There are reasons why I think it will happen now, but I have to admit that history has not proved kind to this sort of prediction in the past. You're like the stock market bears, who keep saying this time it's serious and always run the risk of looking pretty foolish."

HEADLINE: Invite In the Rich? PEN Is Pondering

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
A proposal that might add wealthy nonwriters to the board of the PEN American Center, a group devoted to defending the freedom of writers, has led to alarm among members that the well heeled are about to take charge and to cries of censorship in a stronghold of intellectual freedom.
"The members of our executive board find it hard to agree," said Anne Hollander, the organization's newly elected president. "They think there will be some huge number of people in black uniforms and cutaway coats ordering them around. Rich people are talked about with the most amazing venom by writers, especially nonrich writers. A lot of these writers have never met a rich person." 
 Meanwhile, said Ms. Hollander, PEN is in "transitional agony."
With 2,800 members in the United States and a budget of about $1.1 million a year, she said, PEN is in a financial crunch. Donations are down. Staff members who have left have not been replaced. One solution proposed by a committee last fall is to bring non writers, possibly wealthy ones, onto PEN's 95-member board in the hope that they will contribute and help to raise money. "We can't get our high-minded projects into being without an efficient means of raising money," Ms. Hollander said.
PEN members have been debating the proposal for months, sometimes rancorously, even though some nonwriters -- editors -- are already on the board and agents are members of the organization. Tonight the executive board is to meet again on the issue. If the board members can agree among themselves, the changes will be submitted to a vote by the organization's full membership before June 1.
Part of the problem, Ms. Hollander said, is the executive board's swollen size: 95 members, almost unheard of for any institution. The board members sit for life. Many, Ms. Hollander explained, are "famous writers whose names look good in letters to heads of state saying 'Kindly release X without further delay.' " Among these celebrities are Norman Mailer, Susan Sontag and E. L. Doctorow. The majority of members, especially the famous ones, do not attend meetings.
The new proposal would reduce the board to 24. One-third would be nonmembers of PEN, and all would be rotated.
"Writers want to get together and argue and wrangle," said Ms. Hollander, who supports the proposal. "Nothing seems to get done." Many members are resisting, she said, because they will miss "the fun of standing up and having a wonderful time screaming."
"But a board with no responsibility for the organization, this is what everybody notices in the great world."
The international PEN organization, founded in 1921 by John Galsworthy, is a loose federation of writers' groups, with 124 chapters in 91 countries and 14,000 members worldwide. Over the years, PEN has been a high-profile advocate of oppressed writers, among them Federico Garcia Lorca, Arthur Koestler, Boris Pasternak and, more recently, Salman Rushdie and Ken Saro-Wiwa, who was executed last fall by Nigeria's military Government. PEN organizes less visible activities, too, like literary prizes, writing programs in prisons and forums on writing that are open to the public.
Over the years there have been other attempts to reduce the size of PEN American Center's unwieldy board. All failed. The latest clash is reminiscent of one in 1990 in which Gayfryd Steinberg, the wife of the financier Saul Steinberg, drew criticism for serving as president of Friends of PEN, an affiliated support group. Ken Auletta, a board member, was quoted as calling the Steinbergs "wealthy people gaining respect on the backs of writers," and Ms. Steinberg resigned.
Of the current conflict, Mr. Auletta said recently: "The philosophical side of my brain is against it. The practical side says it's necessary."
Among the members who oppose the change, Ms. Hollander said, is Ms. Sontag, a former president. Ms. Sontag declined to be interviewed, but Ms. Hollander said, "She thinks of this as the end of PEN."
Another opponent is the author Kirkpatrick Sale. "There is a money crisis," he said, "but we have no way of knowing that bringing in richies on the board would solve the crisis."
Lucy Komisar, a foreign affairs writer and editor of the PEN newsletter, is also against the change. "I don't think we should sell PEN to the highest bidder," she said. Ms. Komisar contends that the organization withheld a letter by the Filipino writer Ninotchka Rosca from its newsletter because it criticized the proposed changes.
"I put it in the newsletter for February," Ms. Komisar said. "I was told by Anne Hollander it could not go in. This was censorship."
Ms. Hollander said the newsletter had been delayed to include a summary of the proposed changes and a letter supporting them by Frances FitzGerald, also a board member.
Typically, the battle is being waged in high-minded or intellectual language. "Electing people will create a certain transparency," said Ms. Fitzgerald. "The membership becomes responsible." And in a reference to possible wealthy new board members, she added, "This isn't Marla Trump."
In the minutes of a Dec. 13 board meeting, the group's secretary, Naomi Bliven, apologized to the membership for "a brief display of temper."
Ms. Bliven wrote that as secretary, she was unable to "say with any certainty what the board decided" about the proposals. "Part of the reason may be her fatigue," she added. "Part of the reason may be the furious cross talk."
Presiding over the fighting with what seems like amused tolerance, Ms. Hollander also casts the debate in writerly terms. "The imaginative construction of what we are doing is of utmost importance," she said.
Ms. Hollander, a 65-year-old art historian who has written about fashion, is not as well known as some of her predecessors in the top job.
But the poet Richard Howard, a lifelong friend, describes Ms. Hollander, who was elected president by the full membership last spring, as "shamefully literary."
"I have no advanced degrees, no qualifications," Ms. Hollander said. "I am an anachronism, a lady. I'm supported by my husband. I inherited money from my parents. I don't live on my writings."
She is married to Thomas Nagel, a professor of philosophy at New York University.
"There are writers who feel we have to live like Flaubert, who sat in a farmhouse for years and wrote these great books; he didn't bustle about raising money," Ms. Hollander said. "But that's impossible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Hollander, president of PEN. A plan to add wealthy nonwriters to its board has the group examining its conscience. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: As China Threatens Taiwan, It Makes Sure U.S. Listens

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Chinese leadership has sent unusually explicit warnings to the Clinton Administration that China has completed plans for a limited attack on Taiwan that could be mounted in the weeks after Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, wins the first democratic balloting for the presidency in March.
The purpose of this saber-rattling is apparently to prod the United States to rein in Taiwan and President Lee, whose push for greater recognition for the island of 21 million people, has been condemned here as a drive for independence. 
 While no one familiar with the threats thinks China is on the verge of risking a catastrophic war against Taiwan, some China experts fear that the Taiwan issue has become such a test of national pride for Chinese leaders that the danger of war should be taken seriously.
A senior American official said the Administration has "no independent confirmation or even credible evidence" that the Chinese are contemplating an attack, and spoke almost dismissively of the prospect. "They can fire missiles, but Taiwan has some teeth of its own," the official said. "And does China want to risk that and the international effects?"
The most pointed of the Chinese warnings was conveyed recently through a former Assistant Secretary of Defense, Chas. W. Freeman Jr., who traveled to China this winter for discussions with senior Chinese officials. On Jan. 4, after returning to Washington, Mr. Freeman informed President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, that the People's Liberation Army had prepared plans for a missile attack against Taiwan consisting of one conventional missile strike a day for 30 days.
This warning followed similar statements relayed to Administration officials by John W. Lewis, a Stanford University political scientist who meets frequently with senior Chinese military figures here.
These warnings do not mean that an attack on Taiwan is certain or imminent. Instead, a number of China specialists say that China, through "credible preparations" for an attack, hopes to intimidate the Taiwanese and to influence American policy toward Taiwan. The goal, these experts say, is to force Taiwan to abandon the campaign initiated by President Lee, including his effort to have Taiwan seated at the United Nations, and to end high-profile visits by President Lee to the United States and to other countries.
If the threats fail to rein in Mr. Lee, however, a number of experts now express the view that China could resort to force, despite the enormous consequences for its economy and for stability in Asia.
Since last summer, when the White House allowed Mr. Lee to visit the United States, the Chinese leadership has escalated its attacks on the Taiwan leader, accusing him of seeking to "split the motherland" and undermine the "one China" policy that had been the bedrock of relations between Beijing and its estranged province since 1949.
A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, asked to comment on reports that the Chinese military has prepared plans for military action against Taiwan, said he was awaiting a response from his superiors. Last month, a senior ministry official said privately that China's obvious preparations for military action have been intended to head off an unwanted conflict.
"We have been trying to do all we can to avoid a scenario in which we are confronted in the end with no other option but a military one," the official said. He said that if China does not succeed in changing Taiwan's course, "then I am afraid there is going to be a war."
Mr. Freeman described the most recent warning during a meeting Mr. Lake had called with nongovernmental China specialists.
Participants said that Mr. Freeman's presentation was arresting as he described being told by a Chinese official of the advanced state of planning. Preparations for a missile attack on Taiwan, he said, have been completed and await a decision by the Politburo in Beijing.
One of the most dramatic moments came when Mr. Freeman quoted a Chinese official as asserting that China could act militarily against Taiwan without fear of intervention by the United States because American leaders "care more about Los Angeles than they do about Taiwan," a statement that Mr. Freeman characterized as an indirect threat by China to use nuclear weapons against the United States.
An account of the White House meeting was provided by some of the participants. Mr. Freeman, reached by telephone, confirmed the gist of his remarks, reiterating that he believes that while "Beijing clearly prefers negotiation to combat," there is a new sense of urgency in Beijing to end Taiwan's quest for "independent international status."
Mr. Freeman said that President Lee's behavior "in the weeks following his re-election will determine" whether China's Communist Party leaders feel they must act militarily to change his behavior.
In recent months, Mr. Freeman said he has relayed a number of warnings to United States Government officials. "I have quoted senior Chinese who told me" that China "would sacrifice 'millions of men' and 'entire cities' to assure the unity of China and who opined that the United States would not make comparable sacrifices."
He also asserted that "some in Beijing may be prepared to engage in nuclear blackmail against the U.S. to insure that Americans do no obstruct" efforts by the People's Liberation Army "to defend the principles of Chinese sovereignty over Taiwan and Chinese national unity."
Some specialists at the meeting wondered if Mr. Freeman's presentation was too alarmist and suggested that parliamentary elections on Taiwan in December had resulted in losses for the ruling Nationalist Party and that President Lee appeared to be moderating his behavior to avoid a crisis.
"I am not alarmist at this point," said one specialist, who would not comment on the substance of the White House meeting. "I don't think the evidence is developing in that direction."
Other participants in the meeting, who said they would not violate the confidentiality pledge of the private session, separately expressed their concern that a potential military crisis is building in the Taiwan Strait.
"I think there is evidence to suggest that the Chinese are creating at least the option to apply military pressure to Taiwan if they feel that Taiwan is effectively moving out of China's orbit politically," said Kenneth Lieberthal, a China scholar at the University of Michigan.
Mr. Lieberthal, who also has traveled to China in recent months, said Beijing has redeployed forces from other parts of the country to the coastal areas facing Taiwan and set up new command structures "for various kinds of military action against Taiwan."
"They have done all this in a fashion they know Taiwan can monitor," he said, "so as to become credible on the use of force."
"I believe there has been no decision to use military force," he continued, "and they recognize that it would be a policy failure for them to have to resort to force; but they have set up the option, they have communicated that in the most credible fashion and, I believe, the danger is that they would exercise it in certain circumstances."
Several experts cited their concern that actions by Congress in the aftermath of President Lee's expected election could be a critical factor contributing to a military confrontation. If President Lee perceives that he has a strong base of support in the United States Congress and presses forward with his campaign to raise Taiwan's status, the risk of a military crisis is greater, they said. A chief concern is that Congress would seek to invite the Taiwan leader back to the United States as a gesture of American support. A Chinese military leader warned in November that such a step could have "explosive" results.
In recent months, American statements on whether United States forces would defend Taiwan if it came under attack have been deliberately vague so as to deter Beijing through a posture of what the Pentagon calls "strategic ambiguity."
Some members of Congress assert that the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979 includes an implicit pledge to defend Taiwan if attacked, but Administration officials say that a decision would depend on the timing, pretext and nature of Chinese aggression.

HEADLINE: Shuttling Through the Night: The Overnighters' Odyssey;
Homeless People Living Between Shelter Visits

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
It was another muttering, fatigue-fogged midnight in the sour-aired waiting room of the homeless shelter at Bellevue Hospital. Fifty men in dingy parkas slumped awkwardly on chairs, staring or snoring, the murmur broken every few minutes by the blare of a bus announcement.
"Flushing!" came the call, offering a bed in the city-run shelter in Flushing, Queens, and a way out of spending the night on a chair. "Let's go! Flushing!" 
 Some lined up, but many did not. Several men who lingered said it was easy to understand: the hot water at Flushing often ran out, sometimes the heating broke down, they would be lucky if they got to bed by 2 A.M., and then they would likely be roused at 6 for a ride back to Manhattan that often dropped them many blocks from Bellevue.
"It doesn't make sense," said Fred Mack, a 46-year-old bank messenger. "I don't get enough rest and I've got to get up and go to work."
So he stayed, as did many sleep-starved others, in a small but increasingly problematic pocket of the city's shelter system that has infuriated advocates for the homeless this winter and brought to light some of the knottier problems of getting people off the streets.
These men, some mentally ill, some drug-addicted, some simply down on their luck, are known as "overnighters" -- people who just want a bed for the night and otherwise, essentially, to be left alone -- no drug treatment, no job training, no long-term bed, just warmth through the winter night.
There appear to be several hundred overnighters out of a total of some 7,300 single adults in the New York City shelter system, city officials say. When they are not in the shelters they tend to bed down on the streets, subways or in shantytowns; some stay at relatives' or in cheap rooms until their money runs out each month.
By law, the city must provide them with shelter, and it does. But it has no obligation to make the process overly convenient, and the men, in turn, often complicate things for the city by arriving late at Bellevue, one of two intake points for homeless men, and turning down spots in the Flushing shelter or other far-off places.
"We offer people beds and transport them to those beds, but there are a significant number of people who refuse beds," said Joan Malin, the Homeless Services Commissioner. "The complaints are more from a group that's coming in very late at night and I'd argue, "Come in earlier, work with us."
Advocates for the homeless charge that the city, struggling with a shelter system filled to capacity and about to overflow, purposely makes the Bellevue and Flushing experiences so full of hassles that men will be discouraged from coming. The Flushing shelter, which opened last fall to handle the overflow from the rest of the system, is the only shelter to close down completely during the day, the advocates say, and none of the men can make a temporary base there.
"Some of these people are mentally ill, but they're not stupid, they know a raw deal when they see it," said Mary Brosnahan, the director of the Coalition for the Homeless. "Getting three hours of sleep and getting dumped on the West Side of Manhattan is a raw deal."
City officials vehemently deny the allegations, saying that, in fact, they work hard to bring people in off the streets with various outreach programs. But, said Susan Wiviott, spokeswoman for the Department of Homeless Services, the city wants homeless people to enter long-term programs that will solve root problems like drug abuse and get them housed for good. The overnighters, she said, are using the system wrongly.
"It's not a flophouse," she said was the message to homeless people. "We're providing you with this resource but we want you to use it to regain your independence."
The Coalition for the Homeless argues that many of the men at Bellevue want to enter the longer-term system, but cannot because it is overcrowded. So they shuttle back and forth between Bellevue and Flushing or overnighters' beds in other shelters, or just going back to the streets.
The dispute has reached the level of court battles; the coalition is seeking a ruling in State Supreme Court that by shuttling the men back and forth between Bellevue and Flushing, the city is violating its obligation to provide decent shelter to more than 200 homeless men.
Oblivious of the arguments over their treatment, the men in the Bellevue waiting room know only that every night involves a choice between chair-sleep and an odyssey.
On one recent night at nearly 1 A.M., several men in the packed waiting room said they had arrived in early evening and been waiting hours for a bus to a shelter. A few stretched out on the bare floor; others staked out chairs; one, Allah Rhaheem, was studying for a college math exam.
"I have a very important test tomorrow," he said unhappily, "and I can't study properly because it's noisy and it smells bad."
He had two more worksheets to finish and had no time to go through the Flushing shuttle, he said.
After one call for a bus to Flushing, Carlos Vivo, a 19-year-old man with his face barely visible inside an oversized sweatshirt hood, turned to Robert Jones, 22, an unemployed security guard.
"You going to Flushing, right?" Mr. Vivo asked.
Mr. Jones shook his head hard. "I can't mess with the cold showers, I'll get sick again," he said.
On another late night, Alan Williams, 32, decided he'd go to the Queens shelter, but "You got to go through a whole lot of headaches just to get on the bus," he said of the registration procedure and hours of waiting.
He made it to the last bus at 1 A.M.
"By the time I get there, it'll be time to get up," he said.
The Flushing building, a 180-bed armory that had served as a shelter until 1994 when it closed because the system did not need the beds, could serve as the definition of the bare minimum of shelter. It was clean and, on a recent visit, several repairmen were battling with dedication to fix the building's old boiler after 1 A.M., but its sleeping space looked like a giant school gym full of beds at three-feet intervals.
Mr. Williams figured he would get to bed about 2:30 A.M., after getting his paperwork in order, taking a shower, picking up his linen and making his bed. He expected to be awakened at 6 A.M. for the ride back to the city.
"My eyes weigh like 100 pounds," he said.
Mr. Mack, the bank messenger, stayed back at Bellevue, in part, he said, because he was free to leave there whenever he wanted to, unlike staying at the more "sequestered" shelters.
The Bellevue waiting room has very free access indeed. Those who come in the front door of the shelter must sign in, go through a metal detector and pass inspection by a guard with a metal-detecting wand. But despite the security measures at the front door, a side door leading to the buses on 30th Street was unguarded, and almost anyone could walk in or out.
The misery there was low-grade, but pervasive. The room was well-heated and lighted, but the close quarters, the noise despite a futile sign on the wall demanding silence, the occasional altercations -- all were enough to make Marcus Owens, a self-described manic depressive, yearn for warmer weather.
"If it wasn't so cold I'd much rather sleep in Central Park," he said. "It'd be much more pleasurable there."
"Just the cold made me come in," he said.

HEADLINE: Newark Airport Is Pressing to Surpass Kennedy

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Newark International Airport formally opens a sprawling, $120 million international arrivals hall on Wednesday, a move that aviation experts say positions Newark to become the region's busiest airport.
The light-filled addition to Terminal B is designed to double the airport's capacity to take in international passengers, to 3,000 passengers an hour when it is fully operating by year's end. 
 That, along with a $350 million monorail to open in May connecting the main Newark terminals, could siphon off passengers from Kennedy International Airport who have long been maddened by the lengthy arrival lines at immigration and the maze that constitutes terminal transfers.
"Kennedy is known in the business as the airport people love to hate," said David S. Stempler, a Washington-based airline passenger consultant. "If Newark can capitalize on the fact that connections will be easier, I think it will really have an advantage."
The growth of Newark relative to Kennedy has ramifications beyond air travel. Airports represent powerful economic engines for their cities and regions, and increasing passenger traffic means increased spending and jobs, both at the airport itself and in the surrounding area.
The shift toward Newark also seems to demonstrate that many travelers have finally shed the lingering impression that international travel means flying to or from Kennedy. Indeed, for travelers starting from midtown Manhattan, getting to Newark can be easier than getting to Kennedy.
While Newark 10 years ago briefly passed Kennedy in numbers of passengers, the 1986 statistics were considered an anomaly because of huge fare cuts for People Express, which later went out of business. Two years ago, Kennedy had a very slight edge, with 28.8 million passengers to 28.0 million for Newark. Figures for 1995 were still being compiled, but airport officials said Newark is one of the fastest growing airports in the nation.
And the new, more efficient international terminal sets the stage for even more growth, experts said.
"Over all, people will still be driven by price and convenience rather than which airport is a nice place to be," said Claude Shostal, president of Regional Plan Association, an independent agency that specializes in the three-state region of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. "But at the margins when all other things are equal, about 5 or 10 percent of passengers will opt for the nicer place."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has long accused the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey of favoring the Garden State, announced today that he was commissioning a study on turning the Port Authority's operations over to private management, including the airports. City Hall is said to believe that the gains in passengers at Newark are not because the airport offers any particular advantage but because the Port Authority has let facilities at Kennedy and La Guardia airports get so shabby.
"They are going to have to stop spending money in New Jersey for about 10 years and get New York cleaned up," said John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, arguing that having three great airports would benefit the entire region economically.
Port Authority officials say that they agree and that they are ready to invest $2 billion in improving New York City's airports, but they add that the city itself is causing problems by dragging its feet in negotiations over new leases.
For example, the Port Authority said it was willing to spend in the neighborhood of $1 billion for a new arrivals hall at Kennedy -- projected for completion in 2003 but still in the design phase. The authority says it might not be able to move forward with the plans because of the dispute with the city over $400 million in lease payments.
Fifteen years ago, Kennedy had 98.5 percent of all international passengers at the three airports. Now, Newark has 17.5 percent, La Guardia acounts for 5.8 percent and Kennedy's share has fallen to 76.6 percent. The Port Authority, which keeps these statistics, said this balance was likely to remain.
"I would say those percentages are not going to change significantly over the years," said Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority. "Newark may pick up some international and Kennedy some domestic flights."
But airline executives based at Newark are much more upbeat. Newark has consistently added new foreign destinations over the last decade and at least one foreign carrier, Scandinavian Airline Systems, uses it alone for flights to the New York area.
In addition to gaining passengers, Newark has reduced the flight delays that have long plagued its passengers. For several years, the Federal Aviation Administration has rated it the nation's worst airport for delays, but in the latest ranking, it dropped to seventh on that list, out of the 55 busiest airports.
Until now, international passengers arriving at Newark or Kennedy have been herded into equally dingy hallways, standing in seemingly endless, snaking lines that could easily stretch to 90 minutes during the most harried days of the peak summer travel season.
"This airport really is a bit drab," said Jason P. St. Hill, a British businessman arriving at Newark today, though he noted that he generally chooses Newark for his seven or eight trips to the United States each year because he gets out faster.
In the new building tacked onto the back of Terminal B, Newark's arriving passengers waiting to be processed or for their luggage will be able to stand in light-filled hallways the length of two football fields. The outer, back walls are mostly glass and offer panoramic views of flights taking off against the backdrop of the lower Manhattan skyline.
"It is the most beautiful inspection area I've ever seen," said Paul J. Erdheim, supervising the installations for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the new building.
Before, eight gates fed into 32 immigration stations and four baggage carousels. With the new terminal, 15 gates will be served by at least 56 immigration booths and seven baggage carousels. The messages of where to stand and where to pick up luggage will be flashed on overhead electronic screens.
Today, workers were finishing the lighting and spreading the carpeting.
