HEADLINE: Text of the G.O.P. Response: 'The Future and the Values That Will Shape It'

 BODY:
Following is the Republican response by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to President Clinton's State of the Union Message last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
I'm Bob Dole, and I'm here very gratefully to reply to the President's message on the state of the union. But a reply need not be an argument. Instead, I want to present another view. Another way of thinking about the problems we face. 
 A few years back I met with a group of a hundred high school seniors -- one young man and woman from every state. During the meeting one young man stood up and said: "Senator, everybody has somebody who speak for them. But who speaks for us?" he asked me. "Who speaks for the future?"
That's what I want to talk with you about tonight. The future and the values that will shape it. Those values are at the heart of our disagreements with the President. President Clinton says our differences are few, the budget numbers are close and that we should try to find common ground. We have tried and tried. Again and again. But such a place appears to be elusive.
For while we share an abiding love of country, we have been unable to agree. Why? Because we have starkly different philosophies of government and profoundly different visions of America. So all the talk and fighting in Washington can seem very remote. And we political figures can seem detached. And petty. And far removed from the every-day struggle of American citizens and families.
But the truth is we can not ignore the future. The point of our lives, after all, is to raise children who are smarter and healthier and nobler than we are. To contribute to a country that is better than today's America; to make a world that is better and finer for all of God's creation.
America's greatness -- all that we take such justified pride in today -- America's greatness was built by men and women who sacrificed ease and comfort and the joys of today, to build a better future for those who came after. How many pioneers faced a hostile and threatening frontier? How many immigrants gave their bodies to the mines? And how many soldiers lost their lives on the distant battlefields to secure a better future for their children and their children's children?
In every generations, Americans made these sacrifices, and found in their making a purpose and a direction to life. Now we have to do that in this generation. And thanks to God and fortune, to those who went before, we don't have to conquer a dangerous frontier. We don't have to fight another great war. What we do have to do is face the fact that we cannot give in to all of our own desires. As we have just heard, President Clinton, and those who share his vision of America, have chosen their ground.
The President has chosen to defend, with his veto, a welfare system that no one can defend -- for it is a daily assault on the values of self-reliance and family. He has chosen to defend an education establishment run by liberals whose goal is to operate every school in America by remote control from Washington. He has chosen to veto a defense bill because it provided for defending America against weapons of mass destruction.
He has chosen to defend the status quo in Medicare -- a system on which lives depend and a program in urgent need of rescue. President Clinton has chosen to defend and increase a tax burden that has pushed countless families into their own personal recessions. And unfortunately he has chosen to veto the first balanced budget in a generation, offering only a fantasy in its place.
 
Place Where Compromise Ends
Now if you have a child asleep in your home tonight, you will probably check on him or her before you go to bed. And as you bend over to tuck your child in, think about this: If we continue down this path we will place a tremendous burden of debt on every child in America. Now how can we betray them and their parents and their grandparents? How can we fail to act? We cannot, and we will not.
Every political movement and every public official must locate a place in his heart where compromise ends -- a core of conviction where we keep our conscience. There comes a time when even practical leaders must refuse to bend or to yield. And for Republicans and countless Democrats and independents, we have arrived at that time.
America's troubles are real, but our choices are clear and our will is strong. We must rein in our runaway Government, return power to the people, reduce the tax burden, put parents back in charge of our schools, untie the hands of our police, restore justice to our courts and put our faith once again in the basic goodness, wisdom and self-reliance of our people.
The President spoke with great eloquence tonight about a future with unlimited possibilities. It is a vision we all share, for it is the story of America.
But while the President's words speak of change, his deeds are a contradiction. The President claims to embrace the future while clinging to the policies of the past.
For three years this Administration has valued dependence on Government over self-reliance, Federal power over community, Federal planning over individual enterprise. It has tried to place Government experts in charge of our economy and our health and our lives.
It has put liberal judges on the bench to war with our values and it questions the participation of religious people in public life, treating them as fanatics out of step with America.
President Clinton shares a view of America held by our country's elites.
A nation of special interest groups united only by a dependence on government, competing with each other for handouts, and held back by outdated values. Now for those who hold this view, there's only one answer for our problems:
More government.
Bigger government.
And more meddlesome government.
And if you listened closely tonight, that's what President Clinton talked about. President Clinton may well be the rear guard of the welfare state. He is the chief obstacle to a balanced budget and the balanced budget amendment. He is almost the last public defender of a discredited status quo. We Republicans will not give up the struggle because America will round the corner to a brighter future if we prevail.
 
Miracle of America
I come from Russell, Kan. There's not much money there, but the people are rich in many other ways. Life isn't always easy, but the values are durable. Love of God and country and family. Commitment to honesty, decency and personal responsibility. And self-reliance tempered by a sense of community.
Those values made America the greatest nation on earth, and there is no doubt in my mind that we can get our country back on track if we reassert them again as a people. And if our government returns to them as a matter of national policy.
Now just like the debate over the budget this wither, our arguments this spring will seem a maze of conflicting numbers, assertions and high-sounding words. But what we're really arguing about are the values that will shape our nation, our government, and the future of that child sleeping down the hall.
Now some people try to make these matters complicated, but they're simple in my home town -- and probably where you are as well. Americans know that handouts without responsibility destroy human dignity.
We know that the help of a neighbor is preferable to that of a bureaucrat. And we know that wealth is created by free individuals in their smarts and their sweat. Government programs can only spend it.
Now I'm a very practical man, but I believe in the miracle of America. And I've never gone in for dramatics, but I do believe we have reached a defining moment. It is as if we went to sleep in one America and woke up in quite another.
 
Defunding Big Brother
It is as though our Government, and our institutions and our culture have been hijacked by liberals and are careening dangerously off course. Well, we know the way back, but we must act now. And my promise tonight is that we can, and we will.
If there is no agreement, we will send President Clinton another balanced budget with tax relief for American families, regulatory relief for small business, farmers and ranchers and real welfare reform.
We will always be mindful of the poor and disadvantaged, education and the environment. But we will begin the defunding of Big Brother by unfunding wasteful programs and meddlesome departments. We will send the President bill after bill, returning power and programs to the states and to the people.
We will challenge President Clinton again and again to walk the talk he talks so well. As we do, remember this: Our battles will not be about numbers. They'll be about the character of our nation. Yes, our country has problems. But we can handle them.
Whether it's deficit spending or the welfare bureaucracy or our liberal courts or the trouble in our schools, what's wrong is that the elites in charge don't believe in what the people believe in. That we can fix. We know what made America great. All we need now is the resolve to lead our country back to her place in the sun, and the courage to speak for the future.
 
Work of the Lord
So, when you close the door to your child's room tonight, remember it's not too late. This is a great country. Our strength has always come from the truth, and from sacrifice and honor, and from the bottomless reservoir of hope and work and courage that is the American people. Always, we have built for the future with a half-silent consciousness that we were doing the work of the Lord.
Today, we feel ourselves beset by many difficulties: by violence and resentment, by racial and partisan divisions, by economic storms, by dizzying changes of every kind.
Yet, the blood of greatness, of noble forebearers, of men and women of incredible achievement still runs through us all. That birthright is what it means to bear the name "American."
In this time, in this generation, in this year, we -- like they -- can and will overcome. We need only to rededicate ourselves to earning the name we have inherited.
Thank you very much. God bless America, and good night.

LENGTH: 342 words

HEADLINE: On Crime, Look to More Cost-Effective Antidotes Than Prison

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Prisons Are a Bargain, by Any Measure" (Op-Ed, Jan. 16), by John J. DiIulio Jr.: If you look at the numbers, you discover that cost-effective is what prisons are not. 
 Increasing incarceration rates do not result in decreasing crime rates, in part because few crimes result in imprisonment or arrest. This is not because judges are soft on criminals but because 90 percent of crimes are either not reported or go unsolved.
Mr. DiIulio, while noting the economist Steven D. Levitt's assertion that incarcerating one prisoner reduces the number of crimes by 13 a year, fails to note Mr. Levitt's further assertion that increasing our prison population beyond its current level would not be cost-effective.
The $25,000 average cost a year to keep a convicted criminal in prison that Mr. DiIulio cites takes into account only operational and direct building expenditures and ignores the huge costs of the long-term financing required to build new prisons. A maximum-security bed in New York State, for example, costs $100,000 to build, and $200,000 more to finance.
Moreover, if we abolish parole and adopt "one strike, you're out" sentencing, we will be keeping people in prison beyond the age at which they constitute a threat to society. The average cost of incarcerating a prisoner over age 60 is around $65,000 a year, while less than 1 percent of serious crime is committed by people in that age group.
Incarceration of convicted violent criminals may be the best answer for some young offenders during crime-prone years. But for most nonviolent offenders there are indeed more cost-effective alternatives than prison. Western Europe, Japan, Canada and Australia use such alternatives, and their incarceration rates are between one-tenth and one-quarter of ours. These countries have lower rates of violent crime than the United States. We need to see which of their programs can work for us.
 
ELIZABETH ALEXANDER
Acting Dir., National Prison Project
American Civil Liberties Union
Washington, Jan. 18, 1996

HEADLINE: American Center In Paris Must Sell Its Home

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The American Center, which for 65 years has served as both promoter and window of American culture in Paris, announced today that it had lost its battle for economic survival and would close and sell its new ultra-modern headquarters on the eastern edge of the city.
Inaugurated just 19 months ago, the striking $41 million building designed by Frank Gehry had been hailed as an exciting symbol of American self-confidence and an important addition to the fast-changing Parisian landscape. But from the moment it opened, the building's $6 million annual operating cost was more than the center could afford. 
 One problem was that almost all of the $42 million raised by selling the center's old headquarters on the Boulevard Raspail on the Left Bank was spent on the new building, leaving the center without an income-generating endowment. The center, which receives no United States Government support, also discovered that many promises of corporate sponsorship made in the booming late 80's were broken in the more penny-pinching mid-90's.
Last summer, the center's chairman, Frederick B. Henry, and its executive director, Marie-Claude Beaud, began warning that the building might have to close. They looked for an investor willing to buy it and rent it back to the center. They proposed a partnership with the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. And they tried to convince American corporations that an American cultural presence in Paris was worth saving. But no reprieve was found.
"I think it is sad that, for all its economic problems, a country as rich as the United States is not willing to keep alive a place that is called the American Center," Ms. Beaud said in a telephone interview before she announced the closing to her 23-member staff. "I was very disappointed by the lack of response."
Founded in 1931, the center was a frequent gathering point for American expatriate artists and writers before World War II and even more so in the late 1940's and 50's. It also organized classes in English and in modern American dance that were very popular with young French people. After the center moved from the Boulevard Raspail to the eastern Bercy district, however, it focused principally on the promotion of avant-garde culture.
Even more of a problem, Bercy lies far from many residential areas, and plans for an improved subway connection were repeatedly postponed. Several Americans who expressed regret over the center's closing admitted today that they had never visited the new building. "They went crazy and built this palace in the middle of nowhere," said one longtime resident of Paris.
At least in name, however, the American Center will not disappear. A statement issued by its board said that the center planned to use the proceeds from the sale of the Gehry building "to establish a fund to support a variety of cultural and educational activities and programs, including direct grants." It also said the center would continue to view its principal mission as that of promoting American culture in an international context.
The statement noted that the building would close on Feb. 12 and that funds were available to compensate staff members who would lose their jobs. "This not a plan for the liquidation or termination of the center, but for its continuation in another form," Mr. Henry said, adding that the decision to close the Gehry building was made unanimously at a board meeting here on Tuesday afternoon. "We will convert it from an unsustainable financial drain into a liquid fund."
Mr. Henry, who also heads the New York-based Bohen Foundation, said the American Center faced the same set of problems as many cultural institutions in the United States. "The question is, what are our assets?" he said in an interview. "Are we a building or are we a program? The closure is symptomatic not of a failure to support American culture abroad but of the hard decisions that cultural institutions must take these days."
"It was unfortunately the only reasonable solution," said Ms. Beaud, a contemporary art curator who is the center's first French director. "We tried, we fought, we did everything we could to avoid this. We found money to run most of our programs, but we couldn't run the building. It was very sad, but we had no choice."
Ms. Beaud has been given the job of preparing the center's new program and of finding a buyer for the building. "It's too early to talk about a buyer," she said. "We also don't yet have a price. With the building and everything we have done, we've put in close to $50 million, but any buyer will have to make changes. The original planning permission said the building could only have a cultural use, but we have asked the Paris government to remove the restriction."
With its classical and Cubist facades and its interior gallery and theater spaces, the building was clearly designed as a cultural center. And over the last 18 months, it has slowly found its place in Paris's cultural life with frequent art exhibitions, theater and dance programs, movie festivals and conference series. "We have had almost 150,000 visitors in that time," said Laure Martin, the center's spokeswoman.
Significantly, the board avoided pointing fingers of blame at the center's previous leadership team, headed by Judith Pisar, chairwoman from 1977 to 1994, and Henry Pillsbury, executive director from 1969 to 1994, who were behind the decision to sell the Boulevard Raspail building and invite Mr. Gehry to design the new headquarters.
Neither Mrs. Pisar nor Mr. Pillsbury was willing to comment on today's announcement. In interviews last year, Mrs. Pisar explained that "we wanted the new building to be a cultural statement," while Mr. Pillsbury conceded that fund-raising projections in the late 1980's had proved to be too optimistic.
In a brief statement today, the American Ambassador, Pamela Harriman, said she wished the center well. "The beauty and the genius of Frank Gehry's building will always remain on the Paris landscape as a tribute to American artistic talent and to cultural ties between our two countries," she added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ultramodern American Center in Paris, designed by Frank Gehry. (Luc Boegly/Archipress)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Narrower U.S.-Japan Trade Gap Helps Dollar Surge Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to its highest level in nearly two years against the Japanese yen yesterday on news of a smaller Japanese trade surplus with the United States and new friction between China and Taiwan.
The dollar also rose against most other leading currencies. Its rise against the German mark was driven by the Bundesbank's decision to let a key interest rate drop significantly. 
 Cresting Treasury bond prices, pushed by weak United States economic data, also helped push the dollar upward.
"The feature of today was yen weakness on the back of the Japanese trade numbers and from the heated political tensions in East Asia," Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst for Smith Barney, said.
In late New York trading, the dollar bought 106.93 yen, up from 105.84 yen on Tuesday. It last traded close to 107 yen in February 1994. The dollar ended at 1.4836 marks, up from 1.4791 marks on Tuesday.
The Asian news was crucial yesterday, beginning with Japan's announcement that the country's trade surplus with the United States dropped by nearly a fifth last year, the first drop since 1990.
The Finance Ministry said that the surplus with the United States, its biggest trading partner, plummeted 17 percent, while the overall surplus dropped by 11 percent.
"The trade surplus is in a substantial downward trend," Andrew Shipley, an economist with Schroder Securities Japan, said.
The market also reacted to news reports that China was prepared to fire missiles at Taiwan if it continued to seek international recognition. China experts said they did not think China would attack, but that the warnings should be taken seriously. Such anxiety, Ms. Finstrom said, "created selling pressure on the yen."
In Europe, Germany let its two-week securities repurchase rate drop one-tenth of a percentage point, to 3.55 percent, after falling eight-hundredths of a percentage point last week. When the interest rates of a country drop, its assets and currency become less attractive to investors.
The rate drop is a "sign of slowing economic conditions," Ms. Finstrom said, adding, "That's seen as dollar positive."
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.1910 Swiss francs, up from 1.1880; 5.0800 French francs, up from 5.0643, and 1,590 Italian lire, down from 1,594. The British pound fell to $1.5115, from $1.5138 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: China Threatens Taiwan

 BODY:
China has made no secret of its concern that Taiwan is drifting toward independence with the tacit support of the United States. Beijing pounced on an unofficial visit to America last year by Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to register its strong objection to any potential change in Taiwan's status. But China has now escalated tensions by recklessly raising the prospect that it might use military force to intimidate Taiwan. The United States and other countries must make clear that such a step would unravel Beijing's relations with the international community and undermine China's prized economic boom.
Patrick Tyler of The Times reports that Chinese officials have let the Clinton Administration know that Beijing has completed plans for a limited military attack on Taiwan as soon as this spring unless the island bows to demands for a lower-profile foreign policy. 
 These warnings may well be nine-tenths diplomatic bluff. But even so they suggest that Beijing has lost sight of one of the basic understandings underlying improved Chinese-American relations since the Nixon Administration -- that Taiwan's future status must be settled by peaceable means.
Beijing is plainly infuriated by the recent efforts of President Lee to win increased recognition for his country in foreign capitals and international bodies like the United Nations. The mainland Government sees Taiwan as an integral part of the historical Chinese empire, torn away by foreign imperialists and Chiang Kai-shek at a time when China was weak. Taiwanese see it differently, pointing to their centuries of separate cultural development and, more importantly, their hard-won political democracy and thriving capitalist economy as good reasons for standing somewhat apart.
China apparently hopes its warnings will lead Washington to lean on Mr. Lee to accommodate Beijing. While Washington should urge caution on both sides, the United States must vigorously reject military bullying from Beijing in cases like this.
Taiwan is too big to be treated as a mere pawn in relations between Washington and Beijing. It is America's seventh-largest trading partner, with 21 million people, a vibrant democracy and one of Asia's highest living standards.
More than anything else, it is the fear that today's freedoms and prosperity would be lost under Beijing's harsh authoritarian rule that fuels Taiwan's quest for a separate identity. Beijing would do better to address this fear with political and economic reforms at home rather than threatening the use of force across the Taiwan Straits.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Washington may tighten up on reporting of fees by trial lawyers.

BYLINE: Peter Passell 

 BODY:
EVERY interest payment, stock sale and royalty payment these days generates a notice to the Internal Revenue Service. But when a lawyer receives a settlement on behalf of a client and keeps a big part of it as his fee, the I.R.S. learns about the money only if the lawyer includes it on his tax form.
That may be about to change. Congressional Republicans have added a provision to their budget bill to require reporting of the tens of billions of dollars in legal settlements paid each year. But the tale of how trial lawyers have managed to avoid the requirement illuminates the special clout they have long enjoyed in a Washington dominated by Democrats. 
 After Republicans proposed the idea, President Clinton did not include this seemingly innocuous revenue raiser in his own budget. The White House may change its tune. But Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is not about to let the matter drop. "Your omission," he wrote the President last month, "would appear to indicate a special preference by the White House on behalf of trial lawyers."
Some people forget to report the $30 they got in dividends on, say, 10 shares of Exxon stock Aunt Harriet willed them. But the I.R.S. knows anyway: its computers are combing through computer tapes, matching dividend payments to declarations of taxable income. And Uncle Sam will eventually send out a dunning notice for the tax, plus interest and penalties.
Next to the withholding of taxes on wages, the 1099 reporting form is the Government's handiest weapon in the increasingly computerized war on tax evasion. The requirement has been in force since the 1960's. But the law began to bite only in the 1980's after the I.R.S. began to cross-check hundreds of millions of transactions each year.
Since 1982, reporting of sales of securities has also been required. And by comparison with the reporting of dividends, said Michael J. Graetz of the Yale School of Law, it is a relatively blunt instrument because "the sums reported don't correspond to any line on your tax form."
For all the complexity, though, compliance on capital gains jumped sharply. For while the I.R.S. computers cannot use the figures to pin down unreported taxable income, the electronic trail serves as deterrent to tax evasion.
Payments to lawyers are reported when they are in the form of salaries or consulting fees. That, however, leaves a giant gap for income associated with lawsuits.
Lawyers usually get a third of any settlement -- sometimes more. If the defendant's insurance company settles for $300,000, the money is typically paid by check to the lawyer who, in turn, writes a $200,000 check and keeps $100,000. Or if the case was referred by another lawyer, the $100,000 is divided between them.
A settlement for damages is not taxable income; the money going to the lawyers certainly is. Surely, though, lawyers are diligent tax filers? After all, they are better informed about their legal obligations and more vulnerable to sanction than the average American: conviction for tax evasion usually leads to disbarment.
In fact, tax evasion by lawyers is quite common. Project Esquire, begun by the I.R.S. in 1989, found that roughly 10 percent of lawyers never even filed tax returns -- a higher rate than for the population as a whole.
The dollars involved may be substantial. Lester Brickman of the Cardozo School of Law in New York, notes that a disproportionate number of personal injury lawyers are sole practitioners or in small firms, where tax evasion is easier. And he further points out that referral income -- where the beneficiary is two steps removed from the transaction -- amounts to $3 billion to $4 billion annually. "Taxes evaded probably run from $25 million to $50 million a year," Mr. Brickman said, "and that's conservative."
It is easy to see why Republicans latched on to the idea. After all, hardly anybody likes lawyers, and nobody likes tax cheats. Besides, it would embarrass the plaintiffs' bar, which has bitterly resisted Republican-led efforts to reduce lawsuits along with the fees paid to lawyers.
The more interesting question is why the provision was not part of the President's response to Congressional Republicans. Political influence cannot be counted out, but the trial lawyers' lobby claims no credit. Phil Buchan, an official of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said, "we haven't taken a position on it."
Nonetheless, it seems likely that someone in the White House dropped the idea from the Administration's own bill. A senior Treasury official suggested that the disappearance was simply a mistake. Whatever the reason, the Administration will probably not go to the wall for trial lawyers, who soon may be reporting their contingency income just like everybody else.

HEADLINE: New Signs of Weakness in Nation's Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Fresh signs of a faltering economy emerged yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported that production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent in December, and the Commerce Department said sales of new homes plunged to a seven-month low in November.
Analysts said the reports underscored the weakness of the economy in the fourth quarter and could help persuade the Fed to cut interest rates again next week to stimulate growth. 
 Stock and bond prices rose after the reports were released. Many traders said the latest evidence of weakness could lead to lower interest rates, which would make their securities more attractive.
"The economy is still in an expansion, but it clearly is slowing down," said David Lereah, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "I don't think we are in any trouble of recession, but it clearly is slowing and could use a boost."
The gain in industrial production in December was just two-tenths of 1 percent higher than in November. Output had fallen four-tenths of 1 percent in October.
That meant that growth in production slowed to an annual rate of eight-tenths of 1 percent during the fourth quarter, compared with 3.2 percent during the previous three months. For the year, output rose 3.2 percent, little more than half the 5.9 percent growth in 1994.
Sales of new single-family homes fell for the fourth consecutive month in November, down 2.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 649,000.
The rate was the lowest since 607,000 last April. Sales dropped in all regions except the South. In the Northeast, they plunged to a 13-year low.
"The economy has slowed, the industrial sector has stalled, housing activity is going nowhere, even though mortgage rates are declining, and consumers are worried," said Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch. "The Fed should, and we believe will, ease" interest rates.
The reports, which had been delayed by the partial Government shutdown, were among the last major economic data scheduled before the Federal Open Market Committee begins a two-day meeting next Tuesday.
Many analysts believe it will cut short-term rates by a quarter of a percentage point in an attempt to energize the economy. It last trimmed the Federal funds rate in December, to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent, the second cut of 1995. The rate is what banks charge each other for overnight loans.
In its report today, the central bank said that the industrial sector was operating at 82.8 percent of capacity in December, down from 83 percent a month earlier and the lowest since 82.6 percent in January 1994.
Analysts monitor the capacity rate for signs of future inflation. Many believe a rate greater than 85 percent could lead to production bottlenecks, shortages and rising prices.
The report showed the anemic growth was due mostly to increased output of cars and light trucks and the end of the Boeing aircraft strike. Excluding cars and trucks, output was unchanged.
Manufacturing output rose a tenth of a percent, including a three-tenths of 1 percent gain in durable goods such as cars and appliances. But nondurable goods output fell two-tenths of a percent, the second consecutive decline.
Mining output also fell for a second consecutive time, down two-tenths of 1 percent. Production of utilities, however, advanced four-tenths of a percent.
The Commerce Department report showed that new-home sales have not improved since they rose 8 percent last July, to a 781,000 annual rate.
Existing-home sales fell 1.7 percent in November and single-family housing starts were flat. Mortgage applications have also leveled off.

HEADLINE: 2 Futures Exchanges to Reconsider Joint Efforts

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from big investment banks and other financial institutions that have become the source of most of their business, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange vowed again today to try to put aside rivalry to cooperate more closely.
"Everything is on the table, from buying pencils together to merging," said John F. Sandner, chairman of the Merc, who with his counterpart on the Board of Trade, Patrick H. Arbor, announced the creation of a high-level committee to study "joint strategic initiatives." 
 Complaints about the continuing separation of the world's two largest futures exchanges are coming from big brokers and investment firms like Merrill Lynch, which own seats at both of them. These institutions care little for longstanding cultural differences between the two exchanges and want them to cooperate to lower overhead expenses.
The exchanges have been forced to take a closer look at the financial benefits of cooperation by a drop in trading volume last year. After reaching record-high trading levels in 1994, both exchanges saw 1995 volume in crucial products tumble when interest rates were relatively stable.
For the year, volume at the Board of Trade was off 4 percent despite a huge increase in agricultural trading. The Merc, which entered the year privately crowing that it was about to surpass the Board of Trade to become the world's volume leader, suffered a 29 percent drop.
A number of events on the horizon, including a possible balanced Federal budget and the unification of European currencies, suggested that this year's problems might be a sign of tougher times to come. Full seats on the Merc have fallen from a peak price of $925,000 in 1994 to $575,000. The Board of Trade's seat prices had peaked at $710,000 just over a year ago and now cost $610,00.
A full merger was still considered a long shot. The exchanges have long worked together to lobby Washington and have cooperated on some overseas marketing ventures, but merger talks had begun and halted several times since the 1970's. The reasons cited by participants have varied from clashing operating procedures and fee structures, to differing strategies for growth and bruised egos at the top.
The current hurdles to a full merger include the likely reluctance of Merc members to get involved with the Board of Trade's $182 million building expansion, which has been financed by borrowing, unlike a recent Merc expansion.
The most recent disappointment came in 1994 when efforts to merge the clearing operations that settle trades at the two exchanges collapsed after several years of talks. Earlier that year, the Board of Trade abandoned a joint venture with the Merc and Reuters P.L.C. to develop an international electronic trading system called Globex.
The latest effort to overcome the past will have big-name support. H. Merton Miller, a Nobel Prize-winning professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, who has long been involved in the governance of both exchanges, was named executive director of the joint initiatives committee.
Both exchange chairmen are expected to serve on the committee, along with David J. Fisher, a vice chairman at the Board of Trade and Leo Melamed and John T. Geldermann, both former chairmen of the Merc. The committee also includes top executives from the trading arms of Merrill Lynch, Mitsubishi, Dean Witter Reynolds and Morgan Stanley.

HEADLINE: The State of the Worker

BYLINE: By Thomas Geoghegan; Thomas Geoghegan, author of "Which Side Are You On?," is a labor lawyer.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The first duty of the State, President Clinton seemed to say on Tuesday night, is to open up in the morning. After Woodrow Wilson's 14 Points and Franklin Roosevelt's Four Freedoms, we have come down to this: "Let's just open up!"
I thought, with deep shame, is that all I'm cheering for? Certainly I am on the side of the Age of Possibility, when, heaven knows, anything is possible, when even the Government may close. 
 In his State of the Union Message, Mr. Clinton offered a sentence or two about America's falling wages and standard of living. He referred to his plans for job training vouchers, and he talked briefly about the minimum wage, which he is proposing to raise very modestly. But mostly he spoke about moral values and how we treat our children.
In some future State of the Union, may one of these children stand up and deliver a curse on Congress, the White House and the elites, and even you and me. And we will deserve it. Because there is growing evidence that millions of our children will not have a decent future, a chance to support themselves with a single job.
I have just been reading a study conducted last year about job trends in the Chicago area as part of the MacArthur Foundation's Working Poor Project. The researchers concluded that between now and 2005, an estimated 140,000 jobs will become available. Only about 25 percent of these will require a college degree, and another 25 percent will require a community college education. About half the jobs will be open to those with only a high school education. But of that half, none is projected to pay enough to cover even a minimal budget for an adult and two kids -- what is known as a living wage, about $23,000 a year.
The researchers noted that there will be stiff competition for these jobs: say, 1 job per 27 families for technicians, or 1 job per 138 families for machine setters. It will be a war of all against all for upscale poverty wages.
And what will people think in the future about the debate on the budget deficit that paralyzes us today? Of all developed countries, the United States actually has one of the lowest deficits. Mr. Clinton cut it from 4.5 percent of gross domestic product to about 2.5 percent. As Europeans joke, ours is one of the few countries that meets the Maastricht Treaty goals for entry into a single European currency.
Yet next month, the Government may be about to default, throw away our credit, over nothing. Because we have a Congress and a President who arbitrarily decided to wrench down the deficit to zero in seven years. It came to Newt Gingrich apparently in a dream.
Both parties have signed off on deficit-cutting projections that show an increase in unemployment. Just as frightening is the risk of a strong dollar, which is one possible result from a zero deficit. This would mean our goods would become more expensive abroad, encouraging a whole new wave of downsizing and wage cutting. We may look back on the recent AT&T layoffs as occurring in a golden age.
It is hard to see a necessary connection between a balanced budget and rising wages, though a few Republicans try to make this argument. Perhaps they suppose the payoff will be a huge rise in corporate profits. But we have that now. Or a burst in productivity. Suppose there was. There is no guarantee that any of this will budge the hourly wage up one cent.
It is almost harder to believe that Steve Forbes and his big business supporters really want to cut aid to the poor. Much of what we call welfare -- food stamps, the earned income tax credit, housing subsidies -- is really a disguised gift to business. We give the working poor enough calories to keep going so they don't have to ask for more money from the Boss.
The Clinton Administration says that its proposals on worker retraining and education can halt the steady drop in our standard of living. Well, hardly anyone is really against job training. How may Op-Ed articles in favor of training have we all read? Let the workers train and train, like an army without rifles.
Yet without a wage policy, job training can make matters worse. There is a finite number of high-wage jobs in an economy where people everywhere work for $4.25 an hour.
Of the 20 types of jobs that are likeliest to grow, most require few or no skills. Indeed, we seem to have too many college B.A.'s in the job market now. As a study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics pointed out, one out of five college graduates is already in a job that did not require the degree. If we somehow manage to increase that ratio to one out of three, it is not clear how much good it would do. So 300 families instead of 30 or 40 can chase every single "living wage" job?
Those of us with good jobs should probably just be grateful to the kids who did not go beyond high school. Perhaps it is time we erected a monument to the working poor, who sacrificed their own living standards for ours.
Ihave never understood the attraction of President Clinton's rather mean welfare-to-workfare proposals. He must realize that working Americans would actually be better off if more of us were on welfare. At least the job market wouldn't be flooded with more people.
There is growing evidence that some Americans are beginning to grasp this. A New York Times story last week quoted a New Hampshire woman who got tired of Phil Gramm shouting about how people in prison should be made to work "six days a week." "In order to get a job, an American is going to have to go commit a crime?" she called out in reply.
A decent minimum wage, collective bargaining and unions are all elements of a wage policy the Democrats lack. You may not like the concept of a "wage policy," but at least there is a logical chain of reasoning that leads to jobs that pay a salary people can live on. New Democrats shrink from it. Old Democrats yearn for the Great Society. Both lack the stomach to re-enact a version of the New Deal, which would have to precede, logically and historically, an affluent United States.
It is also said that the United States does not want Europe's problems. But why not? I'd take them over ours. Even if the Germans have higher unemployment, at least they do not have our horrific poverty, for both workers and nonworkers. And our 5.7 percent jobless rate does not include high school kids who are out pounding the streets for jobs. It certainly does not take into account the millions out there searching for second jobs. It doesn't count the nearly 2 percent of our able-bodied male work force sitting in prison. The fact is the bottom half of any European work force is simply better off than the bottom half of ours.
At least the Germans propose rational solutions. For example, the German unions have just offered wage restraint in return for an employer commitment to increase jobs. By "jobs," I mean "living wage" jobs, though many Americans would not remember what those are. One cannot imagine a dialogue like that here. Who would conduct it? Mr. Clinton? The debate about the state of our union exists on a plane of fantasy I would hate to see on the Internet.
There is no "V" chip that will zap us out of working poverty. But there is something the Clinton Administration can do: raise the minimum wage from $4.25 an hour to $7 or more, not just to $5.15 as the President proposes. (That just makes up for half the loss during the Reagan era.) Not all at once, but slowly: phased in over, shall we say, seven years? And this would have a substantial upward effect on wage levels higher than that.
It is fine for New Democrats to talk about moral values, but they should first meet their moral obligations as Old Democrats and push for higher wages.

HEADLINE: Stocks Jump to Yet Another High, Led by Technology Issues

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks jumped broadly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average setting another new record. Technology shares were stars of the market.
The Dow climbed 50.57 points, to 5,242.84, surpassing the previous high of 5,219.36, set on Monday. "Almost half of today's gain came from program trading in the morning," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst for Birinyi Associates. 
 United Technologies and Du Pont, two components of the 30-blue-chip average, showed unexpectedly strong increases after reporting higher earnings during the day that exceeded expectations. United Technologies advanced 3 1/8, to 97 3/8, and Du Pont rose 2 1/8, to 74 1/8.
Other major market indicators showed even larger percentage gains. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 7.17 points, or 1.17 percent, to 619.96. And the Nasdaq composite index jumped 15.42 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,043.46.
Advancing issues outnumbered declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,483 to 900. Volume climbed to 476.4 million shares from 416.9 million shares on Tuesday.
"The main influence was that mutual funds have been coming into the stock market with a huge influx of money," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president of Interstate/ Johnson Lane. "And nothing happened in the last 24 hours to prevent this money from being put to work."
The stock market was also buttressed by signs of conciliation on the budget deadlock in Washington and lower bond yields. When rates decline, consumer and corporate borrowing costs are reduced and economic growth is stimulated. The 30-year Treasury bond jumped 25/32 of a percentage point; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.03 percent, from 6.09 percent on Tuesday.
The surge in technology stocks was led by I.B.M., which has rallied since reporting better-than-expected earnings last Thursday. I.B.M. increased 4, to 107; Micron Technology advanced 5, to 37; Hewlett-Packard added 3 1/2, to 84, and Intel rose 2 1/16, to 54 3/4. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index surged 11.78 points, to 191.22.
Drug issues also finished in positive territory, as traders continued to turn to large-capitalization stocks. Johnson & Johnson, which reported a 23 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit, closed at 93 3/4, up 6; Pfizer ended at 63 3/4, up 3, and Merck finished at 67 7/8, up 1.
Helene Curtis, which surged 8 1/4 on Tuesday, picked up 12 3/4 more yesterday to close at 65 7/8 after saying that it was engaged in talks about a "possible business combination." First Interstate, which agreed to be acquired by Wells Fargo, gained 2 1/4, to 149 1/4. Wells Fargo also gained, closing at 229 1/2, up 1. Even First Bank System, which had been spurned by First Interstate, gained 1 1/2, to 51 3/4.
On the down side, Xerox tumbled 15, to 126 5/8, after the announcement of its fourth-quarter net income, which was below analysts' estimates. Cincinnati Bell slumped 1 5/8, to 33, after AT&T asked to renegotiate certain contracts. AT&T advanced 3/8, to 65 1/4.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Death in Deli And Worries Over Lottery

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
IT was a few days after the violent robbery that had killed Abdul Kareem Alsahybi in his Brooklyn delicatessen. The store was closed, bags filled with bullet-riddled cigarette packs and other evidence clogged the aisle, and Mr. Alsahybi's blood still stained the floor.
But the lottery machine, destroyed in the shootout on Friday night, had already been replaced and was ready for the store to reopen. The shiny new computer terminal blinked its incongruously optimistic message -- "Play here! The lottery jackpot is $10 million!" -- as the murdered man's brother mopped the floor with ammonia and his oldest son greeted grieving friends. 
 Mr. Alsahybi's oldest son, Ali, a slight man of 23, seemed to be trying to understand his loss. He was also wrestling with the troubling notion that the gambling machine that had helped bring the family its livelihood may also have brought it tragedy.
Mr. Alsahybi, who was 48 and emigrated from Yemen 24 years ago, had opened his store four years ago at 493 Henry Street, a residential block on the border of Carroll Gardens and Cobble Hill. Just around the corner, there are statues of the Virgin Mary on many a lawn, and red ribbons left over from Christmas decorate the trees. Violent crime is not associated with this quiet corner of Brooklyn.
But the two men who entered just before 11 P.M. each had a gun. So did Mr. Alsahybi, who may have wounded one assailant. Now, he is dead, leaving behind his wife and seven children who joined him here five years ago.
THERE is no way to know if the shootout was related to the lure of lottery proceeds; small stores that are open late are favorite targets of crime no matter what they sell, and the suspects, whom the police describe as two men in their 20's, remain at large. But officers in the station house of the nearby 76th Precinct strongly suspect a link to the lottery.
"It's the only thing that distinguished it," said a detective who requested anonymity. Neighboring store owners agree, noting that the lottery traffic on Fridays is heavy because Fridays are "Pick Five" days.
Maybe it was the gambling, said Ali Alsahybi, an economics major at Brooklyn College. But standing in the closed store four days after his father's death, he could not imagine the idea of dropping the lottery. He is a young man who finds himself suddenly forced to face some grim realities. One reality is that he has to drop out of school to run the store so he can support his family.
His other reality is that he could not give up selling those state-sponsored tickets and games at the Cobble Hill Deli and Grocery, even if he wanted to. He couldn't afford it. "Without Lotto, maybe nobody will buy our stuff," he said. "The Lotto, it makes people buy food, ice cream."
IT does more than that. The gaming passion of New Yorkers who play out their dreams of instant wealth at lottery counters keeps stores like Mr. Alsahybi's going. Most earn more from gambling than they do from selling newspapers or M & M's. Lottery vendors -- there are 4,557 of them in the city -- make 6 percent on sales, which range from $1,000 a day to twice that, say owners of small stores, depending on the size of the lottery jackpot.
That can make lottery vendors vulnerable. The Police Department says that stores that sell lottery tickets do not suffer from higher crime and that, in fact, those in busy areas are unusually safe because they attract so much traffic. But that theory has its skeptics. Last November, for instance, a retired city correction officer was killed during a robbery attempt in an East Flatbush bar; patrons blamed the advent of Quick Draw keno.
So some storekeepers are not taking any chances. "In poor economic areas, they have bulletproof Plexiglas," said the detective in the station house. "But none of the stores on this side of the highway do," he added, referring to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. "That wouldn't go around here. All around here, it's gentrified yuppies."
It is also an area that feels safe. "You think nothing will happen -- it's all families," said Fisal Shamakh, who runs the Cobble Hill Variety and Grocery on Court Street, a few blocks from Mr. Alsahybi's delicatessen. He sells lottery tickets, too. Mr. Shamakh, who saidhe has not been robbed, tries to get to the bank often so he does not have much cash around. He does not stay open late, either. But he is on a busy street. The Alsahybis' store is not.
Ali Alsahybi is in too much turmoil to decide now how he is going to run the deli, whether he will keep shorter hours or install more security. He will, he said, do what he has to do to support his family. They are all in school, except for the youngest; he is only 4. "If I don't take care of them," he asked, "who will?"

HEADLINE: What Is an Apple Worth?;
Ailing Innovator's Luster as an Acquisition Dims

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
The board of Apple Computer Inc. met for a second consecutive day yesterday to try to devise a rescue plan for the fabled Silicon Valley company, which is leaking money, market share, talent and industry support at an alarming rate.
Despite persistent reports of an impending deal in which Sun Microsystems Inc. would acquire Apple, some executives familiar with recent talks between the two companies said that the two sides remained far apart on the question of price; at least one person said the talks broke off yesterday. With neither company willing to comment, the situation remained unclear.
But for many analysts, one thing was more certain: Despite the most alluring prospect of a possible Sun and Apple alliance -- the creation of a single, dominant Internet computer company -- Apple's problems may have become so great that any potential acquirer, Sun included, would be buying a multibillion-dollar headache.
"Whether they stand alone or are acquired, Apple as we know it is cooked," said Stan Dolberg, senior software analyst at Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. "It's so classic. It's so sad."
Blaming plunging prices in the intensely competitive market for personal computers, the company last week reported a $69 million loss for its most recent quarter and said it would cut 1,300 jobs. Even before that, executives at several computer and software companies said yesterday, they had been receiving an unusually large number of resumes recently from Apple employees, including high-level engineers and key executives.
"Their chief assets are walking out the door," said an analyst at a New York investment company who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Some analysts, trying to make sense of the takeover rumors, said that Apple may have been leaking word of its discussions with Sun in an effort to stimulate interest among other possible suitors and give a lift to the company's skidding share price. Apple stock ended yesterday at $32.25, up 62.5 cents in Nasdaq trading on volume of more than 5.8 million shares; it set a 52-week low of $29.25 on Monday, just seven months after setting a high of $50.125. Sun's shares also closed lower yesterday, down 62.5 cents to $43.50 on even heavier trading -- nearly 12.5 million shares.
Even if Apple were willing to sell out to Sun or another suitor at bargain-basement prices, "the brain drain will have been so fantastically damaging that you have to wonder why they would want the company," Mr. Dolberg said.
Yet some industry executives note that Apple -- whose Macintosh computers are almost universally revered by the estimated 14 million people who use them -- has many valuable assets that might catch the eye of Sun, I.B.M., Oracle, Sony, Motorola and other companies said to have looked at Apple in recent years.
"I can understand why Sun might be interested in Apple," Roger McNamee, a principal with Integral Capital Partners, investment capital and management firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said. "It has lots of assets, particularly in the area of the Internet. The Mac is easiest Internet access platform out there. It is the preferred platform for Internet software development. It has been surprisingly successful with its new line of Internet servers. It's got to be appealing to Sun."
According to figures compiled by Internet service providers, Sun dominates the market for the powerful computers known as Internet servers, which are generally based on the Unix software operating system. But Apple has emerged as the most popular maker of non-Unix Internet servers -- ahead of other makes of machines using the Microsoft Corporation's Windows software. That is a surprising succcess given Apple's relatively low overall market share in PC's, estimated at less than 10 percent.
Part of Apple's appeal to Internet developers is its array of Macintosh software development tools for the Internet's World Wide Web, which allow even casual computer users to create and maintain Web pages. And part of the ease of use of these tools arises from the simplicity of the Apple Macintosh operating system.
Sun and other companies, including the Oracle Corporation, have expressed an interest in creating low-cost computers designed expressly for connecting users to the Internet. Besides the Macintosh, Apple is said to have several technologies under development that could fill that bill.
Other obvious assets, analysts said, include a revenue stream of more than $10 billion a year; more than 14 million loyal customers around the world; a globally recognized brand, and a series of intriguing hardware and software prototypes that, if allowed to develop, may turn into important products.
For Sun, other analysts said, Apple's greatest strength may be that it is not Microsoft. Sun now derives most of its revenue from hardware but has in recent months gambled heavily on software, including Internet server software and an Internet programming language called Java. Microsoft intends to challenge Sun's software with its own products, especially Windows NT.
And in the PC arena, Apple is the best, if not last, hope for challenging the industry standard now dominated by Microsoft and the Intel Corporation. Sun has struggled to appeal to an audience broader than the scientific, engineering and commercial markets where it is strong. But its attempts to reach the consumer market with its own computers have been unsuccessful.
And, according to one big Apple investor, a potential buyer may be able to convince itself that Apple's difficulties arise from poor management rather than incurable, maybe fatal flaws.
"Apple's problems appear to be largely self-inflicted," said the investor, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "There are no signs that Apple's current problems relate to Microsoft Windows. Indeed, there are ample signs of mismanagement. They have been too slow to update products, and they have done a horrible job of forecasting demand. They have nobody to blame but themselves."
"Sun might be interested," he continued, "only if they concluded that a different style of management can produce very different results."
But others questioned whether Sun had what it takes to manage Apple, a company more than twice its size in terms of revenue and employees.
"Apple has some serious production and logistical problems, and questionable economic viability,' said J. William Gurley, an analyst at CS First Boston in New York. "They need -- either through hiring someone or someone buying them -- help with procurement, forecasting, production and distribution, and that's not what Sun is all about."
While Apple makes many of the machines it sells, Sun subcontracts the production of its own computers. And the main microprocessor that Sun uses in its machines, called Sparc, is incompatible with the Power PC chip that Apple uses in its computers.
With such basic incompatibilities, said Tom Copeland, director of workstation research at the International Data Corporation in Framingham, Mass., even if Apple were interested in being acquired, Sun might not be the best partner.
"This would be a fairly strange marriage," Mr. Copeland said. "The fundamental business issues are hard to reconcile. Apple is a retail company aimed at consumers, which is a different business model from a work-station company that sells through specialized resellers. They have different business models, different gross margins, different technologies."
Mr. Gurley of First Boston is another of the many analysts unconvinced of the wisdom of Sun buying Apple at anything close to its current stock-market price.
"You can see what the market thought of Sun acquiring Apple when the stock fell four and a half points Tuesday and was down again today," he said, referring to Sun's shares. "And the joke going around is that the reason I.B.M. was up four points today is because everyone is happy it's not them buying Apple."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Telecom Bill May Sidestep Sticking Point

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Hoping to unsnag a bill to overhaul communications laws, senior Republican senators are discussing proposals to modify a controversial provision for television broadcasters and take it up in a separate bill at some point in the future.
At issue is a provision that would reserve a valuable parcel of the nation's airwaves for advanced digital television services like high-definition television. 
 Critics of the provision, including Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, have said it amounts to a multibillion-dollar "giveaway" to broadcasters.
Government economists have estimated that the licenses would be worth up to $70 billion if they were auctioned off to the highest bidder.
The bill has passed both the House and the Senate but has been under fire by Senator Dole as well as some House Republicans who complained that it was too regulatory.
Many lawmakers do not want to pick a huge fight with the broadcasting industry, which has already announced plans to begin a big public relations offensive on the issue.
Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, said he thought the issues raised by Senator Dole could be best addressed in a separate bill.
"I envision doing some sort of grand spectrum bill that would address plans for the next 15 years," Mr. Pressler said in an interview. Senator Pressler said the communications bill did not currently provide broadcasters with a "giveaway" as Senator Dole has charged, but Mr. Pressler has himself favored the idea of auctioning off the television frequencies rather than reserving them exclusively for broadcasters at no charge.
Several senior Republican staff members said that lawmakers had discussed dealing with the issue in a separate bill, which amounts to deferring any action on the digital television issues and would probably strengthen the ability of broadcasters to make their case to individual lawmakers.
One Congressional aide said the idea was supported by Senator Trent Lott, the majority whip, who has been a strong supporter of the broadcasting industry thus far and has received a sympathetic hearing from top aides to Senator Dole.
But others aides said that lawmakers had reached no decision.

HEADLINE: Bear, Stearns Signs Deal For Valuable Midtown Site

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
In a move that experts say could signal a comeback for New York's commercial real estate market, some of the city's best-known business leaders appear headed for a battle over the right to acquire a prime site in midtown.
Officials at Bear, Stearns & Company said they had signed a contract with CS First Boston A.G. that could lead to the purchase of an entire block of property at 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. Although Bear, Stearns officials would not say what the property would be used for, real estate executives in the city said the investment banking firm had been looking for a site for a new world headquarters. 
 But if Bear, Stearns goes forward with the deal, it could lead to a confrontation pitting the company's powerful chairman, Alan C. Greenberg, and Fred Wilpon, the owner of the New York Mets baseball team and a Bear, Stearns board member, against the British developer Howard Ronson.
The current owners of the property, a partnership that includes First Boston and a group of Saudi investors, had struck an earlier agreement to sell the site to Mr. Ronson for about $55 million, according to real estate executives. Mr. Ronson, who has spent the last two years trying to secure tenants for a 26-story, 800,000-square-foot tower he wants to build on the site, told The New York Observer that the First Boston group was trying to renege on an agreement that would give him more time to exercise his option to buy the property. Mr. Ronson, The Observer reported, is threatening legal action.
Mr. Ronson, who built several Manhattan office buildings during the 1980's but fell on hard times when the market collapsed at the start of the decade, did not return telephone calls to his New York office yesterday.
First Boston officials also declined to comment.
At Bear, Stearns, Mr. Greenberg referred telephone inquiries to a spokeswoman, Mary Flounders, who said, "We've entered into a contract, which is subject to a confidentiality agreement." Ms. Flounders would not say if the contract with First Boston was simply to discuss a purchase or was an actual purchase agreement.
She also would not comment on whether officials of Bear, Stearns, which has its headquarters at 245 Park Avenue, one block from the First Boston site, were searching to replace their current home when the lease expires in four years.
However, real estate professionals in the city said it was common knowledge that the firm was looking for a new location. "Everybody knows that Bear, Stearns's lease is coming up," said James D. Kuhn, president of Newmark & Company, a Manhattan real estate firm.
Mr. Wilpon, a developer who real estate executives said was in charge of Bear, Stearns's relocation plan, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Real estate experts said the dispute over the Madison Avenue site could portend a reversal for the real estate business in midtown, where no big office building projects have been started since the market collapsed.
"What's encouraging is that there is the possibility of a major organization building at that site, which would be a vote of confidence in midtown Manhattan," Richard T. Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress, a coalition of design, construction and real estate professionals, said. "The building industry considers that site to be one of the most strategically located in the city."
John S. Dyson, the city's deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said that Mr. Ronson "has approached us about what we would do to encourage a new building on the site." Likewise, Mr. Dyson said, the city has held discussions with Bear, Stearns officials about their possible relocation plans. "Who the developer is doesn't matter to me or the Mayor," Mr. Dyson said.
Bear, Stearns is considering a number of options, and "I just want to keep them in New York," he said.
For about 10 years, the building on the site has been empty, after a plan by the First Boston group to build a 74-story office tower met community opposition.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Surge On New Hope Of a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded sharply yesterday as more evidence of a weak economy heightened expectations of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, and a stronger dollar brought buyers back into the market.
Traders said the dollar's rise stemmed from a threat by the Chinese Government that it was prepared to fire missiles at Taiwan if Taiwan continued to seek international recognition. A stronger dollar makes Treasury securities and other United States investments more attractive to foreign investors because of the profits that can be made through currency appreciation. 
 The 30-year Treasury issue was up 25/32, to a price of 111 17/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.03 percent, from 6.09 percent on Tuesday.
Late yesterday afternoon, as the bond market was closing, Moody's Investors Service said it was considering lowering its rating for $387 billion in Treasury securities. The credit-rating agency cited its fear that the Government would fail to raise the national debt limit by the end of February and could delay payments to investors.
Analysts said the announcement was clearly an effort to force the White House and Republican leaders in Congress to resolve their differences. The warning itself, they said, could force down the price of specific bonds named by the agency. And it would signal that the United States might soon have to pay more to investors to borrow money.
During yesterday's trading, though, the bond market focused more on the release of a disappointing report by the Fed on industrial production and capacity utilization in December. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said: "The economic statistics released today clearly indicated some sluggishness in U.S. economic growth. Industrial production rose only one-tenth of a percent in December, noticeably below the market's consensus expectation of three-tenths of 1 percent."
Had it not been for an rise in aircraft production resulting from the return of striking workers at the Boeing Company last month, Mr. Fine noted, industrial production would have been flat.
"This lackluster production performance led to a two-tenths of 1 percent decline in capacity utilization to a level of 82.8 percent," he said, "continuing the decline in utilization rates seen since the beginning of the year, and the first time since January 1994 that capacity utilization has been below 83 percent."
Mr. Fine said that capacity utilization had usually been a reasonably accurate guide to inflation pressures, and that even though this relationship might have changed recently, "it's certainly true that if the 85 percent utilization level seen a year ago did not engender an increase in the trend rate of inflation, then 82.8 percent capacity utilization is not likely to either."
Separately, the Commerce Department released figures yesterday for new-home sales in November, which Mr. Fine characterized as suggesting less buoyancy in the housing market. "Though these were November statistics and thus somewhat outdated," he said, "anecdotal evidence, to say nothing of the weather, does not lead one to believe that housing has picked up.
"All of these statistics, of course, continue to point to further Fed easing," Mr. Fine added. "Now we can all sit around and argue as to precisely when the Federal Open Market Committee will make its move." The committee, the Fed's policy-making arm, meets on Jan. 30.
John Burgess, managing director at Bankers Trust Investment Management, said that the market was given an overnight lift with buying driven by the disclosure of the Chinese threat against Taiwan, whichcaused the dollar to jump higher.
Mr. Burgess said the market was also aided by the weak home sales and industrial-production data and conciliatory remarks by Republicans following President Clinton's State of the Union message Tuesday night. Some Republicans noted that the President was gaining more public support, and that they needed to soften their tone in remarks about the budget impasse.
The next significant reports for the market should be December retail data -- which may be better than the anecdotal numbers the market relied on during the Government's partial shutdown -- and the nation's payroll numbers, which should provide a glimpse of January activity.
Traders said the yield at yesterday's five-year auction rose to more than the anticipated 5.317 percent, to 5.360 percent. It was the lowest yield since 5.10 percent a year ago, and lower than the 5.550 percent at last month's auction.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Moody's Warns It Might Cut Ratings on Treasury Issues
Moody's Investors Service, a leading credit-rating agency, warned as the bond market was closing that it was considering lowering its ratings for $387 billion in Treasury securities because it feared that Washington's budget deadlock could lead the Government to run out of money by the end of next month.
Wall Street executives said the move was clearly an effort to force the White House and Republican Congressional leaders to resolve their differences. [Page A17.]
 
Congressional Republicans offered to abandon the national debt as a weapon if President Clinton would support modest budget and tax cuts as a "down payment" on a balanced budget. Mr. Clinton welcomed the offer. [A1.]
 
Iraqi Talks Could Cut Oil Prices
Iraq's willingness to hold talks with the United Nations about selling $2 billion of oil to buy food and medicine could bring a sustained drop in oil prices, analysts said. Iraqi sales have been barred for five years. [A1.]
 
Dow Sets Another Record
Stocks jumped broadly, with the Dow average climbing 50.57 points, to 5,242.84, a record. United Technologies and DuPont rose on higher earnings, and technology shares also shone. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.03 percent. [D10.]
 
Orange County Settles With S.E.C.
S.E.C. charges of securities fraud were settled by the government, board of supervisors and two former top officials of bankrupt Orange County, Calif. [D4.]
 
G.O.P. Seeks Taxes From Lawyers
Congressional Republicans have their eyes on lawyers -- that is, on making sure the I.R.S. knows about the tens of billions of dollars in legal settlements paid each year, a third of which typically goes to lawyers. Some may hide it. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
New Signs of Economic Weakness
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities inched up just 0.1 percent in December. Sales of new homes plunged to a seven-month low in November. [D4.]
 
Bankers Trust Settles Case
Bankers Trust agreed to pay $67 million to Air Products and Chemicals to settle a dispute over money-losing derivatives contracts. Experts said it pointed toward a new, conciliatory attitude at the bank. [D8.]
 
Bear, Stearns in Property Deal
Bear, Stearns signed a contract with CS First Boston that could lead to the purchase of an entire block at 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. Experts say the deal could signal a comeback in New York's commercial real estate. [D4.]
 
Donaldson and Brown Profits Up
Both Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Alex. Brown reported earnings gains of more than 50 percent. Underwriting was strong. [D4.]
 
Johnson & Johnson reported a 23 percent profit rise, more than expected, sending its shares up $5.875 to $93.625. [D5.]
 
Xerox Results Send Stock Down
Xerox reported a $1.1 billion net loss, after a $1.5 billion charge for the sale of an insurance unit and other items. Operating profit of $379 million, was weaker than expected, and Xerox's shares fell 10.6 percent. [D5.]
 
Pan Am to Fly -- Phoenix-Like?
Pan Am, the airline pioneer, is about to the reincarnated. Martin R. Shugrue, the former trustee of defunct Eastern Airlines, and Charles Cobb, a former Ambassador to Iceland and Under Secretary of Commerce, who bought the Pan Am trademark in 1993 for $1.3 million, reportedly hope to reintroduce Pan Am. [D5.]
 
American Express turns to Y.& R.
American Express awarded advertising assignments for its financial services businesses to Young & Rubicam. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $40 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Imperial Congress Threatens Health of Union;
Flat-Tax Switch

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Patrick J. Buchanan's attack on the flat tax (Op-Ed, Jan. 17): Citing the examples of Microsoft's Bill Gates and Palm Beach "lounge lizards," Mr. Buchanan asserts that investment income is not taxed under the plan offered by Steve Forbes, the Republican Presidential candidate. This is false. 
 Taxes on interest and dividend income are withheld and paid at the business level under the flat tax. Even the chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers has stated that this approach is the most ironclad way of collecting taxes from the rich in a system that does not double-tax investment income.
Mr. Buchanan asserts that estate taxes should be maintained for the "super-rich." He noted last year that eliminating double taxation -- including the estate tax and capital gains tax -- "would make the United States the most attractive investment harbor on earth."
Mr. Buchanan also frets that "the Federal budget would be thrown scores of billions of dollars deeper into deficit" under the Forbes flat tax. The candidate who claims to be the true conservative asserts that tax relief should be held hostage to some future hope that big spenders will control their appetites. Even though he worked for Ronald Reagan, Mr. Buchanan seems to have forgotten that it's not the Government's money.
A year and a half ago, Mr. Buchanan endorsed a system that taxed all income but taxed it only once, and at a single, low rate. He challenged Republican leaders to endorse this proposal, asking whether the party "any longer believes deeply enough in the principles of lower taxes and less government to confront Leviathan."
Who would have thought, 18 months later, that the Republican Party would say yes and Mr. Buchanan no?
 
DANIEL J. MITCHELL
Senior Fellow, Heritage Foundation
Washington, Jan. 19, 1996

HEADLINE: Imperial Congress Threatens Health of Union

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Flat Tax Won't Make Us a Nation of Savers" (letter, Jan. 21): 
 David Rockefeller proposes a national value-added tax that will "reward savings and stimulate growth in productivity" by balancing "the imperative to save with the compulsion to spend."
The low savings rate he deplores is caused in part by the movement of funds out of low-interest savings account into stock markets.
Middle- and upper-class beneficiaries of a sales tax system will not move back into savings accounts unless interest rates on deposits are increased, but this would drive up the costs of borrowing, slowing down the economic growth Mr. Rockefeller seeks.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Visiting Prof., George Washington U.
Washington, Jan. 22, 1996
