HEADLINE: Twilight of the Monarchs

BYLINE: By Homero Aridjis and Lincoln P. Brower; Homero Aridjis is president of the Group of 100, a Mexican environmental organization. Lincoln P. Brower is a professor of zoology at the University of Florida.

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
As many as 30 million mon arch butterflies perhaps 30 percent of the North American monarch population -- died after a snowstorm hit their sanctuaries in Mexico on Dec. 30. But storms are not the real threat to the monarchs, which have wintered in the cold Mexican mountaintops for more than 10,000 years.
As is true for so much of besieged nature, the real dangers the butterflies face are man-made, in this case the destruction of the Oyamel fir forests in Mexico's central highlands. 
 About 90 percent of the world's monarchs live east of the Rockies. Each fall, they migrate 2,000 miles from as far away as southern Canada to their winter quarters in the Oyamel forests -- relict ecosystems of the Pleistocene era two miles above sea level. The monarchs swirl down from the sky, festooning the boughs and trunks of the trees with layer upon layer of delicate wings, patterned in white, orange and black.
By early April, the eight-month-old butterflies migrate 800 miles back to the southern United States, where each female lays about 400 eggs on milkweed plants and then dies. The eggs turn into caterpillars, the caterpillars into jade-colored chrysalids etched with golden crowns. When they hatch, this spring generation travels 1,000 miles north to Canada. Over the summer, two or three more generations of butterflies are produced, and the great-grandchildren of those that flew north return to Mexico to repeat the cycle.
But the monarch's existence is threatened by the cutting of the remaining Oyamel forests. When intact, a forest serves as an umbrella and blanket, protecting the butterflies from freezing rains. The logging creates gaps that allow rain and snow to fall through the forest canopy and onto the butterfly clusters. As the weather clears, the life-sustaining heat radiated from the butterflies' bodies leaks out through these holes in the blanket of trees and the monarchs freeze to death.
Nearly two decades of conservation efforts by private organizations in Mexico, Canada and the United States -- as well as a 1986 order by then President Miguel de la Madrid to protect five wintering enclaves -- have done little to stop the destruction. The Mexican Government continues to permit logging in protected and unprotected areas. Illegal commercial cutting is rampant. Local peasants harvest trees for fuel and building materials, and cattle trample and eat the fir seedlings.
It is not too late to undo the damage. The Mexican Government and international conservation groups together should buy or lease the forests from the peasant communities, which are now allowed under Mexican law to sell their communal lands. This must be done quickly: Loggers are lobbying the Government to open up about 25 percent of the protected areas. The land could be bought for about $60 million, a small price in light of what is at stake, environmentally and economically.
Whereas logging is a one-shot deal, the local people could benefit indefinitely if they had help to create high-quality ecotourism ventures. To plan and pay for such projects, Mexico and private environmental groups and foundations need help from the United States and Canada. The three countries should be partners on environmental issues that affect all of them, in keeping with the side agreements to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Can trilateral cooperation save the Oyamel sanctuaries? Or will North America let the forests fall and these majestic butterflies disappear?

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Grandfather Didn't Know From Downsizing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Bob Herbert's "Separation Anxiety" (column, Jan. 19), in which he talks about the unemployment that results from downsizing at corporations like AT&T and how the concerns of ordinary working men and women continue to get short shrift: 
 Some years ago while at New York City's Hall of Records to register the name of my sole proprietorship, I asked to see if my grandfather's furniture company was still listed in the records. For more than 50 years it had operated at Avenue of the Americas and 15th Street in Manhattan.
Though at the time I was disappointed that a huge, musty tome was not pulled out, its long rows of entries to be scanned for the handwritten entry, there it was in the computer printout: Kellner Brothers.
The company closed its doors toward the end of the Great Depression, my dad told me.
What struck me then, which I'm reminded of after reading Mr. Herbert's column, is that though business eventually dried up, my grandfather continued to keep his workers on the payroll because he felt a responsibility to them.
He did it beyond the time when smart businessmen would have stopped.
The "bottom line" was not fiscal then; it was moral.
When my grandfather finally went out of business, he and his family knew that he had done as much as he could and that he wasn't preserving his family's future on the backs of others.
Sure, the scale of business operations is different between Kellner Brothers and AT&T.
But that difference in scale still does not account for how such a corporation can post a profit of $4.7 billion and yet justify abdicating its responsibility to 40,000 employee families and their communities.
 
JANE B. KELLNER
New York, Jan. 24, 1996

HEADLINE: Cornell Sets Record by Raising $1.5 Billion in 5 Years

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Cornell University has announced the completion of the largest fund-raising campaign in the history of higher education, raising $1.5 billion in five years, $250 million more than its original goal.
Most of the money is to be used for financial aid, faculty salaries and academic programs, university officials said. More than a third, $610 million, will go into the university's endowment, putting it in the top 10 in the country at $1.75 billion. 
 Volunteers vied to raise the most money at elaborate events. Last fall in Ithaca, N.Y., they put on skits, such as one in which someone playing Gen. George Patton exhorted the troops to contribute.
"Tens of thousands of people put pieces into this jigsaw puzzle," said Harold Tanner, a chairman of the campaign.
Cornell officials said the university's endowment was low compared with peers like Harvard and Yale, and that Cornell needed to raise the endowment to remain competitive with them, particularly in subsidizing needy students.
Several other institutions, including Harvard, are also in the midst of campaigns to raise more than $1 billion.
In 1988, Cornell had an endowment of $38,652 per student, which was 77th in the country. Today, that number has almost doubled, to $77,078, putting the university in top 40. Even so, Cornell's endowment per student remains a little more than a fifth of Harvard's.
Because universities use the income from their endowments to defray costs, particularly to keep tuitions down, a low endowment means higher tuition and less financial aid.
When they first discussed a fund-raising campaign in 1987, Cornell's trustees considered the rising costs of financial aid, particularly their need-blind admissions policy. Cornell's motto, coined by Ezra Cornell, is: "I would found an institution where any person can find instruction in any study."
Cornell is an unusual mixture of a public and private university. Four of its 11 colleges make up New York State's land grant university, which receives money from the state and Federal governments to subsidize the costs of agricultural and industrial studies. The tuition in these schools is $8,490 for state residents. The other colleges are private, and tuition for all undergraduates is $20,066 this year, similar to tuition at Harvard and Yale.
In the late 1950's and early 60's, Peter Meinig waited tables and graded papers to help his family pay for Cornell. Many of his friends received financial aid. So, three decades later, when Mr. Meinig, now a venture capitalist, and his wife, Nancy, also a Cornell graduate, considered where to contribute, they decided to give $2 million to a scholarship fund for needy students with a potential for leadership.
"The cost of higher education is a big number," Mr. Meinig said. "We need to make it affordable to everybody."
More than $200 million of the money raised is dedicated to financial aid. Some 37 percent of Cornell students receive grants directly from the university. The university's president, Hunter R. Rawlings 3d, said the increased endowment would mean tuition would rise at about the rate of inflation in the next few years.
Another major goal of the campaign was faculty support. The $146 million raised for that purpose will endow 118 positions, another area in which the university felt it was behind its peers. With the endowments, Cornell officials said, it would be easier to retain and recruit talented professors.
Ronald P. Lynch, a graduate of Cornell's College of Agriculture in the 1950's, gave $5 million to endow the deanship of the college. The income from that fund will give the dean, now Daryl B. Lund, more money in his budget to spend at his discretion.
"I have been lucky enough to be very, very successful in life," said Mr. Lynch, an investment banker who serves on the university's board. "A big part of that is the confidence I gained competing at Cornell and surviving at Cornell."
Improving the undergraduate experience will be a priority in the next few years, said Stephen H. Weiss, chairman of the board. The board is studying the first two years of a student's time at Cornell, looking for ways to give more access to professors.
President Rawlings said he was committed to increasing the number of undergraduates who have the chance to do more research with professors.
"It's a shame when undergraduates come into an institution where there are many great minds and don't really participate in that intellectual life," he said.
Even in his college days, Mr. Weiss said, he found Cornell a somewhat bewildering place, until the historian Clinton Rossiter took him under his wing. Mr. Weiss and five or six other students met every Wednesday night for two years at Professor Rossiter's house, eating doughnuts and coffee and discussing politics and the Presidency.
"It changed my whole life," Mr. Weiss said. "None of us who were in that group will ever forget it. That was college for me. It was the best experience I've ever had."
To try to make sure that today's students have similar experiences, Mr. Weiss gave $2 million to establish the Stephen Weiss Presidential Fellowship, an award for distinguished professors who commit their time and energy to teaching undergraduates. Since 1993, three professors have been chosen to receive $5,000 a year for five years.
Although Cornell does not plan to have another major campaign, Mr. Weiss said, officials will still try to raise money for specific projects in the College of Arts and Sciences, as well as to bolster basic sciences at the College of Medicine in Manhattan, and to continue increasing the financial aid pool.
Cornell's campaign was the largest to date, but Columbia, which has already raised more than $1 billion, and Harvard are both trying to break the $2 billion mark.
"Cornell won't be No. 1 for long," Mr. Meinig said. "But that's all right. We'll be back."

HEADLINE: Home Resales Fall Despite Lower Mortgage Rates

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes fell in December for a third straight month, despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two years, a realty group said today, in another sign of a slowing economy.
Sales of existing homes fell to an annual rate of 3.91 million, down 3.2 percent from November, the National Association of Realtors said. The December sales rate was up 4 percent from the same month of 1994 but it was weaker than Wall Street forecasts of a 4.02 million December reading. 
 The average rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loan in December was 7.2 percent, the lowest since 7.15 percent in February 1994, the group said. The December mortgage rate was down from 7.38 percent in November and 9.2 percent a year earlier.
"The positive impact from attractive mortgage rates just isn't enough to offset the weakness coming from the job market and the income market," said Steven Wood, economist at BA Securities Inc. "It's going to be hard outside of a significant further drop in mortgage rates to see how housing can be a positive contribution to economic activity in 1996."
Also today, the Labor Department said the number of people filing new claims for state unemployment benefits rose by 97,000 last week to the highest level since mid-July. First-time applications for unemployment pay rose to 413,000 in the week ended last Saturday from a revised 316,000 in the week earlier. The rise followed a week in which many people were prevented from filing because of snowstorms.
"I think the housing markets are just down a notch from the third quarter," said David Lereah, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. "All major housing measures -- starts, existing- home sales, and new-home sales -- are down from a couple of months ago. The housing markets right now are extremely vulnerable."
The Mortgage Bankers Association's weekly mortgage application survey showed the volume of mortgage applications rose 1.3 percent in the week ended Jan. 19.
Anthony Karydakis, economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, pointed to the mortgage application report as a reason not to be "particularly alarmed" about the housing sector.
The realtor group said the median price of a home, the midpoint at which half the homes sold for more and half for less, was $113,800 in December, down from $114,300 in November and up from $109,100 in December 1994.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises vs. Mark on Report Of U.S.-German Plan to Back It

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a four-month high against the German mark yesterday in late New York trading, recouping early losses. The gain was fueled by a report that German and United States officials wanted to strengthen the dollar against the mark.
The dollar surged after the Market News Service, a wire service, quoting unidentified people, reported that officials from both countries would like to see it rise and that the German Finance Ministry would be happy with a move to 1.60 marks. The ministry later denied that it had a target level for the mark, though it did say it backed a strong dollar. The United States Treasury declined to comment on the report. 
 "That report certainly got the dollar going," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at National Westminster Bank USA in Jersey City. "It just took off and kept accelerating."
The dollar rose as high as 1.4920 marks, its highest level since Sept. 18, and jumped to four-month highs against the Swiss and French francs.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4892 marks, up from 1.4836 marks on Wednesday. The dollar ended at 106.90 yen, down from 106.93 yen. The British pound slipped to $1.5070 from $1.5115.
So far this year, the dollar has risen 3.7 percent against the mark, bolstered by expectations that interest rates in Germany and elsewhere in Europe will fall faster and further than rates in the United States as European governments try to jump-start their sluggish economies.
In recent weeks the German central bank has steadily lowered a key money-market rate, while central banks in Britain, France and Belgium, among others, have also trimmed rates. Several Bundesbank officials have cited the mark's relative strength as one key reason German economic growth is slowing.
The mark's gain of more than 7 percent against the dollar last year crimped exporters' earnings.
Many currency traders expect the dollar will continue to strengthen against most other major currencies.
"Over the next six to 12 months, the other hard currencies are likely to soften against the dollar," said Dimitri Balatsos, international portfolio manager at Furman, Selz Capital Management, which has $6 billion of investment assets.
In earlier trading, the dollar fell against most major currencies as political turmoil in Italy and fresh doubts that France would meet the requirements for European monetary union bolstered the mark against the lira and the franc.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Slight Drop In Coke Stock Despite Profit

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Buoyed by surprisingly high beverage volume in the United States and on-target international growth, the Coca-Cola Company yesterday announced solid fourth-quarter earnings. Nevertheless, the stock fell as much as $2 during heavier-than-average trading yesterday, closing at $73.625, down $1.50.
For the quarter, net income rose 14 percent, to $648 million, or 52 cents a share, from $567 million, or 44 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year, matching the expectations of analysts. 
 For the 1995 year, earnings rose 17 percent, to $2.986 billion, or $2.37 a share, in comparison with $2.554 billion, or $1.98, during the corresponding quarter in 1994.
Roy D. Burry, a securities analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, said investors were reacting negatively yesterday to what he called "some red flags" in Coca-Cola's balance sheet, including an increase of 1.3 percent in the cost of goods sold in relation to revenues, which indicated higher production costs for Coke.
And a decline in the tax rate to 29.9 percent in the fourth quarter from 31.5 percent last year "raised the earnings a penny," said Andrew J. Conway, a beverage analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.
Perhaps adding to some investors' uneasiness about the quality of Coke's earnings, Mr. Conway said, was the performance of Coca-Cola Foods, which makes Minute Maid orange juice and Hi-C drinks. That unit reported a 4 percent drop in volume for the quarter as well as a $15 million operating loss, compared with a profit of $100 million in 1994.
"But as a whole, Coke's quarter was on target, and even a smidgen better than had been expected," said Emanuel Goldman, a securities analyst for Paine Webber. He said the strong North American volume, up 8 percent in the quarter and 7 percent for the full year, reflected gains in Coke's convenience-store business.
Coca-Cola celebrated the quarter and the year yesterday, and Roberto C. Goizueta, Coke's chairman and chief executive, said that in 1995 the company achieved "record earnings, record case-sales volume, record market share and an outstanding total return of 46 percent for our share owners."
There was some disagreement about what the fourth quarter presaged for Coke. "It's a very highly priced stock, and we think it will not outperform the market," said Mr. Burry of Oppenheimer. And Gary D. Black, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, predicted the company would be a disappointment in 1996.
But Terry Bivens, a securities analyst for Donald & Company, said, "I think it's still a good buy because the quarterly results show there is room for improvement, and the Olympics should make a difference, since Coke will be a major presence." Mr. Goldman of Paine Webber said that Coke shares would continue to be promising despite their high multiple.
Although international shipments of Coca-Cola beverages declined in the fourth quarter, volume suffered from comparisons with the company's strong 1994 record. International volume is important because the United States accounts for only 21 percent of the company's worldwide sales.
The company did not provide an overall statistic for its international business yesterday, because Coke announced a basic shift in its administrative structure on Jan. 12 to merge the concepts of its "domestic" and "international" beverage businesses.
Nevertheless, Mr. Goldman of Paine Webber calculated that Coke's beverage volume outside the United States grew 9 percent, "within the 8 to 10 percent range Coke had predicted," he said.
Internationally, fourth-quarter results were hurt by the economic problems of Argentina and Mexico, as well as a price increase in Nigeria. But results were helped by a volume increase of 24 percent in Eastern Europe, 21 percent in Chile and 11 percent in Brazil.
Volume also increased 34 percent in China and 32 percent in India, while the volume growth in one of Coke's highest-margin units, Japan, increased 7 percent.

HEADLINE: Flood of Cash to Mutual Funds Helped to Fuel '95 Bull Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Lured by an unprecedented bull market, and with aging baby boomers growing more concerned about retirement, stock mutual funds are taking in more money than ever before. And that money in turn is driving up stock prices, helping to bring in more money for the funds.
"January is the best month we ever had," Joseph Palombo, a managing director of Putnam Investments, exulted. He said flows of cash into stock funds were running 32 percent higher than in December, which had been the best month ever for his company's mutual funds. 
 For all of 1995, figures released yesterday showed that investors put almost $118 billion into funds that invest primarily in American stocks, 31 percent more than the old record, which was set in 1993. It is also more money than all stock funds had in them a decade ago. Now funds invested in American stocks have $1.07 trillion in assets.
In the process, stocks and mutual funds have replaced real estate and bank deposits as the largest segments of net worth in American households. Not since the late 1960's have Americans been so heavily dependent on the stock market.
That rush to stocks, largely through mutual funds, has aroused hand-wringing by some market analysts, who fear that when the stock market ultimately turns down it will set off a panicky exit by inexperienced investors. But so far, it has been the public that has rushed in when the market has run into temporary setbacks.
Mutual fund companies said yesterday that the sharp fall in stocks earlier this month, when the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 164 points in two days, brought in few phone calls from fund shareholders and even less selling. "Investors just took it in stride," said Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for the T. Rowe Price group of funds. "It looks like it will take more than a couple of bad days to rattle mutual fund investors."
That should come as no surprise. The run of the stock market since 1988, as it recovered from the 1987 crash and then moved on to new heights, has no parallels in market history. The Dow has hit record highs in every year since 1989, a run of eight consecutive years including this one, with the latest high reached on Wednesday. The longest previous stretch was six years, a string that ended with the 1929 crash.
Moreover, leading stock market averages have almost not gone down at all during the period, with no sustained fall since 1990, when Iraq's invasion of Kuwait came just as the American economy was entering a recession.
With the first of the baby boomers turning 50 this year, more and more of them have begun to worry about retirement. With interest rates relatively low, and real estate prices quiet at best in most areas, stocks and mutual funds that invest in stocks have become the asset of choice for more investors. In the last five years, assets of mutual funds specializing in domestic stocks have nearly quintupled.
The Federal Government has also helped, with changes in tax laws that have liberalized rules on deferred compensation and with self-directed pension plans, like 401(k)'s, which are often invested in mutual funds. In fact, some fund companies said the flow of cash into mutual funds in January was inflated because many companies make matching contributions for 401(k) plans in that month.
The year ended on a high note, with domestic stock funds taking in a record $14.7 billion, according to the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group. Among categories of such funds, record amounts of cash flowed into growth funds, the medium-risk level for diversified stock funds, and into the more conservative growth and income funds. But aggressive growth funds, the riskiest group, fell short of the record it had set in July. Many such funds were heavily invested in technology stocks, which began to falter late in the year.
The 1995 figures showed that fund investors were much more cautious about bond funds, which had a good year but showed substantial losses in 1994. Funds devoted largely to taxable bonds took in a net $7.1 billion in the year, far below the record of $79.9 billion set in 1986 but a big turnaround from 1994, when the funds saw net withdrawals of $23.3 billion.
Funds that invest in municipal bonds did even worse. Municipal bonds did not fully participate in the bond market rally, in part because of concerns that the Federal tax laws might ultimately be changed to create a flat tax. Under some versions of the proposed flat tax, all investment income would be tax-exempt, as municipal bonds are now. Thus, municipal bonds would lose that advantage over other investments.Such funds had net withdrawals of $6.9 billion in 1995, which was better than the figure for 1994, when $15.5 billion was withdrawn.
The American stock market outperformed most foreign markets in 1995, and that was reflected in the cash flow figures, which saw funds devoted largely or solely to foreign stocks take in $11.6 billion, down from $43.5 billion the previous year. But fund companies said that January saw a resurgence of interest in such funds.

HEADLINE: U.S. Report on Nation's Tobacco Use Shows Wide State-by-State Disparities

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The first state-by-state profile of the nation's tobacco use, the huge economic penalty it exacts and the various state tobacco-control laws was released yesterday by the Federal Government, highlighting startling disparities.
The report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed adult smoking rates varying from slightly more than 15 percent of the population in Utah to more than 30 percent in neighboring Nevada. Deaths related to smoking followed a similar but not identical pattern, although Nevada again ranked last, with a death rate more than twice that of Utah's. 
 Other parts of the report noted how far each state was from meeting national goals for reducing smoking by the year 2000, big differences in the percentages of teen-agers smoking, and medical costs ranging from nearly $4 billion annually in California to less than $100 million in less populous states.
The report was hailed by anti-tobacco groups as more proof of the need for strict national regulations recently proposed by the Food and Drug Administration. It was dismissed by the tobacco industry as old news.
The Government itself said that the comparisons might stimulate changes in some states but that the report was not part of any particular policy drive.
"This is a snapshot, not an evaluation of what reduces tobacco use and what doesn't," said Michael P. Eriksen, director of the Office on Smoking and Health at the centers, a Federal agency whose headquarters are in Atlanta. "There's no analysis, no recommendations, no conclusions."
The data most likely to attract attention related to smoking among high-school-age students because underage smokers are the target of the proposed F.D.A. rules.
The figures, which date from 1993, show West Virginia facing the biggest problems -- just under 39 percent of its students in the 9th through the 12th grade reported smoking within the month in which they were surveyed. Only 16.7 percent of the high-school-age children in Washington, D.C., had smoked though, a reflection of the generally lower smoking rate among black adolescents.
"These tremendous disparities show the need for national action," said Dr. Michele Bloch, who spoke for the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, which joined with other anti-tobacco advocates in Washington today to urge Congress to support the Clinton Administration's F.D.A. initiative. That proposal would severely restrict the advertising and marketing of tobacco products and would ban some forms of distribution.
Walker Merryman, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry trade group in Washington, said: "This report is more rehash than research. It's not terribly useful for understanding why kids smoke."
Mr. Merryman also disputed the data cited on the medical cost of treating tobacco-related illnesses, saying there was little scientific basis for the calculations.
The Government has estimated that the direct medical cost of treating smoking-related illnesses in 1993 was about $50 billion nationwide. The figures in yesterday's report are lower because they date from 1990.
The estimate does not include the indirect costs of smoking, such as time lost from work. The Government is working on a new estimate of such costs, which public health experts say run at least as high as the direct costs.
Anti-smoking groups said the report pointed to the impact of higher taxes. Eight of the 10 states with the lowest cigarette taxes have a higher than average number of smokers.
The figures are muddy, though, because many states have raised taxes recently while the number of smokers has been built up over decades. The state of Washington, which has the highest taxes at 81.5 cents a pack, ranks in the middle on percentage of smokers, below states like Alabama and Georgia, which are among the lowest taxers.
Public health officials in several states said that having so much comparative data available would be helpful in pushing legislators to back new restrictions or reverse measures passed with the backing of the tobacco industry.
Anti-smoking groups are particularly worried about cases where states have passed industry-backed laws banning cities and towns from imposing their own restrictions. The report shows that one-third of the states now have such pre-emptory laws.
Some of the states worst off in the rankings are the least likely to be affected by the report. "Our legislature doesn't even meet this year," said Willie Davis, Nevada's tobacco education and information officer. Mr. Davis said the comparisons might help in 1997, but he was not optimistic.
"It's hard when the state's economy is so linked to gaming, which is linked to tobacco," he said. "They have the same lobbyists and they are the most influential in the state."

HEADLINE: Niagara Mohawk Stock Dives After Dividend Suspension

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Seeking to strengthen its balance sheet and call attention to its need for relief from the state, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, a big utility in upstate New York, said yesterday that its board had decided not to pay a dividend on common stock in the first quarter.
A spokesman for Niagara Mohawk, one of the larger utilities in the nation, said that the company did not know when the board would reinstate the dividend. It had averaged 28 cents a share in recent quarters. 
 Dividends on all series of preferred stock were declared at the usual rates for the first quarter.
After the announcement yesterday afternoon, shares of Niagara Mohawk plunged $1.25, to close at $8.50 in heavy trading of more than one million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Last year, other utilities like the FPL Group's Florida Power and Light and New York State Electric and Gas cut their dividends in anticipation of greater competition. But utilities have not suspended payments in recent years.
Such actions were common in the late 1980's and early 1990's when many utilities, including Niagara Mohawk, suspended dividend payments because of huge cost overruns and losses related to building and operating nuclear power plants.
Analysts said that Niagara Mohawk's action would only add to the uncertainty that many stockholders have begun to feel about utility stocks, which were popular because many paid dividends regularly and often increased them.
The stocks have been attractive to retirees and those who wanted a steady income with little change in stock prices. In recent years, however, analysts have warned that the stocks have become more volatile and dividends less certain because the utility industry's monopoly has been eroded. Aggressive industrial customers have been clamoring for lower rates and states like California and New York have been seeking to gradually deregulate the industry, which would allow more competition.
Steven M. Fetter, a utilities analyst for Fitch Investors Service, said that Niagara Mohawk stockholders "are nervous now."
"To the extent that this strategy helps the company avoid bankruptcy, then perhaps it will help shareholders," he said.
In October, the utility, which is based in Syracuse, had threatened to seek protection from creditors under bankruptcy laws unless state regulators acted on a sweeping relief plan that it filed with New York State Public Service Commission. Under the plan, the company sought help to get out from under a high-cost, long-term contract with independent power producers and asked the state to take over or refinance Niagara Mohawk's two nuclear power plants at Nine Mile Point on Lake Ontario.
Niagara Mohawk said it needed the aid to remain viable and to eventually implement a plan for a five-year freeze on residential rates and a reduction in rates for industrial customers.
"We recognize that eliminating the dividend is a serious action," said William E. Davis, Niagara Mohawk's chairman and chief executive. "But it is one of several actions that are necessary to provide flexibility as we address growing pressure from mandated power purchases and weak sales."
The utility is still obligated to buy power under high-cost contracts that it signed in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Sales of electricity by Niagara Mohawk -- which serves 1.5 million customers mostly in upstate New York, where the economy has been weak -- dropped 5.5 percent last year, compared with 1994.
Industrial customers want lower rates, including some towns that have threatened to form municipal systems to cut their utility costs.
Mr. Davis said that without state action to lessen its burdens, the utility would seek price increases for this year and the next.
The utility also reported earnings for the fourth quarter yesterday. Net income was $18.2 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with a loss of $87.9 million in the fourth quarter in 1994.
The fourth-quarter earnings in 1994 included a charge of $196.6 million for cuts in the utility's work force.

HEADLINE: Whitman's Aides Project A Rise in Tax Collections

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Despite a shortfall in some tax revenues this year and recent signs that the New Jersey economy has stalled, the Whitman administration today projected moderate economic growth and a rise in state tax revenues in the coming year.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's third budget, which she will present on Monday to the State Legislature, calls for tax revenues to increase by $152 million in the fiscal year beginning July 1, Treasurer Brian W. Clymer said. At the same time he said that tax revenues this year are going to fall $85 million short of his original projection. 
 Mr. Clymer released highlights of the annual budget at a news conference. He said income tax revenues would increase $63 million in the new budget over this year, even though the full impact of Governor Whitman's 30 percent income tax cut took affect this month, and personal income tax collections are $33 million below projections this year.
To help balance Governor Whitman's proposed $16 billion state budget, Mr. Clymer said the administration intended to take $249 million in surplus revenues out of the State Disability Benefit Fund general account.
Employers, along with more than 2.5 million workers in New Jersey, now contribute regularly to the fund, which distributes benefits up to 26 weeks to people who are temporarily disabled.
Governor Whitman had said that cutting income tax rates would spur the economy and create tens of thousands more jobs, but the state economy is expected to create only 39,000 new jobs, a 17,000 decline from last year, state figures show.
Just last week, new Federal data showed that New Jersey's unemployment rate rose sharply in December, to 7.3 percent from 6.1 percent in the previous month. New Jersey had the second highest joblessness rate of any big industrial state. Those figures did not reflect AT&T's recent announcement of 7,000 layoffs.
But senior Whitman administration officials played down the importance of the unemployment report, calling it a blip on the state's economic screen. The Deputy Treasurer, David Kehler, said, "There have been ups and downs. We are much less persuaded by these trends."
Mr. Clymer said that he thought that the state's projections were prudent. "I think that we have been very circumspect," he said.
Mr. Clymer sought to put to rest concerns about the impact of an uncertain economy on the state budget. He said that the state's projected budget surplus for this fiscal year, which had been $550 million, would grow to $900 million. This is, in part, because of a $212 million unexpected savings in Medicaid caused by fewer claims and a $120 million reduction in spending in state agencies that he ordered last fall. Mr. Clymer also said that the state was counting on unspent funds from the judiciary and New Jersey Transit, along with a bond refinancing in the spring that would generate $19.5 million.
By rolling a huge surplus into the new fiscal year, Mr. Clymer will be giving Governor Whitman room to maneuver should there be a sudden sharp downturn in the economy, resulting in a dramatic fall in tax revenues.
Mr. Clymer defended drawing on the disability benefit fund for operating budget expenses, rather than returning some of the surplus to employers and employees. The employer tax ranges from 0.1 percent to 0.75 percent and the employee tax is a flat 0.5 percent, both of which are applied against the first $17,600 in wages earned.
State officials also acknowledged today that part of the shortfall in revenue collections is a result of the state's failure to collect aggressively motor vehicle surcharges slapped on motorists with bad driving records or who have been convicted of driving under the influence. They expected $139 million in revenue from the program this year, but they only collected $49 million. State officials said that they were considering hiring an outside contractor who could do a better job collecting the surcharges.

HEADLINE: British Agent Facing U.S. Arms Charges

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
In the years before the Persian Gulf war, Paul Grecian, a British arms dealer, spied on Iraq. Among the military secrets he provided to British intelligence was the first word of Iraq's development of a "supergun" capable of firing artillery shells 600 miles.
Now Mr. Grecian sits in a South African jail facing extradition to the United States. A hearing has been scheduled for Feb. 16. He is charged with bank fraud, perjury and conspiring to ship 300,000 artillery fuses made by a New Jersey company to Iraq, in violation of an American ban on arms sales to Baghdad. 
 Mr. Grecian says the shipment was part of his cover as a spy. Late last year an appeals court in Britain seemed to endorse his claim, overturning his guilty plea to similar charges there.
Although it has attracted little attention outside Britain, Mr. Grecian's case highlights the West's role in quietly permitting President Saddam Hussein to build an arsenal before the gulf war.
Federal prosecutors in Newark brought the charges against Mr. Grecian in 1993 as part of a related indictment against Rexon Technology, a munitions manufacturer in Wayne, N.J., and its top four officers. The conspiracy is alleged to have occurred in 1989, a year before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Although Rexon paid a fine and closed last year, charges against the officers were dropped. The reason, a senior prosecutor acknowledged, was a 1994 deposition in which Mr. Grecian said he had told Rexon the fuses were going to Jordan at the suggestion of British intelligence.
In a recent telephone interview from prison in Benoni, South Africa, Mr. Grecian said he suspected that the fervor of the American prosecutors' pursuit stemmed from his torpedoing of the Rexon case.
"I am totally in shock," Mr. Grecian, 40, said. "It has been an absolute nightmare these past weeks."
His lawyers argue that the case should be dismissed because it constitutes double jeopardy, since his guilty plea in Britain was overturned. "The refusal by the U.S. authorities to accept the judgment of the British appeal court is an insult to the British legal system," said Kevin Robinson, one of his lawyers.
Federal prosecutors countered that Mr. Grecian's espionage provided no immunity from American law and that his actions here were different from those in Britain.
Donald Davidson, a prosecutor in the United States Attorney's office in Newark, said, "Whatever his dealings were with the British Government, he had no business or authority helping hoodwink the American Government about the destination of these fuses."
Many Western companies prospered in the 1980's by selling weapons to Iran and Iraq, which were locked in a long war. Mr. Grecian first sold to Iran, but switched to Iraq when the war ended in 1988 and President Hussein began to build the Middle East's largest army.
When asked by Mr. Davidson at his deposition whether he had misgivings about having sold war materiel to Mr. Hussein, Mr. Grecian replied: "It's not so much a question of moral qualms. There are a lot worse people to deal with, and an awful lot of established manufacturers were already dealing with him."
Mr. Grecian said he was first approached in the 1980's to gather intelligence because of his access to sensitive foreign military facilities. "My Government asked me to do something and I did it," he said.
Often he simply watched, listened and then shared the information with his controller in London. At other times, he said, he was assigned to obtain specific information.
"The majority of the stuff was pretty mundane, really," he said. "But once we got to the point where I was working in Iraq, the nature of the regime was quite effective in focusing one's mind."
Mr. Grecian says it was to maintain access to Iraq that he misled British Customs and Rexon in 1989 about the destination of the fuses, since both Britain and the United States barred such shipments to Iraq.
"I was asked to proceed with this project by the relevant authorities, or the security services, to enable myself specifically to gather various items of intelligence or data at their request," Mr. Grecian said.
No fuses were actually shipped to the Middle East, but Mr. Grecian provided documents saying the fuses were bound for Jordan, which allowed Rexon to obtain an American export license.
The fuses were part of a larger Iraqi contract arranged for Mr. Grecian by Gerald Bull, a renegade Canadian artillery expert working on behalf of Baghdad. Mr. Grecian learned that the scientist was developing a supergun for Iraq and he described the top-secret project to British intelligence in September 1989. Six months later, near Brussels, Mr. Bull was killed by two shots in the back of the head.
Mr. Bull's slaying generated a flurry of investigations by British customs after the discovery that supergun components had been manufactured in Britain. Mr. Grecian's company, Ordnance Technologies Ltd., became a target and he and three colleagues were charged in 1991 with illegal sales to Iraq.
The defense said the Government had turned a blind eye toward such sales, but the prosecutor told the judge there was no evidence to support the claim. In February 1992 the men pleaded guilty in exchange for suspended sentences.
Ten months later the Government lost a similar case against Paul Henderson, another British businessman who had sold arms to Iraq and spied. In the middle of Mr. Henderson's trial, a former Cabinet member testified that the Government knew British companies had sold arms to Iraq.
The next day Prime Minister John Major ordered an inquiry into the Government's knowledge of arms sales to Iraq. The investigation is expected to release its report next month.
After the Henderson case collapsed, Mr. Grecian filed an appeal. Documents turned over last year proved that Government officials had known about his sales to Iraq. In November, the guilty pleas of Mr. Grecian and his colleagues were overturned.
One document was a memo prepared before Mr. Grecian's arrest. In it, a Foreign Office official suggested that Mr. Grecian might be persuaded to keep quiet if he realized the danger of being identified as the person who had blown the whistle on the supergun.
"If we were not too squeamish," the official wrote, "we might use this point to insure silence."
The 1993 American indictment remained outstanding, but Mr. Grecian could not be extradited from Britain because of the nature of the charges.
Last year he wanted to spend Christmas with his fiancee in South Africa. He said he got in touch with the South African head of Interpol, the international police agency, and was assured that he could enter the country without fear of arrest.
On Dec. 15, when he flew to Johannesburg, Mr. Grecian was arrested. He and his supporters believe that the Interpol official lured him to South Africa on behalf of the American prosecutors.
Since his arrest, he has been held without bail because prosecutors said he might use his experience as an intelligence agent to flee.

HEADLINE: Future in Doubt, Apple Still Fills A Crucial Post

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Indicating that business goes on even as its fate as an independent company hangs in the balance, Apple Computer Inc. today filled a high-level executive post that had been open for nearly a year.
The company named Heidi Roizen, the co-founder and former chief executive of a software producer called T-Maker, to be vice president in charge of its relations with independent software developers. 
 The move came as merger talks between Apple and Sun Microsystems Inc. were said to remain snagged over the issue of the acquisition price Sun would pay for Apple. Neither company has formally acknowledged those discussions yet, but executives close to both sides say that Sun is reluctant to go much higher than the $23-a-share offer it has already made.
Whether Apple emerges from its current financial crisis still independent or is acquired by Sun or another suitor, Ms. Roizen fills a key role as the company struggles to maintain its relevance in the personal computer market.
It will be her responsibility to manage relations with the outside software developers who create programs for Apple's Macintosh computer. Fostering the continued development of word-processing software, spreadsheets and other applications and games has become crucial for Apple.
In recent years, many developers have abandoned work on Macintosh programs in favor of the much more widely used Windows software operating system by the Microsoft Corporation. In fact, Apple is in the unenviable position of having Microsoft now serve as the largest outside developer of Macintosh application programs.
Ms. Roizen's former company, T-Maker Inc., was an early producer of software for the Apple Macintosh computer -- a word-processing program in 1984 called Write Now. T-Maker was acquired by the Deluxe Corporation in 1994, but Ms. Roizen had until now stayed on.
Ms. Roizen, who is 37, has a high profile in the industry from her years as president of the Software Publishers Association, an industry trade group. Analysts said that recruiting her demonstrated that Apple had not abandoned hope for its future, and was a positive signal after a stream of resignations by high-level executives in recent months.
"To attract someone of the star quality of Heidi Roizen is quite significant," said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies. "I'm positive Apple opened up the kimono, and she saw the opportunities along with the challenges."
Merger talks between Apple and Sun Microsystems have apparently broken off, at least temporarily, according to executives close to both companies. Sun has offered just $23 for each share of Apple, still significantly less than their publicly traded value despite a drop in recent days. Yesterday, Apple shares fell $2, to $30.25, in Nasdaq trading, while Sun shares rose 37.5 cents, to $43.875.
People in the Silicon Valley investment banking community say that Apple management is insisting that the company is still worth a premium above the value of its shares in the stock market.
But one analyst, Lucianne Painter of Merrill Lynch, has published a report that places Apple's book value at $22.72 a share and says that a price in the mid-20's would be fair for Apple, based on its earnings outlook for the year. "Apple has not sufficiently defined a cohesive strategy for the future," Ms. Painter wrote.
Some mutual-fund managers and institutional shareholders of Sun Microsystems stock are evidently cool to a merger at any price.
"I didn't buy Sun's stock for this reason," said one fund manager, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If things were so great at Sun, why would they be doing this? They'd be burdened by tons of operational issues, and Scott McNealy has never done a merger of any consquence." Mr. McNealy is Sun's president and chief executive.
Ms. Roizen said today that she had no knowledge of the talks between Apple and Sun, but was joining the company with full awarness of the difficulties it faces. "It's a challenging time for Apple," she conceded.
Apple has tried to regain market share in the hotly competitive PC business, but it has seen its profit margins dwindle as PC prices have plunged. Because it sells products based on its own hardware and software specifications, instead of the industry standards of hardware based on Intel Corporation specifications and software based on Microsoft's, Apple's research and development costs are much higher than those of its rivals.
Last week the company posted a loss of $69 million for its first quarter and said it would cut 1,300 jobs -- roughly 8 percent of its work force.
But just as Sun and, possibly, other suitors see at least some residual value in Apple, Ms. Roizen said that the company retained numerous strengths.
"If they get a couple of things worked out, there are a lot of assets at Apple," she said. "There's still a lot of 'there' there. There are a lot of smart people, and a sense of 'By God, we're tired of being kicked around and let's do something about it.' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Plunge Over a Point On Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after talk of selling by some large hedge funds weighed on already jittery investors.
The market was also held down by a rise in gold prices and by a growing concern that the Government would not raise the debt ceiling in time to avert a default on Treasury securities. After the market closed, Republican leaders and the White House announced a plan to keep the Government open until March 15, a move that might allow the market to bounce back today. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32 , to 11013/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.11 percent, from 6.03 percent on Wednesday and its highest in two weeks.
Traders said that hedge funds were selling intermediate Treasuries securities, particularly two- and five-year notes. A lot of the liquidation, they said, involved the unwinding of yen-financed trades.
In such trades, hedge funds, which are private investment funds for wealthy individuals, buy Japanese yen, borrow in Japan at low interest rates and then buy United States Treasury securities. The difference in rates, said William Shea of the Nikko Securities Company International, has been as much as 5 percent. The risk in the strategy, he said, was if the value of the yen rose.
Mr. Shea said he suspected that the funds began to unload when the yen approached an important technical level.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst at MMS International of San Francisco, said yen-financed trades had been a source of Treasury buying for the last several months so that an unwinding would have a big impact on the market.
Bond prices were also weakened by the announcement late Wednesday that Moody's Investors Service Inc. was considering lowering its rating for $387 billion in Treasury securities. While few in the market believe it will happen, the prospect of a credit review can be enough to unnerve foreign investors.
The Moody's announcement bolstered gold prices. Gold is often sought as a safe haven when there is political or financial turmoil. Gold for February delivery rose yesterday to $406.70 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange of New York, its highest price since Aug. 2, 1993.
Rising gold prices are typically a sign of growing fears of inflation. While yesterday's rise was attributed to the concerns over a default, it still had an impact on the bond market. "The bond market knows why, but is reacting to it anyway," Mr. Shea of Nikko Securities said.
The market was unnerved enough yesterday to ignore a couple of weak economic reports on the economy, as the Labor Department reported that initial jobless claims rose for the first time last week. For the week ended last Saturday, jobless claims rose 97,000, to 413,000.
Separately, the National Association of Realtors said the number of previously owned homes sold in December fell 3.2 percent, to an annual rate of 3.91 million. Both numbers, traders said, were ignored because the market felt that they were weather tainted.
Stewart Taylor, fixed-income market analyst with Thomson Research, Boston, said yesterday's signs suggested the market would test the floor on Treasury prices. "It is likely that the market is rolling over and is on the verge of beginning a correction," he said.

HEADLINE: In America;
Unholy Alliance In Nigeria

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Dr. Owens Wiwa, a Nigerian physician, had nurtured the faint hope that the Royal Dutch/Shell Group would use its powerful influence with the Nigerian Government to help secure the release of his brother, Ken Saro-Wiwa, a poet, playwright and environmental activist who was in prison on trumped-up murder charges.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa's imprisonment was a miscarriage of justice. The miscarriage became an atrocity last Nov. 10 when he and eight co-defendants, after a trial by a court set up especially for them, were sentenced to death and hanged. 
 Three times during the course of his brother's imprisonment, Dr. Wiwa met with Brian Anderson, the managing director of the Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria. Dr. Wiwa wanted Mr. Anderson to intervene on his brother's behalf with the strongman Government of Gen. Sani Abacha.
It was an appeal borne of desperation. Ken Saro-Wiwa was one of the most prominent critics of the nightmarish alliance between the oil companies and Mr. Abacha's Government. He had led an international campaign that focused on the environmental damage caused by the oil companies, the brutality of the Abacha regime and the inequitable distribution of benefits from the industry. The riches from Nigeria's vast oil reserves are being hijacked by the oil companies and the military dictatorship while the Nigerian people suffer in an oppressive atmosphere of extreme unemployment, extreme inflation and a per capita income comparable to that of Haiti.
"I went to see Brian Anderson for only one reason," Dr. Wiwa told me in a telephone conversation on Wednesday. "I asked him to use his influence to see that the trial would not start, so that Ken and his co-defendants could be free because they were innocent."
Dr. Wiwa understood the symbiotic relationship between Shell and the Abacha regime. The essence of that relationship was captured in a classified Government memo regarding protests against Shell in the Ogoniland region, home of the ethnic group to which Dr. Wiwa and his brother belonged. Dated Dec. 5, 1994, the memo said in part:
"Shell operations still impossible unless ruthless military operations are undertaken for smooth economic activities to commence."
Dr. Wiwa said he had been told by Mr. Anderson that it would be difficult to help his brother, but that something might be done if Ken Saro-Wiwa would call off the protest campaign of his organization, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, and if a press release were issued, on the movement's letterhead, saying that there had been no environmental damage in Ogoniland.
"I told him," said Dr. Wiwa, "that we could not do that."
Dr. Wiwa viewed his meetings with Mr. Anderson as critical discussions on a matter of life or death. If his account is true, it means that Shell saw Ken Saro-Wiwa and his co-defendants not as human beings unjustly accused and facing possible doom, but simply as chips in a big-league game of public relations. Your press release or your life.
Shell officials said yesterday that Dr. Wiwa's account was not true. Eric Nickson, a spokesman, acknowledged that the meetings had taken place but said that Dr. Wiwa's version was "misleading," and that Mr. Anderson had never indicated he could be of assistance.
Mr. Nickson noted that Shell had pulled its operations out of Ogoniland in 1993 because of protests and acts of sabotage against Shell. "Whilst we would like to go back," he said, "we are only prepared to go back if we have the support of the communities in Ogoniland. So these meetings were initiated by Mr. Owens Wiwa to find whether there were some middle ground on which to try and resolve this situation."
And what, Mr. Nickson was asked, did Mr. Wiwa want? Under the circumstances, why else would he seek out Mr. Anderson except to plead for help in saving his brother?
Mr. Nickson said he didn't know. "I wasn't present at the meetings, unfortunately."
The execution of Mr. Saro-Wiwa and his co-defendants has been widely condemned by world leaders. But it has not shaken the bond between Shell and the execrable Nigerian Government. They are going ahead with their joint plans to build a $4 billion natural gas project.
They will not miss the chastizing voice of the silenced Ken SaroWiwa.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. BACKING OFF FROM TOUGH STAND OVER ENVIRONMENT

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Republicans are increasingly worried that by imposing deep cuts on environmental programs they are doing even deeper political damage to their party, and they are beginning to back away from further confrontations on environmental issues.
As a result, it now appears more likely that Congress might loosen somewhat the fiscal vise that has gripped environmental agencies during the long budget impasse, while a number of proposals favoring mining, logging, oil and other big industries could vanish from the legislative landscape. 
 Administration officials and environmentalists can hardly claim victory yet. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol M. Browner, said that at a Senate hearing on Friday, she would testify that the cuts already imposed, and the slightly less severe ones still to come, would force the agency to delay some of its highest priorities, including new measures to control dangerous pollutants in drinking water.
But some environmentalists are starting to say, with a hint of wonder in their voices, that they are close to success in making environmental programs what one lobbyist called a "third rail," political slang for issues like Social Security that are best not touched because they carry such voltage with voters.
Increasingly, Republicans are echoing the same message.
This week, 30 Republican moderates in Congress wrote Speaker Newt Gingrich to complain that the party had "taken a beating this year over missteps in environmental policy" and calling on him to correct the course during the continuing budget talks.
"If the party is to resuscitate its reputation in this important area, we cannot be seen as using the budget crisis as an excuse to emasculate environmental protection," said the letter, drafted by Representative Sherwood Boehlert, a maverick Republican environmentalist from upstate New York.
Even some of the party's more conservative advisers are sounding similar alarms these days.
"Our party is out of sync with mainstream American opinion," wrote Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster, in reporting to Congressional clients on a recent nationwide survey on environmental issues.
But many in the party's leadership are reluctant to change course. They say the problem is not their agenda but the way they have explained it.
"What is out of sync is the distortion of our record by the Administration and by radical environmental groups who want to continue to overregulate the economy," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, head of the House Republican Conference.
Environmental groups have mounted a sustained campaign all year to get their millions of members to complain to lawmakers about the Republican agenda, and it appears that the effects are increasingly being felt.
Last week, during the Congressional recess, the entire New Jersey delegation of eight Republicans and five Democrats wrote to the Republican leadership asking that full financing be restored to the Superfund program, a reaction to news that the E.P.A. had suspended the clean-up of hundreds of toxic waste sites.
In his State of the Union address, President Clinton spoke at length about environmental issues, which usually take a back seat to others. He won applause and loud cheers when he denounced the environmental proposals of the Republicans and challenged Congress to "re-examine those policies and reverse them."
The problem for the Republican leadership, though, is that many of those proposals are at the heart of their promise to roll back Federal regulations, and many of the party's leaders, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, one of Speaker Gingrich's loyal lieutenants, are among their most vigorous advocates.
In a speech to the National Association of Manufacturers today, Mr. DeLay, the majority whip, accused Mr. Clinton of lying in his speech when he said that by voting to cut environmental enforcement by 25 percent, Congress was serving the interests of corporate lobbyists at the expense of clean water and children's health.
"That isn't just misrepresenting the truth; that is outright lying," Mr. DeLay said.
But Ms. DiVall, whose clients include a conservative Republican Presidential candidate, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, said in her polling report that some of the party's environmental policies were broadly disdained by Democrats and Republicans alike -- and by most independents, most young people and most women.
"By greater than a 2-to-1 margin, voters have more confidence in the Democrats than Republicans as the party they trust most to protect the environment," her report said. "Most disturbing is that 55 percent of Republicans do not trust their party when it comes to protecting the environment, while 72 percent of the Democrats do trust their party."
The poll came up with especially strong signals on the Republicans' efforts to cut spending at the E.P.A.
"Attacking the E.P.A. is a nonstarter," Ms. DiVall wrote.
Her polling found that only 35 percent of the public would vote to re-elect members of the House who supported the Republican-backed bill cutting financing for the agency, by a third, while 46 percent said they would vote not to re-elect them. If voter turnout in November is higher, she warned, the results would be worse.
Warnings like that seemed to be having an effect today, as the House leadership brought to the floor the latest stop-gap spending bill, to keep the Federal Government open until March. Previous temporary spending bills have singled the E.P.A. out for especially severe cuts, especially in enforcement and clean-up activities.
The measure, passed by the House tonight, would still cut the agency's financing, just as deeply as the spending bill President Clinton vetoed in December but not as deeply as the cuts since Oct. 1, when the fiscal year began.
The Interior Department, another environmental agency that has been operating without a final agreement on its budget, would be financed until March. But the real issue facing that agency is not how much money it can spend, but rather what environmental policies it must follow.
One of the biggest fights of the past year was over changes the Republicans proposed in the mining law. Favored by industry and opposed by environentalists, the measure was part of Interior bill and the broader budget bill, both of which Mr. Clinton vetoed.
Today, Jack Gerard, an industry spokesman, said the budget impasse had "at least for now halted progress toward passage of mining law reform."

HEADLINE: Albany's Anti-City Vote

 BODY:
New York City's budget problems are so severe that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is thinking about cutting the size of the police force. At the same time, however, the State Legislature is doing its best to make the Mayor's job harder by passing bills that would increase the cost of the city's police and fire departments. The Legislature could not have picked a more inopportune time to cater to special interests. Gov. George Pataki can do Mr. Giuliani a favor by using his veto pen.
Working with an uncharacteristic celerity this week, the State Senate and Assembly both passed a bill that could give some city unions an edge in winning higher salaries. The measure would give the state-run Public Employee Relations Board the power to resolve impasses in contract negotiations between the city and its police and fire unions. Currently the disputes are settled by the local Office of Collective Bargaining. 
 Under this office, city unions have not won the fat salary increases given to unions in the surrounding suburbs. As a result, officers in low-crime Westchester towns are paid more than those in the Bronx or Brooklyn. The lesson might be that the state board is too generous. Naturally, the city unions prefer to believe their board is too tough, and have lobbied for the switch.
Mr. Pataki, who vetoed a version of this bill last year, proposed a sensible compromise in December. Presently the state board compares each municipality's wage offers with salaries in surrounding towns. The Governor suggested the board also be directed to compare tax rates, the health of the local economy and a municipality's ability to pay for a new contract without hiking taxes.
The Legislature completely ignored his ideas, passing the bill in exactly the form the unions requested. The bill's supporters argued that any lawmaker who voted against the measure was not showing proper support for the city's brave officers and firefighters.
Only four members in each body dared to stand up against that specious position. The four Senators were Velmanette Montgomery of Brooklyn and Franz Leichter of Manhattan, both Democrats, and Robert DiCarlo of Brooklyn and Roy Goodman of Manhattan, Republicans. The Assembly members were James Brennan of Brooklyn and Deborah Glick and Scott Stringer of Manhattan, all Democrats, plus one Republican, John Ravitz of Manhattan.
The bill's strongest opponent is Mr. Giuliani, who has also been one of the most ardent defenders of the Police Department. But now Mr. Giuliani says he may propose reducing the department by 1,000 officers. This is a welcome change of heart for this administration, which has achieved new efficiency through the merger of the transit, housing and city police forces. The city may be able to cut the force even further if it replaces officers doing clerical duties with less expensive civilians.
But Mr. Giuliani's action should remind the unions, and the politicians, that as the cost of maintaining each police officer goes up, the number of officers the city can afford will drop.
The bill now goes to Mr. Pataki, who has been handed a tough political problem by the Republican-dominated State Senate. But if he is to have any credibility in the coming budget wars, he cannot begin the legislative session by imposing a new economic burden on the city. The bill must be vetoed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Key Players in Washington Agree to 45-Day Budget
House Republicans and the White House agreed to provide 45 days of spending for the parts of the Government that are still without a permanent budget, and the House approved the measure. Senate Democrats objected to education cuts, but were unlikely to be able restore that money. Disagreements also emerged about how to keep the Government from defaulting after March 1.
Speaker Newt Gingrich spoke of extending the debt limit after then, but the White House rejected his terms. [Page A1.]

Treasury bonds slumped on talk that some large hedge funds were selling, and on worry about the debt ceiling. The 30-year bond fell 1 6/32 , to 110 13/32 ; its yield jumped to 6.11 percent. Gold prices rose. [D16.]
 
Stock Mutual Funds Post Their Best Year Ever
The bull market, and aging baby boomers, are causing record inflows into stock mutual funds. One fund manager said flows of cash into stock funds in January were running 32 percent higher than in December. And for 1995, almost $118 billion was put into funds that invest primarily in American stocks. [A1.]
 
Stock prices slipped on disappointing earnings posted by such companies as Procter & Gamble, AT&T and Dow Chemical. The Dow slumped 26.01 points, to 5,216.83. [D6.]
 
Hasbro Argues Against a Merger
Investors bid up shares of Hasbro by $9.875, to $40.50, a day after Mattel proposed a $5.2 billion merger. But Hasbro, whose stock has been a laggard for years, was adamant about its discomfort with the plan, citing antitrust implications. Mattel fell 50 cents, to $31.50. [D2.]
 
Coke Shares Fall Despite Earnings
Investors were not impressed by Coca-Cola's 14 percent increase in quarterly net income. Coke shares fell $1.50, to $73.625. [D2.]
 
Weak Results at AT&T
AT&T posted a fourth-quarter loss of $2.68 billion, reflecting $6.25 billion in previously announced write-offs. Operating income was slightly below expectations. [D3.]
 
Utility Suspends a Dividend
In what is now an unusual move for a utility, Niagara Mohawk Power omitted the dividend on common stock. The company is pleading for relief from New York State. [D3.]
 
Business Week Sees Irregularities
Business Week magazine said it alerted regulators to a pattern of suspicious trading in stocks recommended in its "Inside Wall Street" column. [D4.]
 
G.O.P. Backpedals on Environment
Republicans are beginning to back away from confrontation on environmental issues, fearing political damage. [A1.]
 
Soviet-Styled Adviser for Yeltsin
Boris Yeltsin chose a Soviet-schooled industrialist as Russia's top economic official. The new official spoke out against measures to rein in government spending and to encourage a free market. [A1.]
 
Home Resales Fall for 3d Month
Sales of previously owned homes were down 3.2 percent in December from November. It was the third drop in a row, despite lower mortgage rates. [D3.]
 
A Slower Pace at Boeing
Despite strong orders, Boeing is planning to build just 215 planes this year. While the number is lower than analysts had predicted, many see the move as prudent. [D2.]
 
$40,000 a Second? No Problem.
Even as the price of running a commercial during the Super Bowl has reached a historic high of $40,000 a second, newcomers like Mastercard International and Kinko's are lining up to get on the broadcast. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
By Airline Standards, a Good Year
The airline industry rounded out what for it was a very good year, when its profit margin was a whopping 3.9 percent. But carriers made some important decisions. For instance, several stopped service on money-losing routes. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Michigan Senate Passes Bill To Curb Taxes for 8 Areas

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Taking one of the most aggressive steps yet by a state to use tax policies rather than spending ones to revitalize impoverished areas, the Michigan Senate today passed a bill that would abolish all state and local income and property taxes in eight areas singled out for economic development.
The bill, expected to be passed by the state House of Representatives next month and already championed by the Governor, would create tax havens in eight impoverished areas across the state to be selected later this year. Residents and businesses in the eight "renaissance zones" would, for up to 15 years, pay only Federal taxes, local sales taxes and taxes tied to bonds already issued. 
 The effects of the plan may cross state lines. Michigan's Governor, John Engler, has established himself as a national leader in Republican efforts to overhaul the nation's welfare system. With the current legislation, other states hoping to spur economic growth in poor areas may look to Michigan as well.
Over the last nine years, New York State has provided a complex set of partial exemptions from various business taxes in several dozen areas called enterprise zones. But New York's plan is not as generous as Michigan's because it does not eliminate state income taxes for local residents.
In Michigan, tax bills in the eight zones would drop considerably under the Senate plan. A family with a home worth $70,000 and annual income of $60,000 would see its tax bill drop by $5,378, according to estimates by the Michigan Treasury Department.
Small businesses would save even more. A business with annual revenue of $500,000 in a building worth $250,000 would see its annual tax bill drop to $410 from $8,625. A company with annual revenue of $50 million in a building worth $3 million would find its taxes falling to $15,000 from $680,000, according to estimates from the office of Senator Richard E. Posthumus, the majority leader of the Michigan Senate.
"We're going way beyond what any other enterprise zone has ever done by making the taxes zero," Mr. Posthumus said. "It is not an end-all answer, and it is not going to solve every problem, but I think this is the boldest attempt to reinvigorate our cities that has been tried anywhere in the country.
"If it works, you'll see a number of states begin to adopt it."
But Senate Democrats who opposed the bill contended that it lacked adequate provisions requiring businesses setting up shop in a tax haven to hire local residents, and that the measure would mainly help businesses and the affluent, not the poor.
Experts in public policy said the legislation was the most ambitious effort yet by a state government to rely on free enterprise for economic revival in specific areas. But they added that other enterprise zones have had mixed results because companies have often set up operations inside the zones to save money on taxes but then bring in workers from more affluent neighborhoods.
William D. Eggers, an expert on enterprise zones at the Reason Foundation, a public policy research group in Los Angeles that advocates free-market policies, said the Michigan plan should not be seen as a cure-all. It "is probably the nation's most far-ranging, far-reaching enterprise legislation that has been enacted or has a good chance of being enacted soon," he said, "and is a positive development and a step in the right direction, but is certainly no panacea for the problems that are plaguing urban America."
Academic studies have found that as little as 15 percent of the workers in some enterprise zones actually live the zone, Mr. Eggers said.
Experts in inner-city development praised the Michigan plan, saying the tax breaks would increase home ownership and create jobs.
"The best police officer you can have is a homeowner, and the best family value you can have is a job," said John Bryant, chief executive of Operation Hope, a nonprofit investment bank founded to redevelop Los Angeles after the 1992 riots.
Mr. Bryant said it would probably take five to six years to see strong results, but "you are starting to create the foundation for the American dream."
Michigan's largest city, Detroit, has one of the United States' most troubled inner cities, and the city, once a symbol of American industrial might, has become a testament to urban troubles. Governor Engler said today that renaissance zones "could make a big, big difference" in Detroit.
The city's Mayor, Dennis Archer, said today that he was reserving judgment on the plan until he saw which provisions became law. But Mayor Archer said the version the Senate passed could help areas like Del Ray, a neighborhood with environmental problems that "sorely needs economic development."
The Senate legislation is a package of nine bills that would allow cities and counties to apply for the special tax status in eight small tax havens of up to eight square miles across. Five zones would be in cities, and three would be reserved for rural areas. The state would reimburse localities for the loss of any financing for schools.
Through a complex formula, cities could create patchworks of tax havens in their needy neighborhoods. For instance, Detroit could apply for one enterprise zone encompassing up to six areas of up to 355 acres each.
Assuming the House passes the measure and the Governor signs it, a state panel would choose the winners, and tax exemptions would start on Jan. 1, 1997.
Governor Engler said today that he believed that the key to revitalizing areas turned on tax credits, because the country had unsuccessfully "tried social spending for more than two decades."
Using tax credits is also cheaper. Senator Posthumus said the Senate plan was unlikely to remove much revenue from the Governor's $28 billion budget.
But Grand Rapids, which may apply for one of the zones, estimated that it would lose $1 million a year in local taxes if it is chosen, said Doug Rothwell, chief executive officer of the Michigan Jobs Commission.
While Senate Republicans overwhelming favored the plan, Democrats split evenly on the main bill in the package. Eight favored it; eight opposed it.
"The very poor wouldn't be paying very much in income taxes anyway," said Philip J. D'Anieri, a spokesman for Senator John D. Cherry Jr., the minority leader of the Michigan Senate.
As for the fate of the bill, Mr. D'Anieri said, "Republicans are in control, the Governor has put a high priority on it, so it is likely to pass the House."
