HEADLINE: Clinton's Speech Oversold Health of Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Although I give President Clinton high marks for the content of his State of the Union address, I disagree with his statement that "our economy is the healthiest it has been in three decades." However necessary, there is a price to be paid for severe downsizing at every level -- corporate, government and military. We may be poised for recession. 
 If the most recent statistic of 5.6 percent unemployment was a true measure of joblessness, the President's conclusion might have some validity. But that figure, based as it is on an extrapolation of 12,000 phone calls each month, is flawed.
The more reliable figure is the number of weekly new unemployment claims, which is a total measurement. For the second half of 1995 it will be in excess of 9.5 million.
There are 7.6 million people who hold multiple jobs and are counted twice. Manufacturing jobs increased by 504,000 in 1994 but decreased by 201,000 the first 11 months of 1995. Inventories have risen in all but one of the past 19 months. The leading indicators are negative, with downsizing continuing unabated.
We need a huge program of necessary job creation. Enlightened selfishness demands that we enlarge the consumer and taxpaying base, which will decrease our costs for unemployment benefits and welfare. This is sound economics.
Myriad projects cry out for action. We must restore our deteriorating infrastructure, elevate our second-class educational system, accelerate the building of low-cost housing and put even more than 100,000 police officers on the street.
Should a recession hit, forget about balancing the budget in seven years. We are wasting billions in job retraining if the jobs are not there.
In addition to necessary job creation being sound economics, we get the fringe benefit of restoring dignity to the vast army of the unemployed.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, Jan. 24, 1996
 
The writer served on President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Speech Oversold Health of Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Bob Dole and his fellow Republicans picture themselves as the wave of the future, but their vision is a rose-tinted past shorn of barbarities. 
 What is that "self-reliance" Mr. Dole plugged in his speech when he evoked his Depression-era boyhood in Russell, Kan.? A return to family farms (without subsidies, of course) before they were taken over by the agribusiness that now contributes mightily to his party?
To little shops before the malls killed them off? To a prairie destroyed by development? To hunting on the old frontier? To a time before the national and international changes we must face? To working for starvation wages without safety, health care, security now or later or anything else that makes life decent?
Mr. Dole proclaims "the end of the welfare state," but all he can offer in its place is an inward-looking and fear-mongering "ill-fare state" without grace or joy or compassion; it would give us a United States chopped into 50 pieces that compete over which can do the least for its citizens.
 
JOHN E. ULLMANN
Hempstead, L.I., Jan. 24, 1996

NEW YORK CITY
 
Mayor Weighs Police Cuts
 Mayor Giuliani pledged that the Police Department would not reduce the number of officers patrolling New York City's streets and subways even as he acknowledged that he was considering a reduction of 1,000 officers. [Page A1.]
 
 Police officials said departmental improvements would ease the effect of a reduction in officers. [B3.]
 
Taxi Fare Increase Approved
 New York City's taxi commission approved a 20 percent fare increase and imposed the first mandatory age limit for yellow cabs, over the protests of drivers who said that what the panel was giving with one hand, it was taking with the other. [B1.]
 
 A judge ruled that there was insufficient evidence to support the allegation that the city's Taxi and Limousine chairman was "house counsel" for a murderous drug gang. [B4.]
 
When Arafat Outshines G.O.P.
 During the recent election for chief executive of the new Palestinian government, Yasir Arafat recognized that he had to give at least an appearance of tolerance for competition. Which is more than you can say about leaders of the Republican apparatus in New York. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Spring Bringing Fees at Garden
 In response to a steep drop in public financing and rising operating costs, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will begin charging admission for the first time in March. [B4.]
 
New Chief for Transit Authority
 The chief of the transit system in Washington has accepted the top job at the New York City Transit Authority, a high-ranking New York transit official said last night, taking the helm at a time of deep cuts and uncertain capital projects. [B4.]
 
Stepfather Charged in Beating
 The stepfather of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo was charged with slamming her head against a wall weeks before her death. As the new indictment was announced, echoes of Elisa's case continued to sound through the city, with yet another report criticizing the city's child welfare agency and a new hearing into the system's failings. [B6.]
 
Rifkin Apologizes for Murders
 At a sentencing hearing in Queens, Joel Rifkin, who has admitted killing 17 women, said he was sorry and told the families of his victims that he had never understood just what it was that drove him to murder. "You all think that I am nothing but a monster, and you are right." [B6.]
 
Man in Needle Incident 'Unfit'
 Prosecutors will not challenge psychiatric findings that Angel Coro, the man charged with jabbing a 6-year-old subway rider with a hypodermic needle, is incompetent to stand trial. Mr. Coro, 51, was declared unfit at a hearing in a Manhattan court. [B7.]
 
REGION
 
Sharpe Aide Is Indicted
 A Federal grand jury charged Newark Mayor Sharpe James's closest aide today with accepting bribes in exchange for city contracts. He is the highest-ranking official to be indicted in the two-year-old investigation into corruption in Newark. [B1.]
 
Rise in Tax Revenues Expected
 Despite a shortfall in some tax revenues this year and recent signs that the New Jersey economy has stalled, the Whitman administration projected moderate economic growth and a rise in state tax revenues in the coming year. [B5.]
 
A Clean Airport Building
 While the $120 million International Arrivals Facility, which formally opened this week at Newark Airport, is not architecturally ambitious, it is unquestionably one of the cleanest airport buildings in the world, both hygienically and esthetically. [B1.]
 
Towers Sale Called Feasible
 A study commissioned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey concludes that selling the World Trade Center is feasible. But Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson said that tax-rate figures used in the study, by Chemical Bank, were seriously flawed. [B5.]
 
Forest Plan Is Derailed
 A plan to sell federally owned grasslands in the Oklahoma Panhandle to help finance the purchase of a huge tract of wilderness property straddling New York and New Jersey has been derailed because of opposition in Oklahoma. [B5.]
 
Record Fund-Raising at Cornell
 Cornell University has completed the largest fund-raising campaign in the history of higher education, raising $1.5 billion in five years. [B7.]

HEADLINE: The Garden In Brooklyn Plans to Levy Entrance Fee

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In response to a steep drop in public financing and rising operating costs, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the 52-acre emerald expanse in the heart of the city's most populous borough, will begin charging admission for the first time in March.
The decision by the garden, among the last of New York City's cultural institutions to charge an entrance fee, comes a year and a half after the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx began charging a similar fee and at a time when many institutions are increasing existing fees. 
 Beginning March 15, adults will be required to pay $3, senior citizens and students $1.50 and children 6 to 16 50 cents. Admission to the garden, a meticulously groomed triangle near Prospect Park, has been free since it opened in 1910 on the site of a former ash dump.
It has since become the most popular horticultural attraction in the region, attracting more than 900,000 visitors last year with displays of 12,000 kinds of plants, including a grove of cherry trees that the American Institute of Architects calls the nation's best. Well over three-quarters of its visitors live in the city, though busloads of foreign tourists are becoming common.
Judith D. Zuk, president of the private nonprofit garden, said that the decision was reached after a 10-month study of the experiences of other cultural institutions. She estimated that even if the garden loses 10 to 15 percent of its visitors, the new fees will add at least $500,000 a year to a budget that now totals $9.1 million.
"It did not seem at all possible to have a balanced budget and maintain the quality of the garden, much less move into new initiatives," Ms. Zuk said. "And it would be a shame for this organization to remain static."
Five years ago, city and state funds accounted for nearly 50 percent of the garden's operating budget; today, Ms. Zuk said, the total is 38 percent. At the same time, private contributions have increased -- by 25 percent last year, to $2.5 million -- though Ms. Zuk said they have not kept pace with rising costs.
Remaining revenue comes from sales of items like gifts and gardening supplies. Even an additional $600,000 in annual revenues from catering functions on the grounds has not proved sufficient, she said.
Aside from inflation and rising maintenance expenses, higher costs are a result of the garden's attempts to play a more vigorous educational role. More than 90,000 children now take part in programs like the long-beloved Children's Garden, where they learn about plants and the environment with hands-on gardening. The Botanic Garden's scientific effort, while far smaller than that of the Bronx garden, is also expanding. Research projects, led by an effort to catalogue every plant in the metropolitan area, will cost $368,000 this year, the most the garden has spent on a scientific endeavor.
Slightly sweetening the entrance fee is a new policy in which the garden will stop charging 50 cents to enter the popular Japanese garden, and officials promise they will not mimic the larger garden in the Bronx and charge extra for attractions within the garden. This is partly because of their experience with the Steinhardt Conservatory, a tropical, temperate and desert habitat that opened in 1988. Entrance cost an additional $2. Many visitors declined to enter the building, and the fee was rescinded.
Part of the problem, Ms. Zuk said, was that "you could look in the windows."
Ms. Zuk contended that the Brooklyn garden remains a bargain, pointing to a $6.75 charge at the Bronx Zoo and $4 at Wave Hill, the historic Bronx mansion overlooking the Hudson River. The American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have both recently increased their recommended entrance fees, to $7 for adults. The suggested contribution to the Natural History Museum went up $1 last summer, after a $1 increase the year before. Some 50 to 70 percent of visitors pay the suggested amounts.
Ms. Zuk said the actual cost to the garden of each visitor is nearly $10, so visits remain subsidized. In addition, the garden will be free on Tuesdays, and a special admission rate of $15 to $18 a year will be available to nearby residents.
The hope is that the charges will spur membership, something other cultural institutions have experienced after initiating charges, Ms. Zuk said. The Bronx garden had feared attendance would go down when it instituted its $3 fee, but it remained steady at 500,000 at year, even as its Victorian conservatory and other attractions were closed for renovations.
At the Brooklyn garden this week, the reaction to the impending fee was mixed. "I think this is so terrible," said Charles Zanghi, a retired firefighter who grew up in Brooklyn and visits three or four times a year to view the bonsai tree collection.
His friend, Vincent Graziosa, who lives in Staten Island, disagreed. "You may object, but $3?," he said. "Frankly, I think it's worth it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors to the Steinhardt Conservatory, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, will not pay additional fees. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Winners and Losers in the Rohatyn Sweepstakes;
Friends in High Places Sing Banker's Praises

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, now officially on the list of those being considered for vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, a rare bit of public lobbying is under way on his behalf.
The White House has confirmed published reports that Mr. Rohatyn, a managing director of Lazard Freres & Company, is a possible candidate for the vice chairmanship, second in command to Alan Greenspan, the chairman. Mr. Rohatyn has declined to comment, but friends say he has made clear to them that he wants the job, and they gave out names of chieftains of major corporations who, if approached, would speak publicly on Mr. Rohatyn's behalf. 
 A half-dozen did. All are frequently consulted by the White House on policy matters, so their words carry weight. They praised the 67-year-old Mr. Rohatyn as a friend who would push for greater economic growth, sharing their view that this is possible without running the risk of higher inflation. They see Mr. Rohatyn as a strong voice for lowering interest rates a bit to stimulate the economy, replacing Alan S. Blinder, the outgoing vice chairman, who has been the leader of that camp at the central bank.
"Mr. Rohatyn's views on growth would add an important perspective to the Fed's deliberations," said Dana G. Mead, chairman of Tenneco Inc., and the current chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers. "Many businessmen I know, and I am not speaking for the N.A.M., would support the nomination, Democrats and Republicans alike."
But political obstacles could emerge that could sink Mr. Rohatyn as a candidate almost as quickly as his name arose last week. He would withdraw his name, friends say, if Mr. Greenspan did not favor Mr. Rohatyn as vice chairman, or if Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin opposed the candidacy. Both are New Yorkers like Mr. Rohatyn, friends of his for years. Neither, however, has said a word about the Rohatyn candidacy.
Senate confirmation could also be a problem. Mr. Rohatyn would have to go before the Senate Banking Committee, headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, whom Mr. Rohatyn opposed for re-election in 1992. Still, the Administration is widely expected to grease the way by linking its nominee for vice chairman to Mr. Greenspan's reappointment as chairman. Mr. Greenspan, a Republican, comes up for reappointment in March. He is highly regarded by Senate Republicans.
The corporate support emerged publicly in interviews yesterday from the likes of Robert Crandall, chairman of American Airlines; Lawrence A. Bossidy, chairman of Allied Signal Inc.; Paul O'Neill, chairman of Aluminum Corporation of America, and William Stier, chairman of Pfizer Inc. All see Mr. Rohatyn as he has described himself in speeches and articles: favoring stronger economic growth, but also balanced budgets and low inflation, standard goals of central bankers.
"If he were to become President Clinton's nominee, I would not hesitate to lobby for him," said Mr. Stier of Pfizer, the big pharmaceutical company where Mr. Rohatyn is a director. "He favors more growth for the economy, but it has to be done responsibly."
Mr. Rohatyn, who played such a huge role in guiding New York City through what amounted to bankruptcy in the mid-1970's, has been seeking a major public service job as a finale to a 46-year career as an investment banker. He had been a contender to be Mr. Clinton's first Treasury Secretary, a post that went to Lloyd Bentsen.
And while any Fed vice chairman operates in the shadows of the chairman, Mr. Rohatyn is known abroad and might envision himself as the Fed official who speaks at international gatherings, a role now exercised mainly by Mr. Greenspan along with Mr. Blinder. If Mr. Clinton were to lose the election, Mr. Rohatyn might emerge as one of the more influential Democratic policy makers left in Washington.
One senior Administration official, asked why Mr. Rohatyn would even want the Fed vice chairmanship, said: "I think he sees it as his valedictory. He may be staring at the prospect of nothing else, and this may look better by comparison."
If nominated and confirmed, he would have a tenured four-year term, as Mr. Clinton's third appointment to the Federal Reserve. Mr. Blinder, who announced last week that he would not seek reappointment, was the first. Janet L. Yellen was the second; she is an economist on leave from the University of California at Berkeley.
Having Mr. Rohatyn on the Fed for the next four years would please Mr. Crandall at American Airlines. "We need a guy like Felix, who says we have to avoid inflation, but at the same time says we have to find ways to encourage faster economic growth to meet our social commitments and create jobs."
Some executives, however, were reluctant to comment, including John Snow, chairman of the CSX Corporation, who currently leads the Business Roundtable, a group including chief executives of 200 giant corporations.
Other business groups do not necessarily see Mr. Rohatyn as their spokesman. The hope of the United States Chamber of Commerce is that a "traditional businessman" more representative of its members, would be named, said Martin Regalia, chief economist of the group. Mr. Rohatyn, he said, "is someone with a Wall Street background and not someone we would lobby for."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about support from business executives for the candidacy of Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, for the vice chairmanship of the Federal Reserve misspelled the surname of one executive, the chairman of Pfizer Inc. He is William C. Steere Jr., not Stier.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Principles?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You say of Boris N. Yeltsin (editorial, Jan. 17) that running for a second term as President of Russia would cause him to "betray his principles and ability to provide enlightened leadership." 
 Since when has Mr. Yeltsin had principles? Since he betrayed his country and sabotaged the Union treaty?
Since he shelled his own Parliament? Since he waged an unnecessary and brutal war on Chechnya?
Perhaps you have him confused with the one who did provide enlightened leadership, who ended the cold war, let Eastern Europe go, released us from the threat of nuclear annihilation, and created a new treaty for the former Soviet states that would have allowed for an economic union, not military dictatorship.
Oh, yes -- Mikhail Gorbachev. Seems he was the one with the ability to provide enlightened leadership.
 
SHEILA M. KORTLUCKE
Lawrence, Kan., Jan. 22, 1996

HEADLINE: Fed Watchers See a Shave for Rates

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
To most economists looking at signs of a slowing economy and well-subdued inflation, the question on interest rates boils down to this: Why not cut?
And while many economists expect just that, nothing is ever simple with the Federal Reserve. The Fed approaches a meeting of its top interest-rate committee next week against a backdrop of several unusual factors. There's the budget impasse, and the disruption in economic statistics caused by the Government shutdown. Just ahead lie some key decisions on the Fed leadership: While President Clinton is widely expected to reappoint its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third four-year term, there are two vacancies on the seven-member governing board. And even the Fed is aware that this an election year. 
 The majority view among Fed-watchers is that the caution lights flashing on the economy recently will lead the Fed to shave another quarter of a percentage point off the key Federal funds rate next week. Not only is inflation docile, the argument goes, but the Fed faces more risk -- and potential election-year criticism -- if it lets the economy falter than if it gives it a little more juice.
Since last summer, the Fed "has been looking for windows of opportunity to make small adjustments to keep the economy growing, not too fast and not too slow," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor. "I think that window is once again open."
But John P. LaWare, who retired as a Fed governor last spring, said he thought the economy was "a little bit stronger" than many other analysts do. Consequently, he said, he would be inclined to "stand pat" at this point.
Mr. LaWare said he also thought that "while there will be a lot of political pressure to lower interest rates and stimulate the economy in an election year," a majority of his former colleagues on the Fed's top policy committee might "be pretty much of my mind."
Most analysts estimate that economic growth slipped to a rate of about 2 percent in 1995's fourth quarter, from 3.2 percent in the previous three months, and that disruptions from severe weather have since pushed it even lower.
But Mr. LaWare, now vice chairman of the Secura Group, a Washington-based consulting firm, said he believed the economy could regain enough footing without an interest-rate cut to grow at 2 percent to 2.5 percent this year. That is a pace, he said, that most Fed members would consider "very satisfactory" and "not likely to rekindle any inflationary pressures."
Some analysts also say the release of transcripts this week from a Fed meeting in October 1990 could increase the pressure on Mr. Greenspan to push for a rate cut next week, perhaps in part to avoid repeating an embarrassing misreading.
In that closed-door meeting, Mr. Greenspan, resisted a cut in rates by telling other board members that "at the moment, it isn't raining," adding, "The economy has not yet slipped into a recession."
But Government officials later determined that a recession had actually begun three months earlier. And Paul L. Kasriel, the chief economist at the Northern Trust Company, a Chicago bank, said he did not think Mr. Greenspan "would want to risk doing that again."
Still, most economists give Mr. Greenspan reasonably high marks for guiding the economy since then. The Fed's rate-setting committee raised its most important rate, the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, seven times as the economy grew rapidly in 1994 and early 1995.
Since last summer, it has trimmed that rate twice, by a quarter of a percentage point each time, bringing it to 5.5 percent. The last cut came on Dec. 19, a day after the stock market fell 101 points and needed reassurance to resume its record-setting climb.
Only a handful of economists are worried about a recession now. But many say Government figures released over the last two weeks depict an economy in need of some rejuvenation. And most are betting on another tiny quarter-point cut that would drop the funds rate to 5.25 percent, making credit a little cheaper for consumers and business.
Some also think the Fed might whittle the discount rate, which it charges on its own short-term loans to banks, to 5 percent from 5.25 percent.
To these economists, the case for giving the economy a spark is fairly compelling. While inflation has remained at a minimal 2 to 3 percent, the recent Government and industry statistics, however late and incomplete, show that the economy is weakening by most measures.
"I think all the risks are that the economy is going to be weaker, not stronger," Mr. Kasriel said. Given the normal lag time of six months or more for Fed rate cuts to have an impact on the economy, he added that he thought the Fed would cut the funds rate by a quarter-point next week so it could be "on the sidelines as we move into the second half of an election year."
Others would like to see the Fed take even firmer action. Worried about slowing auto sales, Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, said last week that he thought that the Fed needed to cut the funds rate by at least half a percentage point.
But even some analysts who advocate a rate cut say the economy is still fundamentally healthy.
Mr. Gramley, who served on the Fed board in the early 1980's and is now a consulting economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said he expected the Fed to cut both the funds and the discount rate by one-quarter of a point next week to keep the economy growing at 2 percent "or a little better."
But noting that stock prices are still soaring, the dollar has strengthened and American exports have been booming despite sluggish economic growth overseas, he added, "I don't really think an easing is critical at this point."
Other analysts, including Donald J. Fine of Chase Securities Inc. in New York, think the Fed could wait until it meets again in March before deciding to cut rates.
But whatever happens, nearly everyone agrees it will largely be decided by Mr. Greenspan, the Reagan Administration appointee who has made himself seem indispensable to both Democrats and Republicans in his eight and a half years of watching over the economy.

HEADLINE: Bernard Rosenberg, 72, Author And a Professor of Sociology

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Bernard Rosenberg, distinguished professor emeritus of sociology at City College and the City University Graduate Center and a contributing editor of the intellectual journal Dissent from its inception, died on Thursday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in the Bronx. Professor Rosenberg, who lived on the East Side of Manhattan, was 72.
His daughter Deena said the cause was congestive heart failure. 
 The author, co-author or editor of more than 20 books on subjects from Thorstein Veblen to juvenile delinquency to Broadway musicals, Professor Rosenberg also wrote scores of articles and essays about American politics, American Jewry and mass culture.
In his political writings, he brought his eclectic knowledge and corrosive wit to bear on anti-democratic institutions. On the subject of American Jewry, he remained optimistic about the future of the Jewish people, despite extensive assimilation. In his articles on mass culture, as in his "Mass Culture: The Popular Arts in America," the pioneering 1957 book he wrote with D. M. White, he asserted strenuously that culture need not be lowered to reach a wide audience.
His "Sociological Theory: A Book of Readings," compiled with L. A. Coser and published and republished beginning in 1957, was a standard text. Professor Rosenberg was also the co-author of several works on the problems of the young, including "Work, Youth and Unemployment" (1968) and "The Varieties of Delinquent Experience" (1969). From 1964 to 1967, when Lyndon B. Johnson was in the White House, Professor Rosenberg was a member of the President's Commission on Juvenile Delinquency.
At the time of his death, he was at work on two books: one was a collection of his essays; the other, "In Defense of Culture," focused on the cultural roots of behavior, norms, customs, languages and artistic forms of expression.
Professor Rosenberg, who retired in 1992, was an instructor at Brandeis University in 1954 when Dissent was founded and he began working with Irving Howe and other editors. Professor Rosenberg remained a contributing editor until his death.
He was born in Detroit in 1923, received a bachelor of arts degree from the University of Michigan in 1945, a master's degree in social science from the New School for Social Research in 1947 and a doctorate from the New School in 1949. In 1946, he did graduate work in sociology with the eminent Swiss psychologist Jean Piaget.
Professor Rosenberg began his teaching career at Wayne University in 1948 and came to the City University system in 1956. He became a professor there in 1967.
Besides his wife of 47 years, the former Sarah Greenspan, Professor Rosenberg is survived by his son, Daniel, and his daughters, Rebecca and Deena, all of Manhattan; a sister, Leona Kutlov of Detroit and a grandchild.

HEADLINE: A Humane Plan for Iraq

 BODY:
Iraq's increasingly desperate economic and diplomatic isolation seems to have softened Saddam Hussein's resistance to a humanitarian plan for feeding his country's hungry children. Baghdad has now agreed to talk with the United Nations about carrying out an American-sponsored resolution that would allow Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over the next six months to help finance purchases of food and medicine.
It is still not clear whether the Iraqi dictator is willing to accept the resolution's reasonable conditions. He should, without further delay. Mr. Hussein's long refusal to consider the plan has made Iraq's own citizens, especially its children, the longest-suffering victims of the Persian Gulf war. 
 The U.N. resolution is a strictly humanitarian arrangement, separate from the issue of allowing Iraq to resume unfettered oil exports once it fully complies with U.N. arms control requirements.
Before the Persian Gulf war, Iraq exported some three million barrels of oil a day. That would be worth about $10 billion over six months at today's prices. The U.N. resolution authorizes sales at only one-fifth that level. Under the resolution 30 percent of the funds would be used to compensate Kuwait and other victims of Iraqi aggression. Relatively modest sums would also be diverted to pay the costs of U.N. arms inspection programs and to compensate Turkey for use of its oil pipeline. The remainder, some $1.3 billion, would go to buy food, medicine and other essential civilian goods for Iraq.
Several factors propelled Iraq to the table. Damaging disclosures by a high-level defector last summer made it evident that, at least until very recently, Iraq has been concealing evidence from U.N. arms inspectors and continuing to work on prohibited weapons programs. That eliminated any chances that the Security Council might lift sanctions completely anytime soon.
Meanwhile Jordan, which had been Iraq's most sympathetic neighbor and its most important conduit for remaining trade, turned sharply cooler. Finally, the cumulative effects of more than five years of broad international sanctions have produced acute food and medicine shortages in Iraq.
Even a limited return of Iraq to saturated world oil markets would cause problems for other oil producers, including such financially pressed countries as Saudi Arabia and Mexico, as prices fell in response to increased supply. Yet the overriding consideration must be humanitarian relief for suffering Iraqi innocents.

HEADLINE: Panel Clears Plan to Enlarge Taxicab Fleet

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
City Council members cleared the way yesterday for the addition of 400 new medallion cabs, the first increase in New York's fleet of yellow taxis since 1937.
The measure, proposed last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as a way of helping balance the budget, will raise the number of medallions -- the shields mounted on the hoods of all legal yellow cabs -- to 12,187, an increase of 3.4 percent. 
 For six decades, the only way to acquire a medallion has been to buy it from a previous owner, and the scarcity has helped drive the price up to an average of $200,000. But the 400 new ones will be sold at auction, with the proceeds going to the city.
The sale of the new turquoise medallions, included in the budget for the fiscal year that started July 1, was approved by the City Council's Transportation Committee yesterday and is expected to win easy approval from the full Council. The last hurdles to its passage appeared to be resolved when the committee's chairman, Councilman Noach Dear of Brooklyn, said the Giuliani administration had addressed several concerns he had about the plan.
City officials say that besides bringing $80 million into the city's coffers, the sale will also improve taxi service in the city, particularly in the boroughs outside Manhattan. While the city's population has grown about 6 percent since 1937, no new medallions have been issued.
In April the first 100 medallions will be sold to the highest bidders. Forty will be reserved for individuals with a minimum bid of $160,000. The other 60 will be awarded to fleet owners and that minimum bid has been set at $190,000.
"This is a step in the right direction," said Mayor Giuliani. "It will help provide more effective taxi service throughout the city, because we've had too few taxis."
But the sale has exposed a rift between the owners of large, long-established taxi fleets, who do not oppose the move, and smaller operators, who say they will be badly hurt. The small operators are not particularly concerned about increased competition for fares -- they say there will still be plenty of business to go around -- but they fear the new medallions will drive down the value of their medallions.
"We're talking about individuals who may have spent their entire life in the taxi industry and may want to retire," said Robert Familant, president of the Taxicab Service Association, which represents 40 percent of the small medallion owners. "We don't want those folks to be in competition with the city" when they want to sell their medallions, he said.
Others said that the increase is much too small to have an impact on the price of the medallion.
"Unfortunately, a medallion is absurdly priced," said Edward Rogoff, a management professor at Baruch College, who studies the taxi industry. "For the last 50 years, it's been a great investment."
In 1937, after a decade of oversupply, city officials thought that there would never be a need for more taxis and set a ceiling at 11,787. A series of fare cuts prompted 7,000 owners to return their medallions to the city in the 1930's, refusing to pay the $10 yearly licensing fee.
On Thursday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission approved a 20 percent fare increase. Beginning March 1, the charge for the first one-fifth of a mile will rise to $2 from $1.50, and each additional one-fifth of a mile will cost 30 cents, up from 25 cents. The night charge of 50 cents and the rate of 20 cents a minute stuck in traffic were unchanged.
Discussing the sale of new medallions, some taxi drivers and owners agreed yesterday that more taxis would improve service in Manhattan. But they said that it would not necessarily mean more yellow taxis outside Manhattan.
"It's a matter of economics," said Ronald Stoppelmann, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, a coalition of 18 of the oldest and largest fleets, with 1,900 medallions among them. "People in the outer boroughs don't hail cabs as much."
But Christopher R. Lynn, the Chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said that service outside Manhattan would be improved, because he plans to increase the issuing of summonses and other penalties to drivers who refuse to accept fares to the outer boroughs.
The proposal was presented to the committee for a hearing and a vote yesterday after Mr. Dear said his objections had been addressed. For one thing, the Taxi and Limousine Commission had softened some elements of a new rule, adopted along with the fare increase, that sets mandatory retirement ages for cabs. Mr. Dear said he also won some concessions on the timing of the planned medallion sales.
"I just wanted to make sure that some issues were resolved," he said yesterday. "It was a compromise. I'm pretty happy with it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald Stoppelmann president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, conferred with a lawyer, Howard Gerber, yesterday. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
When the Rev. Harvey Cox, the Victor Thomas Professor of Religion at Harvard University, suggested in the Jan. 1 issue of The Nation magazine that fear and loathing of the religious right was pushing secular liberals into a self-defeating antagonism toward all religiously based arguments about public policy, he didn't have to wait long for a response.
"Is the American left hostile to religion?" asked Katha Pollitt, an associate editor and columnist for The Nation, a left-wing weekly. "I wish!" 
 While Professor Cox believes that secular liberals are tempted to rule religious appeals and imagery out of order in the political arena, Ms. Pollitt believes that the United States is drenched in religion ("Could a politician be elected if he admitted to being a nonbeliever?" she asks in the Jan. 22 issue). That drenching "goes for the so-called left as well," Ms. Pollitt says; witness, she adds, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Michael Lerner and his Tikkun magazine, and feminist theology.
Professor Cox worries that the alliance that once existed between religious and secular liberals in the Populist movement, Progressivism, the civil rights struggle and the protest against the Vietnam War has fallen into disrepair.
Ms. Pollitt replies that secular liberals have no problem working with religious allies whenever their goals coincide: Planned Parenthood can join with the Roman Catholic bishops to combat "family caps" on welfare payments, and liberals do not hesitate to embrace the Pope if it suits their purposes.
While Professor Cox urges "let us welcome religious conservatives" into the political debate because "although they almost always advance the wrong answers, religious conservatives do often raise important questions," Ms. Pollitt cannot imagine what those questions would be: "Whether Judgment Day is coming sooner rather than later?"
Professor Cox holds that "the great religious traditions remain one of the few repositories of an alternative" to today's vision of the world as "an economic roller coaster propelled by a logic of infinite growth."
He sees religion as a reminder that humans "are finite creatures," as a seedbed of community and virtue and as an engine of both prophetic judgment and utopian vision. Religious imagery in public life, he writes, offers "a discourse that at its best can speak out powerfully against greed, ennui and coldness of heart."
Ms. Pollitt could not disagree more. For her, religion is "a farrago of authoritarian nonsense, misogyny and humble pie, the eternal enemy of human happiness and freedom."
One begins to suspect that this marriage cannot be saved.
Obviously what divides Professor Cox and Ms. Pollitt is temperament as much as theology.
Professor Cox is an inveterate yeasayer who has always spied the workings of God's grace (as well as the contours of the Social Gospel) in one cultural movement after another, from the pragmatic secularism of the Kennedy era to the carnival spirit of the counterculture and the worldwide growth of Pentecostalism. So, he asks, why not cast an appreciative eye at the Christian Coalition, or at least at the wider body of conservative believers who surround them?
He responded to Ms. Pollitt's onslaught with characteristic good humor. It was, he said, "pungently written."
Ms. Pollitt, on the other hand, is a born naysayer. With equal amounts of satisfaction and self-mockery, she recounts in her column how, by merely mentioning on the CNN television program "Crossfire" that she does not believe in God, she earned the title "Free-Thought Heroine of 1995" from the Freedom From Religion Foundation.
She is, in fact, a kind of conservative, relishing the role of unreconstructed defender of that old-time atheism. (One can imagine her singing, "It was good enough for Diderot, it's good enough for me.")
Aside from temperament, there are two points on which Professor Cox and Ms. Pollitt remain diametrically opposed. Are there, in fact, important questions raised by religious conservatives that should be discussed by secular liberals?
And is there enough overlap, or common language, in the discourse of believers and unbelievers to make a conversation possible, despite the differences in their starting points or fundamental premises?
The best way to address the first point might be by trying an example. Unfortunately, Professor Cox felt compelled to devote so much of his short article to trying to make clear that he was not a stalking horse for the religious right that he barely hinted at what those important questions might be.
As for the second point, Ms. Pollitt makes it clear that religious believers come so close to being alien creatures and speak a language of faith so untranslatable into her framework of secular reason that communication is well nigh hopeless.
The Nation reports a lively stream of mail, and so far it appears to be running in favor of the Free-Thought Heroine of 1995. The response she has been getting personally is even more favorable.
"Whenever I feel unloved," she said in a recent telephone interview, "I can always write another column assaulting religion, and I get all this fan mail."

HEADLINE: A Boot Camp for G.O.P. Freshmen

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The freshmen who marched into Washington at the head of the Republican revolution a year ago met here today for a midterm retreat, where they planned to lick their wounds from a year of battles and to gather strength for another charge at big government. Instead, they heard themselves lambasted by conservative hard-liners, whose visions made even the sternest among them blink.
A year has gone by and almost none of the ambitious Republican agenda has become law, speaker after speaker thundered this morning, as the freshmen and some sophomores listened, seemingly in shock. Others on the program said the Republicans should never have relented on their strategy of forcing the Federal Government to shut down to force President Clinton to accept the Republican budget. 
 "When you had the Government down, you should have left it down," Al Dunlap, a conservative who is the chief executive of the Scott Paper Company, told the Republican lawmakers at a midmorning meeting. The strategy was hurting Republicans in the polls, Mr. Dunlap acknowledged, but they still should have held fast.
"No job is worth having that isn't worth losing for doing the right thing," he said.
While those who spoke at the retreat did not mention Speaker Newt Gingrich by name, some of their anger was apparently directed at the Speaker, who has deferred action on issues unpopular with many lawmakers but dear to the hearts of conservatives, like term limits.
About 50 of the 73 Republican freshmen and 14 of the sophomores in the House arrived in Baltimore on Thursday evening for the two-day retreat, organized by two conservative groups, the Heritage Foundation, a research center, and Empower America, a public-policy organization. They brought in a number of conservatives, including William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary and drug czar who is a founder of Empower America; Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation; Dr. Wade Horn, director of the National Fatherhood Initiative, and Ben Wattenberg, the syndicated columnist and moderator of the weekly public television program "Think Tank."
In many ways the experience for the freshmen was like a Marine boot camp -- they were being ripped apart from the outset by tough-talking drill instructors, but left with the notion that they are invincible.
"You haven't gone too far -- we've barely done anything yet," Mr. Bennett said in the keynote speech Thursday night. "You've just started this thing. They will talk about how harsh you are and how mean you are, and you've just got to hold your ground."
With Democrats holding their own in the Senate and Mr. Clinton proving wilier than the Republicans had anticipated, the heady times they enjoyed in the first 100 days of the 104th Congress, when they began to enact their Contract with America, has given way to near gloom during the budget battle.
"A lot of people came in with unrealistic expectations on what could be accomplished," said Representative Phil English, a freshman from Pennsylvania.
Another freshman, Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen of New Jersey, said: "I think the class, over all, is still optimistic. But the dose of reality is that I don't think everybody understood how masterful the President is and how well he does on the pulpit."
The sponsors billed the event as an opportunity for the Republican underclassmen to get away as a group from the rarefied political air of nearby Washington to exchange ideas and reset their agenda.
Beyond that, the gathering was an effort by conservative forces that are now fretting about the Congressional leadership of Senator Bob Dole and Mr. Gingrich to jump start the conservative political revolution, with the underclassmen again providing the spark.
"You have got to get a C.E.O. who believes in you," said Mr. Dunlap, the Scott Paper executive, "and it's not Bob Dole. Bob Dole is yesterday. The Senate is yesterday. You are tomorrow."
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader who in recent weeks has come to rival Mr. Gingrich as the conservative standard-bearer among the freshmen, paid an unannounced visit to the gathering to deliver a brief pep talk, telling his troops not to be discouraged by recent setbacks.
"Think of it as a video tape you are watching," Mr. Armey said, "and the most powerful man in the world, the President of the United States, has his finger on the pause button. But he can't hit the stop button."
Together, the 73-member freshman class and the 48 members of the sophomore class provide more than half of the 236 Republican votes in the House of Representatives.
A little more than a year ago, just after they were elected and before the 104th Congress opened with its Republican majority, the incoming freshmen gathered in the same place, the Lord Baltimore Hotel, to hear some of the same speakers lay out the battle plan for the conservative revolution and to sing praise for the wave of eager new foot soldiers. This year there was no escaping the somberness that hung over most of today's sessions.
"I keep hearing how we failed and how we are getting beat up," said Representative Sam Brownback, a freshman from Kansas. "I don't think we have."
Sandwiched between a prayer breakfast this morning and a bus ride back to Washington late this afternoon, the Republican underclassmen attended public sessions on "Government Downsizing," "Empowering Citizens" and "Strengthening America's Families and Culture." At each public meeting, they got healthy dosages of advice before retreating to private caucuses to ingest it in what a member called "quite candid" discussions.
The underclassmen said that they did not expect to draw up a complete new agenda here, but they were clearly leaving Baltimore with the intent of pushing their revolution onto battlefields that their leadership has so far avoided, including term limits.
"I would encourage you to be far bolder than you have been," Jim Miller, a budget director in the Reagan Administration and now the counselor for Citizens for a Sound Economy, told the lawmakers in the session on reducing government. "You have to cut back, cut back, cut back that monster."
Mr. Dunlap caused the room to fall silent when he said the Republicans should try to balance the Federal budget immediately instead of over the seven years sought by their leadership.
"You ought to do it in one year," said Mr. Dunlap, who was described in his biographical sketch as "Rambo in pinstripes" because of the way he cut costs and the staff at Scott Paper.
"A seven-year balanced budget will fail," he asserted. "In seven years the characters will change, the mood of the people will change."

HEADLINE: Economic Surge in BangladeshUndercut by Political Turmoil

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh

 BODY:
Each morning, as the smoggy winter dawn begins to lift, thousands of women in colorful saris, some cradling infants, walk in a silent tide along the causeway leading from the Baridara slum district toward this city's growing network of garment factories.
In poorly lit tenement buildings, the women sit at rows of sewing machines making clothes -- socks and shorts, windbreakers and track suits -- that trade experts say reach one in every five American homes. Last year, factories employing more than a million Bangladeshi women recorded sales to the United States of $1.5 billion, more than 40 percent of Bangladesh's booming export earnings. 
 With 120 million people, Bangladesh ranks among the dozen poorest countries in the world, with a per capita income of less than $250 a year. But because of an economic awakening symbolized by the garment factories, which barely existed only a few years ago, the country is no longer the "international basket case" that Henry A. Kissinger called it more than 20 years ago.
Progress has been so startling since 1991, when 15 years of coups and military rule gave way to an elected civilian Government, that development experts have begun to speak of Bangladesh in new ways.
"In my view, there is a good possibility of Bangladesh becoming another Asian tiger," said Forrest E. Cookson, an American economist working on reforms at Bangladesh's central bank that are part of a broader transition to a free-market economy.
But Bangladesh's dream of emulating the economic booms of some of its neighbors is fragile.
Because politicians here -- in particular, the two women who head the Government and the main opposition party -- have been unable to rise above enmities that go back to Bangladesh's earliest days, after it emerged from the civil war that dismembered Pakistan in 1971, many fear the economic turnaround could be halted by new political turmoil.
A watershed was passed this month when the Government of Prime Minister Khaleda Zia decided to proceed with a general election despite a decision by all major opposition parties to boycott it. Balloting for the 300 elected seats in Parliament has been set for Feb. 15. If the election goes ahead, as is expected, Mrs. Zia's Bangladesh National Party, opposed in most seats only by splinter groups, is sure to return to power in a landslide.
Mrs. Zia's main political rival, Sheik Hasina Wazed, who heads the Awami League party that is the main opposition group, has vowed to disrupt the voting. And even if the voting goes ahead without violence, the Awami League has said it will continue with the protests it has led since leading an opposition walkout from Parliament in 1994. Politically inspired strikes have already shut down the economy for at least 35 days in the past year.
The political impasse centers on a dispute about how to conduct the election, which must take place before Feb. 22, when the Zia Government's five-year term expires. Saying they do not trust the Government to hold a fair vote, the opposition parties have demanded that Mrs. Zia hand over power before the election to a "caretaker" administration like the one that oversaw the 1991 vote. The Government has refused.
But many Bangladeshis say the election dispute is only a symptom of a deeper issue: whether Bangladesh can establish a stable democracy. Among pessimists, the debate goes further, to speculation on the causes of the instability. Some blame personal rivalries between Mrs. Zia and Mrs. Wazed; others say the rivalries are a symptom of an age-old fractiousness among ethnic Bengalis that is as much a part of their inheritance as their penchant for poetry and philosophical speculation.
"Sometimes I think we are just a politically immature people," said Mahfuz Anam, editor of The Daily Star, an English-language newspaper published in Dhaka, the capital.
Like many Bangladeshis, Mr. Anam worries that the politicians' squabbles could eventually provoke a new coup by the army, which held effective power from the first military coup in 1975 until the fall of the last military ruler, Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, in 1990.
Much of the debate turns on the enmity between Mrs. Zia and Mrs. Wazed. Mrs. Zia, 50, is the widow of Ziaur Rahman, an army general who took power after the 1975 officers' plot that killed the country's first Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and was himself assassinated in an aborted coup in 1981. Mrs. Wazed, 48, is Sheik Mujibur's daughter.
Friends of the two women say each harbors bitter feelings over the killings, with Mrs. Wazed convinced that General Zia had some involvement in her father's death, and Mrs. Zia suspicious of an Awami League link in her husband's killing.
Many who know both women say personal feelings have triumphed over wider considerations.
"The country is walking a tightrope, and it can go either way -- all the way to the other side, where there is prosperity for all, or into the abyss," said a Western envoy who tried to persuade Mrs. Zia and Mrs. Wazed to take part in the election on terms both could accept.
For the moment, many Bangladeshis are taking comfort from what they have heard about the army commander, Lieut. Gen. Abu Saleh Mohammed Nasim. Although he was appointed by Mrs. Zia in 1994, General Nasim has links to the Awami League through his role as a "freedom fighter" in Bangladesh's independence war in 1971, when the leader of the freedom struggle was Mrs. Wazed's father.
General Nasim has told diplomats that he wants to keep the army out of politics, but he can hardly be immune to the rising anger that many Bangladeshis harbor toward their politicians. In Dhaka and other cities, in the countryside where 80 percent of the population lives, and at the dinner tables of the foreign-educated elite who dominate the top levels of Government bureaucracy and business, there is bitter criticism of Mrs. Zia and Mrs. Wazed.
"We are just a poor country, but we are starting to rise up, and now the politicians are fighting again," said Ahmed, 18, a tractor owner at a brick kiln near the town of Bogra, an hour's drive north of Dhaka.
Kiln workers nodded in agreement. But when they were asked about a military coup, there was a chorus of dissent. Among many Bangladeshis, army rule is associated with corruption, arbitrary powers, even murder -- abuses with which General Ershad, currently serving a 13-year sentence in a Dhaka prison, was formally accused after his ouster.
[Court officials said on Jan. 26 that General Ershad had been charged with ordering the murder of a rebel army general after the 1981 failed coup, Reuters reported.]
"The army will destroy everything, as they did before," one older man said.
Ahmed, the kiln worker, and his brother Mohammed, 21, who like Ahmed uses only one name, typify what changing economic opportunities have meant. Like millions of Bangladeshis, their father was a hired hand in the rice paddies. His sons worked as laborers at the kiln, pooled their savings, took a loan, and bought a small tractor that they drive 10 hours a day, pushing a wooden rotary arm that grinds up clay used in making the bricks.
It is dirty, exhausting work, driven by the building boom in Dhaka. But it brings the brothers the equivalent of $17.50 a day, more than their father earned in a month. Already, they have bought some land, and hired men to grow rice.
Although more than 50 percent of all Bangladeshis still live below the official poverty line, it is through enterprise like the two brothers' that the economy is growing.
Despite the strikes, the official growth rate is about 4.5 percent. Economists like Mr. Cookson believe the real rate may be as high as 6.5 percent, close to the rates that propelled booms in countries like South Korea and Taiwan. Exports have been growing by 20 percent annually. Foreign exchange reserves have grown more than 10 times since 1991, to $3.4 billion.
Nor is economic momentum the only measure of progress. Although the population has grown by more than 50 million since 1970, the rate of increase has slowed dramatically, to 1.8 percent a year from more than 3 percent in 1975, as a result of one of the most effective birth-control programs in any developing country.
With fewer than 40 percent of Bangladeshis able to read and write, innovative programs provide food for students and pay small stipends to parents who keep their girls in class. Improved sanitation and health care have cut infant death rates to 88 per thousand, 15 percent lower than 25 years ago.
Perhaps most important, a boom in agriculture has brought the country close to feeding itself, with food imports of more than 10 million tons now down to 2.5 million tons a year.
The progress was set in motion long before military rule lifted. But few here question that it was the return to parliamentary government that provided the essential spur, and the threat to continued democratic rule that is the biggest danger now.
As political tensions increased in recent months, some of the economic success began to fade. Investors from Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan who had been rushing to take advantage of the low wages and windfall profits in the garment industry started to look elsewhere.
Inflation began to push upwards as the Zia Government, looking for votes, pumped money into pork-barrel projects. Wealthy Bangladeshis who had been investing at home stashed money in foreign banks.
Many Bangladeshis had hoped that signs of an economic downturn would prompt an agreement on the election. Talks mediated by the American Ambassador, David N. Merrill, appeared at one time to be close to agreement on an interim government.
But the talks failed when Mrs. Zia insisted that ultimate authority during the election period rest with Bangladesh's President, Abdur Rahman Biswas. Mrs. Wazed rejected the arrangement, calling President Biswas a stooge for Mrs. Zia.
The impasse has left the two leaders unrepentant. In an interview, Mrs. Wazed spoke with animosity for Mrs. Zia, saying the Bangladesh National party that General Zia founded and his widow now heads was "born in a cantonment," meaning a military barracks.
"So their character is not at all democratic," she said. "They have rigged elections. They have killed voters, and they have armed cadres all over the country. So how can we trust them to hold an election?"
Similar allegations are made against the Awami League by many Bangladeshis who remember the party's time in power, from 1971 until Sheik Mujibur's assassination in 1975. Sheik Mujibur declared Bangladesh a one-party state, founded a militia that was under his personal control and abolished civil rights.
Aides to Mrs. Zia declined requests for an interview. But an official who represented her in the election talks, Agriculture Minister Abdul Mannan Bhuyian, said the Awami League had sought from the outset to find an excuse not to take part in an election. "They know they cannot win an election, so they have tried to overthrow us with a mass movement," he said.
Now, Bangladesh faces an election that many people regard as meaningless, with little prospect that the Awami League will accept the results or call off the strikes.
To Mr. Anam, the newspaper editor, it is an ominous situation. "We are in the grip of a Government without credibility, and an opposition without responsibility," he said. "Is it any wonder that people are losing faith in our politicians, saying 'If this is democracy, who needs it?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Women working in a Dhaka garment factory are part of a fragile economic boom in Bangladesh. They earn an average of $30 a month and the fruits of their labor can be found in one in five American homes. (John Giannini for The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CLINTON'S ADVISERS;
Sharp Split Over Issues: Economics Or Values?

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
James Carville, the political strategist for Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign, will soon be on the book tour circuit with a prescription for the Democratic Party: focus on pocketbook issues like wage stagnation and measures to promote family stability.
"No. 1 is the paycheck, stupid," said Mr. Carville, refining his 1992 message that the campaign was about the economy. "No. 2 is, Daddies matter. Big time." 
 Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's current strategist, argues conversely that the President should emphasize values, Administration officials say.
Mr. Morris counsels that Mr. Clinton should focus not on paycheck issues but on concerns like protecting children and changing the welfare system, and on education, Medicare and the environment.
These two strategists represent different sides in a debate that is raging so heavily inside the Democratic Party and the White House that the centrist Democratic Leadership Council devoted much of its January magazine to it: should the party stress economics or values in this election year?
Arguing for a heavy dose of economic issues with an eye toward appealing to labor and blue-collar voters are Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign advisers, like Mr. Carville and Stanley B. Greenberg, as well as more liberal aides like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and the deputy White House chief of staff, Harold M. Ickes, Administration officials say.
"The economy has to be a major battleground for any Democrat aspiring to national office," said Mr. Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's campaign pollster in 1992.
Pushing a values-based theme, one they think has broader appeal across class lines, officials say, are the new campaign team of Mr. Morris, the pollsters Mark Penn and Douglas Schoen, and moderate Democratic allies like Bruce Reed, the domestic policy adviser, and Donald Baer, communications director.
"I think we've underestimated the value of values in our politics and they are very important," said Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council.
All sides agree that the President will and should make some synthesis of the two concerns. And he did to some degree in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night.
While Mr. Clinton leaned heavily toward values, supporting school uniforms and reducing violence on television, he also called for an increase in the minimum wage and for corporations to share good times as well as bad with their workers. The proponents of paycheck issues believe he may yet move further their way.
"These two things are centrally related," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary. "The despair people feel about popular culture is related to insecurity about economic well-being."
"The issue is the effective fusion into one bigger idea," Mr. McCurry added. He described Mr. Clinton's reference to an "age of possibility" as a "holding pattern phrase" until he presents a fuller vision later in the campaign year.
What the President must decide is whether middle-class insecurities about layoffs and stagnant wages outweigh fears of crime and declining schools. His challenge is to appeal to both middle-class suburban independents and disenchanted blue-collar Democrats.
In weighing the debate between economics and values, William Curry, a Clinton adviser, likes to point to William Jennings Bryan, the turn-of-the-century populist.
Bryan began as an economic populist championing an easy money policy over the gold standard favored by Eastern bankers and industrialists. He reached the high point of his career at the 1896 Democratic convention, when he defended the free silver position by proclaiming, "You shall not crucify mankind upon a cross of gold."
But by the end of his life he had switched from economic to cultural issues, supporting Tennessee in its prosecution of John T. Scopes for teaching Darwinism instead of a strict interpretation of the Bible.
"Over the century since then, basically we the Democrats have run the 'cross of gold' speech against the Republicans," Mr. Curry said. "And they have run the Scopes trial against us, each of us looking to appeal to the same constituency."
Moderate Democrats say the lack of focus on cultural issues has been a mistake. They point to polling data showing that voters are comfortable with their own economic situation and yet still think the country is going in the wrong direction, suggesting that they are troubled by something broader than economics.
Mr. From contends that while Mr. Carville's quip that "it's the economy, stupid," seemed to sum up the 1992 campaign against President George Bush, the Clinton victory was really brought about by values issues, including Mr. Clinton's support of the death penalty and pledge to "end welfare as we know it."
But those Democrats who want pocketbook economics to play a major part of the campaign say the President risks looking cut off from working people if he simply cites his economic achievements of low unemployment and inflation rates and nearly eight million new jobs.
"To fail to acknowledge job insecurity, stagnating wages of many people and the widening income gap is to risk being out of touch with reality," one Clinton adviser said. "This is the problem Bush faced in 1992."
Another question is how to bring the economy into the campaign. Is it enough to speak of government programs to provide education and training of displaced workers, or of a higher minimum wage, pension and health care portability?
Should the President stump for corporations to cut down on the disparities between executive pay and workers pay, and for corporations to raise salaries as profits rise?
Praising Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message, David Kusnet, a former Clinton speechwriter, said, "I think it sets the stage for what I hope will be an even stronger call for corporate responsibility on downsizing and pay increases in line with productivity and training workers for new and better jobs."
But some Clinton advisers worry that such stands could become polarizing, particularly if they start to focus on executive salaries and benefits and veer towards class warfare.
White House aides say that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is leery of language that could alienate business leaders. And one Democratic adviser involved in the debate says that appeals to class warfare divide the electorate, losing voters with $50,000 or more annual incomes, while Mr. Clinton's stands on values issues is another, less divisive way to reach blue-collar workers.
Mr. Clinton is not expected to move into full campaign gear until at least April, when it becomes clear who has won the Republican nomination. For now, his aides will be watching the performance of the economy and the performance of the Republican field, calibrating, for example, on how well the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan does with his protectionist appeal to workers. And the debate will continue.
"A lot of this," said one Clinton adviser, "depends on what happens over the next few months."

HEADLINE: Battle Brews in Atlantic City

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
What happens when you mix tons of garbage, millions of dollars in proposed tax cuts and a couple of powerful competitors with outsized egos?
In Atlantic City, it adds up to a battle between two of the gambling industry's biggest rivals, Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman and chief executive of Las Vegas-based Mirage Resorts, and Donald J. Trump, the ubiquitous real estate developer and operator of three Atlantic City casinos. 
 Mr. Trump has declared war on a pending New Jersey bill that would provide a huge tax break to Mr. Wynn, who is planning to build a $500 million, 2,000-room hotel and casino in Atlantic City on the site of a former municipal landfill. Mr. Wynn, who sold his previous interests in the Atlantic City gambling industry in 1987, was selected last September by the city to build his resort, to be named Beau Rivage.
But Mr. Trump is leading a coalition of Atlantic City casino operators who say that a measure before the state Senate would give Mr. Wynn an unfair advantage by allowing him to obtain a tax cut to recoup his costs for cleaning up the 178-acre site where his casino is to be built. After competing proposals were submitted last fall -- one by a group that included Mr. Trump -- Mr. Wynn was awarded the contaminated land free of charge from the city. At that time, however, plans for the public to finance the cleanup of the site had not been announced.
Although the landfill measure, sponsored last fall by Senator William Gormley, a Republican from Atlantic City, would allow developers who are building on any of the more than 300 landfills around the state to apply for the same sales-tax abatement, Mr. Trump contended in an interview that the legislation was created specifically to assist Mr. Wynn. "I think it's an unnecessary favor and a lot of people are trying to figure out why this favor is being done," Mr. Trump said. "People should look into what's going on."
Mr. Gormley denied that his measure was created on Mr. Wynn's behalf. "I introduced this before ever talking to Mirage people," the Senator said.
For his part, Mr. Wynn seemed to enjoy watching his rival steam over the bill. During an interview this week with the New York radio host Don Imus, Mr. Wynn facetiously said, "I don't think he likes me. I don't think the Donald likes me."
Alan M. Feldman, a spokesman for Mirage, called Mr. Trump's allegations "blatantly hypocritical." Mirage has not lobbied for the landfill measure, he said, and neither Mr. Wynn nor the corporation has contributed funds to any of Senator Gormley's campaigns.
Mr. Trump himself has received tax breaks on many of his projects outside the gambling industry. But Alan Marcus, a spokesman and lobbyist for Mr. Trump, said the casino industry is so lucrative that additional incentives are not needed. "The incentive is the ability to operate," he said. "This sets a dangerous precedent."
Despite Mr. Trump's invective and his lobbying efforts in Atlantic City and Trenton, the landfill measure was unanimously approved by the Senate's natural resources committee earlier this week, and according to Mr. Gormley, it has received the endorsements of key labor and environmental groups.
Mr. Gormley confirmed that he stayed at Mr. Wynn's flagship Mirage hotel in Las Vegas last month, but said he was there to participate in a gambling industry conference, and paid for his room. A 14-year veteran of the state Senate and chairman of the judiciary committee, Mr. Gormley sponsored legislation, passed last year, that loosened casino regulations and helped to attract Mr. Wynn back to the city.
Should the landfill bill, in its current form, pass the full Senate and House and be signed into law by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, it would allow developers like Mr. Wynn to apply to the State Department of Commerce for a 50 percent cut on the retail sales tax to finance a landfill cleanup. Projects that promise to benefit the local economy would most likely receive the tax abatement, Mr. Gormley said.
By giving tax incentives to businesses that clean landfills, Mr. Gormley said, the state would receive much-needed assistance with a widespread environmental problem and create jobs.
Like many landfills around New Jersey that were abandoned before 1982, the Atlantic City site is filled with municipal waste from local businesses and homes. Since then, tighter restrictions for closing down landfills have been implemented.
Mirage Resorts submitted one of only two bids for the site. The other, for a golf course, was submitted by Mr. Trump's group.
Nicholas R. Amato, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, which represents 11 of the city's 12 gambling halls, said his group supports "the purpose and concept" of the bill but believes that incentives to promote economic development should maintain "a level playing field among all casino operations" and that taxpayers, not casino developers, should be the beneficiaries of any tax relief.
Both Mr. Amato and Arthur M. Goldberg, the chairman and chief executive of Bally Entertainment, operator of two Atlantic City casinos, said more developers would have bid for the landfill site had they known their cleanup costs might have been reimbursed. "We were looking at the land," Mr. Goldberg said in a telephone interview from Las Vegas, where the Bally's Grand competes with Mr. Wynn's Mirage.
"I talked to my board and they wanted me to quantify the cost of cleanup," he said. "I couldn't do it."
He added, "But if I had known it would be reimbursed it would have been no problem."
The Atlantic City gambling industry is coming off its strongest performance in seven years, after posting revenues of $3.75 billion in 1995, a 9.5% jump in revenues from the previous year. "We have the hottest gaming jurisdiction in the United States," Mr. Trump proclaimed.
"Everybody wants to be there. And somebody comes in and gets a piece of land for nothing, and we clean it up for them too. It's extremely unfair and highly unconstitutional."

HEADLINE: After 3-Year Wait, Arms Pact Wins Senate Backing but Faces New Russian Opposition

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Today, three years after President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a major strategic arms reduction treaty, Start II, the Senate approved it, 87 to 4.
But the treaty, which would cut the number of nuclear warheads held by both countries by 50 percent, may be dead, some senior American officials fear. The current Russian legislature, elected on Dec. 17, is significantly more opposed to Mr. Yeltsin than the old one, and it may prove impossible to get the necessary votes there to approve the treaty as written. 
 Even the old legislature, or Duma, had a large block of centrists, nationalists and Communists who favored a renegotiation of Start II, feeling that Mr. Yeltsin, in the euphoria of an early partnership with the United States, gave too much away.
The Russian criticism, expressed by centrists like Sergei Karaganov, a Yeltsin adviser and academic, is that Russia was wrong to give up the mainstay of its nuclear force -- land-based, multiwarhead missiles -- while the United States need only reduce its crucial force of submarine-based missiles.
Today, with the Parliament dominated by Communist and nationalist deputies, the push to renegotiate rather than approve will only be stronger, senior American officials acknowledge. And the Duma is unlikely to even take up the treaty until after Russia's presidential elections in June. The treaty requires approval by a simple majority of both houses of the Russian parliament.
Still, the American officials think that the treaty is in the best interests of both countries, and they are very much hoping that the legislature will approve it in time for the next summit meeting between Presidents Clinton and Yeltsin in Moscow in April, when the treaty could be formally ratified.
But there is more gloom than optimism. "While we hope the Duma will ratify Start II, it seems unlikely that they will," said Marc Thiessen, spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which bottled up the treaty for months last year in an unrelated effort to force a reorganization of the State Department.
Spurgeon Keeny, president of the Arms Control Association in Washington, said today: "The Duma is doing nothing on it. The Russians have made it very clear, publicly and privately, that they want to look at the treaty very closely. The Duma has a bunch of new people who are a more conservative, nationalistic group, and the criticism in Russia is that they got a bad deal. It's unlikely the Duma will act before their presidential elections in June. And many think it's unlikely the Duma will act until after our presidential elections in November."
A senior American official who follows the issue closely said "there is a prospect" the Russians will approve the treaty, "but it's not a high prospect. I wouldn't hold my breath."
The vote tonight in the Senate came in a flurry of business before the senators left for the weekend. To speed the process, they decided to debate the treaty only after completing their vote on it.
Signed with great fanfare just before President Bush left office, the treaty would reduce Russian and American arsenals to no more than 3,500 warheads each, one-third their 1990 total and roughly half the totals permitted under the Start I treaty, which is currently in force. Start II is intended to follow Start I seamlessly, and allows a seven-year period for reductions.
The treaty would eliminate Russia's big multiple-warhead land-based missiles, regarded as the most significant strategic threat to the United States. On the American side, it means the elimination of the large Peacekeeper, or MX, missile and the reduction of warheads in the Minuteman missile from three to one. It also counts the number of warheads on bombers in an accurate way, which is a benefit to the Russians, since bombers, which the Americans also rely on, were counted as only one warhead, artificially, under Start I.
Basically, the treaty brings the American arsenal down to roughly the level that the Russians "are going to be at anyway," given money constraints, one American official said. "There's a good case to be made in the Duma for the treaty."
If the treaty fails, however, it would be an important setback to the psychology of arms reduction. It could damage the chance of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. But it also would mean that more nuclear material would be deployed all over Russia that could be diverted, increasing proliferation concerns.
The reasons for the delay in approving Start II are many. President Bush put the treaty before the Senate on the last day of his presidency. But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, it was important to get the agreement of new countries like Belarus, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, who inherited Soviet missiles, to agree to give them up, to join the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty as non-nuclear states and to ratify Start I themselves.
Start I went into effect on Dec. 5, 1994. But Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, took over the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in January 1995, after the Republicans took over the Senate, and held up the treaty, as well as a number of ambassadorial appointments, as a way to pressure the Administration to abolish some agencies, like the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and give their functions to the State Department.
The Administration ultimately cut $1.7 million from the budgets of these agencies and the treaty reached Congress in mid-December -- just as Russians were electing their new, more conservative legislature.
Mr. Thiessen, the Senate Committee spokesman, said that Mr. Helms felt "no responsibility" for a delay that could kill the treaty. After all, Mr. Thiessen said, the old Duma did not approve the treaty either.
As for the possibility of renegotiating the treaty, Mr. Thiessen said: "Every time the Russians complain, this Administration caves." But American officials said tonight they thought the prospect of renegotiation was very slim.
American officials will press the issue this weekend, when Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin is in Washington to meet Vice President Al Gore, and when Secretary of State Warren Christopher meets the new Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, in Helsinki on Feb. 10 and 11.
President Clinton spoke to Mr. Yeltsin for 40 minutes this afternoon, to receive assurances that the Russian President remains "committed to economic reform and a continuing, strong U.S.-Russian relationship," said the Presidential spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. They also discussed Bosnia and Chechnya, but the Start II treaty did not seem to be a topic.
