HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Snap Back From Slide With Good Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered strongly from early losses yesterday, halting a recent slide on revived hopes of a Federal budget agreement.
The comeback was bolstered by a short-cover rally, as market participants who sold borrowed securities hoping prices would continue to fall were caught off guard by the upswing and sought to limit their losses. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose a full point, to 11113/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.11 percent on Thursday, when investors sold off on the dismal outlook for a budget accord and large hedge funds dumped Treasury securities.
The selling by hedge funds continued early yesterday, with a number of large funds still unwinding yen-financed trades. In such trades, hedge funds, which are private investment funds for wealthy individuals, buy yen, borrow in Japan at low interest rates and then buy United States Treasury securities.
And few market participants were willing to hold long positions before the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week. The Fed's Federal Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday and Wednesday.
But traders said the market bounced off some technical support levels that made afternoon buyers out of morning sellers.
The market was heartened by signs the Senate would pass a stopgap spending measure. It eventually approved the bill, 82 to 2, yesterday, but after the close of the Treasury cash and futures markets.
Weak economic data also gave comfort to the market, bolstering hopes for a cut in short-term interest rates by the Fed.
The Commerce Department reported that November wholesale inventories, or the stocks of unsold goods on wholesalers' shelves, fell four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the largest drop in inventories since March 1994, when they fell half of 1 percent. November sales were up four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a gain of a tenth of a percent in October.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said the market appeared to believe that the economy was headed for softer ground within the next couple of months.
"So despite the fear of budget problems which could cause rates to spike upwards," he said, "buyers are afraid to completely jump off the train."
Some of the cautiousness in yesterday's market, he said, may be a result of lackluster note auctions this week still weighing on investors' minds as they prepare for a new quarterly refunding in early February. The Treasury is expected to announce the size of its quarterly sales on Wednesday. The sales are expected to include a three-prong offering of about $43.7 billion of notes and bonds.
"Therefore, with a refunding that includes a bond issue, in addition to 3- and 10-year notes, the market faces a risk of indigestion," Mr. Chan said.

HEADLINE: Speedy Ride on the French Railway Gives One View of the Labor Strike

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BORDEAUX, France, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Claude Bouquet has been working on the railroad most of his life. Today his day began at the Montparnasse station in Paris at 7:39 A.M., when he hoisted himself into the engineer's cabin of a silver-and-blue, super-high-speed train so streamlined it seems to be streaking along even when standing still.
In six more years Mr. Bouquet will be 50, and as an engineer, he can retire from the French National Railways soon after that at 74 percent of full pay, which now averages about $3,400 a month before taxes and payroll deductions. 
 Generous provisions like these have brought the French railroads to the point where they now have 353,400 former employees or their survivors collecting pensions, and only 182,350 working railroaders -- one reason why the system was $35 billion in debt even before losses last year that were estimated at $3.2 billion more.
The French Government, which has owned the railroads since the 1930's, pays $4 billion of the $5.4 billion pension bill every year in one way or another, but when it proposed changing retirement rules for state employees to cut the ballooning state deficit, Mr. Bouquet and most of his colleagues went out on a three-week strike last month that paralyzed the country.
"If the Government hadn't put retirement age in question, the strike wouldn't have lasted longer than a week," he said. "I don't belong to a labor union, but when they told us that our pensions were in danger, I walked out, too."
Stung conservative politicians, economists and commentators have been asking since the strikes whether French workers will ever be willing to make the kinds of sacrifices in compensation, benefits and standard of living that American, British and other workers have accepted in the name of improving competitiveness.
A day spent with Mr. Bouquet provided some answers.
He lives near Tours in the Loire Valley of central France, a few blocks from the sprawling St.-Pierre-des-Corps depot where he started out as an apprentice worker in 1967. He had driven another train to Paris the night before and spent the night in railroad accommodations to be ready for his morning call.
Now he is at the head end of a double train with 20 passenger cars, the on-board computer in the electronic console programmed for the trip ahead as he waits for a bell from the conductor signaling him to start moving at 8:15.
He presses a lever and behind him, electric motors that generate 8,800 horsepower at maximum speed groan into action. The train, TGV 8409, begins threading its way out of the station.
Within a few minutes the train is on the left-hand track of the double-track high-speed main line to southwestern France and entering the three-mile-long tunnel at Villejuste. Mr. Bouquet keeps the speed to 130 miles an hour -- "These trains aren't pressurized, and going faster would make your ears hurt," he grins -- and then accelerates to maximum speed, 187 m.p.h.
"There are no visual signals on this line -- they all come into the console electronically, transmitted from Paris through the rails," he explains as the train wolfs down more than three miles a minute. "As long as I stay within the speed limit for the sector, I am in control, but the machine would take over if I didn't."
Half an hour after leaving Paris, the train has already covered 75 miles. Mr. Bouquet says that as a little boy he never dreamed of working on the railroad; he wanted to study at a university. "My father died when I was in high school, and my mother had to take me out of school and send me to work," he says. "I passed three aptitude tests and went to the railroad because they paid apprentices a small salary, and I needed one to help my mother."
A bell goes off reminding him to keep pressing the "dead man's pedal" designed to bring the train to a halt if a driver falls asleep or unconscious. Mr. Bouquet has worked Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday this week. After a three-hour pause, today's shift will end just before 6 P.M. when he drives another train from Bordeaux to Tours.
"The usual working week can have as few as two consecutive days, or as many as six," he says. "I'm guaranteed 112 days off a year, including at least 20 on weekends, and when I overnight at home, which is usually every other day, I am guaranteed 14 consecutive hours off between shifts."
That is in addition to paid holidays, and five weeks of vacation. Mr. Bouquet worked his way up through less sophisticated classes of locomotives to the high-speed trains over 23 years, but even now, at the top of his profession, he doesn't make a fortune by French standards. His base salary, before taxes, is $2,300 a month, supplemented by about $1,100 a month in night and holiday differentials and a bonus for distance traveled -- $54 for every 625 miles, a little more than what he will cover today.
If he puts in 37.5 years, he can collect the maximum pension of about three-quarters of gross pay. But according to special pension rules granted by the state in the days of steam when railroading was often blood, sweat and tears, engineers can retire at the age of 50.
"The Government never properly explained how the change in the pension system would work," Mr. Bouquet said. "Only the unions gave us their version, and the way that sounded, we were going to be forced to leave at 50 and have no option to keep working for the full pension benefit even if we wanted to."
Railroad officials said details were to have been worked out by a mediation board, but it went out of existence when the Government shelved the plan as a step toward ending the strikes.
Mr. Bouquet is aware of the calamitous state of French Government finances, with a deficit of more than $60 billion last year.
"The state takes plenty from us wage-earners, too," he says. "By the time my health insurance and pension deductions are taken out, I don't have much of my pay left. This year there's a new tax to pay off the health insurance deficit, and that will be another 160 or 200 francs a month," the equivalent of $32 to $40.
Arriving in Bordeaux three minutes ahead of schedule at 11:26, Mr. Bouquet watches passengers disembark before he moves his train off to the rail yard. "My wife works, but when I retire we'll do other things," he says. "I'm the president of a swimming club and I like sports, and I'm sure I'll find plenty to keep me occupied."
And the Government will find some other way to cut the deficit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Claude Bouquet, a French railroad engineer, checked his schedule as his high-speed train sped past the countryside at up to 187 miles an hour. (Craig Whitney/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Watchers Expect A Cut in Rates Next Week
Federal Reserve policy makers meet next week to discuss interest rates, and while many economists would expect lower rates, because of low inflation and signs of a slowing economy, the Fed will consider several unusual factors. There's the budget impasse, and the disruption in economic statistics.
Also, important decisions on the Fed leadership are looming. Many Fed watchers expect a quarter-point drop in short-term rates. [Page 36.]
 
The Senate passed stopgap spending legislation to keep the Government open for another seven weeks, at reduced spending levels. Efforts by Democrats to add amendments were defeated. [1.]
 
Mexico Making Payment to U.S.
Mexico plans to return on Monday the $1.3 billion it borrowed from the U.S. last year. It will still owe $10.5 billion, as well as $11 billion to the International Monetary Fund. Lately, Mexico's economic outlook has improved drastically, with its stock market at a historic high, interest rates plummeting and the battered peso showing signs of stability. But most Mexicans remain mired in a deep recession. [1.]
 
Dow Spurts to a Record
The Dow Jones average set its third record of the week, as investors grew less concerned about budget talks in Washington and on the strength of good corporate earnings. The Dow gained 54.92 points, to 5,271.75, for a rise of just over 1 percent. For the week, the Dow was up 87.07 points.[37.]
 
Treasury prices recovered from early losses on revived hopes of a Federal budget agreement. The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose a full point. Its yield fell to 6.04 percent from 6.11 percent. [36.]
 
Mattel Presses Hasbro
Mattel refuted Hasbro's contention that the breakdown of merger discussions was tied to antitrust concerns. Mattel said that during intense talks this week, Hasbro won a richer price for itself and the choice of its chairman as a co-chairman of the merged company. Hasbro shares rose $2.50, to $43, but remain well below the $52 offer from Mattel. [34.]
 
Perjury Charge at Tobacco Company
A former research chief of Brown & Williamson Tobacco, Jeffrey S. Wigand, testified that the company had engaged in perjury, destruction of evidence and the quashing of research into safer cigarettes, according to a transcript of sealed testimony given in Mississippi. [7.]
CBS broadcast an interview with Mr. Wigand that its legal team had previously barred. Since his deposition has been published, CBS said, it no longer faced a lawsuit. [1.]
 
Small Aid Package for Fokker
The Dutch Government said it would grant an emergency bailout package worth $219 million to Fokker, but acknowledged that the money would keep the aircraft maker from collapse for no more than six weeks. The amount is relatively small, but it does try to preserve thousands of jobs. [34.]
 
Investors Lift Sotheby's Stake
An investment group including Bass family members increased its stake in Sotheby's to 5.3 percent. It hinted that it would prod the auction house to act to lift its stock price, which has languished. [35.]
 
New Charges Against a Maxwell
Prosecutors who lost a high-profile fraud case against two sons of the British publisher Robert Maxwell said they would bring new charges against one son, Kevin, and three former company executives. [34.]
 
Funeral Homes Consolidate
Big chains now own 12 percent of the nation's funeral homes in urban areas and are quickly acquiring more. [6.]
 
Dollar Climbs Against Mark
The dollar rose against the mark but fell against the yen. The dollar was as high as 1.4940 marks, for the first time since Sept. 15. "It appears the market just likes the dollar over all," one banker said. [43.]
 
Chinese Buying Lifts Wheat Prices
Wheat prices surged after China finished a three-day buying spree equal to one-fourth of the wheat produced last year in Kansas. [43.]

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Fervent, Tough Manager

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
Lawrence G. Reuter, the man who was named yesterday to head the New York City Transit Authority, is both a self-described advocate for public transportation and, transit officials say, a tough budget-cutter in tune with an era of declining subsidies and rising costs.
There will be ample opportunity for him to use such facets of his professional personality when he takes over the nation's largest public transportation agency, sometime in March. 
 New York subway and bus riders face possibly painful service changes, and judging by the comments of people who worked with Mr. Reuter in his most recent position, as head of the Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, he will not shrink from them.
Faced with stagnant ridership in the capital and less money to provide service, Mr. Reuter cut some $200 million from the Washington agency's operating budget over the last two years. He cut about 700 jobs and bus service, consolidated departments and, through a new labor contract, encouraged workers to retire early.
And to avoid taking on new costs, he successfully opposed Federal regulators who ordered new subway platform edges in Washington to aid blind riders, saving some $30 million.
Four members of the Board of Directors of Washington's public transit agency praised Mr. Reuter's efforts, and expressed regret at his departure, noting that in the rarefied world of big-city transit managers, a replacement would not be easy to come by. "He's cut millions and millions and made very substantial reductions in the number of persons working for the system." said Gerry Hyland, a board member from Virginia. "That's not an easy thing."
But Mr. Reuter does not meet with universal praise in Washington. "He did little or nothing," said James Thomas, president of Local 689 of the Amalgamated Transit Union. "He inherited a system that practically operated itself."
"Of all the general managers that were here, I think he was anti-worker," Mr. Thomas said.
 But Mr. Reuter, 45, who worked for the New York transit system in the early 1980's, is described by others as unequivocally dedicated to mass transit. As head of the mass transit system in San Jose, Calif., between 1990 and 1994, he helped put the area's fledgling public transit system on a firm footing, said Rod Diridon, executive director of the International Institute for Surface Transportation Policy Studies, a government-funded think tank in San Jose. Mr. Reuter left San Jose for Washington in March 1994.
"To him, public transportation isn't just a job, it's a religion," said Mr. Diridon, a former chairman of the American Public Transit Association.
Mr. Reuter was a "major factor" in obtaining more government money for an extension of the light rail system, Mr. Diridon said, and he pushed hard for a half-cent sales-tax increase for public transit, approved by voters but struck down by California courts for violating a state law.
Mr. Reuter was born Jan. 12, 1951, in Somerspoint, N.J. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in engineering from Florida Technological University in Orlando, and in 1979 became an executive with the Railway Service Corporation, a Florida company that rebuilt freight and passenger car equipment.
He joined New York City's transit agency in 1982, rising rapidly through positions of increasing responsibility, thanks to the advocacy of David L. Gunn, a former agency head. Mr. Reuter served as general manager of the Staten Island Railway, vice president in charge of buses and subways, and eventually senior vice president of operations. "He's one of the best in the business," Mr. Gunn, now the general manager of the Toronto Transit Commission, said. "If you ride the subway you're lucky." Mr. Gunn said his former subordinate would "fight for the resources he needs to do the job."
An official with Local 100 of the Transit Workers Union said Mr. Reuter is remembered as "fair and reasonable, a good businessman." The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: "He could be trusted. If he gave his word, it was good."
Mr. Reuter has been negotiating for the New York job since November. E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said of Mr. Reuter in a statement yesterday: "After an extensive nationwide search, it was clear that Larry Reuter was the natural choice to run New York City Transit. He is unquestionably the most well-respected transit manager in the country and brings with him a major advantage in having previously managed the day-to-day operations of both New York City Transit's subways and buses."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Reuter said he looked forward to the challenge of running New York's bus and subway system, adding that he had missed it. "I would say I'm what I would consider a real advocate of public transportation," he said. "In most urban areas public transportation is absolutely essential, a great economic development tool."
Married with three children, Mr. Reuter is described as being devoted to his 17-year-old son, Jonathan, who suffers from the spinal birth defect spina bifida.
Perhaps the clearest demonstration of what several said is an essential element of his character -- a courteous firmness -- came last March, when Mr. Reuter went before a transportation subcommittee of the United States House of Representatives to declare that he would not replace the 18-inch wide granite edges on Washington's subway platforms with 24-inch ones with raised bumps, as Federal officials were ordering him to do, to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act. Advocates for the blind were divided on the issue; his own agency's study indicated they were not needed.
The Federal Transit Administration threatened to sue. Mr. Reuter told the subcommittee: "We're going to say no to putting those down." He was criticized by some on the committee at the crowded, contentious hearing. But ultimately Mr. Reuter won his fight, as well as praise for firm diplomacy.
"I thought at the time he was walking into a mare's nest," said Jeff Nelligan, a spokesman for the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, who was present that day. "I thought he wound up walking out with his dignity intact."

HEADLINE: Ever Quirky, and Now Gifted, Too;
With $42 Million, Bard College Joins a New League

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Small and slightly quirky liberal arts colleges tend to turn out almost as many poets as they do bankers. As a result, they seldom receive the king-sized gifts needed to entice talented professors and embellish their campuses.
But Bard College these days is smiling like a lovable misfit who managed to inherit most of the family fortune: it has received a gift totaling $42 million from three of its trustees. 
 This would have been impressive at an Ivy League school with a billion-dollar endowment, but it is particularly extraordinary at a school that was essentially reborn after World War II, a school whose endowment is only $22 million. Bennington College, a rival progressive school, has never received a gift larger than $3 million.
In one stroke, the gift allows Bard to more than double its endowment and eases the yearly pressures of raising money to make ends meet. Paradoxically -- and
paradox is a treasured intellectual concept at Bard -- the gift will help the school continue to move away from the clique of unconventional, arts-centered colleges like Bennington, Antioch and Hampshire, with which it is often compared, into the realm of more traditional colleges like Vassar and Wesleyan, with whom it is increasingly competing for students.
Building a more comprehensive school that maintains the Bard creed of idiosyncratic inquiry seems to have been the intent of the three donors, not one of them an alumnus. They are Richard B. Fisher, chairman of the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Leon Levy, general partner of Odyssey Partners, an investment firm, and Susan Weber Soros, director of Bard's Manhattan-based Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts and the wife of George Soros, the billionaire financier.
"These people are attracted to a place like Bard because the period of creative institution-building is in front of them, not behind them," said Dr. Leon Botstein, who as president for 20 years has orchestrated Bard's growth as masterfully as a symphonic conductor, which he also is. "These are people who made their money by doing something new, not something old. They haven't clipped coupons."
All this talk of new ventures is not to deny that Bard is still what the poet John Ashbery, a Bard literature professor, calls a "a really individual, slightly eccentric liberal arts college."
On a gently rolling campus about 25 miles north of Poughkeepsie with stately views of the Hudson River, professors have wide latitude to shape their own courses, and papers are preferred over tests. Classes are small and requirements flexible; seminars outnumber lectures.
The science offerings tend to be fairly straightforward and the menu limited. But in the arts and social studies, professors seem to have a fondness for thematic or provocative courses over pure survey classes.
In a course called Florence, a student examines not just Florentine writers like Dante and Machiavelli, but, for instance, the paintings of Botticelli, to discover what about Florence brought out such passionate feelings in its citizens. The history department offers a semester-long course called the Decision to Drop the Bomb.
Critics have accused Dr. Botstein of a kind of flabby intellectual chic, but he says he believes it important to immerse students in beguiling content, through writing or performing, before giving them the broad historic sweep that some schools feel should come first.
"When you teach someone baseball," he said, "they get invested in knowing what the rules are because they have enjoyed the act of hitting and catching. You don't sit them down and teach them the rule book."
Students like Joshua Birenbaum, a senior from San Jose, Calif., seem to thrive. He is a law and philosophy major who likes to point out that he scored in the 99th percentile on his Law School Assessment Test -- an accomplishment that belies Bard's reputation, acquired in the 1960's, for flaky, drugged-out students.
"It's similar to what you see with children learning," he said of Bard's philosophy. "They're grasping at objects they're interested in. By taking the detail classes, you'll want to get the survey approach."
Yet Dr. Botstein believes that students need a foundation in the classics, and Bard requires a first year of great texts, even though the teachers may balance "The Odyssey" with a more obscure work like the Hindu epic "The Ramayana."
Despite its offbeat image, Bard's admissions standards -- and its tuition, room and board of $26,934 -- rank it among elite schools. It admits 50 percent of its applicants, and the average entrant scores 1230 on the Scholastic Assessment Test. Almost 70 percent of its students receive financial aid.
"I wanted a small school, a rural school, a school that was really about education and not getting a degree so you could get a good job," said Emily Stuart, a senior from Winston-Salem, N.C.
Allison Slavid, a senior from Needham, Mass, said: "The people who like it here are the people who when you were young you liked to have over on a rainy day. They were the people with the best ideas."
The trustees give Dr. Botstein much of the credit for the college's growth. He is tall and wears owlish glasses; his surviving hair is curled as tightly as steel wool. His office has the look of a West Side intellectual's redoubt, with books piled haphazardly on shelves and copies of magazines like Daedalus and The New York Review of Books vying for desk space with a package of Sudafed. In his spare time, he is the chief conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra.
His delivery can be loftily Shakespearean, but in a conversation bristling with Wittgenstein and Mahler, there remain the Yiddishisms of a Holocaust refugee childhood. He described a fierce rainstorm outside his neo-Gothic office as shreklech -- frightening -- and the large libraries maintained by Harvard and Yale as a tsorah, or travail.
Dr. Botstein, 49, came to Bard in 1975 when it had 600 students, a $100,000 endowment, mountains of debt, an inadequate gym and a congested library. Now the college has 1,000 students, no debt, a new gym and a new library; it is midway through a three-year campaign that has raised $83 million.
"We worked hard to try to figure out what's a good curriculum," Dr. Botsein said. "If we were rich and secure we would never have been inventive."
The college has grafted on graduate programs in economics, environmental studies, curatorial studies and decorative arts, and it is planning a new performing arts center and student center. Its faculty includes such stars as Chinua Achebe, the Nigerian novelist; James Chace, the author of nine books on international affairs, and Elizabeth Frank, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1985 for a biography of the poet and critic Louise Bogan.
Dr. Botstein shrugs off suggestions that he pried out the millions he has raised by his considerable charm.
"I believe profoundly in the importance of what is being done," he said. "It is not about some superficial socializing. It is about having a goal that needs doing and making the person who is giving the money feel an integral part of solving the problem. The donor is not simply a cash machine."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
MEXICO TO REPAY PART OF U.S. LOAN

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Responding to signs of its economic recuperation and impatience in the Clinton Administration for repayment, Mexico plans to return on Monday the $1.3 billion it borrowed from the United States last year.
While Mexico will still owe the United States $10.5 billion, as well as more than $11 billion to the International Monetary Fund, the planned installment on Monday underscores the Government's ability to bounce back after a disastrous economic crisis that brought Mexico to the brink of national insolvency and threatened the stability of other markets around the world. 
 In Washington, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said: "The program is working to restore stability and the basis for growth. We are confident the United States will be paid back with interest for the assistance we have provided to Mexico under the support program."
In recent weeks, Mexico's economic outlook has changed markedly from the gloomy days of devaluation and near default a year ago.
The stock market has climbed to a historic high, interest rates have plummeted, the badly battered peso has shown signs of stability and there have been a few indications that unemployment, while still punishingly high, is easing slightly.
But the street-level economy where most Mexicans live and work remains deeply mired in one of the worst recessions this century. While exports have soared on the strength of a weaker peso, domestic sales nosedived. Inflation has eroded wage increases to the point that the buying power of most workers declined by 30 percent last year, and record numbers of cars and houses were repossessed by Mexican banks, which themselves are reeling badly from the crisis.
"In general things are getting better," said Jonathan Heath, an economist in Mexico City. "But you have to be very wary of how you interpret the indicators. Unemployment may have gone down but I can assure you we haven't created many jobs recently. People are adjusting. Some are taking half-time jobs, some taking jobs that pay less and some are so discouraged they're simply not looking for work anymore."
Monday's repayment is expected to help defuse criticism of President Clinton's handling of the Mexican crisis just as the first Presidential primary elections are near.
"It's 100 percent politics," Mr. Heath said. "The United States is starting the primary season and its wants to be paid back. They don't want Mexico to be shoved back in their faces."
To repay the money, Mexico plans to capitalize on one of the most striking aspects of its recovery strategy. Even though a year ago the Government had lost almost all of its foreign currency reserves and was facing a seemingly unpayable mountain of debt, Mexico has returned successfully to the international capital markets, including a recent sale exceeding $1 billion in debt denominated in German marks.
The proceeds from that sale will be used to repay most of the American loan. The rest will presumably come from the $16 billion Mexico now has in its reserves.
"Mexico rapidly regained access to international capital markets and has established the basis for the resumption of growth," Mr. Rubin said in Washington.
Mexico has several reasons for acting now. On Monday $1.3 billion of short-term money it borrowed from the United States falls due. It represents part of $2 billion in short-term American loans that Mexico borrowed last February to avoid default. The $2 billion had a term of just 90 days and Mexico had extended it several times. The Government paid back $700 million in October, and then extended the unpaid portion one more time.
So far Mexico has paid $750 million in interest.
In all, Mexico has used $13.5 billion of the total $20 billion authorized by the United States. That includes $1 billion that was used to pay back money borrowed under an earlier rescue program. The total owed by Mexico therefore never exceeded $12.5 billion.
Some of the early signs of Mexico's tentative recovery have been strong, even if there is no indication they can be sustained. Last Tuesday the Mexican stock exchange reached a high of 3,087 points and the peso strengthened to 7.33 to the dollar, its highest value since last November. Later in the week, the stock exchange lost some ground while the peso-dollar exchange rate remained firm.
Interest rates on Government treasury certificates this week dropped to 37.23 percent; last year those rates exceeded 80 percent.
The Mexican Treasury Department has announced that for the first time in five years, Mexico had a huge surplus in its commercial trade balance. Helped by the cheaper peso, Mexican exports soared 31 percent in 1995 while imports declined by 8.6 percent. In all, Mexico exported $7.39 billion more in goods and services than it imported.
Mexico has also drastically revamped its overall debt, refinancing most short-term loans and spreading out payment in such a way that its chances of default have been considerably reduced.
The thorniest debt problem last year was represented by the dollar-denominated treasury bonds, called Tesobonos. At the beginning of 1995, Mexico had just over $29 billion of Tesobonos outstanding, and most of the money was due in less than a year.
As of this week, 99.6 percent of the Tesobonos have been paid off, leaving just $115.7 million.
Mexico's emergency recovery program has not been entirely successful. Inflation for 1995 reached 52 percent, far exceeding original forecasts. Thousands of businesses have closed and many others are barely surviving.
Last year was the most violent and crime-ridden year in Mexico City since the 1910 Revolution and many middle-class Mexican families have doubled the height of the concrete walls that traditionally surround Mexican homes. Installers of electrified fences are among the few local companies to have had a banner year.
One sign of the contrast between Mexico's progress and its pain is that on Monday, just as the Government is scheduled to proudly pay back the $1.3 billion to the United States, a group of desperate Mexican debtors intends to act out being tortured and burned outside the Association of Mexican Banks in a demonstration of their frustration.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEW THINKING ON POLLING;
Changing Opinions Through Information and Debate

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A little bit of reliable information, plus plenty of time to digest it and debate it, can be a liberating thing.
When the 459 randomly selected, demographically diverse delegates to the National Issues Convention arrived in Austin, Tex., on Jan. 18, 59.3 percent said they thought the Federal Government spent too much on foreign aid. Twenty-six percent thought the level of aid, $17 billion, or 1.1 percent of Federal expenditures in 1994, was about right. 
 By the time the delegates left town three days later, the ranks of the too-much camp had shrunk to 47.7 percent of delegates. And the ranks of those who thought the level of foreign aid spending was "about right" had swelled to 40.7 percent.
"Support for foreign aid solidified," said Prof. James S. Fishkin of the University of Texas, who organized the $4 million convention sponsored by the University of Texas at Austin and the Presidential Libraries.
"Instead of wanting to cut it, as they did at the beginning, they wanted to maintain it after the deliberations," said Professor Fishkin. "Afterwards, when they got better information about foreign aid, they were no longer interested in cutting it." In the pre-deliberation poll, filled out by each delegate before going to Austin, 24 percent had mistakenly believed that foreign aid was the largest part of the Federal budget.
For Professor Fishkin, those shifts in thinking are evidence of the value of encouraging Americans to deliberate in a serious way so that they can make informed judgments.
The experiment in Austin included a pre-deliberation poll and briefing materials on the family, the economy and foreign policy prepared by Public Agenda and the Kettering Foundation, two research organizations. Intensive small-group discussions as well as televised forums with issue experts, four Republican Presidential candidates and Vice President Al Gore were held, and there was a post-deliberation poll at the close of the convention.
Some experts in opinion research criticized Professor Fishkin's experiment as expensive and artificial, since it is conducted in a setting that takes people out of their everyday environment.
But he said his goal was to supplement traditional survey research, not supplant it.
"Lots of polls represent top-of-the-head judgments, or even what Philip Converse -- the University of Michigan -- calls nonattitudes, or phantom opinions," he said Thursday after the results were released. "Sometimes polls communicate things where people don't have any opinion at all but they are obliging in just giving some answer to a question. And there is nothing there. Or it's very top of the head, just a vague impression of sound bites."
Delegates to the convention, a random sample that mirrors the entire country, selected by the National Opinion Research Center, which is affiliated with the University of Chicago, reached conclusions that should encourage both Democrats and Republicans in Washington
For example, Democrats who favor increasing the minimum wage should like the way support grew among delegates for this proposition: "The average worker does not receive a fair day's pay for a fair day's work."
The pre-deliberation poll found that 26.6 percent of delegates strongly agreed; 32.8 percent somewhat agreed; 29.6 percent disagreed somewhat; and 6.7 percent disagreed strongly. In the post-deliberation poll, the strongly agree group climbed to 40.4 percent and those in the agree somewhat category grew slightly to 34.6 percent. The group that disagreed somewhat dropped to 18.9 percent from 29.6 percent. And the group that disagreed strongly fell to 4.2 percent from 6.7 percent.
Republicans should be heartened by the shift in thinking about the social safety net and which level of government should control it heartening. The pre-deliberation poll found that 49.5 percent of the delegates wanted the states to handle the money and decide how much support to offer the poor. Support for that view shot up to 62.5 percent in the post-deliberation poll.
While delegates did not have specific briefing papers on the flat tax, the idea that has drawn so much attention to Steve Forbes's Republican Presidential bid, there was a drastic shift in attitudes about a flat tax.
When asked if they would prefer replacing the current graduated income tax with a single-rate flat tax, 43.5 percent of delegates in the pre-deliberation poll favored it and 43 percent opposed it. In the post-deliberation poll, support for a generic flat tax fell to 29.8 percent, opposition rose to 49.7 percent.
And the group saying they did not know what they thought rose to 20.5 percent from 13.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Whitman Budget Rides on Optimism

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 26.

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman delivered her celebrated campaign promise to cut state income tax rates a year ahead of schedule, but she has yet to move as aggressively on her other campaign pledge to make government "smarter and smaller."
State spending has risen $700 million since Mrs. Whitman took office two years ago and she has not fully paid the cost of the $1.2 billion reduction in income tax revenues with equivalent cuts in spending. 
 Now, as Mrs. Whitman prepares to present her third state budget on Monday, she will seek to hold the line on overall spending and make some of the tough spending choices that critics say she has deferred. Much of the success of the $16 billion budget will depend on the state's economy. And almost every week there is another indicator that suggests the economy is faltering and not producing as many jobs as she had predicted her tax cuts would create.
With Republican moderates promoting Mrs. Whitman as a vice-presidential prospect, it is important that the local economy remain stable if she is to maintain her national standing and high poll ratings among New Jersey voters. On Thursday, senior Whitman administration officials, disputing recent reports that suggest a sharp downturn in the New Jersey economy, projected moderate growth in the coming year. At the same time, they revised downward their revenue forecast for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30.
Neil Upmeyer, president for the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton, N.J., said: "What she has done is to take the politically attractive route of first cutting taxes -- and by doing so, what she is doing is starving government. The problems are compounded by economic problems. And so now, she is going to have to confront the spending cuts."
In the last two years, Governor Whitman and the Legislature have been able to lower income taxes, along with some business taxes, without making huge spending cuts. They employed budgetary maneuvers that some critics say were too risky and that the Whitman administration insists were fiscally prudent. These included reducing the state's contribution to public-employee pension systems; stretching out debt payments for $1.3 billion in state transportation bonds to 20 years from 10, and pulling "surplus" dollars out of various state trust funds.
On Thursday, State Treasurer Brian Clymer said that he planned to help balance the budget by drawing $249 million in surplus funds from the state's Temporary Disability Benefit Fund general account. Both employers and employees regularly contribute to the account, which distributes benefits to disabled people for as long as to 26 weeks.
By using this fund and ordering a round of budget cuts quietly last fall, Mr. Clymer was also able to announce that the state's projected budget surplus for this fiscal year would grow to $900 million from $550 million.
But other fiscal problems remain, because the Governor and the Legislature have deferred some tough decisions. They are under pressure to replenish an expired state fund that provides $400 million for hospital care for the poor. They are also required this year to resolve the dispute over spending inequities between wealthy and poor school districts.
Mr. Clymer announced on Thursday that plans were under way for state agencies to trim more than $300 million from their budgets this year. And he has asked state commissioners to present plans showing how they would cut their budgets up to 20 percent for the new fiscal year. He said the process allowed commissioners to identify the most important services their agencies now provide taxpayers. Governor Whitman has spent much of the last two weeks studying the proposals and determining what services to keep and what to spare. Her administration is expected to unveil highlights of the spending components of her budget plan on Saturday.
In this budget, the administration is also looking to fold the Banking Department into the Department of Insurance. Until now, the Whitman administration has not taken major steps to streamline the state bureaucracy. So far, it saved $6 million by eliminating two small state agencies, the Department of Higher Education and the Department of the Public Advocate.
The Whitman administration's most successful effort to curb government spending has been in getting the state's largest public employee union late last year to agree to a four-year pact with a wage freeze in the first two years and a requirement, for the first time, for workers to pay for part of their traditional medical coverage.
Governor Whitman set the tone earlier in the year that she intended to be tough in labor talks when she flung open the tollbooths along the New Jersey Turnpike last Fourth of July weekend rather than cave into the demands of striking toll-takers.
At the same time, the administration has had little success with its ambitious plans to reduce spending by putting government services in the hands of outside contractors. Of the $60 million that the Governor had anticipated saving in this year's budget, about $10 million has been realized. The administration saved another $600,000 when employees at the New Jersey Veterans Memorial Home in Paramus came up with a plan to cut costs rather than have the veterans home turned over to an outside contractor. Plans for a private management company to take over the state's prison health system are stalled due to a dispute over the bidding of the contract.
For the most part, efforts to turn over government services to the private sector have affected state workers who were not earning large salaries. They include mostly custodians and day-care workers, as well as motor vehicle clerks who were not offered competitive wages and benefits when the Whitman administration turned over 24 regional offices of the State Department of Motor Vehicles last summer to private management companies.
The Whitman administration's inability to get large privatization efforts off the ground is one of the reasons there has not been a significant decrease in the state work force in the last two years, as had been expected.
