SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3178 words

HEADLINE: What's in a Mohawk?

BYLINE: By RJ Smith; RJ Smith is a contributing editor of Details. This is his first article for the Times Magazine.

 BODY:
EVEN FOR A BREAK-ALL-THE-RULES PUNK ROCK BAND, some rules still apply. It's 10 minutes to stage, and the members of Rancid are sitting in their tour bus, parked behind the the Horticulture Building at the Utah State Fair Park in Salt Lake City.
"Hey, Lars, wanna put up my 'hawk?" the band's 30-year-old lead singer and guitarist, Tim Armstrong, asks the 24-year-old guitarist, Lars Frederiksen. 
 "You ever seen a mohawk being put up before?" Armstrong asks. "First, you gotta put on a punk rock record."
"It could be a G.B.H. record, or it could be the Sex Pistols," chimes in Frederiksen. "Tonight it's Green Day, because they are our friends and we love them." He sounds like the Frugal Gourmet patiently explaining the value of preheating the oven.
Armstrong's color of choice is Midnight Blue, the brand Manic Panic. He shaves the sides of his head every other day so they shine. Frederiksen deftly divides the crest of hair into six spikes, twisting each to a point and dousing it with Aqua Net Ultimate Hold. Then he bakes the whole thing with a hair dryer.
"Ultimate Hold, the poor man's quick fix," boasts Frederiksen.
"But the best is Knox gelatin," says Armstrong sub rosa. "That's the punk rocker's secret."
Frederiksen stands back and admires his handiwork -- a crown that could pop balloons. Finished, the artist asks for the time. Ten minutes and four Green Day songs have passed, and four punk action figures go to battle: Frederiksen and Armstrong wear bondage pants and combat boots; the bassist, Matt Freeman, 29, is in all black, and the drummer, Brett Reed, 23, looks like a tattooed Ed Norton.
Some bands achieve hugeness; others stumble off the bus only to find it thrust upon them. The latter seems to be the case with Rancid. They started four and a half years ago, Bay Area homeboys with absolutely no ambition but to hang together as friends and punk rock fans. They made two records for the Los Angeles-based independent label Epitaph. They toured in one ratty Econoline van or another. They became local heroes.
Around the same time, Seattle grunge, a new strain of hard rock with a sound reminiscent of late-70's punk, was sweeping the country with a little help from MTV and the summer Lollapalooza tours. Record company executives called the music alternative, but with groups like Pearl Jam, Nirvana and Soundgarden selling millions of records, the question was, alternative to what?
Punk became the answer, or rather the answer again, the next logical step for kids looking for a little more rebellion in their music. Back in 1977, British punk was a working-class music that with a few chords and a lot of volume tried to disassemble the pop tune. It chewed up melodies, scoffed at arrangements. Punk wanted to smash things up -- the idea of a hit record, of the pop star, of the record business.
Back then, punk's anger had the ability to shock even its own fans. But punk in the age of Rancid, Green Day, the Offspring and the flood of bands now signed to major labels is as tuneful as anything on the radio. It's still hopping mad, and radiates the hostility that made grunge a household word. But this punk is different from grunge too. Grunge is noisier, darker, less catchy and far less political than the music that Rancid and Green Day are making. Its attitude is me-against-the-world, not punk's us-versus-them. Today's punkers have returned class identity to pop radio; they talk about the disenfranchised nobility of "the kids" the way Woody Guthrie once talked about the farmer.
Today's punk is having one of the same problems as grunge -- the curse of its own popularity. Rancid's original fans loved the music because it shot away from the mainstream, but the new punk has been devouring the mainstream. By the end of last year Green Day's "Dookie" had sold an estimated eight million and the Offspring's "Smash" five million. Madonna started coming to Rancid shows, and sent a naked photograph of herself, pleading with the band to sign with her label instead of Epic, which offered a deal worth $1.5 million. At the peak of the bidding war, Rancid turned them both down. The band re-signed with Epitaph, which released Rancid's new " . . . And Out Come the Wolves" in August. Even though the musicians stayed at the label where they were comfortable, the pressure continued to grow.
"Personally, I try not to think of it too much," says Matt Freeman. He smacks a fresh pack of Winstons so hard that when he pulls one out, the cigarette is bent like a nail. "It's like being in the eye of the tornado, everything's gradual. Think about it: you never see your friend get fat. But maybe if you go away for a few months and then come back. . . . "
The band has been away, touring Europe while the new record was released. Now Rancid is playing a sold-out show in Salt Lake City, its bus parked beside a marker commemorating where the Donner Party crossed the Jordan River. Rancid has found its own crossroads, the X where punk rock and the mass audience meet.
When the lights go down in the Horticulture Building, fans squeeze in like ears of corn -- fans who have driven from Wyoming, Idaho and all parts of Utah. Rancid's music recreates the world of late-70's punk the way a Southern preservation society might recreate a Civil War battle -- not literally, but with disparate pieces blurred together by memory and longing. The California-born Armstrong sings with a British accent, the guitars ring of anthems long silenced and the rhythms bubble with souped-up ska, the reggae beat the original punks loved.
The sound in Salt Lake City is mangled by the room's barnlike acoustics, but the band doesn't care. When Rancid roars into "Salvation," about Armstrong's stay in a Salvation Army shelter and his job picking up donated appliances door to door, the crowd jumps. It's the video of this song that made the band MTV sensations. The packed concrete floor of the Horticulture Building breaks up into honeycomb cells of thrashing fans spinning in circles, rocketing off one another.
Afterward I ask Sarah Kessenich, 17, what she thought of the show. She pulls my hand to a golf-ball-size knot on the back of her head, beneath her blue hair. "I wanted to jump up and kiss Tim -- but when I tried to, a bouncer dropped me on my head," she says. She has pats of blood on her white T-shirt and says she passed out twice tonight. She looks radiant. "It was a total punk-rock show. One of the best I've ever seen." Kessenich and four friends come from Evanston, Wyo., 90 miles away. In Evanston, they get beat up by the dozen or so local jocks -- or sportos, as they call them.
Rancid gave these kids a feeling of acceptance for who they are, but now they face new misery: the same people who torment them for dressing like punks are turning into Rancid fans by the thousands. Tonight punks have even been shoved aside by snowboarders and sportos racing to the heart of the mosh pit.
At show's end, there's a convergence far stranger than the alchemy of jock and punk. A few buildings away in State Fair Park, a cowboy dance is winding down. And so two groups become one, Stetsons and studs, cowboys and mohawked punks, all searching for their cars under the lights as the mainstream reshapes itself.
"I COULDN'T BE HAPPIER," SAYS BRETT GUREWITZ, between phone calls in his Los Angeles office. He unwraps a grape sucker -- the perfect joke on the mogul's cigar -- and ostentatiously savors it before describing the demographic of the Rancid audience. Gurewitz, a former guitarist with the punk band Bad Religion, is the sole owner of the Epitaph label, which sold millions of punk records last year. Using custom software and market research, he's able to peg his target base.
"Today's Rancid fans are high-school- and college-age kids, probably mostly male, who are tired of listening to their big brother's music. Mostly suburban. Let's say he's an 18-year-old kid, he's got a skateboard and a bike, he's got a boom box. Besides Rancid he also probably likes to listen to the Wu-Tang Clan, probably also likes to listen to Pennywise, probably also likes to listen to Coolio. He feels somewhat disenfranchised by the pace and change in today's culture. He hates being called 'Generation X.' He's a typical young rock-and-roller."
On Sunset Boulevard, a long line of typical young rock-and-rollers is snaking past guards, past a lunch truck and far beyond the Deco-era dance hall Rancid will play tonight. I'm hanging out with a group of 10 fans who drove down from Victorville, a California desert town 85 miles outside of Los Angeles, as they wait for their body search on the way into the club. "This is gonna be my fourth show," boasts Scotty Riddle. He points to the empty space on his right arm where he plans to get a Rancid tattoo.
What do they do for fun in Victorville? "Come down here," four of them say at once. That, they add, and skate.
One day while skateboarding the streets of Victorville, David Armijo stopped into a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant for a bite. He walked right up to the counter and then he spotted the taped-up sign: WE DON'T SERVE SKATERS. He felt mad at the restaurant, he said, but maybe he also felt strangely good.
"They think you're an outsider, and they kick you out of places," he sighs.
"How can they do that?," asks Joe Trozera. "That's so illegal."
"We said to the guy at the counter, 'You can't outcast someone in a group,' says Armijo. "And he just said, 'Let's see you try and do something about it.' Then they kicked us out!"
For some of Rancid's biggest fans, it's this mark of the outcast that defines their sense of who they are. Greg Dalton lives in the San Gabriel Valley, east of Los Angeles. "I skate, I party, I listen to music, that's about it," says the 17-year-old. He loved Rancid's first two albums, and he loves the scorn his friends once heaped on him for it. "That became the whole point for me. I liked it when people told me that. I wanted to be part of it.
"Skateboarding's like that too. The reason skating and punk get wrapped up together is they've both always been hated by everybody. Skaters are hated by businesses and the police -- you screw up the streets. Everybody used to bag on me for skating, and now they're all dressing up like skaters. The whole scene's sold out," he says sadly.
Jon Steward recently shaved off his mohawk, but his is not the cue ball look of a skinhead tough. His gentle, asymmetrical face meets you with friendliness. It's extremely white, suggesting light reflected off the moon.
"My family, they kicked me out when I got a mohawk," he says. "I'm a college dropout. I got kicked out because of the things I did, hanging out with the wrong crowd. But now, it's cool."
"People put you down, but the punk crowd's not like that. It's cool. People accept you in punk, and they don't care about anyone else." Steward came to the Hollywood show by himself, and waits in line alone.
"I hang out with myself. If people can't accept me for who I am, they can just [expletive] off. I'm not gonna change for no one else." He stands very close as we talk, looking right into my eyes. He doesn't blink.
"When you go to shows, you meet so many friends. I don't hang out with them after the show, but, like, during the show you become like best friends with them. That's what it's about."
His father left the family when Jon was 4; he says he doesn't know what his mother does for a living. "Now I'm living in my car, in Pasadena or, just, wherever. I can't get a job. No one hires you with mohawks. People stare, they judge you on how you look. If I get a job, I'll work hard."
Today's punks are part of the first generation to grow up knowing they had no birthright to an expanding economy. They were marinated in gloom -- the media maxim about the pie growing smaller might as well have been flashed hourly on MTV. To teen-agers, it was an unavoidable prescription of failure.
The skaters driven out of Kentucky Fried Chicken, the mohawk kicked out of the house -- in ways big and small, Rancid speaks to people who feel persecuted by the adult world. That's a sentiment older than Frankie Avalon. But Frankie saw the future as an endless summer; to Rancid the future promises diminishing returns.
The band telegraphs that it cares about its fans, that there is little distance between them. In this way modern punk shares a lot more with Bruce Springsteen or John Mellencamp than with the Sex Pistols. It celebrates covert companionship, friendships built as bulwarks against public institutions. There's a loyalty to one's set almost as thick as that among street gangs. And like a gangbanger, a fan's loyalty is ultimately to an abstraction, an irreducible essence that guides one through the night.
LIFE BEGINS AT THE 7-ELEVEN. CERTAINLY there's no better vantage from which to chart Rancid's career than the parking lot of the Solano Avenue 7-Eleven in Albany, Calif. There, in a town just north of Berkeley, Armstrong and Freeman spent the late 80's hanging out while Armstrong's brother Jeff worked the counter. And there, this afternoon, Matt Freeman pulls in to buy an armful of Diet Cokes. He's driving Brett Reed's 1970 Impala, ankle-deep with fast food wrappers, empty soda cans and unpaid parking tickets. He points out the big new houses of town. These days his dad, a retired cop who raised Matt here, couldn't afford to live in Albany.
When we get to the house he grew up in, Freeman points to where he first saw a little kid riding his bike down the street. That was Armstrong.
Their bond is the root of Rancid. They were in Little League at the same time, went to high school together and then formed the ska band Operation Ivy. After the 1989 breakup of Operation Ivy, stars of a Berkeley punk scene that included Green Day, Freeman watched Armstrong, whose father was an alcoholic, fall apart. He'd drink 20 and more beers in a day, and then take Valium. Waking up on the street, Armstrong would stagger away to another round. He worked in pizza joints, sold tie-dye to the hippies on Telegraph Avenue and spent every cent on alcohol. Friends were abandoning him in droves.
Three times Armstrong's drinking and drugging landed him in the hospital. When nobody else would put up with him anymore, Freeman and Jeff Armstrong drove him to detox centers, and ultimately to a Salvation Army shelter. After two weeks there, and after a black resident mistook him for a right-wing skinhead and threatened to kill him, Armstrong swore off alcohol forever.
"It was never a question of, 'Let's get sober so we can get the band together again.' I threw that out the window after a while. I was working, doing my own life," says Freeman. "It was a question of taking care of my friend. When we got Rancid together, it was just something for him to do. He said, 'I need something in my life, I need something to shoot for.' It just rolled from there.
"I'm not an expert on alcoholics, and I don't feel comfortable telling people what to do. I was just sticking by him. I loved the guy, and I didn't want to see him die. He was the only best friend I ever had." Freeman stops for a minute. He has to, because suddenly he's crying.
Armstrong hasn't had a drink since Aug. 1, 1991. As if to tempt fate, he lives, with Reed, two floors above a liquor store in a scary part of Berkeley. They started Rancid with the most modest goals. They returned to Gilman Street, the cooperatively run club that was the site of Operation Ivy's finest moments; they rehearsed there in exchange for cleaning the toilets.
"It was a nightmare," Armstrong says excitedly. "But sometimes I think alcohol saved my [expletive]. I don't regret any one drink I ever had, I swear I don't, I had to go through it. What else can a 13-year-old kid do? Alcoholic family, total chaos all the time."
Frederiksen's father bailed out when Lars was 3, and his mom worked as a keypunch operator during the week and was an Avon Lady on weekends to support Lars and his brother. He grew up near San Jose, drinking with the street punks, getting arrested more than once. He, too, cleaned up.
Sitting in an empty room on the Los Angeles set for the band's latest video, Frederiksen could be the ultimate product of punk evolution. He's wearing shoes known in Britain as creepers, the thin suspenders he calls "skinhead braces," black slacks rolled neatly above the ankle and several nose rings.
He's perched in a cavernous bedroom of a 1905 mansion located on a South-Central block. It has decayed beautifully, this house that's boarded up except when rented for videos and horror-movie shoots. All around Frederiksen the plaster is peeling, there are holes knocked in the walls, broken light fixtures. This could be a squatter's castle, and he could be its punk rock philosopher king, bouncing on the balls of his feet.
"I wouldn't say I had a hard life, but I remember eating Raisin Bran for dinner a bunch of times," he says. "All of us are from single-parent homes. We watched either our mother or father go out and kick [expletive] for a living. I think that's where we get this work ethic.
"We're all like a pack of badgers," he says. "If you attack one of us, we'll regroup and we'll attack you. We didn't grow up in nice neighborhoods, we didn't go to college. We've got tattoos on our necks."
He'd go on, but he's been called to the set, where a stylist is applying makeup for the shoot.
The band mime their song "Ruby Soho" dozens of times for the camera while the album version blasts from speakers. Between takes Epitaph's Brett Gurewitz works the room like a boxing trainer, keeping the energy up. He pats the director on the arm, gives the thumbs-up to a cameraman, mouths "looks great"to Armstrong. When there's a longer break, he settles on the front porch, pulls an I.B.M. Thinkpad from a green briefcase and makes notes to himself.
One by one, band members drift out. They sit together and watch the cars pass their hillside manor surrounded by a cyclone fence. What ensues is a classic California punk rock discourse: tattoos and hot rods, hot rods and tattoos. Everybody argues about who's got the most botched inking. Then somebody mentions a road rally that a group of punkers are putting on, Los Angeles to Florida. Gurewitz suddenly stands up, palms out.
"O.K., here's what you do," he begins. It's seminar time. "You want to win this thing, you go to the auto parts store. You buy every kind of radar-detector there is. You line them up around the inside of your car. From every angle, you're covered. Then -- you just floor it."
Everybody hoots. Down on the street, a little kid rides by on a bicycle.
Tomorrow Rancid flies to Seattle and begins a U.S. tour. Tomorrow the band will take Gurewitz's advice and floor it. But right this moment, in this mansion on the hill, this broken home, right now the band members have set up house. They're shooting the breeze, watching the sun set. People say you don't get to pick your family. But sometimes, maybe you do.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2039 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Quick: Name a New Musical Star

BYLINE: By ETHAN MORDDEN; Ethan Mordden is the author of "Broadway Babies: The People Who Made the American Musical" and "Rodgers and Hammerstein."

 BODY:
YOU'RE GOING OUT THERE A youngster," Warner Baxter warns the young Ruby Keeler at the climax of the 1933 film "Forty-Second Street," "but you've got to come back a star!" Baxter's urgent tone reflects a terror of unemployment at the height of the Depression. "Two hundred people!," he emphasizes. "Two hundred jobs!" Nevertheless, Keeler's split-second glance of elation as she cases the auditorium after stepping on stage tells us her agenda is less social welfare than that Great American Privilege, fame.
This is reasonable; this is theater. Throughout its golden age of Jerome Kern, Rodgers and Hart, the Gershwins and Cole Porter, the Broadway musical specialized in the induction of fresh talent. Just as Keeler replaces an injured (but also aging, therefore, as Hollywood sees it, powerless) Bebe Daniels in "Forty-Second Street," so there was a constant absorption and elevation of newcomers. 
 That's all finished now. The musical has lost the ability to sustain the integration of new star talent. When a uniquely charismatic performer does appear, there is no follow-up role to proclaim his or her arrival -- no "Funny Girl," say, to celebrate the discovery of a Barbra Streisand in "I Can Get It for You Wholesale," a show she stole so thoroughly that she made one of the greatest show-biz careers not only possible but absolutely necessary (even if it took her away from the theater for life).
This is why theatergoers have been so enthusiastic about the appearance, in a single season, of three of the most popular musical-comedy stars of the post-World War II era: Carol Channing, Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett (though Ms. Burnett, in a comedy, isn't singing). This trio recalls a time in Broadway's history when going out there a youngster and coming back a star meant something to the great majority of Americans. Today, the culture looks elsewhere for its show-biz stars -- to the movies, as always, but also to television, pop music, even politics and crime. Theater, in 1990's America, is a backwater.
But when the young Carol Channing made her debut in the revue "Lend an Ear" in 1948, revealing a hit-and-run personality and a voice that covers every note between moan and squeak, it was virtually a cultural imperative that she be feted -- or tested, perhaps? -- in another show, this time in a star part. As Ms. Channing had won particular notice in a spoof of 20's musicals in "Lend an Ear," her next engagement the following year was a 20's spinoff, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," in which she played that decade's most essential gold digger, the cunning yet loopy Lorelei Lee.
Oddly, Julie Andrews also arrived in a burlesque of the 20's, the English musical "The Boy Friend," in 1954. But where Ms. Channing was daffy, Ms. Andrews was cool, elegant, porcelain with a human face. After a little coaching in cockney style, she was not only a natural but inevitable as Eliza Doolittle in "My Fair Lady," a mating of actor and character as symmetrical as Clark Gable playing Rhett Butler.
Carol Burnett too made her Broadway debut in a period burlesque, the "Princess and the Pea" spoof, "Once Upon a Mattress," in 1959. As Winifred the Woebegone, the Princess herself, Ms. Burnett stood out in a company of nine principals for a broadness of gesture that is oddly down to earth in its effect. Like a 'edieval court jester, she expresses what we're all feeling -- an eagerness to please, an impatience with fools and a gratitude for kindness. She just does it the way General Patton made war. Once again, the musical's gods of tradition and destiny demanded that she be given a main chance. After five years as television's favorite singing comic, she too graced Broadway in a star part, the usherette-turned-movie-idol in "Fade Out -- Fade In."
This ceaseless cultivation of innovative talent gave the musical a vital sense of continuity, of being able to command its own history. However, not long after the accession of Ms. Channing, Ms. Andrews and Ms. Burnett, the system broke down. When was the last truly important star discovered and nurtured on Broadway? Ms. Streisand? That was 30 years ago.
What happened? Ensemble shows, for one thing -- the dark, sophisticated "concept" musicals such as "Company," "Grand Hotel," "The Secret Garden." These are operettas for grown-ups, problem plays too finely textured to endure a star turn. Moreover, the rise of pop opera has created gigantic constructions that overwhelm performer charisma with roller dome races and helicopter takeoffs, and whose popularity extends so far beyond the theatergoing community that they become tourist attractions, like the hansom cabs in Central Park or the Hard Rock Cafe. Do tourists really care who's playing Jean Valjean this week?
There is as well the current emphasis on revivals -- literally, as if trying to pump a heartbeat into a moribund form by resuscit'ting the classics. Within the last generation, Broadway has seen major reappearances of "Oklahoma!," "Brigadoon," "West Side Story," "Guys and Dolls," "Carousel" and now "Show Boat," none of which demands headliners.
True, we have also had "Gypsy," perhaps the greatest of all star vehicles, from Ethel Merman through Angela Lansbury to Tyne Daly. But "Gypsy" is one of the exceptions that proves the rule, as is "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," expected in March with Nathan Lane, and "The King and I," originally written around Gertrude Lawrence but later staged in honor of Yul Brynner. Perhaps this "He said/She said" aspect of the latter piece will be settled when Donna Murphy and Lou Diamond Phillips square off as Anna and the King (also in March), as neither is yet a star in the Broadway sense of not just charming: fascinating. Not just talented: inventive. Not just outstanding: unique. Call it a wild magic.
Without star roles to accommodate our newly discovered stars, where are they to work? How is the musical to continue without this essential nourishment? When Judy Kaye took over for Madeline Kahn in the more-or-less Carole Lombard role in "On the Twentieth Century," there were unanimous cheers for her deliciously thorny comic style and unbearably virtuous soprano. An age ago, producers would have been lining up around the block to feature the actress in her own show; it never happened. Mostly, Ms. Kaye does regional productions of "Annie Get Your Gun" and "The Merry Widow" or concert presentations of history-book titles like "Leave It to Jane" or "Oh, Lady! Lady!," as if she were her own grandmother.
More recently, Faith Prince won notice in a supporting part in "Nick and Nora," then blew the town away as a tumultuously appealing Miss Adelaide in "Guys and Dolls." But with no follow-up vehicle, she went into a dismal play ("What's Wrong With This Picture?") and a television sitcom ("High Society").
Is it any wonder that this season the musical has concentrated on durable stars? Ms. Channing's Dolly made her gala return, and Ms. Andrews has reclaimed her old movie role in "Victor/ Victoria." Ms. Burnett has a new piece, "Moon Over Buffalo." Standing ovations are part of the package, like the playbill and souvenir T's, because America has become a clapping nation. Television, always the bellwether, teaches how: watch as audiences on game and talk shows clap not to express approval but to provide punctuation. They clap before commercials and after commercials, when someone enters and when someone leaves, when they are told to and even when they are not. And, in the theater, they clap for Ms. Channing, Ms. Andrews and Ms. Burnett as if they'd never seen a star before.
It's odd. The cheaper fame has become, the more dearly the public values the real thing. On good nights, Ms. Channing (who plays her final New York Dolly this afternoon) would see them rise to their feet four times: on her entrance, after "Before the Parade Passes By," after the title song and at her curtain call. Back in "Forty-Second Street," Ruby Keeler only sweeps the house with her eyes. Ms. Channing stares at us, perhaps to urge us to worship: the goddess is in. All three women are at the top of their form, but that's irrelevant. In Keeler's day, the public clapped because stars were wonderful. Now it claps because stars are famous.
And dying out, at least on Broadway. Will there be no new musicals built for stars, no "Gypsy," no "Funny Girl"? Has performer power been purged by authors, directors, even designers? Paradoxically, one current pop opera has produced a star role, a part that, like Rose in "Gypsy" -- and unlike Evita or the Phantom -- has so far demanded someone special. Norma Desmond, the heroine of "Sunset Boulevard," is pop opera's first true diva part, as witness its catalogue of prima donnas, from Patti LuPole, Betty Buckley and now Elaine Paige in London; Glenn Close in Los Angeles and New York; Diahann Carroll in Toronto; Helen Schneider in Germany; and Ms. Buckley now in New York, to be followed by Ms. Paige in her American qtage debut in August. (It will be interesting to see how the unknown Linda Balgord fares as Norma on the coming national tour, the first time that Andrew Lloyd Webber will run the show without a headliner. The cynical might see Ms. Balgord as an economy move; if audiences accept "Sunset Boulevard" without a star, future productions will be easier -- and cheaper -- to cast.)
In the old days, of course, stars stayed with their shows till they closed; Julie Andrews played Eliza Doolittle for three and a half years, counting the New York and London runs. Performers today are less keen, and the parade of Norma Desmonds gives us an insight into stardom that we miss in Ms. Channing, the lovable dinosaur, or in Ms. Andrews and Ms. Burnett, the heroines who walked out, if only for 30 years. These three women are simply claiming parts that belong to them, Ms. Channing and Ms. Andrews by creator's copyright and Ms. Burnett with her playwright's blessing.
The many Norma Desmonds, however, are competing in a sweepstakes, each laying claim to a role that, unlike Mary Martin's Nellie Forbush, no one yet owns. Once, the musical built itself around stars because the performance defined the show in exactly the way that the Marx Brothers or Joan Crawford defined their movies. Today, the musical is an alchemy of composition and performance in which the former contains the latter, unfortunately at a time when composition is weak.
This is why revivals are so common: to bring back the experience of attending an entertai'ing show. Not an absorbing or enlightening show -- an amusing show. What's amusement without superb comics, singers, dancers? From the writers we ask no more than talent. But from the performers, we want genius. Thus we compare Norma Desmonds: to retrieve the excitement of the unique performance in a genre that has stifled it.
We see, for instance, how Glenn Close reveled brilliantly, shamelessly, in Norma's egomaniacal glamour, how her murder of her departing lover was, to her, logical: stardom gives the troubled ego a support structure, so to offend stardom is to attack one's very identity. To Betty Buckley, such lurid connection between what one plays and what one is does not compute. Fame is beauty plus talent, right? Who added murderous rage to that recipe? It is as if Ms. Buckley were trying to rationalize stardom even as it dissolves before our eyes. So where Ms. Close played crazed, Ms. Buckley does wounded. Ms. Close fumed; Ms. Buckley cajoles. She doesn't want to kill anyone. Ms. Close's Norma was a bat out of hell, while Ms. Buckley's is a wounded bird. The advantage of seeing two pros in the same role is captivating in the way star roles used to be: the play reveals the player as we watch. That was theater: not fame itself so much as personality.
This must be what Warner Baxter means when he exhorts Ruby Keeler just before she comes back a star. It's not about taking something. It's about sharing something. It's about being part of a culture in which gifted people liberate us all by liberating themselves. In giving up that culture, we haven't just lost the wild magic; we have lost a belief that we need any.
It's all over but the retrospectives.

HEADLINE: FILM;
In Iran, Simple Films Can Speak Volumes

BYLINE: By GERALDINE BROOKS; Geraldine Brooks, who has traveled frequently to Iran since the revolution, is the author of the book "Nine Parts of Desire: The Hidden World of Islamic Women."

 BODY:
WHEN 7-YEAR-OLD RAZIEH, DISobeying her mother, goes to watch some snake charmers, a neighborhood woman chides her for being where girls aren't supposed to be. Razieh, the character at the center of "The White Balloon," replies, "I wanted to see what it was that was not good for me to watch."
Like many current Iranian films, "The White Balloon" creeps to the very edge of what Iran's censors consider good to watch. Just beneath the surface of its deceptively simple story lies a catalogue of Iranian social ills, among them poverty, the tension between the pre- and post-revolutionary generation, racial prejudice and even hints of child abuse. 
 Earlier this month, in protest over a United States Government decision to support a $20 million covert plan against the Iranian Government, Iran tried to withdraw "The White Balloon" as its official entry in the best foreign-language film category for the Academy Awards. But the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is ignoring Iran's demand. "The film was delivered here, it's eligible and we're going to screen it," says Bruce Davis, executive director of the Academy.
The attention may end up helping "The White Balloon," which is up against 40 other entrants in its category. And by leaving the film in competition, the Academy may have kept Iran from gagging a star witness in its own defense. Jafar Panahi's gentle movie, which opened on Wednesday, is itself an eloquent protest against outdated United States stereotyping of Iranians as a nation of wild-eyed Islamic extremists.
The people of "The White Balloon" are neighborhood folks: shopkeepers and housewives concerned with getting the next meal on the table and arriving at the in-laws' place on time. In this, and in "The Jar," an Iranian film that played in New York last year about attempts to repair a cracked water jar at an impoverished desert school, small events become the stage on which larger issues are played out.
Social criticism is thus possible in current Iranian films, despite the censorship they must withstand. Each film must be approved both in screenplay and in final cut. The cast and crew must be vetted for political and religious correctness, and a rating system determines how wide and well publicized the film's release will be.
Even with these restrictions, though, Iranian films remain surprisingly severe on the subjects of Government failures and social malaise. Like the Iranian press, which is allowed to be more critical than is typical in other Middle Eastern countries, movies too are allowed to express a range of opinion. What is not allowed is sex and gratuitous violence. Perhaps it is the absence of these two Hollywood standbys that makes watching Iranian movies like "The White Balloon" so refreshing to Western audiences.
Film makers who have continued to work in Iran since the revolution may be zealous former revolutionaries like Mohsen Makhmalbaf; his 1989 film, "Marriage of the Blessed," indicted the swift marginalization of Islamic idealists in a society still run by a careless rich elite. Or they may simply be artists who have stayed to fight for the cultural soul of their country rather than emigrating in search of a more hospitable creative environment.
Iranian films, especially those by Abbas Kiarostami like "Through the Olive Trees," have been increasingly admired at international film festivals. (Mr. Kiarostami wrote the screenplay for "The White Balloon.") In April the Walter Reade Theater in New York will begin a monthlong retrospective of Mr. Kiarostami's films and showcase new Iranian movies.
Iran's mullahs haven't exactly reveled in such attention. Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has noted that Western film juries often give prizes to movies that show Iran's poverty and distress. Of course, the same juries give prizes mainly to Western films that similarly show their society's ills. One example with which the Ayatollah Khamenei may be familiar is "Dances With Wolves," the 1990 Oscar winner for best picture, director, screenplay, original score, cinematography, editing and sound recording. It also happens to be one of the few American films that were allowed to be distributed in Teheran. It was approved because its stark portrayal of brutality toward American Indians shows the Great Satan in a bad light.
"The White Balloon," winner of the Camera d'Or for best first feature film at the 1995 Cannes Film Festival, is striking in its almost entirely secular portrayal of Iranian daily life. Apart from an early scene in which a character passes a prayer place, from which voices rise and fall, blessing the prophet Mohammed, the film contains no reference to Islam.
The action takes place on the eve of the Persian feast of Nowruz. After the revolution, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, trying to elevate the importance of religious holidays, discouraged observance of this pre-Islamic New Year festival. But Shiite Islam's gloomy commemorations of martyrdom couldn't vanquish Nowruz. Despite harassment, Iranians clung to their joyful spring feast, which takes place on the equinox. These days it is observed with as much verve as ever.
For Nowruz, Iranians clean house, bathe carefully and don new clothes -- symbolic rituals in which they slough off any lingering ills from the old year. The table is decorated with a mirror, candle and white foods. Light, fire and white are all representative of God in Zoroastrianism, the ancient Persian religion. In an echo of the ceremonial foods of the Jewish springtime Passover table, Persians assemble seven foods whose names begin with the letter S, like sabzi -- green herbs symbolizing nature's springtime rebirth. There must also be a goldfish bowl, with the goldfish representing the mystery and joy of life.
It is the quest of Razieh (played by Aida Mohammadkhani) for a plump "dancing" goldfish that propels the action of "The White Balloon."
Iranian films often have child protagonists, to avoid the mine field of Islamic restrictions on the portrayal of adult male-female relationships. Actors portraying a married couple, for instance, cannot touch each other on screen unless they are also married in real life because it is a violation of Islam for unrelated men and women to touch. And actresses, like all Iranian women over the age of 9, must cover all the hair and curves of the body, even in scenes depicting private moments in the home where, in real life, every woman sheds her Islamic coverings. In addition, there cannot be any extended close-ups of attractive actresses, because that might be construed as exploiting female beauty.
With the 7-year-old star of "The White Balloon," this isn't an issue. The child, with her gap-toothed smile and tragic eyes, gives an incandescent performance. A critic for The Hollywood Reporter says she "displays a range of emotions that would stymie Meryl Streep."
Razieh nags her mother into letting her buy the goldfish, then accidentally drops the money down a sidewalk grate and persuades various passers-by to help her retrieve it. Alternately kvetching and sobbing, then lit up with hope and delight, Razieh has an intensity that drags the viewer back into the sometimes terrible realm of childhood, where the loss of a few dollars can be a catastrophe.
The film is shot almost entirely in tight frames that mimic a child's-eye view of the world; it is unpanoramic, with the focal point always on what is close and immediate. At times the frames have the intimate feel of Persian miniatures, with Teheran's weathered mud bricks providing the geometrically patterned background and impassive onlookers gazing from the sidelines at the doings of the passionate protagonists.
The film works almost flawlessly at its superficial level, re-creating the ardent intensity of childhood in a sometimes oblivious adult world. But there is so much more going on here. Each of Razieh's encounters contains a small, ominous aside. Together these add up to a profile of the quiet desperation of ordinary Iranian lives in a society ravaged by revolution, war and international isolation.
In the early scenes, Razieh's nagging is as relentlessly maddening as a midnight car alarm. It is evident that her mother (played by Fereshteh Sadr Orfani), bustling to finish the shopping and cleaning in time for the New Year feast, is a victim of holiday stress. For one thing, she can't afford new shoes for her son -- the Nowruz equivalent of not being able to provide the major item on a Christmas list. For another, her husband, who appears in the film only as a bellowing voice, flinging soap and curses from the bathroom, keeps up a constant flow of distracting demands.
Like many economically struggling Teheranis, the meter-reader husband has a second job. But what he does to make ends meet is kept secret because it is somehow shameful or illicit.
Economic hardship is explored again when Razieh meets a lonely young conscript from the provinces who can't get home for New Year because he lacks the bus fare. Other social pressures emerge. An elderly tailor is intimidated by a young client of the post-revolutionary generation who knows how to use the new system against the old-timers. A young Afghan refugee is abused, used, then thanklessly abandoned in the film's haunting final scene. And there is a suggestion that Razieh's father may have punched her brother in the face.
Perhaps to emphasize the characters' isolation, almost everybody speaks with a non-Teherani accent. As in the film "Moscow on the Hudson," when every New Yorker turned out to be from someplace else, the Teheranis in "The White Balloon" speak Farsi accented by Polish, Turkish and thick regional patois.
Mr. Panahi, the 35-year-old director of "The White Balloon," was to have visited the United States to promote the film during its American release. Instead, friends say he is "location scouting" in the provinces and could not be reached to comment on the attempted withdrawal of his film from Oscar consideration.
Previously, Mr. Panahi has identified the sequence in which Razieh watches the snake charmers as one of his favorites. The scene, he said, was drawn straight from his own childhood, when he defied his father to sneak into "unsuitable" films. Like Razieh, he too "wanted to see what it was that was not good for me to watch."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fereshteh Sadr Orfani, left, and Aida Mohammadkhani in "The White Balloon" -- Ordinary people, not outdated stereotypes. (October Films) (pg. 9); "The Jar," above, an Iranian film, tells a simple story about a cracked water jar at a school; Tahereh Ladania, right, appears in "Through the Olive Trees," a film by Abbas Kiarostami, who wrote the screenplay for "The White Balloon." (Film Forum; Miramax) (pg. 9)

HEADLINE: The View From: Dixwell Avenue, New Haven;
Q House Perseveres as the Economic Crunch Takes Its Toll

BYLINE: By MARY ANN LIMAURO 

 BODY:
THE Dixwell Community House sits in the midst of one of New Haven's oldest black neighborhoods. For more than 70 years the agency's programs have touched the lives of area residents. The founding of the nation's first black Girl Scout troop is only one page of its notable past.
Much has changed, though, since the center opened in 1924 in a brand new two-story brick building several blocks from its present site, seeking to "house the legitimate activities of colored youngsters in the dangerous period of adolescence." 
 The once vibrant area along Dixwell Avenue -- a street that snakes from the edge of the Yale University campus in downtown New Haven to neighboring Hamden's town line -- has measurably declined. Many of the businesses and professional offices that once filled the neighborhood are gone -- along with much of its middle class -- lost in the 1950's and 60's when urban renewal swept through the area.
Harsh economic times and increasing societal ills have also taken a toll, and now the Dixwell area struggles with unemployment, drugs and crime. The Elm Haven Housing Project, a 312-family public housing unit that abuts the Dixwell Community House, regularly tops the city's other 14 housing complexes in number of crimes reported.
Yet, the Dixwell Community House perseveres, surviving shifting politics and the fickle business of vying for financial support.
"Our biggest challenge has always been to secure funding," said Eleanor Boyd, president of the center's 21-member volunteer executive board.
"And as the economic crunch goes on, it gets harder and harder for private agencies to find funding," said Ms. Boyd, who is also director of pupil personnel services for the New Haven School District.
Still, the last several years have been kind to Q House, a nickname given to the center many years ago by children who couldn't pronounce its name. Over the last two years, grants totaling $261,000 from the state's Office of Policy and Managment allowed the center to improve its programs for teen-agers. An endowment fund, created in 1992, has cash and pledges totaling nearly $100,000. An active alumni organization, some 150 strong, provides fund-raising support as well as policy advice.
The stark masonry building, built in 1971, is set back from the street, its cold stone exterior belying the warmth to be found inside. About 50 children from two nearby elementary schools attend the afterschool program each day, one of the agency's earliest efforts. The youth center, open six days a week for 13- to 19-year-olds, attracts about 50 each evening; an outreach program also seeks young people who need help. Life line, a food distribution program for families and home-bound elderly men and women, serves about 175 clients each week. Health services, day care for pre-schoolers and an adult basic education program are also among the community house's services.
Most recently, the 24-year-old Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society took over the second floor of one wing of the building. "Quality programming has always been our emphasis, along with integrity and responsibility," said Theodore F. Hogan, the agency's executive director.
Mr. Hogan, a retired telephone company executive and long-time community advocate, grew up in the Dixwell neighborhood and the Q House, and was once chosen its "boy of the month" at age 12.
For years, Q House programs had focused on pre-adolescent children, he said, until the agency decided to re-establish its program for teen-agers in 1992.
"We weren't addressing the needs of kids 13 and above, so we shifted our focus," Mr. Hogan said. The state grant awarded in 1994, he added, allowed Q House to beef up its fledgling program for teen-agers with a variety of recreational, educational and personal development offerings.
"These are difficult times in dealing with youths," said Mr. Hogan. "Crime and drugs are up, education is down, the family is broken up, and there's a pervasive disrespect for authority among young people. Here at Q House, we deal with it by doing what we always have -- stressing values, teaching the kids to respect not only their elders but themselves, and also getting across the message that they have to pay their own way."
An annual membership fee of $10 provides a valuable lesson for the youngsters, said Mr. Hogan, the lesson that "society can't give you everything, you have to help out by putting something back into the pot."
The program's structured environment outlines a set of rules for everyone. The first one is posted at the front door: "Gentlemen, please remove your hats before entering this building."
Others posted on a nearby bulletin board warn against smoking, drugs or alcohol, and bad language, and a reminder that damaging any Q House equipment or property will not be tolerated. "The kids know that you have to follow the rules; if you don't, you'll be kicked out for a week of two," said 16-year-old Myajuan Hunter, a junior at Hill House High School in New Haven, who was among teen-agers in the center's game room on a recent afternoon.
The game room, with its three pool tables and Ping Pong table, gets lots of visitors. An adjoining weight room, stocked with Nautilus equipment and staffed by a parttime trainer, is also popular.
Other activities offered at the youth center, which is open Monday through Saturday from 4 P.M. to 10 P.M., include a basketball league, computer lab, wood shop, talent shows and dances. One wall in the main corridor regularly serves as a canvas for resident graffiti artists.
Ms. Hunter -- whose mother is enrolled in the adult computer classes -- said she and her friends visit the youth center every day. "My friends and I get bored with nothing to do so this is a good place to come and stay out of trouble," she said.
Sixteen-year-old Jerod Goodman, playing a round of pool with three friends, agreed. "The youth center gets kids off the streets and doing something positive," he said, explaining that he was referred to the center by Juvenile Court several months ago. "We get to talk to the counselors about our problems, and we get to go on trips and see more than just the neighborhood, so it's a totally positive thing."
About 150 young people are served by the Q House outreach effort, which recently expanded beyond the Dixwell neighborhood to include all of New Haven. Funded by a state juvenile justice system grant, The program's staff works closely with the courts, probation office and schools. Originally directed at ages 14 to 17, the program now serves youngsters from 9 to 21.
"We act as mentors, guiding the kids, giving them the tools to become contributing members of society," said Miyiam Sheffield, director of youth services, who, assisted by a staff of six, oversees both the youth center and the outreach program.
Ms. Sheffield described the outreach program's participants as frequently truant from school and sometimes homeless. "We focus on bringing positive things into their lives -- not just recreational, but educational and cultural as well," she said. "Some find it difficult to leave the streets because that's all they know, while some will respond and become role models."
Ms. Sheffield said she and her staff see the results of their efforts daily. "It could be just that they've stopped dealing drugs, or maybe they're getting along better with their parents, or they're back in school and pursuing their education, which is so important," she said
"I see the Q House as being a leader," said Ms. Boyd, "not only in the Dixwell area but in the entire greater New Haven community. We just have to keep working to find the funds to stay open and keep going."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 31; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: A Witness to Her Time

BYLINE: By Edmund White; Edmund White's most recent books are "Our Paris: Sketches From Memory" and "Skinned Alive," a collection of stories about AIDS.

 BODY:

RAT BOHEMIA
By Sarah Schulman.
232 pp. New York:
Dutton. $19.95.
SO many books about AIDS have been sentimental that it's a relief to read one that refuses to find transcendence in the act of dying. As someone who is himself H.I.V. positive, I tend to avoid reading AIDS novels; the only thing I want to read is tomorrow's newspaper saying that a cure has been found. But given my high level of resistance, I suppose my surrender to "Rat Bohemia" is all the more a testimonial to its gimlet-eyed accuracy, its zero-degree honesty, its charnel-house humor. AIDS burnout has at last found its bard in Sarah Schulman. 
 The heroine is Rita, a woman from Queens who kills rats for Pest Control, a local agency housed side by side with Food and Hunger. As she admits, she pays careful attention to everything going on around her: "I want to be a witness to my own time because I've had a sneaking suspicion lately that I'm gonna live a lot longer than most of the people I meet. If I'm gonna be the only one still around to say what happened, I'd better pay close attention now."
She is a lesbian, though anything but a separatist, since she befriends a wide spectrum of people, especially gay men who are dying from AIDS. The strategy of observing gay men with AIDS from a lesbian perspective is ingenious. Rita has known the same rejection by her family as have other victims of homophobia -- in fact, the callousness of the families of lesbians and gay men is the major theme of this novel. As an activist in Act Up she has also experienced all the frustration of fighting a losing battle. But as a lesbian she announces to a bed partner, "I've never heard of anyone who really got H.I.V. sexually from another woman." Both inside and outside the disease, Rita is an ideal chronicler of a community in distress.
One of her defenses is to develop a gallows humor -- she refers to "musical caskets" and "follow the bouncing corpse." Her Cuban friend Manuel observes: "I think they should change the name of this disease. From AIDS to AIDA. Only Leontyne Price can do it justice." Operatic melodrama is exactly what Rita avoids. "One thing I know for sure," she muses, "is that AIDS is not a transforming experience. I know that we tend to romanticize things like death based on some kind of religious model of conversion and redemption. We expect that once people stare down their mortality in the mirror they will understand something profound about death and life that the rest of us have to wait until old age to discover. But that's not what happens. Actually, people just become themselves. But ever so much more so."
Rita may be trying to improve her powers of memory, but she has little hope that the life being wasted and lost all around her will be recalled for very long. Her gay friend David is dying, and what disturbs him most is the idea that he and others who have already died will be forgotten. He tells anecdotes about those who died a decade ago, hoping to keep their memories alive, but Rita is starting to confuse one with another. He goes on trips so he can write letters to friends in New York, letters that will stand as a memorial to him after he's gone. I kept thinking of a friend of mine whose own prospects are bleak but who is devoting most of his time to preparing the slides and written records left behind by three dead friends for a new archive in New York devoted to artists who have died of AIDS. So much memory, so few rememberers.
Rita's best friend is another young lesbian, nicknamed Killer, a professional plant-waterer who is clever about everything except how to get a decent job. Until she can find one, she rents out her own apartment as a bed-and-breakfast to European tourists she picks up in expensive espresso bars.
The form of the book is puzzling. I remember that back in the 1970's feminists were always saying they rejected the Aristotelian form that had dominated so much of Western literature, with its tightly woven plot, its subordination of detail to overall design, its rigid economy of means. Perhaps "Rat Bohemia" is a thoroughly non-Aristotelian contraption. Its first section, told from Rita's point of view, introduces all the principal characters (including David and Killer) and the theme that human beings have become the moral equivalent of vermin. The second section, written from David's point of view, amplifies the idea that families are out to kill their gay children. David's parents speak constantly of the deaths of obscure elderly relatives but never acknowledge the weekly losses that David must deal with. His father has almost totally rejected him; the only intermediary is the mother, herself acutely insensitive to her child's needs. Even when he was young he was disliked because he was too much a sissy: "There was always an invisible Dave, one that had never existed and never could exist, that they expected to find, miraculously each morning at the breakfast table. And when, instead, all they got was little silly-willy me, with limp wrists and a will of steel, little courageous sissy-wissy me, they were deeply angry."
The third section, which functions as a parenthesis, at least in the plot, is called "Killer in Love," and is an idyll-in-the-ruins between Killer and her quirky new girlfriend, Troy. These women speak like gutter dandies and have become experts in the semiotics of the lesbian body. Whereas so much of what precedes and follows this section is an angry storm, here the novel is becalmed, snared by poetry: "Will I stay in bed reading in the morning while my lover sleeps beside me? The trees outside my window. My tattoo. Her book. Will I bustle, bring her coffee? Read the paper silently? Comment on an article and happen to look up? Her body there before me. Sitting sipping coffee. Eating bread so slowly. Hair unkempt. Feet bare." I suppose the narrative so convincingly depicts the absence of family love, and the paucity of convincing images of love that homosexuals can use to validate their own affairs, that this middle section functions as the necessarily calm eye of the storm, a utopian interlude in an otherwise infernal story.
The fourth part of the book, again told by Rita, intensifies her longing for parental love as well as her burden as a survivor and a witness to the deaths of so many friends. She runs into a closeted lesbian novelist, Muriel Kay Starr. Almost all the characters in "Rat Bohemia" are reading her new book, "Good and Bad." Starr gives Rita her version of her tormented friendship with David (who has just died). But Rita isn't buying it. She says to Starr: "He was mad at you for writing closeted novels. For not even being out in your author bio on the back of the book."
That links up with the closing pages of "Rat Bohemia," a reprint of the first four chapters, all very brief, of "Good and Bad." In this excerpt we discover for ourselves exactly how Starr has battened on the lives of her gay and lesbian friends, retold their stories and even captured their suffering -- but in impeccably commercial heterosexual terms.
The form of this book surprised me, and its humor often struck me as highly elusive. But a rapacious cruelty and despair (represented by the rats and rat extermination) are joined to a whimsical bohemianism, a fierce individualism. As Killer explains, in the 50's people could afford to be Beats, but "nowadays, with the economy the way it is, you can't drop out or you'll be homeless. You gotta function to be a boho. You have to meet the system head on at least once in a while and that meeting, Rita, is very brutal. Nowadays you have to pay a very high price to become a bohemian."
There are few other works of fiction that I could compare with "Rat Bohemia"; the only book I know that presents its contemporary misrables with the same jauntiness is "My Life as a Mole," a collection of New York stories about gay life, published in 1988. Otherwise, Sarah Schulman seems to have the field to herself. Even her own earlier books, like "People in Trouble" and "Empathy," despite the fact that they, too, take place in the East Village and deal with AIDS, carry none of the emotional punch of "Rat Bohemia." The force of her indignation is savage and has blown the traditional novel off its hinges. If she were contributing to the quilt project, her quilt would be on fire.

HEADLINE: After Oslo

BYLINE: By Barbara Smith; Barbara Smith is the Middle East correspondent of The Economist.

 BODY:

PEACE AND ITS DISCONTENTS
Essays on Palestine in the Middle East Peace Process.
By Edward W. Said.
188 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $12.
AN intellectual, says Edward W. Said, a professor of English and comparative literature at Columbia University, must be a rebel against prevailing ideas. In "Peace and Its Discontents" he follows his own precept well: few can match the pungency with which he challenges conventional wisdom on the Middle East peace process -- the belief that it is an ineluctably good thing, threatened by self-evidently bad extremists. 
 Mr. Said mounts his challenge from high moral ground, having long favored a political solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict. But the Oslo compromise he finds contemptible. His people, the Arab-American professor argues fiercely, have been gulled into giving away their trump -- Israel's desire for Arab recognition -- for little more than a pat on the back from the United States. The interim arrangement leaves residents of the West Bank and Gaza subservient to Israel, and also subject to the petty dictatorship of Yasir Arafat, a leader he finds beyond redemption.
A fatal weakness of the peace agreement, he argues, is that it squanders the gains and sacrifices of the intifada without getting in return any commitment from Israel on Palestinian self-determination, the status of East Jerusalem or repatriation or compensation for Palestinian refugees. It splits the Palestinian nation in half, writes Mr. Said (who was displaced from his birthplace in Jerusalem in 1948), offering no future at all to the 55 percent, many of them stateless, who live outside the occupied territories.
"Peace and Its Discontents" brings together articles written after the September 1993 Rabin-Arafat handshake and is addressed primarily to an Arab audience. Though some of the articles have also been published in American and European magazines, they were originally written for Al Hayat, a leading Saudi-owned Arabic newspaper published in London, or for Al Ahram, a weekly newspaper published in Cairo.
Their sorrow and their anger are good, scolding stuff, an articulate tirade against perceived folly and uncritical applause. But, inevitably, the articles are dated. And since they were written before Yitzhak Rabin's assassination, some are off-key. Mr. Said's argument is based on the premise that the Oslo agreement enabled Israel to attain all its strategic and tactical objectives without its having to cede anything of value in return. Tell that to the Likud opposition, let alone to Rabin's confessed murderer. His assumption, moreover, that the terms of the agreement give Israel no cause for complaint or fear sits oddly with the current state of that country, now torn by religious and political dissension.
Mr. Said writes that Palestine must be restored "to its place not simply as a small piece of territory between the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan River but as an idea that for years galvanized the Arab world into thinking about and fighting for social justice, democracy and a different kind of future." This sounds high-minded, but the Palestinians' fight, so far as it existed, got nobody anywhere: the Arab world obtained neither social justice nor democracy, and Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza continued to suffer from a repressive occupation. Now, at least, Israel has moved its troops out of most of the main towns in the West Bank and Gaza, and Palestinians have held free elections. What happens next is unknown.
The Oslo agreement is a gamble. The issues that matter most were left to the talks on a permanent solution, due to start in May. The Palestinians have no guarantee of getting what they want, or anything like it. Mr. Said expects the worst and could well turn out to be right: he certainly has reason to mourn the gap now yawning between the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza and those in the diaspora. But he tosses aside the inevitable question: what should the Palestinians do instead? Surely, he says impatiently, among six million Palestinians any number of alternatives could be found. Yes, but what were they then and what are they now?

HEADLINE: The Momentary Science

BYLINE: By Richard Parker; Richard Parker, an economist, teaches at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government.

 BODY:

THE CRISIS OF VISION IN MODERN ECONOMIC THOUGHT
By Robert Heilbroner and William Milberg.
131 pp. New York:
Cambridge University Press.
Cloth, $44.95. Paper, $14.95.
ECONOMICS -- a relative latecomer to the modern social sciences -- has frequently had occasion to revel in the stature it has achieved. The President has no Council of Sociological Advisers, and there is no Nobel laureate in psychology or history. Economists are everywhere sought after, called upon by governments, corporations and the news media to impart meaning to what so often seems frightening and confusing -- from our declining wages and stagnating productivity to our endless trade and budget deficits. So why does economics as a profession seem under siege? 
 A recent study by the American Economic Association, for example, found that nearly two-thirds of graduate economics professors consider their calling "overly mathematical" and "too unrelated to the real world." The number of Americans earning Ph.D.'s in economics has fallen by almost half in the past 20 years, to barely 400 a year.
In universities, the field of economics exists in a fractious state labeled -- for want of a better term -- "post-Keynesian," akin to the oddly drifting larger world we've come to call "post-Communist." As in the external world, a divisive fundamentalism seems rife. There are the old advocates of neoclassical synthesis, monetarists, new classicals, neo- and post-Keynesians, neo-institutionalists, supply-siders and several variant Marxists -- a cacophony, in short, in a profession that for the preceding 40 years had effectively spoken in one voice.
But why? The explanation by Robert Heilbroner and William Milberg in "The Crisis of Vision in Modern Economic Thought" may be the most imaginative to date. It is, they argue in this disarmingly challenging little book, what they term "a crisis of vision."
For Mr. Heilbroner, the Norman Thomas Professor of Economics, Emeritus, at the New School for Social Research, and Mr. Milberg, an assistant professor of economics at the New School, vision is neither a religious nor a mystical experience. It is what Joseph Schumpeter 40 years ago identified in his commanding "History of Economic Analysis" as a pre-analytic, pre-theoretical grasp of the central issues each great period in economics is meant to address. Possessed of such vision, economics enters what Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg call "classical situations," extended historical moments when the richness of the central vision gives rise to industrious reflection and analysis that fills out the vision and gives it both power and meaning for its particular age.
Adam Smith and the classical economists possessed such a vision. So did Alfred Marshall and the marginalists -- and so, of course, did John Maynard Keynes. But, the authors argue, in the 1970's economics was battered by real-world events as well as by a theory crisis induced by the challenge of the "rational expectations" school. By moving away from Keynes and instead seeking understanding through the advancement of mathematically sophisticated (but increasingly arcane) analytics, it failed to maintain a vision. As a consequence, Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg believe, economics lacks purpose and clarity -- and, not least, relevance to the larger world.
To those who insist that economics is best precisely at techniques, not visions, Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg offer strong historical evidence to the contrary. Revisiting the shaping moments and works of each great "classical situation," they identify how visions emerged and took hold -- whether the visions were those of David Ricardo, Lon Walras, Marx or Keynes -- and how they guided practice and theory.
In a series of chapters at the heart of the book, Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg then examine how the Keynesian "moment" came unraveled, how its challengers --first monetarism but then, with greater force, rational expectations -- sought to overthrow the Keynesian model, and how neo-Keynesianism's attempted "rescue" has fared in response. For those interested in the momentous shifts in intellectual argument about economics over the past two decades, "The Crisis of Vision in Modern Economic Thought" offers a powerfully insightful tour d'horizon of the battlefield.
It has long been the gift of the book's senior author, Mr. Heilbroner, to treat competing schools of thought with both clarity and seriousness, all the while linking their contributions to his central concern with economic vision. Educated (like most of his generation) into an instinctive Keynesianism, he has always been strongest addressing economics through the lenses of the history and the philosophy of ideas, tracing the evolution of arguments through the course of time.
Significantly, he and Mr. Milberg insist here that for economics to recapture a sense of vision, it must understand why it is (as the philosopher Daniel Hausman has called it) "a separate and inexact science," apart from the natural sciences. In particular, economics must better understand why it is a subject deeply immersed in history -- at present reflecting the presuppositions of capitalism and its institutional arrangements -- rather than, like physics or chemistry, a means for discovering universal natural laws.
Secondly, the authors argue, unlike both 19th-century classical economics and the modern post-Keynesian contenders, a new economic vision must come to terms with the public sector's inescapable role in balancing the forces to which capitalism gives rise. Mr. Heilbroner and Mr. Milberg acknowledge the contrary political fashions of the moment (especially in Washington), but they insist that the tendencies of modern markets require a dynamic public sector, albeit one adaptive and ingenious enough to address (and, where needed, shape) the market's changing structures and forces.
Will Robert E. Lucas Jr. -- last year's Nobel laureate for his work in rational expectations -- be persuaded? Unlikely. But for the moment a great number of economists, policy makers and informed citizens seem uncertain, and genuinely concerned, about how to address the confusion and division that characterizes the post-Keynesian era. For them, the authors have written a trenchant and challenging prolegomenon.

HEADLINE: Bad News

BYLINE: By Kevin Phillips; Kevin Phillips is the publisher of The American Political Report. His most recent book is "Arrogant Capital: Washington, Wall Street and the Frustration of American Politics."

 BODY:

BREAKING THE NEWS
 How the Media Undermine
 American Democracy.
 By James Fallows.
 296 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.
IN 1991, E. J. Dionne Jr., now a columnist at The Washington Post, inaugurated the current spate of books on "whom and what Americans hate" with his book "Why Americans Hate Politics." Since then we have had books on why Americans loathe Washington, lawyers, Wall Street, foreign lobbyists and the like. It is a flourishing genre. In the autumn of 1994, a Time/CNN poll pinpointed the groups Americans particularly thought had too much influence in Washington: big corporations, the news media, Wall Street, lawyers, foreign interests and the rich. Now comes James Fallows, the Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, to tackle one of these transgressors in "Breaking the News: How the Media Undermine American Democracy." The headline on the back of the jacket goes whole hog, in big red letters: "Why Americans Hate the Media." 
 This flamboyance does not make it a bad book. On the contrary, it's a useful one, partly for the simple reason that the book's target -- the power of the news media and of their leading word warriors -- resonates at the grass roots. The citizenry seems to agree with many of his points. The elite news media in Washington are a permanent government of sorts. And Americans don't think there's enough accountability, although Mr. Fallows could have weighed in with some data. No poll, to be sure, has actually asked whether the people favor term limits for Washington pundits -- eight years and you're back in Cincinnati, Harry -- but the press panels I have been on agree that the public would support the idea.
Mr. Fallows also bowls a strike when he describes prominent national journalists as upper-bracket folks who lean to upper-bracket public policy. Some of them -- he certainly names names -- get more for a single speech than the average family makes in a year, and the chapter on the "buckrakers" should produce chuckles at the Chillicothe Rotary Club along with apoplexy among the regulars on "This Week With David Brinkley." Endorsements of cutbacks in entitlements and of the North American Free Trade Agreement come too easily to unctuous millionaire journalists.
He attacks "The McLaughlin Group" and similar television programs as gong shows whose participants know they are clowning. In fact, too many talk shows do operate as described by one especially candid participant: "What's good TV and what's thoughtful analysis are different. That's been conceded by most producers and bookers. They're not looking for the most learned person; they're looking for the person who can sound learned without confusing the matter with too much knowledge. I'm one of the people without too much knowledge. I'm perfect!"
Mr. Fallows's pithy language generally makes for easy reading, whether he's assuming that the core audience for the nightly news is aging -- based on "what seem to be their most frequent advertisers," namely, "Geritol, Polident, Mylanta, Attends" -- or venting recurrent (probably excessive) put-downs of Mike, Diane, Sam and George and their incomes and supposed double standards. But like the mass journalism he attacks, Mr. Fallows has all the juicy stuff -- the big names, the income estimates, the personal foibles -- up front (or at least midbook). The last hundred pages slump into John Dewey, Walter Lippmann and a turgid dissection of coverage of President Clinton's health care proposal that only insomniacs will be interested in reading.
Near the beginning of the book, the author quotes Charles Prestwich Scott, for half a century the editor of The Manchester Guardian, as saying that "the function of a good newspaper and therefore of a good journalist is to see life steady and see it whole." Theoretically, it still is. Scott's words, however, come out of 19th-century journalism, when newspapers had soared to a huge readership from the minor circulation of the 18th century, and were still far from competition from broadcast and information technology. Since then two forces have converged, weakening Scott's thesis in a way Mr. Fallows could have better explored. First, the news media have become just one competing component of a highly corporate and profit-driven information megabusiness, which reaches from straight entertainment to on-line data. And second, there is the related problem of how the news-and-analysis segments of the mass media, especially broadcasters, face profit demands. They either increase their show-biz quality or else migrate to PBS or the Learning Channel. Show biz is winning, but the audience is generally shrinking anyway.
MOREOVER, Americans don't hate "the media" entirely. People in northwest Connecticut don't hate The Litchfield County Times. History buffs don't hate The Georgia Historical Quarterly. Cooks don't hate Gourmet. The media Americans are presumed to "hate" are the gatekeepers and trumpet players of national debate and opinion, the people who hold forth in their columns and at anchor desks, who enjoy incomes in the top 1 percent and offend large chunks of America as they deploy their ebbing power -- new technologies are already diffusing it -- to explain, simplify or oversimplify American culture, politics and economics. Mr. Fallows presumes that the power is enormous, but he may exaggerate.
Twenty years ago, following Watergate, I published a book called "Mediacracy: American Parties and Politics in the Communications Age," which argued that aristocracy and democracy were giving way to a "mediacracy" in which a new information elite would dominate. Some of that has happened. But I overestimated the political power of the new media elites. The media elites of the late 1960's and early 1970's, even had they been so inclined, couldn't stop successive waves of conservative politics beginning in 1968 and 1972, resuming in 1980 and running right up to 1994. Arguably, the media elites even helped provoke them. Now there is a new conservative element among the working press, but there are signs that the public is starting to sour on some of the new conservative trumpet players as it loses faith in the new conservative Washington. Newt Gingrich and Rush Limbaugh may well be losing political and broadcast market shares together.
Mr. Fallows's book -- again like the prestigious news media he faults -- could have greater scope. The journalists on the television networks, national news magazines and newspapers that the author targets derive much of their weakness not from specific journalistic failings on their part, but from the fact that they have been absorbed into the larger national establishment and elite that the public dislikes. Many of his subjects are also part of the Washington establishment in the broader sense of being millionaires, Ivy League roommates of senators, more frequent travelers to Tuscany than to Texarkana, husbands and sisters of superlobbyists, fellow parents at Sidwell or St. Albans and fellow partygoers with the rest of the cabal to an extent that would have been impossible 60 or 80 years ago, although traces of this new status were becoming apparent in the 1940's and 1950's. Insider lawyers, lobbyists, Congressmen, bureaucrats, trade consultants, economists and foreign-policy makers are in just as much disrepute as insider journalists because they, too, have helped make Washington a city only 20 percent of Americans trust. Voters don't separate these groups as much as some Pulitzer Prize or Emmy winners would like to think. Grass-roots Americans view this whole crowd as part of a giant buddy system, as in some ways it is.
As an indictment, "Breaking the News" is in some ways overstated. The author overdoes a negative portraiture to make his point. Anyone with an hour for a Nexis computer search can come up with 50 courageous exposs in 1995 of special interests buying Congressional favors, lobbies run amok, the plight of the middle class and suchlike in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, The Chicago Tribune, The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Los Angles Times and The Boston Globe. The ghost of Lincoln Steffens is not gone from the nation's pressrooms. A well-edited compendium of these articles would sell out in Wal-Marts and Kmarts from Maine to California, rebutting what Mr. Fallows seems to imply about the fecklessness of the press.
Or would it? It is not an accident that Mr. Fallows's book is laced with quotations from journalists supporting his case. There may be enough oversimplifications in the book to warrant follow-ups and critiques, but there is also too much candor and truth to dismiss it.
