SECTION: Section 7; Page 33; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 663 words

HEADLINE: Star Over Trenton

BYLINE: By Jerry Gray; Jerry Gray, now a Congressional correspondent for The New York Times, was formerly Trenton bureau chief.

 BODY:

Christie Whitman for the People
A Political Biography.
By Sandy McClure.
Illustrated. 282 pp.
Amherst, N.Y.:
Prometheus Books.
$24.95.
Six years ago, Christine Todd Whitman broke upon the New Jersey political scene when she came within a whisker of upsetting Senator Bill Bradley. Three years later, as a decided underdog, she whipped Gov. Jim Florio to become the state's first woman governor. Now, midway through her first term, Mrs. Whitman has made the short list of potential Vice-Presidential running mates for the 1996 Republican ticket. 
 On paper, Mrs. Whitman seems an ideal candidate for a political biography. But one of the first serious attempts to test that notion -- "Christie Whitman for the People," by Sandy McClure -- comes a cropper. Ms. McClure serves up a Christine Whitman who is so sugary that it should cause even the Governor queasiness. "This is a story," the preface declares, "about a wealthy woman from a politically prominent family -- a wife, a mother, a governor -- who is fulfilling the deeper promise of her heritage."
 Part of the problem with the book appears to lie in the fact that the author ignored the admonition Orson Welles used to deliver when he was a pitchman for a winery: "We will sell no wine before its time." Despite her recent political stardom and the fact that she hails from one of the most powerful families in New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman is a newcomer on the political stage. And while there is much about her upbringing and her political grittiness to make for some interesting reading, once you are beyond her tax-cutting aplomb, there is not a whole lot left for a decent political biography. The youngest of four children, the future Governor was born on Sept. 26, 1946. Her family's wealth lay in construction: the Todd men built Colonial Williamsburg and helped define the Manhattan skyline by erecting Rockefeller Center. But politics, too, was a family business. Mrs. Whitman's father, Webster Todd Sr., led the state Republican Party during much of the 1960's and 70's and used his personal wealth to keep it alive. He was a friend to Presidents and served as Dwight Eisenhower's economic minister to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mrs. Whitman's mother, Eleanor Schley Todd, was a political player in her own right. She led the Women's State Republican Club of New Jersey and several times she was a delegate to the Republican National Convention.
 As a child, Christie Todd is variously described as "an American version of the mischievous Madeline in Ludwig Bemelmans's famous books," as tomboyish, as uncomfortable with her looks ("she was a plain, overweight child") and as petulant. At the 1956 Republican National Convention in San Francisco, the 9-year-old Christie upstaged a news conference called by her mother and other G.O.P. women by turning up wearing a Mickey Mouse hat with a novelty dagger poking out of her head.
 As a political reporter for The Trentonian, a Trenton-based daily, Ms. McClure covered the Whitman gubernatorial campaign and followed the Whitman Administration on a nearly daily basis for its first 18 months. As a biographer, she was given open-door access to the generally insular Mrs. Whitman. She spent hours interviewing the Governor, members of her family, her friends and members of the gubernatorial staff. "Certain family members, who normally shy away from press coverage, opened their homes, family albums and scrapbooks to me," Ms. McClure says.
 Yet in the main part of "Christie Whitman for the People," we are given little more than a tedious rehash of newspaper clips from her 1993 run for governor, which included a nightmarishly bumbling election campaign that was rescued at the 11th hour by her promise of a tax cut. By the end of the book, we have made quick stops at the highlights, and some of the lowlights, in Mrs. Whitman's life. But we never gain any real sense of how those events shaped the woman or her politics.

HEADLINE: The Road to Deferred Gratification

BYLINE: By Robert Kuttner; Robert Kuttner is co-editor of The American Prospect.

 BODY:

THE GOOD LIFE AND ITS DISCONTENTS
The American Dream in the Age of Entitlement, 1945-1995.
By Robert J. Samuelson.
293 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $25.
Robert J. Samuelson's intriguing thesis is that Americans are "in an almost permanent state of public grumpiness" because the postwar boom and its institutions created a culture of "entitlement." By this word, he means not just Social Security and Medicare but a presumption that capitalism could be tamed by a blend of Government safety nets and corporate management techniques. So unusual was this period and so exaggerated the expectations it spawned, Mr. Samuelson argues, that we were bound to be disappointed. 
 In reviewing the postwar boom, Mr. Samuelson finds several aspects historically exceptional: America's temporary dominance of the world economy; the crusade against Communism, which gave us unity and national purpose; the apparent success of Keynesianism in smoothing business cycles, and the temporary triumph of managerialism, which suggested that corporations could be stable and benign. These conjunctures, he contends, caused us to mistake a singular era for a permanent resolution of life's uncertainty and capitalism's turbulence. We also came to expect far too much of government, overloading it with claims that backfired in a frustration with politics. We confused, he says, "progress with perfection."
 Mr. Samuelson concludes with a familiar lament about the politics of overload: Citizens have contradictory views about whether government should do much or stay cheap. The politician's course of least resistance is to have taxes lag behind outlays, leading to chronic deficits. And while citizens join interest groups, they resent a politics that seems dominated by selfish lobbyists. The growth of rights and entitlements compounds all these tensions. "Government that is overused," he says, "undermines its own competence and subverts consent."
 Mr. Samuelson writes briskly and confidently. His copious footnotes suggest a work informed by a good deal of reading and reflection. The entitlement thesis is provocative, and at least half right. Still, he begs the central question: Whose good life? Whose discontents?
 Mr. Samuelson repeatedly poses what he calls the postwar paradox: "If American society, by and large, has been so successful, why do so many Americans feel so dejected about the results?" But he takes great pains to avoid the most parsimonious explanation: recent slow growth and widening inequality. In a too-abbreviated discussion of income distribution, he acknowledges that most households have realized scant material improvement for a generation, even as economic security has also been eroding. The generation before, when average incomes doubled, the largest relative gains went to the poor and the working class, and both social benefits and job security were at a peak of reliability. No wonder so many people feel sour today.
 But Mr. Samuelson selectively uses 1940 as a bench mark, to suggest that Americans are significantly better off than in the old days: "In 1940, more than a fifth of Americans still lived on farms," he writes. "More than half of households didn't have a refrigerator." Using 1973 -- the peak of the postwar boom -- yields a stunningly different story, and a more straightforward explanation for the current anxiety.
 The 1980's and 1990's have been splendidly satisfying for the top 5 percent of Americans, but justifiably uneasy for many others. Mr. Samuelson's chronic overuse of the pronoun "we" elides the plain fact that grumpiness and economic distress are not universal. He insists that Americans generally are living better: "We are healthier, work at less exhausting jobs and live longer than at any time in our history." This is the fallacy of composition -- the error of attributing the same characteristics to the parts and the whole. Or, as Tonto once explained to the Lone Ranger, "What you mean, 'We'?"
 Having offered a novel analysis that Americans suffer from excessive entitlement, Mr. Samuelson offers the mild cure of the prevailing wisdom: acknowledge that there are limits, balance the Federal budget and redeem the idea of personal responsibility. At times, Mr. Samuelson seems to place himself on both sides of his own argument. His message that Americans should cease indulging a pessimism based on inflated expectations requires him to remind us how well we are really doing, thanks to increased prosperity, security and social insurance. But his message also is that many of these measures were unsustainable: "The face of American capitalism has changed," he writes. "It is less protective and more predatory." But if that is so, then Americans are right to feel anxious. It's hard to have it both ways.
 A weakness of this book is conflating several arguments rather than helping the reader sort them out. Were our expectations for stable prosperity exaggerated all along? Or are we really doing a lot better than we admit? Is it that some people are doing better at the expense of others? Or that some aspects of the human condition are beyond material remedy? These are very distinct and somewhat contradictory contentions, each with different implications.
 A related flaw is leaving out politics. Surely, some groups and individuals have gained immensely from the new configuration of state and market, to the pain of others. His tacit counsel is passivity: lower our expectations. His cures would largely accept the growing maldistribution of life's rewards as an immutable hallmark of capitalism, and leave remedy to the individual. Mr. Samuelson dismisses an interventionist set of cures as more entitlement and overload, without quite acknowledging that his is just one side of an enduring political debate, and not a proven law of economics.
 The economist and philosopher Albert O. Hirschman, in a gem of a short book titled "The Rhetoric of Reaction" (1991), identified three recurring arguments against government intervention, dating back more than two centuries. He called them perversity, futility and jeopardy: tinkering with the economy and society would either backfire or be a waste of time and resources or place other valued institutions at risk. To these rhetorical staples, we can now add entitlement: interventions impair our democracy, hobble our economy, sap our personal responsibility.
 In sum, "The Good Life and Its Discontents" combines sound partial insights with a thesis that doesn't entirely compute. One virtue of the book is to remind us how much has changed in two short decades. Mr. Samuelson is certainly right that there are limits to American power and to what government can provide. He also is right that much of the recent increase in standards -- cleaner air, more reliable medicines -- is not experienced as discretionary personal consumption. And he is right that Americans are "schizoid" in what they expect of government. Yet one can profit from Mr. Samuelson's thoughtful prose and still come to markedly different conclusions about the cause, cure and above all the politics of America's current discontent.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The American Surety Building;
An 1890's Skyscraper May Become a Landmark

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE American Surety Building, at the southeast corner of Pine Street and Broadway, was the Seagram Building of the 1890's, the apotheosis of sensitive office-building design at a time when new skyscrapers were widely criticized.
But in search of beauty, the owners skipped a few legal steps, and almost had to demolish what everyone praised. Now the Landmarks Preservation Commission is considering whether the 1896 building, doubled in size in 1921, is worthy of landmark designation -- and so is the current owner. 
 The introduction of the steel frame in New York in 1889 immediately doubled the economic height of office buildings -- at that time buildings usually topped out at 10 or 11 stories. The doubling also increased land values.
In 1894 the American Surety Company, established in 1884 to guarantee corporate and legal obligations, paid almost $1.5 million for a squarish plot at Broadway and Pine, measuring only 85 feet on a side. The architect Bruce Price won a competition for a new skyscraper.
Price's 21-story building, 312 feet high, was apparently the second tallest in New York, after the 313-foot-high Manhattan Life Building of 1893 at 66 Broadway, which is no longer standing.
THE American Surety Building came at a time when the new crop of tall buildings was shocking New Yorkers. In 1894 the Real Estate Record & Guide said the incipient generation of 20-story buildings "evokes only one feeling, that of horror."
The Chamber of Commerce proposed restrictions on tall buildings, and most architects agreed with a bill introduced in Albany to restrict heights.
Their objections involved increased sewage, congestion and fire danger, and the shutting off of light and air to adjacent buildings.
There was also the question of esthetics: In the magazine Architectural Record the critic Russell Sturgis decried the "inconceivably ugly back walls and side walls . . . hardly justifiable even in the rear wall of a cheap brick three-story dwelling house."
Perhaps because of the controversy the new American Surety Building was unlike any previously built. In basic quality it was almost public in character. Built entirely of Maine granite, it presented Broadway with a giant Ionic entry portico surmounted by standing female figures representing honesty, fidelity, self-denial and other virtues, by the sculptor J. Massey Rhind.
Above, the relation between the raised banding and the width of the shaft worked with particular harmony, and the upper floors and attic were sumptuously carved.
But the most distinctive elements were the lot-line walls: they were fully detailed, all the way around the building, something not even done on Fifth Avenue mansions.
The writer Barr Ferree, writing in Stone magazine, praised the American Surety Company and predicted "the heartfelt thanks of all art lovers for its wise and generous action."
But it turned out that the American Surety Company was being generous with the property of another: John Jacob Astor 4th. Astor owned the L-shaped parcel around the new building, and the American Surety Building's cornices, banding and other elements projected up to three feet over the low buildings on Astor's lot. Astor protested in mid-construction and was rebuffed.
In May 1896 he had his engineers, Purdy & Henderson, file plans for a new 21-story building on his land that would not only shear off much of Bruce Price's decoration, but block up the 200-odd windows that overlooked Astor's property.
Within a few weeks the American Surety Company had agreed to lease Astor's property for $75,000 a year, about $900 for each office it was protecting.
The American Surety Building remained a point of reference for critics and architects long after its construction, even after the 1916 zoning law placed the first regulation on office heights.
IN 1921 the company expanded, and its architect, Herman Lee Meader, extended the building 40 feet on both Pine and Broadway, matching the exterior design exactly but more than doubling its area, making what had been an elegant shaft rather ungainly.
Meader put in a light shaft along the new south side of the building, but he repeated Price's earlier touch of projecting the cornice over the adjacent property, an effect still visible from the street.
In 1975, when the Bank of Tokyo cleaned the facade and half-restored, half-modernized Meader's sumptuous lobby, Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic of The New York Times, called American Surety "one of those sleeper landmarks."
The Landmarks Preservation Commission, under its chairwoman, Jennifer Raab, has been very active in downtown Manhattan, which has heretofore been lightly touched by preservationists. In September and December the commission held hearings on the American Surety Building.
The owner, the Hiro Real Estate Company, continues to decline comment, but according to Deborah Sack, a spokeswoman for the commission, Ms. Raab has been having "a lot of discussions" with Hiro.
This scenario has occurred often when an owner will accept designation but wants to work out fine points of what will and will not be regulated, and how closely.
Ms. Sack said the commission would hold a determining vote on the American Surety Building sometime this spring.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The building, whose space was doubled in 1921, is now being considered for landmarking. A vote is due in spring. (Rachel Cobb for The New York Times); The 21-story American Surety Building in 1896, year of its completion. (The American Architect and Building News)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Casino Wars;
A New, Dazzling Las Vegas Downtown

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
A SEQUINED wall of mega-resorts along the famous Strip just outside this desert city is growing ever larger and outlandish in a nearly $2 billion hotel-building spree now under way.
Meanwhile, just a few miles away the gritty historic casino hub downtown is tidying up, has built itself a canopy of two million lights and is erecting its own hotels on a far lesser scale. 
 Casino operators are hoping that the dazzle of even more theme architecture and amusement-park spectacles will attract some of the city's 29 million visitors their way. Companies are spending unprecedented amounts of money, building bigger and bigger resorts with emphasis on the "curb appeal" of a 150-foot Statue of Liberty or a rustic Italian village with 10-acre alpine lake.
To remain competitive, many hotel operators without a crane swinging overhead are formulating plans to expand towers into their parking lots, or are considering buying a dowdy hotel neighbor to either spruce up, or blow up and build anew.
The latest of the downtown's huge construction projects to be completed is along Fremont Street, a main thoroughfare that, in recent years, was best known for its growing number of topless clubs and "Check Cashing Here" services. Casino profits in the neighborhood sagged in the last four years as gamblers avoided the area's seediness for the splendor of an exploding volcano or a streetside pirate-ship battle on the Strip.
Casino operators felt compelled to unite, with help from the city, to revitalize the area by closing off traffic to create a pedestrian mall and the largest light show ever. Fremont Street is now the nave for an 80-foot high cathedral vault of lights stretching five blocks.
After dusk, during hourly shows, lights blink with images of fighter jets buzzing the neighborhood or snowmen dancing to a jingle. On one recent evening, thousands of people craned their necks to watch.
"Downtown had aged," said Mark Brandenburg, managing partner of the downtown Golden Gate Casino and Hotel, which was built in 1905. "We needed a must-see attraction. You come downtown now and it feels clean and safe. It has a unique mystique of the steel frame that unites the eight casinos. There is no question that it has made Fremont Street more attractive to a middle-America market."
Called Fremont Street Experience, the project preserved the neighborhood's quirky neon atmosphere, while ejecting the once-regular crew of pornography peddlers and panhandlers with a new city ordinance that specifically focused on downtown. Nevertheless, the area is not targeted to the family market; hence its theme: "Where adults come to play."
THE $70 million cost of the Fremont Street Experience was divided by eight neighborhood casinos, which supplied $25 million; the city, which spent $27 million, mostly on a new parking garage; and by tourists, via a downtown hotel room tax. Casino operators, long competitive with one another, spent months of second-guessing ideas that ranged from creating a Venice-like system of canals (with gondola rides) to suspending movable floats above the street.
"In the old days, the approach from the casinos' point of view was to bring people in, and then lock the front door so they couldn't get out," said Donald D. Snyder, president and chief executive of the casino-financed partnership that manages the Fremont Street Experience. "The hotels agreed to a project that creates an environment and makes it comfortable for people to be outside.
"On top of that, they put a light show on every hour on the hour that potentially sucks people out of the casinos. That would never have happened a few years ago. That is where the industry has changed. The competition on the Strip has done that."
As hoped, the project's investment is slowly spurring a downtown revival. It is too early to know whether gambling revenues will increase over the long run, but the city estimates that downtown hotels have already committed $700 million in expansions.
For example, Fitzgerald's Casino and Hotel has announced plans for renovations, retail shopping and 600 new rooms. The Las Vegas Club Casino has broken ground on a 20-story tower and three new restaurants.
Meanwhile, Main Street Station's casino is scheduled to open in 1996 after being closed for four years. New retail tenants move in regularly, replacing T-shirt shops. And there is talk of building commercial office towers nearby. There are few downtown despite the city's distinction of having one of the fastest growing corporate real estate markets in the country.
"If you look at the Las Vegas Strip, you look at $6 or $7 billion in development," said Jan Laverty Jones, Mayor of Las Vegas. "But the dearth of spending over the years was downtown."
Redevelopment downtown comes at a critical time, because its competition, the Strip, is awash with bulldozers and construction workers building resorts, each one more grandiose than the next. At least four major hotel/casinos are scheduled to open on the Strip during the next two years, during which time the city's overall hotel room count will rise 15,000 to 105,000, according to the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority.
The Stratosphere Corporation is building the tallest structure west of the Mississippi, called Stratosphere Tower, with an 1,149-foot tower with a revolving restaurant at the top and a 12-story hotel complex at the base. The $300 million project, which will have 1,500 rooms, is scheduled to open in April.
The Empire State Building, Chrysler Building and a pastiche of dozens of other New York landmarks make up the facade of New York, New York, a $350 million, 2,100-room hotel being built by MGM Grand and Primadonna Resorts. It is scheduled to open in December, and will be encircled with a "Coney Island Roller Coaster."
MIRAGE RESORTS INC., which already owns three Las Vegas hotels, the Mirage, Treasure Island, and Golden Nugget, just broke ground on Bellagio, a $900 million evocation of a romantic northern Italian city. The 46-story, 3,000-room hotel, geared to the luxury market, will open in about two years.
Mirage joined with Circus Circus Inc.'s development company, Golden Strike, to build the French Victorian-theme Monte Carlo. The 3,000-room hotel is to cost $325 million, and open late this year.
Both the Monte Carlo and Bellagio are located on the former 162-acre site of the Dunes Hotel -- one of the last large tracts of vacant land along the developed portion of the Strip -- which Mirage bought in 1991 for nearly $75 million, and then blew up.
"It is the fact that there is little empty land left," said Alan M. Feldman, spokesman for Mirage. "The next movement in Las Vegas is going to be tearing down existing buildings or renovating old ones."
It is already happening. Circus Circus bought the 40-acre Hacienda Hotel last summer for $80 million to, at a minimum, renovate. Its fate will be announced later this year.
Despite a flurry of hotel building, and resulting revenue, Mayor Laverty Jones is encouraging nongaming companies to relocate here. She believes the casino boom will eventually slow, especially if California chooses to expand its now limited gambling.
"If this community is going to continue to grow, it needs a diversified company base," Ms. Laverty Jones said. "We need higher paying jobs and more technical expertise."

HEADLINE: Cheaper by the Dozen: New Cars for Less Than $11,000

BYLINE: By PEGGY SPENCER CASTINE 

 BODY:
SMALL cars are bigger and better than ever. Many have larger dimensions and a broader choice of options. Even subcompacts have clever designs offering more interior space, or they pack more punch under the hood. And there is a longer list of nameplates from which to choose, from standbys like the Civic and Metro to newcomers like the Accent and Sephia.
Most significantly, all small cars are coming with bigger price tags. To a great extent, this is because Americans have developed such large expectations. No longer will mainstream buyers tolerate econoboxes that deliver high mileage but shudder in a breeze, or cute bugs with personality galore but faulty heaters. 
 We want our small cars to be substantial, with air-conditioning to boot. And how about power windows?
All that substance has a price, and it is usually in five figures. In May 1994, for example, this section included a list of 10 cars priced below $9,000, including three under $8,000. Today, only the Hyundai Accent sneaks in below $9,000.
One result is a booming used-car market. People shopping for second cars or commuter cars have often turned to midsize sedans that were returned after leases ran out, or to popularly equipped models that had done service in rental fleets.
Yet, when the average new car costs $20,000, there is considerable appeal to the idea of driving a pristine, potentially trouble-free model -- unscratched, undented and full of that new-car smell -- for around $10,000.
Some quite serviceable transportation is available for less than $11,000 (including the ubiquitous "destination charges," which are supposed to account for the cost of shipping a car from the factory). Of the 12 cars that cleared that barrier (the popular Chevrolet Cavalier just missed it), six were made in North America; three came from Japan and three are in the vanguard of a wave of vehicles from South Korea. Most handled well, had enough power to climb hills and offered acceptable if not spectacular styling. Some surprised with sporty handling. A couple would be winners in practically any class, and there's nary a Yugo in the bunch.
Here is what you can expect today for $11,000:
 
Dual air bags (in '94, only 2 of the 10 cheap cars had two bags, and 6 had none at all).
 
Reasonably comfortable though hardly cushy seating for an average-size driver and front passenger, plus a back seat that can accommodate at least two children
 
Enough cargo space to haul home groceries, handle a set of golf clubs or accommodate bags for a weekend.
 
Excellent fuel economy.
 
Handling that ranges from excellent to adequate (or at least as good as many sporty cars of decades past).
 
Fit and finish that are generally good, and sometimes superlative.
There is plenty of choice, too, for those willing to pay. But stripped-down models may be hard to find on dealers' lots, particularly if you insist on certain equipment and have your heart set on one color. Also, some manufacturers push you up-market if you want certain options, like anti-lock brakes, or force you to buy a package of goodies in order to get, say, air-conditioning.

The Accent, which replaced thelate and rarely lamented Excel last year, is a decent little car that has gained new respect for its Korean manufacturer. Not only is the Accent the lowest-priced car available, it is among the best deals, providing ade quate power, fairly good handling and a tolerably smooth ride. Note, however, that the base model is just that: no factory-installed options are available. And thanks to the Excel's woes, the resale value may be poor.

 A '95 redesign increased the size and price, but not the substance, of the Metro (above) and Swift. These are still small cars that seem to work best for intracity commuting or pizza delivering. Adding to the frail feeling is a hood that sweeps down and away from the cockpit, giving the driver a sense of floating in a bubble as 18-wheelers storm by.

Choices: 3-door and 5-door hatch backs

 This successor to the Festiva grabbed attention when it was intro duced in 1994 as one of the first small cars with dual air bags. It does look sleeker than its boxy predecessor, although it feels more cramped inside. The Aspire is very much from the old school of small cars: it is certainly economical, but in space, power and amenities it falls behind fresher de signs like the Neon and Civic.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2836 words

HEADLINE: When Charity Runs Out

BYLINE: By DAVID CORCORAN 

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
WHEN 1995 started, Carlos Torres had a $22,000-a-year job as a supervisor at an auto parts factory in Essex County. When it ended, he was a charity patient at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center here, still a little dazed by his run of bad luck.
First the plant closed. Then his unemployment insurance ran out. Then last fall, just after he'd finally lined up a new job, he fell on a street in Paterson and shattered his right arm. It still hasn't healed properly. 
 Mr. Torres's care -- from the emergency room to the operating room to the recovery room to St. Joseph's orthopedic clinic to physical therapy and back to the operating room (for a bone graft) -- has cost the hospital thousands of dollars. Thirty-one years old, unemployed and single, he has no health insurance and hasn't been disabled long enough to qualify for Medicaid. So the hospital has only one way of recovering some of those costs, for him and thousands of other patients who have no public or private health insurance: New Jersey's $300-million-a-year program to reimburse hospitals for charity care.
Now, because of a bitter partisan dispute in Trenton over how to finance it, the charity program is in danger. St. Joseph's and 80 other hospitals, large and small, got their last checks from the charity care fund on Jan. 15, and unless the Legislature can agree on how to renew it, there will be no checks on Feb. 15. So hospital administrators like Sister Jane Frances Brady, who runs St. Joseph's, are scrambling -- not only to persuade the lawmakers to restore the fund but also to figure out how to get along if it is not restored.
"This is a historic moment," said Sister Jane, who has run St. Joseph's since 1972. "We've never come to the place where our cupboard is literally bare. We're really up against it. And what we're going to have to do is cut the sail to fit the cloth" -- perhaps, she suggested, by suspending non-emergency services for some charity patients.
The state charity payments make up about 7 percent of St. Joseph's $265 million budget, so their absence will start biting soon. The hospital will have no choice but to cut services or pay for charity care from other accounts. But even if the financing crisis is resolved (and there is widespread expectation in Trenton that it will be, though no one can say when), a much larger problem is looming over St. Joseph's and other urban hospitals, like Jersey City Medical Center, University and United and Beth Israel Hospitals in Newark, East Orange General and Elizabeth General.
Although the Federal budget impasse makes any talk of specific numbers meaningless, it is clear that Congress and the Clinton Administration are planning hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of cuts over the next seven years in Medicare and Medicaid, the two gigantic programs that pay for care to the aged, poor and disabled.
The Medicaid money may well be distributed to the states in block grants, and Republican lawmakers say the states can allocate it more efficiently than Washington can. But it will still be far less than the urban hospitals have learned to count on, forcing them into what administrators call a vicious circle.
"If New Jersey under block grants gets $14 billion less in Federal subsidies over seven years than it would have received, what does it do?" asked Gary Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, a trade group that represents most of the state's hospitals. "Does the state come up with that much money? Not likely; you'll have to begin cutting services as well. Not only will the state pay less to insurance companies, who will cut what they pay to hospitals, but the hospitals will also be seeing more people who aren't covered, which means more charity care."
Every hospital in the state is required to treat anybody who needs care, regardless of ability to pay. In an era of managed care, when private as well as public insurers are trying to hold costs down, the requirement places burdens on every hospital, urban or not. But for urban hospitals like St. Joseph's, which got 63 percent of its revenue last year from government sources, the state and Federal cuts will force a painful reassessment of their mission.
"Urban hospitals have few cost areas that can be cut any more than they have been cut," said Jim Knickman, a vice president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, which finances research into health care. "Even if they take care of few charity patients, it will be difficult for them to cut operating costs, many of which are fixed. The real prospect is one of potential hospital closures."
 
THE HOSPITAL
From Cows to Clinics
St. Joseph's Hospital had 12 beds when it opened in 1867, in a small frame house in the fields of South Paterson. The Sisters of Charity of St. Elizabeth, who still run it today, cared for cows as well as patients.
Now the hospital anchors a whole neighborhood, not to mention its city's economy. It has 651 beds, making it the state's fourth-largest hospital. With more than 3,000 workers, it is the largest employer in Paterson, a city long since deserted by the brawny textile mills that grew up around the Great Falls of the Passaic River.
It admits 26,000 patients a year, and the emergency room sees more than 50,000. The main campus sprawls over a large city block -- a maze of wings and towers in an architecture critic's nightmare of clashing styles from different eras -- and the hospital has outposts throughout Paterson and in half a dozen other communities. It has become a vast regional supermarket of care for its mostly poor, mostly black and Hispanic community.
Where St. Joseph's starts, for many, is in the emergency room, which was already packed at 11:30 on an otherwise quiet morning last week. Its 21 beds were filled, and half a dozen patients waited on gurneys in the aisles -- people with chest pains, asthma, possible broken bones from car accidents and falls in the snow.
"You can be relatively quiet, and then you can get overwhelmed," said Dr. James N. Pruden, St. Joseph's chief of emergency services. "In 1990 we had 40,000 patients; last year it was 51,600. There's just a lack of availability of other resources in the community. There's an increasing incidence of asthma, and AIDS.
"And this is the only place that's open 24 hours a day, seven days a week. As private practitioners become less and less available, become more and more focused on a fixed, 9-to-5 mind-set, then we're the only place people can turn to. When they come, we don't even know if they have insurance or not. If this hospital can't take care of them, who can?"
St. Joseph's would rather see non-emergency patients in its 27 specialized clinics, where the care is less intensive, and therefore less expensive. Every weekday morning, the hall of its ambulatory care wing and the waiting room of its Family Health Center fill with clusters of people in wheelchairs and on crutches, mothers with strollers, pregnant teen-agers. They are awaiting X-rays, gynecological exams, pregnancy counseling, eye care, foot care, skin care . . . the whole array of services that people in a wealthier community might be likely to seek from a private specialist.
Many are charity patients: people like Carlos Torres, the unemployed man with the shattered arm, and Carolyn Jackson, a 47-year-old former teacher's aide with painfully inflamed joints who is still waiting to qualify for Social Security disability insurance -- her ticket to Medicaid.
For now, the hospital does not much care whether they have insurance or not. The point is that if they can be treated while they are still relatively healthy, they are less likely to need expensive acute care later on. "If there were no clinics," said Kathleen M. Hay, St. Joseph's director of ambulatory care nursing, "emergency rooms in the cities would just be bombarded with patients. We'd be back to the bad old days of the 70's, when there were 24-hour waits."
But with all their nonpaying patients, the clinics are hardly profit centers. The question is how many of them will survive, and in what form, if the urban hospitals begin losing the funds that sustain them.
 
THE ADMINISTRATOR
Daughter of a Revolution
Sister Jane Frances Brady wears a business suit, not a habit. But she lives at the convent across the street from the hospital and begins the day with Mass ("where I pray for the strength to get to the end of it") at 6:30 every morning.
 She is not the type to raise her voice. She is an accountant as well as a nun, with an M.B.A. from Seton Hall and a master's in hospital administration from Columbia, and associates say her strong points are her mastery of detail and her steely persistence.
Those same qualities can also make her come across as something of a control freak; she speaks of "my hospital" and "my emergency room" and even "my tuberculosis patients," and when hospital people mention "Sister," there is no question which sister they mean. But she is not overly severe. It helps to know that she never misses an episode of "E.R.," and that she likes to travel to third world countries with volunteer medical teams, so she can lay hands on real patients.
"It's a busman's holiday," she said in an interview last week. "The people are desperately poor, but you have direct contact with them. You don't have to worry about bureaucracy; you can hold patients, carry them out of the operating room. Here, you're constantly going to meetings and plowing through paperwork."
Sixty years old and tall, with a young, open face, she has been at St. Joseph's nearly half her life. She grew up in White Plains, where her father was an engineer for the New York State Thruway Authority and her mother was a special-education teacher in the New York City schools; she became a nun after graduating (summa cum laude) from the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, which is run by the Sisters of Charity. It was clear to her, after college, that she wanted to use her gift for administration in the order's mission of charity; she started at St. Joseph's in 1966, just about the time Medicare and Medicaid were revolutionizing the way hospitals did business.
"When I came, we were like a community hospital," she said. "I was given a tour on my first day here, and it took from breakfast to shortly before dinner. Now it would take you two weeks."
 By paying for patients who in the old days would have been charity cases or wards of local government, the two huge Federal programs gave urban hospitals a dependable financial base, allowing aggressive ones like St. Joseph's to follow their mission and expand their services to meet the needs of the broad, secular community.
Many, including St. Joseph's, also saw the opportunity to develop profit-making services -- a sports medicine clinic, a regional cardiac center -- to make their finances even more secure. And although some lawmakers would like to see the urban hospitals narrow their focus and concentrate on their central mission of care for inner-city residents, Sister Jane says there is no going back to the old days.
"We're a $260-million-a-year business," she said. "You have to have profit centers. As much as we have a mission to the poor, we have many obligations now. I'm the biggest employer in Paterson. I can't expect my vendors to give me stuff and not pay them."
She was asked whether the government and private insurers didn't have an obligation to make sure that hospitals were spending their money efficiently. It was the closest she came during the interview to raising her voice.
"Absolutely," she replied. "But 'inner-city hospitals aren't efficient'? That's a red herring that's thrown up all the time, by people who don't understand the situation. They'd be stunned if they stayed here overnight. Stunned! They'd see the tuberculosis patients, the AIDS patients, the 13-year-old mothers who don't have a clue how to take care of babies.
"These are real people with real names and real faces. They're not made up."
 
THE OUTLOOK
Scrambling for Solutions
The stalemate in Trenton over the charity care fund reminds people on both sides of the budget impasse in Washington: though everybody agrees that some way needs to be found to keep the payments going, the two sides are locked in a bitter standoff over where the money is to come from.
For three years, the state paid for charity care by tapping a huge surplus in its unemployment insurance fund, which boomed in the 1980's with the surging economy. But as joblessness grew in the 90's, the surplus shrank, and business and labor groups demanded that the Legislature find another source of money. Authority to use the unemployment fund ran out on Dec. 31.
At first Governor Whitman proposed a 25-cent increase in the cigarette tax ("users' fee," as she put it, since smokers are more likely to need hospital care). But neither party would vote for a tax unless the other one did; Democrats were particularly infuriated by Republican assertions that they owed it to "their" urban constituents to find a way to pay for charity care.
Last week, as the hospitals and their advocates began warning of cuts in services, lawmakers began launching volleys of competing alternatives -- from prosaic (tapping the unemployment fund again) to partisan (drawing the money from the general Treasury, a move Democrats would love since it would almost certainly force the Governor to take back part of her 30 percent income tax cut) to exotic (a new statewide video lottery).
For her part, Mrs. Whitman seemed to wash her hands of the issue, saying the Legislature had rejected her solution and would have to find its own. But she may have more to say in her annual budget message tomorrow.
"We'll be confronting a crisis if we don't find a solution," said her Health Commissioner, Len Fishman, who is especially concerned about the charity fund because it also pays for a program that offers low-cost health insurance to people without it -- particularly working families with children.
"Urban hospitals are critical," he went on, "not only because they serve large numbers of people who are uninsured but also because they're where tertiary services" -- advanced, expensive specialties like cardiac and cancer care -- "are located. We don't have an extensive public hospital system in this state, and that's a good thing, because the poor get better care in hospitals where most patients are insured. To maintain that kind of system, we have to make sure charity care continues."
As for the deep reductions lurking down the road, in Medicaid and Medicare, Mr. Fishman says he is optimistic that urban hospitals can adapt. "I trust that hospitals in this state will be able to meet that challenge, and find ways to deliver services more efficiently," he said.
In Paterson, Sister Jane Frances Brady is not so optimistic.
"Everything is so tight," she said, raising her voice just a little. "The managed-care payers are crushing, crushing, crushing the price of care, always asking us to do more with less.
"In the old days we could shift the cost of caring for the poor to the private payer; we can't do that anymore. Everybody only wants to pay for their own patients."
 
CASE STUDIES
 
Diagnosis: Stroke. Insurance: None.
In New Jersey, hospitals are required to care for anyone who needs treatment, regardless of ability to pay. Hundreds of thousands of New Jerseyans have no health insurance, often because they have jobs but cannot afford private insurance or because they are single, which generally makes them ineligible for Medicaid.
Last year 125,000 such patients were treated in New Jersey hospitals. Asked for a sampling of the kinds of people who qualify, St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson offered these four case studies, all from 1995.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: Hostile Environment

BYLINE: By Mark Dowie; Mark Dowie's latest book is "Losing Ground: American Environmentalism at the Close of the 20th Century."

 BODY:

THE LAST STAND
 The War Between Wall Street
 and Main Street Over
 California's Ancient Redwoods.
 By David Harris.
 373 pp. New York:
 Times Books/Random House. $25.
There are few places where the battle between cowboy capitalism and wilderness preservation has been fought with such ferocity as Scotia, a quaint lumber-mill town on a wide bend of the Eel River in northern California. Deep in the heart of America's ancient redwood forests, Scotia has been transformed over the past decade from a genial company village where everybody knows everybody and nobody locks the front door to a community riven with animosity and fear. It all began in 1985 when a smooth-talking corporate raider from Houston decided to buy all the shares of Scotia's only employer, the Pacific Lumber Company, a prosperous but undervalued family business whose bylaws stipulated that the welfare of the area where it operated had to be on an equal footing with the financial rewards to shareholders. 
 In "The Last Stand," David Harris spins a fast-paced and colorful yarn of Scotia's concurrent introductions to Wall Street greed and radical environmentalism. Mr. Harris recounts a descent into modernity that began the day Charles Hurwitz, the chairman of the Maxxam Group, began to accumulate the common stock of the lumber company, run for three generations by the Murphy clan, a family committed to sustainable-yield forestry and perpetual community.
Neither of those values was of particular interest to Mr. Hurwitz. But, saddled with junk bond debt and anxious to get on with his next takeover, he promised the Murphys, their employees and the people of Scotia that he would respect and preserve their traditions.
Before long, any members of the Murphy family remaining in the company were removed from office and orders were given to double the harvest of old-growth redwood. Enraged local environmentalists went to court to protect stands of ancient forest that provide habitat for animal species long ago endangered by logging in the Pacific Northwest. As the lumber company's new management was reassuring its workers that nothing had changed, the company pension plan was quietly being transferred to a Los Angeles insurance company no one had heard of, and in the process $50 million was stripped out to pay the first installment of junk bonds that had been underwritten for the takeover. (The insurance company was Executive Life; the underwriter was Michael Milken.) A lawsuit brought against Maxxam by the Murphys and their supporters in their former family business was laughed off by a Reagan-appointed Federal judge.
After Executive Life failed, the fact became public that the insurance company had got that pension contract after buying a large block of Maxxam bonds from Mr. Milken. And a Congressional hearing on insider trading and leveraged buyouts later disclosed that during the stealth phase of the takeover, Boyd Jeffries, the Los Angeles superbroker, had parked Pacific Lumber Company shares with Ivan Boesky so that Mr. Hurwitz would not have to report to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he owned more than 5 percent of the stock and so reveal himself as a raider.
Through the personal experiences of ordinary people affected by the takeover, Mr. Harris describes the painful transition of a town and its company from enlightened to unenlightened capitalism. The response of Bill Bertain, a Scotia lawyer whose family owns the local laundromat, is particularly poignant. Irate over the way trees and people were treated by the lumber company's new owner, Mr. Bertain, who had never handled anything larger than a divorce, went head to head with Maxxam in the Federal courts and brought the Hurwitz-Milken conspiracy to the attention of Congress. If there is a hero in this book, it's Mr. Bertain.
Mr. Harris's tale comes alive in his reporting on the environmental community's response. As chain saws whine through some of the last redwood groves in America, back-to-the-land monkey-wrenchers and Wobblies conspire to stop the cuts by blocking roads, sitting in trees and "spiking" redwoods with long metal shrouds that destroy mill saws (and turn into fragmentation bombs if a saw blade hits the spike at the right angle). Mr. Harris takes us into the homes and psyches of Greg King, Darryl Cherney and Judi Bari, the courageous but often foolish eco-warriors of Redwood Summer, Earth First's last stand against Maxxam and the lumber company. Earth First retreats after Mr. Cherney and Ms. Bari are car-bombed (Ms. Bari was badly injured) in Oakland, Calif., a crime that remained unsolved as "The Last Stand" went to press.
Mr. Harris quite reliably weaves a good parable. But unlike his earlier nonfiction books "Dreams Die Hard" and "The League," this one -- on a topic that cries out for the kind of reflection that someone like Mr. Harris, who cut his teeth on the campus activism of the 60's, could provide -- is long on narrative and short on analysis. In his attempt to live and speak through the world of his characters, Mr. Harris sadly loses his own voice. (He also has an irritating habit of switching first and last names in the same paragraph, so that in one sentence we are with "Charles," in the next with "Hurwitz.") His grammatical license and overwrought similes are at times distracting, and it is hard to believe that the working-class mouths of Humbolt County are quite as foul as he portrays them. But these last are small weaknesses. "The Last Stand" remains an essential read for anyone curious about the innards of a hostile takeover, the Realpolitik of resource economics or the psychodynamics of radical environmentalism.

HEADLINE: WHAT IMMIGRATION CRISIS?

 BODY:
By casting the debate on illegal immigration as one about values, Rayner ignored the fundamental complaint many Americans have on this topic. After a lifetime of employment, and the subsequent financing of numerous social programs via taxes on our incomes, we now question who really benefits. 
 Rayner's solution of providing "Federal assistance to heavily impacted areas such as Los Angeles" is the most disturbing aspect of his article. While economic expectations for most "native" Americans have been diminished, government assistance for those who are not citizens seems unlimited.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Housing Within Reach of Southampton Locals

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
MANY young families who live and work in the Town of Southampton find it difficult, if not impossible, to compete in the housing market with more affluent purchasers who are looking for vacation houses.
But in one 40-unit single-family-house project to be built in the Riverside section of the town, state grants will allow income-eligible buyers to purchase three-bedroom, 1,489-square-foot colonials on half-acre lots for $83,990. Purchasers must either not have owned a house for three years or be first-time buyers. 
 The project, called Brookside Estates, is being sponsored by the Long Island Housing Partnership. The developer and builder is the Park Ridge Organization of Ronkonkoma.
Vincent Cannuscio, the newly elected Town Supervisor of Southampton, said the development would provide badly needed housing that local families can afford. "The area is so desirable as a second-home community that sellers tend to get inflated prices for houses," he said.
Brookside Estates is one of several on Long Island benefiting from a state grant program administered by the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Housing Finance Agency. Under the program, developers receive a $25,000 grant for each unit to help reduce their cost to buyers who otherwise would be shut out of the housing market.
Since its inception in 1985, the state program, which also provides grants for the rehabilitation of existing housing, has helped create 12,000 new housing units statewide, and has helped rehabilitate 11,000 units.
Over the 11 years, Nassau has received $2.19 million in grants for 112 new housing units, of which 70 are completed and 10 are under construction, with the balance not yet started. Suffolk has received $26.138 million in grants for 1,402 units, of which 1,253 are completed and 66 are under construction.
For every dollar the state spends, the private sector invests $4 to $5, so that the $300 million in grants that have so far been provided under the program have generated more than $1 billion in private investment in repairs and new construction, said Joseph Mendez, acting director of the Affordable Housing Corporation.
Projects either are developed by local nonprofit groups who hire builders to act as their general contractors, or are sponsored by a group that works in partnership with a developer. The developer must agree to limit profits to 10 percent of cost.
For some of the families purchasing at Brookside Estates, even the state grant will not be enough to bring costs to a level they can afford, said Joseph Sanseverino, director of the Suffolk County Community Development Agency.
His agency therefore has allocated $275,000 in Federal grants under the Federal Home Program for 11 of the 40 houses, allowing each of those homes to be purchased for $58,990. The Home Program, created under the National Affordable Housing Act of 1990, can be used for both new construction and rehabilitation of existing dwellings.
Buyers will be chosen by lottery later this spring, with preference being given to local residents. Applications must be received by the Housing Partnership, at 180 Oser Avenue in Hauppauge, no later than March 17.
To be eligible for the state program, a family of four cannot earn more than $50,720 a year. A single person can earn up to $35,504.
Income limits to qualify for the additional Federal grant are lower. Annual income of a family of four, for example, cannot exceed $41,500.
ASSUMING a purchase price of $83,990 and a 5 percent down payment of $5,450, buyers at Brookside Estates can expect to pay $557 monthly on a $79,500 mortgage at 7.5 percent interest over 30 years. Taxes on the houses are projected to be $350 a month, for a total monthly housing cost of $907.
If the house is resold within 64 months, the state grant must be fully repaid; repayment is reduced to 90 percent if held for 66 months and forgiven if held for at least 114 months. The Federal grant must be repaid in full if the house is resold in less than 10 years; after that, repayment is waived. New buyers at Brookside Estates need only meet the state income standard, which is higher than the Federal requirement.
Brookside Estates will be the third project built by Park Ridge under the state program. In 1986, the developer built 30 houses in Selden in a single-family project called Hope Ridge. They sold for $68,000. Subsequently, it built a 72-unit condominium in Manorville called Cobble Ridge, where town houses sold for $78,000.
The program's most active nonprofit participant in Nassau and Suffolk is the Long Island Housing Partnership, which has built or sponsored almost 500 units.
Other groups include the East End Rural Preservation Corporation, which currently is building six three-bedroom single-family houses priced from $65,000 to $70,000 on Shelter Island. Buyers have already been chosen by lottery.
In the Wyandanch and North Amityville sections of the Town of Babylon, 20 single-family houses are being built under the program on scattered sites. The sponsor is the town and directing the project is the Community Development Corporation of Long Island, a Centereach-based nonprofit group that administers community development activities for Babylon. Houses in the Babylon program are still available, said L. Von Kuhen, the group's director.
The Long Island Housing Partnership, in conjunction with the Town of Southampton, recently completed another single-family house project in the town. At the 30-unit single-family development in East Quogue called the Pines, three-bedroom houses ranged in price from $83,590 to $94,930. About 200 would-be buyers signed up for the lottery.
"The cheapest house out here is $150,000 to $160,000, and I never could have afforded to own one," said Jo Ann Doyle, who moved into her $94,930 colonial at the Pines in April. Ms. Doyle, who is single, said she owns a liquor store in East Quogue that provides her with an income of about $30,000 a year.
Single people often have the most difficult time affording a house of their own, said Marianne Clemente, who works as a computer operator for an aerospace company.
"For the longest time I was living with my parents trying to save money to buy something," she said. "Unless you make over $40,000 or have two salaries, it is very hard to save enough, and most single working people, I feel, fall into that category."
ON Sept. 26, she purchased a two-bedroom condominium in a 66-unit development in Middle Island called Country View Estates, where condominium apartments were reduced in price from $98,990 to $73,990 by a $25,000 state grant. The units, each occupying a full floor in a two-story, Victorian-style town houses, have two bedrooms, dining areas and eat-in kitchens. Monthly common charges are $110; taxes are now $48 a month, but they will rise to $287 by the end of the year.
"It took me 20 years to get my piece of the rock," Ms. Clemente said. Her company once planned to move to Texas, and she gladly would have gone, she said. "Now my answer would be, 'No,' " she added.
Buyers at Country View Estates were picked by lottery. However, two contracts fell through, so two of the apartments are still available, said David Scro of Scro & Scro Properties in Ronkonkoma, the developer of the 21-acre project.
Among families who have purchased at Country View Estates are Richard Morel, a New York City corrections officer, and his wife, Donna. They have two small children. Until they bought their new home, they lived with Mrs. Morel's mother in East Setauket.
Under a mortgage program being offered by the Roslyn Savings Bank, which views the state grant as a $25,000 equity that buyers already have in their houses, the Morels were able to obtain almost 100 percent mortgage financing. They paid only $400 in cash to the bank at the closing.
Their monthly payments for their mortgage and common charges come to $900, Mr. Morel said, "which is not much more than we would have to pay for rent."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1251 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Residential Complex in Edison Gets the Green Light

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: EDISON

 BODY:
EARLY this month a developer deeded to the township a 30-acre forest of hardwood trees in the Dismal Swamp for a nature-study preserve.
The action sealed a compromise struck two years ago involving the developer, Continental Properties, of Brick, conservationists and Edison Township, ending eight years of debate over the future of much of the 600-acre swamp. 
 Last year the developer, which had originally owned 375 acres of the swamp, donated 225 acres of its property off Talmadge Road to the township. , Under state law the land now cannot be developed. In addition, the deed transfer of the forest stipulates that it will remain forever open.
Now Continental, which has been slowly developing its non-wetlands property, has a green light to proceed with the rest of its scaled-back project calling for 1,034 residences. In addition, it was granted approval for 330 rentals adjoining but outside the swamp property.
The swamp is a wilderness of scrub and marsh that is home to wood turtles and more than 200 species of birds, including the blue heron.
When she heard of the forest transfer, Jane Tousman, a former township councilwoman and a founding member of Save Our Swamp, or S.O.S., which fought in court for preservation of the entire tract, said she was "going to stand up and cheer because saving land like this is like finding a gold bar."
The developer had successfully met each of the S.O.S. challenges in court before a compromise was reached.
The transfer defines the shape of Continental's $135 million housing and retail development, called the Villages at Edison. Now, Continental will shift 179 units planned for the forest site to another section of the project without increasing its overall density of 1,034 residences -- condominium town houses, single-family homes and rentals, including 105 for low- and moderate-income elderly tenants. The township had originally approved 2,230 units after the developer agreed to extend Talmadge Road through the swamp. But the number had been cut after additional wetlands were found on the site. Also planned are 86,000 square feet of retail space.
The developer can also move ahead on the construction of 330 high-end rentals to be known as Talmadge Village. The $30 million project will rise on 24 acres the developer owned adjacent to the swamp that the township rezoned from industrial to multifamily use as part of the compromise.
"The only reason it worked is that people were willing to compromise," said Mark Fisch, a principal of Continental. He noted that the rezoning of the 24-acre site "was the additional bonus needed for the compromise to make economic sense," Securing the approvals made it a reality, said Mr. Fisch, whose company in the last 15 years has built or is now building some 3,500 dwelling units in the township.
One project is Durham Woods, the 1,000-unit rental where eight buildings were destroyed and 127 families were left homeless when a natural gas pipeline exploded nearly two years ago. The buildings have been replaced and the complex, which borders what will be Talmadge Village, is nearly fully occupied, said Mr. Fisch.
While the tug-of-war between preservation and development is not new, the one over the Edison tract is distinctive in several ways. First, it involved Mrs. Tousman's group of five environmental-minded women, who plotted strategy over coffee against a big developer. It also reflects the increasing use of land deals as an option to acquisition.
THEN there is the compromise itself, which was contingent upon the developer's securing the necessary approvals over two years, all of which are now in place. Unless that happened, Continental could have proceeded with the court-upheld plan calling for 1,034 residences, including developing the forest.
"In the world of municipal trade-offs," said Andrew A. Strauss, a Trenton-based planning consultant involved in conservation, commenting on the compromise, "a land deal is a practical planning and zoning tool used to solve debates over open space.
"What it comes down to is how much density a community is willing to accept" -- and will it get more than it will lose.
In Edison's case, Mayor George A. Spadoro said the township could absorb the additional 330 units and that the deal was important because it allowed "us to add to our supply of open space without incurring any debt."
Edison lost much land to development in the mid-80's building boom. From 1980 to 1990 some 10,325 residences were built in the township and its population rose to 88,680 from 70,193, it is now about 90,000. To serve that population it needs 900 acres of open space to meet the standard of 10 acres for every 1,000 people; its existing supply is now more than 600 acres. Recognizing this, the township, as part of a master plan re-examination last year, made open space preservation a priority.
Mayor Spadoro said Edison was seeking funds under the state's Green Acres Program -- the major source of public money for the acquisition of open space -- to buy three parcels, together totaling some 50 acres. It is also negotiating with Conrail to donate an 100-foot wide, over one-mile-long old railroad right-of-way to turn into a greenway; and it wants to preserve as much land as possible edging an eight-mile stretch of the Raritan River for a public waterfront walkway.
"Having the forest and the adjacent marshlands protected fills in one piece of that puzzle," said Mayor Spadoro.
"There were a lot of concessions along the way, but the end result of preserving so valuable a piece of open space for future generations was worth it," added Mrs. Tousman.
Mr. Fisch of Continental said that "everyone is happy, to a degree." He said with the upscale rental units his company's two projects "will cover each segment of the housing ladder."
Of the 1,034 units making up the Villages at Edison, 60 single-family homes and 128 town houses already have been built and sold. The remaining 459 town houses planned comprise Village Pointe, which includes the 179 units transferred from the forest site.
The one- to three-bedroom units will range in size from 1,000 to 1,660 square feet and in price from $90,000 to $140,000. Construction has begun and 20 units have been sold, said Mr. Fisch.
WORK is proceeding on the 387-unit rental component, called Village Court.
The one- and two-bedroom garden-style market-rate units have 920 to 1,265 square feet of space and rent for $750 to $850 a month. The subsidized units for the elderly are smaller, and monthly rents are $525 to $600. To qualify, tenants must have an annual income of no more than 80 percent of the Middlesex County median, which is $44,240for a single person or $50,560 for a two-person household.
At Talmadge Village the 330 upscale rentals will consist of one, two and three-bedroom units; many of the larger units will be duplexes, with 660 to 1,275 square feet of space.
Following what the National Multifamily Housing Council in Washington calls a growing trend they will have features often associated with town houses, such as separate front entrances and laundry rooms. Most will also have garages and recreational amentities, including a pool are planned. Rents are expected to be $725 to $1,000 a month.
The units, designed in traditional style by Sullivan Associates of Philadelphia, will be marketed "to people who do not want to buy or cannot afford to buy a town house," said, Mr. Fisch. Construction is to start next week.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Real Estate Industry Slims Its Image for the 90's

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S residential real estate boards, multiple-listing services and real estate agencies are responding with various degrees of enthusiasm or antipathy to the mergers, downsizing and technological transformations within their industry.
Generally, consolidation in the interest of survival prevails. It's just a matter of how much. 
 "There are now 24 boards in the state, down from 32 in 1993," said Gerald R. Kunde, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Realtors in Hartford, "and we will see more consolidations."
Last October the National Association of Realtors ruled that agents and firms throughout the country may choose to belong to only one real estate board in their state to qualify for subscribing to a regional multiple-listing service.
A statewide multiple-listing service, often talked about, "is not on the front burner," said Mr. Kunde, adding that "we are waiting to see if those that have gone regional serve the market."
Brokers are also dwindling in numbers, although some boards report modest increases in memberships. Real estate licenses issued annually by the state's Real Estate Commission have dropped from 38,300 in 1987 to 20,000 in 1995.
Mr. Kunde said that boards in Norwich, Danielson, Willimantic, Litchfield and New Milford were considering mergers; Greater Hartford and New London have regionalized their multiple-listing services, that Hartford, New Haven and Waterbury were cooperating, but not consolidating, and that the shoreline boards of Madison, Guilford and Old Saybrook had merged.
A major change in Fairfield County is the formation of the Westport-Weston-Norwalk-Wilton Board of Realtors -- the largest in the county with 875 members. In 1994, the Norwalk Board of Realtors was dissolved because of financial difficulties. Its members accepted an invitation to join the Westport-Weston Board, and last spring they all merged with the Wilton Board.
Harriet Haffner, president of Haffner Realty in Norwalk, is the newly elected first president. "Real estate has become big business," she said. "I have been a boutique business. To remain viable we have to function like the A. & P. We have to stock the shelves with as many listings as possible, be able to disseminate as much information as the big firms do to our agents and the home-buying public."
In spite of the expense and training required for computerization, the complexities of merging, and a poor housing market, she said, "1995 was my best year."
THE board-of-choice ruling has been of particular benefit to large companies and national chains with offices in several towns. Whereas they formerly had to join the real estate board and multiple-listing service in each municipality, they may now join only one board and buy one regionalized multiple-listings book.
Fairfield County's new Consolidated Multiple Listing Service produces two such books, one for down-county, the coastal area close to New York City, one for up-county, the Danbury and Shelton areas, with a total of about 18,000 listings. "One volume costs $25 a month, two are $50," said Donald Hull, director of the Norwalk-based service. "Most people buy the one for their area."
"We have about 4,000 members and sell some listings to an additional 700 members from Branford to Essex," he said. Using a Moore Data Systems program, the information is available to real estate agents and appraisers around the state, provided that they join one Fairfield County Board. "The next step," he said, "is tying into the Internet."
"The biggest shake-up was losing our own multiple-listing cash cow," said Kevin Bender, president of the Northern Fairfield County Association of Realtors, formerly the Greater Danbury Board of Realtors. Serving Danbury, Bethel, Brookfield, New Fairfield and Redding, with outside members from New Milford, Newtown and Ridgefield, the board had 1,200 members in the mid-80's. "People joined just for access to our multiple-listing service," he said.
The board is now down to 800 members, an increase of 10 percent over last year, but dues went up from $96 to $135 to help absorb the loss of service revenues. A $110 initiation fee is waived for licensed brokers. "The marginal people are gone," said Mr. Bender. "Agents today are treating this more as a profession than a hobby."
Large boards like Mr. Bender's and those in more affluent communities have tended to remain independent, some even continue to produce their own local multiple-listings books.
In Greenwich and Darien, rated, respectively, the second and sixth most expensive housing markets in the nation by Coldwell Banker Schlott (Beverly Hills, Calif., is first), local real estate boards and local multiple-listings services are not likely to merge or become regionalized in the foreseeable future. However, some agents and companies in those towns have joined the Westport-Weston-Norwalk-Wilton Board, and subscribe to the Consolidated Multiple Listing Service.
"We have no reason to merge with anyone," said Linda Hodge, vice president of Preferred Properties in Greenwich, where the median house price is $641,625, according to the Coldwell Banker Schlott survey. However, the company's six additional Fairfield County offices belong to various town boards and use the Consolidated Multiple Listing Service.
"What has to be worked on is embracing Greenwich, Darien and New Canaan into the regional multiple-listing service," said Peter Helie, president of William Pitt Real Estate. Based in Stamford, the agency has 14 offices around the state, mostly in Fairfield County.
Mr. Helie was a founder of Fairfield One, a multiple-listing service that joined with Realtors MLS to become the Consolidated Multiple Listing Service of Fairfield County. Fairfield One was capitalized in 1993 as a nonprofit corporation with loans of $500,000 each from William Pitt, William Raveis, Prudential and Coldwell Banker Schlott.
The PRC computer system of Fairfield One was not compatible with the Moore Data System of Realtors MLS, which was managed by Mr. Hull. In order to consolidate "a settlement was negotiated jointly with PRC," said Mr. Hull.
William Pitt had dropped its membership in the Stamford Board of Realtors. "We now belong to the New Milford Board," said Mr. Helie. "It was the most reasonable."
Costs in Stamford include a $900 one-time initiation fee for companies, and $200 for individual agents who are new to real estate. The agent's fee is waived for licensed brokers. Annual dues are $150. "About 40 people have gone to other boards," said Jan Milliken, president of the Stamford board, "but some are coming back."
In an economy move two years ago, the board sold its building on Third Street and now occupies rented quarters on Hope Street. "We've been talking to New Canaan, Darien and Greenwich about sharing some costs, but not merging and losing individual identities," said Ms. Milliken.
ANOTHER holdout against mergers is the Ridgefield Board, where memberships increased slightly this year from 185 to 200. Dues are $225 annually and the initiation fee is $150.
Memberships have increased more substantially at the Greater Bridgeport Board, from 690 in 1994 to 750 today. "We cut our dues from $150 to $129, and we waive the $100 initiation fee for licensed brokers," said Jeffrey Craw, the president.
"Memberships are going to shrink again," he said, "as agents take advantage of technology and become more efficient and sell more houses. But technology only helps with the preliminaries. This is a personal business -- people still want to touch and feel that house, see the community, have a human contact."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harriet Haffner and Gilbert Strickler check multiple listings at Haffner Realty office in Norwalk. A sampling of the houses for sale (right) on computer screen in the office. (Photographs by Susan Harris for The New York Times)
