HEADLINE: Vietnam Gives An American 5 Years in Jail

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Jan. 27

 BODY:
An American Vietnam War veteran who said he came back to Vietnam to live in peace was sentenced to five years in prison today for bringing weapons, banned videotapes and books into the country.
Everett Sennholz, 45, was arrested in August when a .30-caliber rifle was found in a shipment of his household goods in Haiphong, a port city 90 miles southeast of Hanoi. Vietnamese officials called the rifle a military weapon, but Mr. Sennholz maintained he used it only for hunting. 
 The case has alarmed foreigners in Vietnam because Mr. Sennholz appeared to have shipped his rifle, as well as the books and videos, without expecting any problem.
Vietnam has been trying to open its economy to the outside world. Communist hard-liners have objected to creeping Western influence, though, inspiring a crackdown on "cultural poison."
"His act has violated national security," Judge Nguyen Van Canh said as he read the prepared verdict.
Mr. Sennholz appeared shaken by the sentence.
A self-employed tax consultant from Puyallup, Wash., Mr. Sennholz said he had visited Vietnam five times since 1992 and was planning to marry a Vietnamese woman, settle in Haiphong and teach English. He said he had served in the Vietnam War as an Army weapons specialist, but gave no further details.
The Vietnamese allowed two American diplomats and 10 foreign journalists to attend the court session, but they were not allowed to talk to Mr. Sennholz. An American consular official who visited Mr. Sennholz in jail last week said he appeared to have been well treated.
In addition to the prison sentence, Mr. Sennholz was fined $12,700 for trying to bring in 23 banned videotapes and 24 banned books.
"If not discovered, they would have greatly affected social safety and order, and the Vietnamese people's traditions and customs," the judge said.
The books included Stanley Karnow's "Vietnam: A History." The videotapes included "Rambo," which posits that Vietnam is still holding American prisoners of war, and the pornographic 1970's movie "Behind the Green Door."
Mr. Sennholz said that he had reported the tapes and books to the authorities, as required by law.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Come To Africa

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: KIGALI, Rwanda

 BODY:
While on a stopover in Rwanda, the American U.N. representative, Madeleine Albright, asked her staff and the crew of their Air Force jet to pose for a picture on the runway of Kigali international airport. They all stood on the steps of their Boeing 737, which was emblazoned with the words "United States of America." There was a Greek-American, a Czech-American, Jewish Americans, black Americans and white Americans, there were Air Force crewmen from small towns and State Department experts from Ivy League colleges, and they were all standing there shoulder to shoulder. As they posed for the camera, I watched the Rwandan ground crew watching them. They had a slightly quizzical look. I couldn't help but wonder what the Rwandans made of this scene.
That picture represented everything that is good about America: the spirit of community, the melting pot, the willingness to help strangers in need and a concept of citizenship based on allegiance to an idea not a tribe. It is everything that a country like Rwanda is not. 
 I thought about that scene and I started to get mad -- mad about the budget debate in America today. We have something so special compared with almost every country in the world, but if we want to preserve it, we have to pay for it. I don't know exactly where the budget compromises should come. And there is certainly truth to the argument that to preserve our social safety nets, they have to be reformed and probably reduced in scope. But I do know this: When I listen to many of these freshmen Republicans I hear mean-spirited voices, uninterested in any compromise. I hear cold, Jacobin voices, who denounce government, who really want to let the market rule and who really want to scrap as much welfare, gun control, Medicare, Medicaid and taxes as they can.
Well, Africa today is a freshman Republican's paradise.
Nobody in Liberia pays taxes, there is no gun control in Angola, there is no minimum wage in Burundi and there is no welfare as we know it in Rwanda -- but a lot of their people sure wish there was. Like the desk clerk in Luanda, who looked at me as if I was out of my mind when I asked her if it was safe to take a walk three blocks from the hotel, down the main street of the Angolan capital in the middle of the day. No, no, no, she shook her head -- not safe. I'll bet she wouldn't mind paying some taxes for more police.
And then there was the Liberian journalist who approached me in Monrovia and demanded to know why the U.S. Marines came to Liberia after the civil war broke out in 1989, evacuated the U.S. citizens and then just left the Liberians to fight it out alone. "We all thought, the Marines are coming, we will be saved," he said, "but then they left. How could they leave?" Poor fellow, his country has no marines to come rescue him. I'll bet he wouldn't mind paying some taxes for a few marines.
They don't worry about "Big Government" in Liberia. They don't worry about government at all -- thanks to the gangs and warlords who rule most of the land. No, Liberians may never again have to worry about government regulations or red tape. In fact the only regulation I saw at the Executive Mansion there was a sign on a bullet-shattered window at the front door. It said: "Deposit Your Weapons Here."
Employers don't have to fret at all about pesky worker-safety rules in Angola, let alone services for the handicapped. The 70,000 Angolans who have had limbs blown off by land mines planted during the last 25 years of civil war seem to make do just fine on their own. You see them limping around the streets of Luanda, hustling for food and using tree limbs as a substitute for the human variety. They sure looked happy to me.
And in Rwanda and Burundi, no one is asked to pay for Head Start, unemployment insurance, Medicaid, national service or student loan programs. Instead they just have a brutal competition for scarce land, energy and water, in which Tutsi and Hutu take turns downsizing the other tribe in order to grab more resources for their own.
They say the freshmen Republicans almost never go on Congressional junkets. Too bad. They might want to come to Africa and glimpse what happens to countries where there is no sense of community, no sense that people owe their government anything, no sense that anyone is responsible for anyone else and where everyone, rich or poor, is left to the tender mercies of the global marketplace.

HEADLINE: Challenger's Legacy;
Risks Remain Despite NASA's Rebuilding

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Could it happen again? Without a doubt, experts agree, though NASA says the likelihood of catastrophe is less today than on that icy morning a decade ago when the space shuttle Challenger, 73 seconds into its flight, erupted in a ball of flame, killing seven people.
Like the owner of a costly but temperamental car who keeps trying to make do, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has invested more than $5 billion since the accident to rebuild the nation's fleet of winged spaceships and enhance the safety of hundreds of parts and systems, including the flawed engine and its leaky seal that doomed Challenger. And it has successfully flown 49 shuttle missions since then, no small accomplishment. 
 Even so, NASA officials see the risk of catastrophe as roughly 1 in 145 missions for each ship and worry that another disaster is almost inevitable. The aging fleet of four shuttles is to continue flying its wide range of science research missions for at least 10 years and become the central link to an international space outpost that is a pillar of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy. Orbital construction of the sprawling outpost is to start next year, with astronaut crews inhabiting it from 1998 to at least 2012.
Given the stakes, NASA is laboring to improve the shuttles still further and is planning a new generation of reusable spaceships meant to debut around 2005 that would be cheaper and safer to fly.
But experts inside and outside the space agency warn that the current risks are greater than generally assumed. Declining budgets and the political war over the Federal deficit, they say, threaten to erode safety and precipitate another calamity, despite all efforts to the contrary.
"NASA is again experiencing the economic strain that prevailed at the time of the disaster," said Diane Vaughan, author of "The Challenger Launch Decision," a new book published by the University of Chicago Press.
"Few of the people in top NASA administrative positions exposed to the lessons of the Challenger tragedy are still there," Ms. Vaughan said. "The new leaders stress safety, but they are fighting for dollars and making budget cuts."
Daniel S. Goldin, NASA's Administrator for nearly four years, has led a crusade to do things cheaper, smaller, faster and better, as he puts it. And breaking with predecessors, he has gone out of his way to highlight the possibility of astronaut loss, trying to prepare the nation for the worst even while insisting on a policy of cutting no corners.
"Safety is the highest priority," he said in a statement prepared for the disaster's 10th anniversary. "But human beings have always taken great risks to reap great rewards." Space flight, Mr. Goldin emphasized, "is inherently dangerous and every member of the NASA team understands those risks."
One imponderable is the political repercussions of another disaster, with experts split on whether the shuttles would survive to fly again or be retired as dangerously obsolete.
"I think we're over the period of political vulnerability, where an accident would pull the plug," said Lori B. Garver, executive director of the National Space Society, a private group in Washington that promotes space exploration.
Another imponderable is how deep budget knives might cut. In the past five years, the shuttle's annual budget has dropped from more than $4 billion to $3 billion and the main contractor work force has shrunk from 34,000 to 24,000 employees, even while the spaceships do roughly the same work, flying seven or eight times annually. In the next few years, plans call for the program's budget and ranks to shrink an additional 10 percent, and perhaps much more.
Jose Garcia, a veteran manager at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, where Challenger was launched, wrote an open letter to President Clinton in August to warn that the dollar squeeze was eviscerating the launching team and hastening another disaster.
"In their misguided attempt to economize," he said, "they have lost sight of what keeps the shuttle safe."
But many experts see the astronomical costs of running the nation's $65 billion fleet of shuttles as a drag on innovation at NASA, a faded star whose luster is just starting to return.
Bryan D. O'Connor, director of the shuttle program at NASA headquarters in Washington and a former astronaut, said the pressures were tolerable and that the winged spaceships were safer than ever before because of repairs as well as intangibles, like better communication among team members.
But he added that the Federal cost-cutting drive and the political war surrounding it were major distractions. All last week, NASA workers were unsure whether their agency would be financed and whether they would be back at work on Monday.
"There's pressure across the whole government," Mr. O'Connor said in an interview last week. "We're doing our part. We're working hard. But we also need to keep our priorities in mind, the first of which is safety. And on that score I think we're doing a pretty good job."
 
Recovering From Calamity
Most analysts agree that the Challenger disaster was partly rooted in a push to make the shuttle fleet pay for itself by carrying lots of government, scientific and commercial payloads. Pressures were intense as President Ronald Reagan called publicly for the shuttles to be cost effective.
The program made its debut in 1981, flew nine missions in 1985 and had plans for at least 24 a year by 1990. It was in that atmosphere that Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, began its last flight, the nation's 25th shuttle mission. The spaceship roared off the launching pad at 11:38 A.M. with a crew of six astronauts as well as Christa McAuliffe, a high school teacher who was to give school lessons from space.
The fiery explosion 73 seconds later was eventually determined to be the result of a leaky 15-story booster rocket that ignited the spaceship and its tons of highly flammable hydrogen fuel. A pair of boosters, mounted on either side of the shuttle, assist the spacecraft into orbit on each flight.
During a two-year hiatus in missions, engineers made repairs to hundreds of systems that in retrospect were judged unsafe, especially the solid-fueled boosters and the liquid-fueled main shuttle engines, which work at dangerously high heats, pressures and speeds.
NASA, prodded by Federal authorities, also sought more realistic risk estimates. Before the explosion, agency officials regularly put the chance of disaster at 1 flight in 100,000 -- close to the 1-in-1 million odds often associated with commercial airline flights.
By 1988, when shuttle flights resumed, the risk of catastrophic failure during the fiery ascent to orbit was estimated at 1 in 78, analogous to a hazard over the entire mission of roughly 1 in 50. As the agency continued to spend money for repairs, and did more thorough risk analyses, safety was seen as enhanced. A detailed NASA study by Science Applications International Corporation last year put the chance of catastrophic failure at between 1 in 76 and 1 in 230 missions, with 1 in 145 the most probable number.
While reliability is rising, the study concluded, "the risk of at least one more catastrophic failure is substantial" before the shuttles are retired sometime in the 21st century.
Last year, NASA began to install a major round of improved parts for the shuttle's temperamental main engines, long viewed as highly risky. Every shuttle is powered by three of the 3.5-ton, 14-foot-long giants, and all of them throughout the fleet are to get the upgrades, which include new fuel pumps, oxidizer pumps, power heads, heat exchangers and combustion chambers. The strengthening is to be completed by the year 2000 and to cost $1 billion.
The new systems tend to have fewer parts, fewer welds and to be made of materials that are stronger and lighter. The new pump bearings, for instance, are made of a high-tech ceramic compound, which is 30 percent harder and 40 percent lighter than steel.
"Hit them with a hammer and you'll dent the hammer," said June Malone, a spokeswoman at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala.
The upgrades are seen as eventually reducing shuttle dangers still further. Ben Buchbinder, head of hazard assessment at the Futron Corporation, in Bethesda, Md., and a former top shuttle-risk official at NASA headquarters, said the engine upgrades would reduce the overall danger of catastrophe to roughly 1 in 200 missions.
"There's a range of uncertainty," he said in an interview, emphasizing that great unknowns haunt the risk-study enterprise.
 
Wrestling With Intangibles
The shuttles now carry into space no major commercial or military payloads, which were banned after the accident and instead were put on unmanned rockets. In large measure, pressure to defray shuttle costs by carrying lots of payloads, which contributed to the disaster, is gone. But in its place is a barrage of new demands as the Government seeks to cut costs to the bone and as shuttles become a linchpin for an international space station that is meant to symbolize a new era of post-cold-war harmony.
Of late, NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, an independent body of experts, has repeatedly noted the budget pressures and criticized the shuttle program for a laggard pace of safety improvement. It has worried especially about the skittish main engines, whose dangers have been recognized for more than a decade.
"There is a distinct possibility," the panel's chairman, Paul M. Johnston, recently told Congress, "that overzealous reductions in the work force and NASA budgets, while at the same time retaining tight schedule pressures, may introduce increased levels of risk."
After hearing testimony from private and NASA experts, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican who chairs the House space subcommittee, was clearly upset and edgy.
"We're not sure," he said, "that safety has not been compromised."
The screws could tighten further in the near future as NASA moves to privatize the shuttle fleet, putting virtually every aspect of its operation in the hands of the United Space Alliance. The new contractor, based in Houston, is a unit of Rockwell International Corporation, the shuttle's maker, and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, a major shuttle contractor. The team hopes to soon put about 80 shuttle contracts under its purview.
The idea of a single contractor was endorsed last February as a cost-cutting device by a NASA panel headed by Dr. Chris Kraft, an aerospace consultant and former director of NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston.
"The Challenger incident created a safety environment in NASA that is duplicative and expensive," the Kraft panel reported. "Safety is one of those terms that can be used to hide behind and prevent necessary change and innovation."
Such sentiments gall many private analysts, who charge that the Challenger lessons are quickly being lost amid the confusion of the Federal budget wars.
"We seem to be lapsing back into a lot of the bad old practices that contributed to the accident," said John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group based in Washington.
"Apart from not flying the shuttle, there's nothing that can be done to prevent another accident, but there's lots that can be done to make it happen sooner rather than later," he said in an interview. "We seem to be doing a lot of those things."
 
Reaching Beyond The Shuttle
At the urging of Mr. Goldin, the NASA Administrator, the agency is now starting to plan a new generation of reusable spacecraft that in theory will be much cheaper and safer to fly than the shuttles, whose technology is a quarter century old.
The new spaceship is based on an idea studied for decades but not feasible until recently -- soaring into orbit on a single stage. Today, all rockets and shuttles rely on multiple stages because of the need to shed weight in the struggle to overcome the Earth's gravitational grip. The progressive abandonment of burned-out stages, composed of fuel tanks and heavy engines, allows speeding vehicles to become lighter and to move faster as they ascend.
The new ship, known as the Reusable Launch Vehicle, would be light to begin with, thanks to modern electronics and materials. Its huge internal fuel tanks, for instance, would be made out of composites formed of epoxy glue and strong fibers instead of metal. Thus, in theory, the vehicle would need only itself to soar into space.
Its numerous engines, fueled by liquid hydrogen and oxygen, would be far less complex than those of the shuttle and would operate at lower temperatures, pressures and speeds, greatly increasing the ship's safety.
Rick Bachtel, head of the project at NASA headquarters, said the goal was to achieve a risk of catastrophic failure of roughly 1 flight in 10,000. "Common sense tells us it won't be as reliable as an airline," he said in an interview, "but we're trying to take a step of that magnitude."
With slim financing, NASA is studying the idea in an experimental flight program known as X-33. Three teams, led by Rockwell, Lockheed Martin and McDonnell Douglas, are working on three competing designs and the agency expects to select one of them later this year.
The first flight of the X-33 is to occur in 1999, with a decision made at the turn of the century on whether to press ahead with the Reusable Launch Vehicle. If so, test flights of the ship would occur 2004 or 2005, and the innovative craft would be operational around 2008, if everything goes as planned. Contractors are already talking about flying the ships like airplanes, regularly ferrying tourists and business people into orbit.
But experts are quick to note that in the 1970's the same kind of promises were made for the original shuttle, many of which turned out to be false. Others worry that the new spaceships may be too difficult to build, or will be far less reliable than advertised.
But space enthusiasts love them, seeing the sleek new designs as a way to nurture the dream.
"As a nation," said Ms. Garver, executive director of the National Space Society, "we must dare to accomplish difficult tasks."

HEADLINE: Weary but Unwavering

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Three weeks of picketing night after frozen night, three weeks without a paycheck to support his three children, wife and 83-year-old mother, and three weeks of seeing "scabs" do his job have dulled Jose Caraballo's enthusiasm toward striking.
When Mr. Caraballo took to the streets with more than 30,000 building maintenance workers on Jan. 4, he was as gung-ho as any of them, his anger focused like a laser at management and its demands to slash starting salaries. But now, Mr. Caraballo, 43, a building porter who once studied law in his native Uruguay, seems angry at the world -- angry not just at management but also at the cold, at life without a paycheck and at the way the union is running the strike. 
 "It's hard, tremendously hard, to live when you haven't received a paycheck three weeks in a row," said Mr. Caraballo, whose job is to haul 27 floors' worth of garbage down the freight elevator and put it out on the curb. "It's scary because I'm not able to make this month's rent payment."
As Mr. Caraballo and other night-shift workers picket their building at 20 Broad Street from 5 P.M. to midnight, with the New York Stock Exchange towering over them on one side of the street and Morgan Guaranty's headquarters on the other, the strikers often feel like pawns caught in a struggle between forces greater than themselves.
"The union should realize we want a positive solution very soon," said Mr. Caraballo, a man with deep-set brown eyes and thinning black hair. "Many strikers are desperate since they have no money to live on."
With a dazed, wounded face like the farmer's in Millet's painting "The Man With the Hoe," Mr. Caraballo stands stolidly in the cold, bundled up in a boxy green coat, a black knit cap and a purple plaid scarf that is often wrapped around his ears as well as his neck. His point of vulnerability is his feet -- his shoes are of thin leather, definitely not Timberlands.
For Mr. Caraballo and many of the other strikers, the moments of solace are few. A striker splurges for a dozen hot chocolates for the late-night pickets. Some warm air streams up from the subway grates to help thaw their toes. And a man working at one of the financial firms in the building makes his daily offering to the strikers -- sometimes coffee and donuts, sometimes soda and rolls.
Hour after hour on the picket line leaves a lot of time for worry as the strike continues. Mr. Caraballo said his wife cannot get a job to help with their expenses because she is studying for a degree in bilingual education at Boricua College. Fortunately for them, her father, a taxi driver, is giving them about $100 a week during the strike. Mr. Caraballo also receives $7 in strike benefits for each day he pickets.
"We have to watch our money very closely," said his wife, Cecilia, who immigrated with her husband from Uruguay 10 years ago. "The children are unhappy because we're not taking them to movies or McDonald's during the strike. We don't even have the money to rent videos."
His concern about his family's sacrifices has muddled his thoughts about the strike. His thinking is part hang-tough, old-fashioned militancy and part wishing that the strike had ended yesterday.
On the one hand, he is eager for the union to act more flexibly to end the strike. On the other hand, he rejects the building owners' demand to cut the workers' $573 weekly starting salary by 40 percent. Then, sounding as implacable as a grizzled union negotiator, he said that even if management were to modify its stance and propose a starting salary that was 20 or 10 percent less, that would still be unacceptable.
"Imagine what would happen," he said in hesitant English -- an Argentine-born co-worker often translated for him. "There's a good chance they would get rid of the workers with higher salaries and then replace them with two employees earning a lot less. We can't accept a two-tier wage system."
Buildings owners are promising that veteran workers will not be dismissed. But dismissal is not Mr. Caraballo's only fear; he says that cutting starting salaries by 40 percent, to $352, would push workers toward welfare. "With what I earn now, it's not easy to support six people," he said. "At $352 a week, it would be impossible."
He acknowledges that the $573 he is paid -- $445 after taxes -- is "pretty good." But Mr. Caraballo, who lives in a three-bedroom apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, said it still does not afford him lodgings large enough for his family. "My three kids sleep in the same room," he said, noting that his Uruguayan mother has her own room.
Mr. Caraballo said he left Uruguay because that nation's economy was in crisis and job prospects were bleak.
"After I moved here, I wanted to return to school, but once you have children, you know, you have to support your family," he said. His dream, he says, is to become an X-ray technician.
But these days, he can think only of the strike. Perhaps one of the worst moments for Mr. Caraballo came when his building's owner, the Mendik Company, one of New York's largest real estate concerns, hired nonunion temporary workers and they made funny faces through the lobby window to ridicule the pickets.
"I feel very bad that the scabs are doing a job that is our job," he said.
But his anger toward them was leavened with understanding. "I understand there are a lot of people around who need a job," he said. "They're not really responsible for their situation. They're just trying to make ends meet."
Like many strikers, Mr. Caraballo admits to boredom on the picket line. He wishes Gus Bevona, president of the striking local, 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, would do more to buoy the strikers' spirits.
As three young men dressed in blue wool overcoats and expensive suits strode past him, seemingly oblivious to the strikers' existence, Mr. Caraballo complained that everyone ignores them.
"The union should organize rallies," he said. "We all feel ignored. It would be good to get more television coverage."
While praising Mr. Bevona for sending the strikers letters every day or two, he said the union should hold a large meeting to find out what is on the strikers' minds.
"The union should at least call a general meeting to tell us what's happening and to explain the different positions between union and management," he said. "The union should hear what the 35,000 strikers think about all this and what their situation is."
Tomorrow: A building manager's perspective.

HEADLINE: Strokes Cost $41 Billion a Year, Study Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The medical bills and lost earnings of Americans who suffer strokes each year total almost $41 billion, a new analysis has found.
Each year, 500,000 Americans suffer strokes, and 150,000 die from them. Strokes are the third leading cause of death, after heart disease and cancer. 
 Researchers from the University of Iowa tried to add up the financial toll by looking at the lifetime cost of strokes that occurred in 1990. They calculated that the average lifetime cost of a stroke, including medical care and lost earnings, was $103,576.
The research, conducted by Dr. Thomas N. Taylor and others, was presented on Thursday night at a stroke conference sponsored by the American Heart Association.
The researchers calculated that the lifetime cost of the strokes occurring in 1990 was $40.6 billion.
While the medical cost of caring for stroke victims is high, the researchers calculated that the lost earnings of stroke victims accounted for a higher proportion of the total economic cost, 58 percent.
"Improving survival can't substantially impact the cost," said Dr. Patricia Davis, one of the researchers. "We have to get people back to work after strokes."

HEADLINE: Congress Must Raise Debt Limit To Avoid Default, Clinton Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton urged Congress today to "stop playing politics" and raise the Government's legal debt limit so it could borrow more money and avoid defaulting on its financial obligations.
In his weekly radio address, broadcast less than a day after he signed emergency legislation to avert a third Government shutdown in as many months, the President said an unprecedented default by the Government on its debt could lead to higher interest rates and could even halt the mailing of Social Security checks. 
 "Our unbroken record of keeping our word could end," he said, "with taxpayers bearing the cost for years to come because interest rates would go up on United States obligations.
"And for tens of millions of Americans, the unthinkable could happen: the Social Security checks they count on would not be able to be mailed out," Mr. Clinton added.
On Friday, the Senate rejected, on a vote of 46 to 45, a Democratic proposal to raise the limit on the national debt to $5.4 trillion, from the current level of $4.9 trillion.
Although the Government actually reached its borrowing limit in November, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has used two pension trust funds for civil servants to avoid defaulting on maturing Government securities.
But Mr. Rubin has warned Congress that his options for dodging default are running out, and he has estimated that the Government will run out of borrowing power by March 1. Congress is to adjourn at the end of next week and will have no opportunity to act until it returns on Feb. 26.
Last week, Moody's Investors Service said the threat of a default could prompt it to consider downgrading its highest rating, AAA, on $387 billion in medium- and long-term debt that is coming due Feb. 29 and April 1. United States debt has traditionally been considered risk-free in terms of repayment.
In the Republican response to Mr. Clinton's remarks, Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire accused the President of inconsistency.
"While we always welcome the President's support, his sincerity about working together to fulfill our goals is too often fleeting, with no real action to back up his words," Senator Gregg said.

HEADLINE: Bahrain Rulers Say They're Determined to End Village Unrest

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Jan. 27

 BODY:
After a resurgence of civil unrest in the Shiite Muslim villages that surround this capital, a leading member of the Sunni Muslim ruling family said today that the Government was determined to put an end to the violence "once and for all."
"It cannot continue," the Prime Minister, Sheik Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, said of the riots, arson and explosions that broke out last weekend in a renewal of a 13-month-long confrontation between the Government and the Shiite-led opposition. 
 "These methods in a country like this will burn it all," Sheik Khalifa warned. "It will burn the dry and the green."
Bahrain, an island country of 600,000 people in the Persian Gulf, is connected by a causeway to Saudi Arabia and is the headquarters of the United States Fifth Fleet.
With hundreds of people in jail in connection with the disturbances, Bahrain has appeared relatively calm in recent days. But the arrests, including those of leading Shiite clerics, have added to political and sectarian tensions in a country where Shiites are in the majority.
The trouble began in December 1994 with the arrest and deportation of a Shiite cleric for circulating a leaflet signed by 20,000 people demanding the restoration of Bahrain's Parliament, which was dissolved in 1975.
After violence early last year that left at least 13 civilians and 3 policemen dead, there were signs that the Government might open a political dialogue with its opponents. But opposition leaders have accused the Government of reneging on a commitment to do so, and the disturbances that have resumed of late have included bombings at a shopping mall and a hotel.
In his interview today, Sheik Khalifa, whose family has ruled Bahrain for more than 200 years, did not spell out what the Government might do if the violence continued. But the Defense Ministry has said its forces are prepared to enforce martial law, and Sheik Khalifa, who is the younger brother of Bahrain's Emir, Sheik Issa bin Salman al-Khalifa, said he believed that "action has to be taken straight away to eliminate these problems once and for all."
The Government announced today that it had arrested 180 people in connection with recent unrest, Reuters reported. Earlier in the week, it had said it was holding 544 people: 174 rounded up in recent days and the rest for the protests last year. But two Government officials suggested today that the number might be higher, saying that more than 350 people had been arrested since the beginning of the month.
The main Shiite opposition group, the London-based Bahrain Freedom Movement, puts the number of detainees at about 2,000.
The most prominent person in custody is Sheik Abdelamir al-Jamri, a Shiite cleric who was a member of the dissolved Parliament. The Bahraini authorities have also announced the arrests of seven other leading clerics, and a ninth, Ahman Mansour Ali, is also reported to have been imprisoned.
All are expected to face trial on charges of inciting riots, and Bahraini officials, who say privately that there is evidence linking the attacks to Iran, have said the clerics may also be charged with taking part in a foreign-backed plot.
Although Shiites comprise only about one-tenth of the world's one billion Muslims, in Bahrain they outnumber Sunnis -- members of the rival branch of Islam, to which the Khalifa family and most of the country's elite belong -- by about 2 to 1. Shiism has dominated Iran since the 10th century, and the Manama Government has suspected Teheran of trying to stir up trouble among Bahrain's Shiites since Islamic militants took power in Iran in 1979.
Iran has denied any involvement in the unrest here, and the daily Iran News said on Monday that Bahrain was using Teheran as a scapegoat to justify its refusal to grant political rights to its people. It said that Bahrain's ruling family had "denied its people even the most basic semblance of democracy -- Parliament -- through which they could have a say in shaping their future," and that it was only natural that "mass dissatisfaction and civil disturbance should be the outcome."
But other regional leaders, including President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, have suggested foreign involvement in the unrest here, and today Sheik Khalifa came as close as any Bahraini official has to publicly pointing the finger at Tehran.
"These people had studied in Iran," the Prime Minister said in describing many of those under arrest. "What did they study, how they have been trained, how they have been contacted, their confessions -- all this will come out in court."
Unlike its Gulf neighbors, Bahrain produces no oil of its own, and mounting unemployment, particularly among the Shiite majority, is clearly a major cause of discontent. In Shiite villages like Bani Jamra, one of the sites of this week's unrest, anti-Government graffiti demand jobs and the overthrow of the Khalifa family.
Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of daytime fasting, began last Sunday, and many here say that the slower pace it traditionally brings has helped quell the violence. In Bani Jamra this afternoon, the streets were almost deserted, and the few residents who were outside the closed doors refused to talk with a foreign reporter.
By today, the riot policemen who were dispatched last weekend to Shiite villages had been withdrawn, although a police convoy was moving conspicuously through Manama on its way to what officials said was an exercise.
The Bahraini officials made clear that they were no mood to give in to their critics' demands as a way to win a permanent end to the violence.
"Yes, the Western countries and the people here talk about democracy," Sheik Khalifa said. "We are not afraid of democracy. We are afraid of the people who would misuse it."

HEADLINE: Gramm Brings Fiscal Message To the Kitchen Tables of Iowa

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MARION, Iowa, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Senator Phil Gramm came here this morning for coffee, banana bread and an intimate chat with the Steffeck family around their dining table. But the four towheaded Steffeck children were nowhere in evidence.
"I don't know where our kids are," said Laura Steffeck, peering up from the table past two dangling microphones and into the shifting, murmuring mass of two dozen reporters and campaign workers. "Can they get through?" 
 With the children produced and the coffee poured, Mr. Gramm commenced to do what he has done at kitchen tables across Iowa this week: lecture the family on economics.
"In the five years since 1950 that we've had a balanced Federal budget, prime interest rates averaged three and a half percent," he said, speaking loud enough to reach past the Steffecks clustered at the table to the reporters spilling back into the living room.
Lamar Alexander may have his red-plaid shirt, but Phil Gramm has come up with a trademark gimmick in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination that he believes powerfully conveys his program for "kitchen table economics." He outlines the program at kitchen tables.
Politicians talk about the budget "in an environment which to most people is totally artificial," Mr. Gramm explained to the Steffecks, describing his epiphany. "And so it suddenly struck me: Where do most people make their budget decisions, and make the hard choices in their family life?"
The answer: "Right at their kitchen table."
He may be trying to eliminate artifice, but Mr. Gramm's effect can be to bring political kitsch into the kitchen. It does not help that his largely untouched cup of coffee tends to share space on the table with a bouquet of half a dozen microphones, accompanied by a few small black tape recorders like so many sinister brownies.
It also does not help that Mr. Gramm, dressed in a gray suit and white shirt, can sound less like a neighbor than like the economics professor he was in his home state of Texas, or the candidate he is.
At the Cox home in Dubuque on Tuesday, Drew, age 11, timidly asked: "I mean, what's it going to be like in the future?-- Is there going to be all these gangster people running around?"
Mr. Gramm paused, then began, "Well, let me say that I'm very concerned about violent crime."
At each stop, Mr. Gramm exchanged some niceties with the families, admiring their homes and inquiring about their jobs. When he discovered at a home in Ankeny that his host, Jeff Behan, worked as a mechanical engineer for John Deere, he declared:
"One of my dreams is to someday have a John Deere tractor with a front-end loader. And I want what's called a Rhino bush hog."
He added, "I want to run over and tear up things that a conventional bush hog will not mow down."
Mr. Gramm tested his kitchen-table technique in New Hampshire and South Carolina. This week, he brought it to Iowa for the first time, accompanied by a black-and-white chart with a remarkably precise breakdown of "What a Balanced Federal Budget Would Mean to Iowans." It lists, for example, "$2,067 savings on a six-month loan" and "$1,099 savings per year on a 30-year mortgage."
"Here is the point," Mr. Gramm told the Steffecks and their increasingly restive children. "For the last 25 years, the Federal Government has borrowed 50 cents out of every dollar that's been saved in America. That's 50 cents out of every dollar that has not gone to build a new home, a new farm, a new factory, to generate new economic growth."
Although he remains back in the pack in polls, Mr. Gramm's facts and figures clearly impressed the four families he visited this week who were selected by the Gramm campaign because they were undecided.
"I just didn't realize how strong he was on positions I care about," Mrs. Steffeck said later. "He just doesn't seem to be getting his message across real clearly, maybe, to people like me."
The children, she added, "were a little nonplussed." She said she and her husband were also considering Patrick J. Buchanan and Alan Keyes.
Mrs. Steffeck, who brewed an extra pot of coffee for reporters, said she did not mind having so many strangers track snow through the house. "It's used to thousands of kids," she said of the house. "Nothing was broken."
Still, one cameraman, losing control of his tripod, knocked an angel cut from a paper plate from its perch in an ivy plant. As the crowd poured out of the house, the angel was still lying on the floor, behind a speaker.

HEADLINE: Many Exchange a Briefcase For the Sample Case of Sales

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL

 BODY:
To sell vitamins and shampoo to friends and neighbors, Sharon Killion Morton quit her job as an advertising sales representative for USA Today, where she made $110,000 a year and drove a company Mercedes-Benz.
Bill Dorr, who lost his job as a Wall Street investment banker in a cutback, now peddles a discount long-distance telephone service to former co-workers. 
 And Dr. Robert Greene, an internist, has had such success selling products like In-Vigor-Ol, an herbal energy tonic, that he plans on becoming a gentleman physician, seeing just one or two patients a day.
All three of these people are part of a most unlikely trend: professionals and white-collar executives who have joined the ranks of direct selling popularized by companies like Tupperware and Mary Kay Cosmetics. Where once this work was the province of stay-at-home wives who added a few hundred dollars a year to the family income, the new recruits dream of six-figure earnings and freedom from the seismic upheavals that have riven the world of traditional work.
"We're seeing a much more highly educated group of people coming in," said Neil H. Offen, president of the Direct Selling Association, a trade group in Washington. "We're seeing a lot of middle-management executives who've been laid off because of corporate downsizing. The American reality of 'you work hard, play by the rules and your talent will get you to the top' is not true anymore in the corporate world."
The number of Americans involved in direct sales rose 34 percent from 1990 to 1994, to 6.3 million from 4.7 million, figures from the Direct Selling Association show. A sharp increase in the number of men in the ranks -- the figure was 10 percent in 1992; by 1994 it was 24 percent -- is evidence of the influx of white-collar workers, Mr. Offen said.
Most of the selling is done part time, usually from people's homes but increasingly in the workplace. White-collar recruits speak of wanting to cushion themselves from corporate job-slashing, provide for a secure retirement and enjoy more time with their families.
But many are likely to be let down; according to Mr. Offen's group, 90 percent of those who sell earn less than $5,000 a year. And many direct-sales companies have been accused by prosecutors of shady practices, including violating anti-pyramid laws and making false claims about "miracle" products.
"At first I was skeptical, but I kept hearing how much money has been made this way," said Mr. Dorr, a former managing director in the fixed-income department of Bear, Stearns & Company.
The appeal of direct selling to executives like Mr. Dorr comes largely from the earnings potential of multilevel marketing, a compensation system in which people profit not only from their own sales but also from the sales of others they bring into the company.
Mr. Dorr, 55, tries to persuade people to switch their long-distance carrier to Excel Telecommunications, a small company based in Dallas, and, more important, to become Excel sales representatives like him. He earns commissions on the phone bills of the customers he signs up, as well as on the bills of customers signed up by the sales representatives he recruits, and their recruits' customers, and so on.
With a network spreading from the top down and commissions flowing to each person higher up the chain, multilevel marketing -- MLM, in the industry shorthand -- has created millionaires, but it has also drawn government lawsuits when companies have veered too close to illegal pyramid schemes.
Most states say an illegal pyramid exists when recruits do not go forth to sell a concrete product, but only to gather more recruits, who typically must pay a fee to join the company.
"Every illegal pyramid is an MLM company," said Robert Ward, a Michigan assistant attorney general. "But not every MLM is an illegal pyramid."
The ranks of multilevel marketers include the Fortune 500 giants Amway, founded in 1959, and Mary Kay, founded in 1963. Of the 140 member companies in the Direct Selling Association, the majority are multilevel marketers.
The Shaklee Corporation, a maker of nutritional and personal-care products sold through multilevel marketing, says that about 20 percent of its several thousand sales leaders come from the ranks of professionals and corporate executives.
"It's a factor of what's happening in the economy," said Karin D. Topping, a Shaklee spokeswoman. "People are looking for alternatives, knowing there is no secure job."
Ms. Morton, a Fort Worth resident who resigned from USA Today to sell Shaklee products, complained of her old job: "It was real frustrating. There was the constant pressure of sales quotas. They were always reorganizing sales categories and sales territories."
Paula Cook-Ehrlich worked as an executive in the airline industry until five and a half years ago, when she became a distributor for Nu Skin International, a maker of skin-care and nutritional products.
Ms. Cook-Ehrlich, 46, is a "blue diamond" distributor for Nu Skin, the highest sales level. The company, which is based in Utah, says blue diamonds earn an average of $704,000 a year in commissions.
"In five and a half years, I'm living a life style people couldn't imagine," Ms. Cook-Ehrlich said by telephone from her home on an island in Miami's Biscayne Bay. She said Nu Skin had attracted many doctors to its sales ranks because of the way managed care was eroding doctors' incomes and autonomy.
Dr. Greene, the internist, said he began selling high-fiber weight-loss drinks and anti-wrinkle creams for Rexall Showcase International because he wanted the financial freedom to spend more time with his children, ages 10 and 16, at their home in Bedford, N.Y.
"It's the life style that attracts me to this," said Dr. Greene, 49. Colleagues have taken to calling him Mad Dog because of the tenacity with which he solicits patients and friends to become Rexall distributors. A percentage of their profits, of course, would pass up to him.
"This is hot stuff," Dr. Greene is likely to tell patients who come in to his two Westchester County offices.
"I ask everybody, 'Are you interested in looking at this?' " he said. "If they say no, I say: 'Fine, give me permission to call you back in three months. We never know where life leads us. You may be fired, your company may go out of business, and besides that, I'd like to share with you my success.' "
Until a year ago, Dr. Greene had been merely a doctor, not a salesman, but he said he had not found it hard to sell packaged goods. Any embarrassment, he said, is quickly dissipated "just from the fact I'm $90,000 richer." That is the sum he said that he, his medical partner, Dr. David Ennis, and Dr. Ennis's wife, Laurie, had made together representing Rexall, which bought the name of the former drugstore chain.
Doctors and dentists who engage in multilevel marketing present a special case, medical ethicists say, because of the trust patients normally place in them. Some angry patients have been known to switch practitioners when asked to buy a product in the examining room.
New York State regulators say no state laws prohibit medical professionals from selling a line of goods out of their offices. Problems would arise, they say, only if a dentist, for example, recommended a remedy for an ailment that he was not licensed to treat, like heart disease.
Dr. Lewis Kulik, a dentist in Manhattan who sells Rexall remedies, said he generally advised patients first to consult a physician for nondental ailments. But in the case of a patient made anxious by dental work, Dr. Kulik offers Calmplex 2000, a Rexall herbal product that is billed as reducing tension. "If they feel it will help them, they might want to purchase a box," he said.
The American Dental Association, in its code of ethics, says the sale to patients of dental products from which dentists profit is not prohibited. But last year, partly in response to the rise of multilevel marketing, the association warned dentists not "to exploit the trust inherent in the dentist-patient relationship for their own financial gain."
Companies that use multilevel marketing are hoping that the influx of distributors like Dr. Kulik and Dr. Greene will raise the image of the field, which has a history of scams and fly-by-night operators. Mr. Ward, the Michigan assistant attorney general, says the average multilevel marketer remains in business just 18 to 24 months.
The field has also been known for inflating claims about its products and the earnings a distributor can expect to make.
"They often represent that they have miracle products," said Larry Hodapp, a senior lawyer at the Federal Trade Commission. "This seems to appeal to MLM's, the fact that it's a medical breakthrough that will result in astronomical growth for the company."
The maker of an herbal concoction called Juice Plus sold by multilevel marketing once employed O. J. Simpson to testify that it cured his arthritis.
In 1994, Nu Skin paid $1 million to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission that it exaggerated the effectiveness of its Nutriol baldness remedy and Face Lift wrinkle cream, and that it overstated the income that distributors could expect. Nu Skin released data showing that the bottom 70 percent of its distributors cleared an average of just $311 in commissions in 1994.
"One of the biggest problems in the field is outrageous earnings claims," said Mr. Offen of the Direct Selling Association, which requires members to adhere to a code of ethics. Updated in 1993 in response to government cases against the industry, the ethics code prohibits income misrepresentation and "inventory loading" -- encouraging distributors to buy a basement full of products to reap a higher commission. Much of that merchandise never gets sold.
Mr. Offen said the turnover rate in multilevel sales is high; as many people drop out as join up in a given year. Based on a survey his trade group commissioned, only 6 percent of those in the business pursue direct sales full time. Of those, 1 out of 10 makes more than $100,000 a year.
"Anybody who says it's easy to make big money in direct selling is lying," Mr. Offen said. "It takes hard work, lots of effort. But it is a wonderful opportunity, where 1 out of 10 who go full time are making $100,000."
C. Steven Baker, the director of the Chicago regional office of the Federal Trade Commission, expressed skepticism. "They tell you you can get into these things part time and as you go it'll become full time," he said. "But people find no matter how hard they do it, they can't give up their day job."
Despite the industry's controversies, many experts expect its ranks to grow. "Over the last five to 10 years, there's been a lot of downsizing, and people have been taking early outs," Mr. Ward said. "They don't want to work for somebody else because that somebody else let them down."

HEADLINE: War Crimes Tribunal on Bosnia Is Hampered by Basic Problems

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The international tribunal investigating war crimes in the former Yugoslavia is facing fundamental problems that could undermine its ability to bring suspects to justice, lawyers and human rights officials assert.
One of the most pressing problems is the possible departure of the chief prosecutor, Richard Goldstone, a South African jurist whose independence and drive is credited with reinforcing Washington's decision to make war crimes prosecutions a cornerstone of the Dayton peace accord signed last December. 
 Mr. Goldstone, who met with Clinton Administration and United Nations officials in Washington and New York this week to try to iron out some of the problems, has said he must be back in South Africa by June or July. Lawyers familiar with the tribunal's work say that it is vital for the panel to show momentum in the next several weeks and that they are concerned about its fate if Mr. Goldstone leaves.
Even as the Clinton Administration offers intelligence material and the tribunal haggles with NATO over how its forces in Bosnia will help, the panel is trying to resolve other urgent questions, including these:
*How can the leaders of Serbia and Croatia, obliged under the Dayton accord to cooperate with the tribunal, be persuaded to send the indicted war criminals they harbor to The Hague, where the tribunal sits?
*How can suspects be arrested, given the opposition from the Pentagon and NATO to having their soldiers in Bosnia make the arrests?
*What headway can the tribunal make in investigations only now beginning of Serbian paramilitary leaders whose troops are accused of committing many of the worst atrocities?
*How aggressively can the investigations into President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia be pursued now that they have signed the Dayton accord and are needed to help keep the peace?
Created by the United Nations in 1993 after the Balkan war stirred outrage because of the worst atrocities in Europe since World War II, the tribunal makes its own decisions on who to pursue and how to investigate them. Its 11 judges from 11 countries, including Judge Gabrielle Kirk McDonald of Texas and the president of the court, Judge Antonio Cassesse, a distinguished jurist in international law from Italy, have developed their own trial procedures.
Nearly 150 lawyers, analysts, investigators, translators and clerks, including a core group of about 20 American attorneys and F.B.I. agents on loan from the Justice Department, work for the prosecutor under fortress-like security at a triangular building at The Hague. Formerly an insurance company headquarters, the space has been renovated into an ultra-modern courtroom and office suites.
About 50 investigators are divided into nine teams assigned to particular targets. A special team was created last year to look into the three leaders, Mr. Milosevic, Mr. Tudjman and President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, but it has made little headway, according to tribunal officials.
So far, the court has indicted 52 people -- 45 Serbs and 7 Croats -- on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity. Only one of the 52 is in custody, a Bosnian Serb, Dusko Tadic, a relatively small fish. Arrested in Germany in 1994, he is charged with the deportation of Muslim civilians to the Omarska camp near Prijedor in northwestern Bosnia and the rape and murder of prisoners there.
 
The Judge Problem
Change Could Harden Serbia's Attitude
Mr. Goldstone said he made clear from the moment he agreed to be the chief prosecutor that he would eventually have to leave to resume his position on the newly formed South African Constitutional Court. He said President Nelson Mandela had agreed for him to take a maximum two-year leave of absence, which ends in July. His absence from South Africa is an increasing political embarrassment for Mr. Mandela, who must appoint an interim judge every three months to fill his empty chair, Mr. Goldstone said.
Mr. Goldstone was known during the closing era of white rule in South Africa for heading a commission on political violence and issuing a tough report on senior police officials, and he says his personal priority is still South Africa. But in the last few days Mr. Goldstone has said he would consider staying on if a successor was not found.
Some supporters of the tribunal say they were concerned about whether a replacement could be found who had as much symbolic value as Mr. Goldstone and who could also pass muster at the United Nations Security Council, which must approve any appointee. It took more than six months to find Mr. Goldstone after Russia and Muslim countries scuttled other possibilities.
A Serbian attorney said it was important for Mr. Goldstone to continue if there was to be any hope of getting the Serbian Government to cooperate. "Milosevic doesn't care about The Hague because he doesn't think it will happen," said Srdja Popovic, a lawyer who defended members of the Milosevic Government before falling out of favor and being forced into exile in the United States. "If Mr. Goldstone goes it will be another signal for Milosevic not to worry."
 
The Cooperation Problem
Zagreb Won't Blink And Belgrade Stalls
The key to getting Serbia to arrest and extradite its suspects, according to lawyers and diplomats, is to convince Croatia to do so first. But Croatian officials complain that it is unfair to pressure them without doing the same to the Serbs.
"Milosevic will never cooperate unless Tudjman does," said Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, an organization based in New York. "If the West's golden boy doesn't cooperate, why should Milosevic?"
Mr. Roth said Washington and Western Europe had leverage on Mr. Tudjman, who has good relations with Germany and Washington and is eager to be admitted to European institutions.
The Croatian Deputy Foreign Minister, Ivan Simonovic, said in an interview that Croatia "wants to cooperate" but that his Government is not satisfied that equal pressure is being put on Serbia to surrender its indicted suspects.
"Legally there is no question under the peace agreement that every country is bound to cooperate with the tribunal," said Mr. Simonovic, who is also a law professor and who met with Mr. Cassesse when the judge visited Zagreb in mid-January to press for the extradition of the seven Croats. "But we think it's unjust toward Croatia and the federation that we have to cooperate first."
It is conceivable that Croatia will "blink first," Mr. Simonovic said. "But first we expect more pressure on the other side by the international community."
The Croatian Government was under "tremendous" pressure from its public not to give up the seven indicted Croats while three prominent Serbian military officials indicted for atrocities against Croats at Vukovar in 1991 remained free, he said.
Officials at the tribunal said last week that they had turned down offers by Croatia to give up the seven on the condition they were tried in Croatia and could serve sentences there.
Belgrade continues to stonewall the tribunal, Mr. Goldstone said. A meeting between Mr. Cassesse and Serbian officials in Belgrade last Tuesday apparently failed to gain any important result. On Thursday, however, the Bosnian Serb leadership, apparently under pressure from Mr. Milosevic, said it would allow international investigators to visit mass grave sites in their territory.
Belgrade has ignored requests to arrest the Bosnian Serb leaders, Gen. Ratko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic, both indicted on charges of genocide for the killing of thousands of Muslim civilians at Srebrenica, tribunal officials said.
Even on simpler matters, such as allowing the tribunal to open a liaison office in Belgrade, the Milosevic Government has balked. Belgrade has also refused to pressure Bosnian Serb officials to permit the court-appointed defense attorney for Mr. Tadic, the only indicted suspect to be arrested, to go to the site of the Omarska camp.
That was a ploy to frustrate the tribunal, lawyers said. If Mr. Tadic's attorney cannot visit the site, the trial will not be able to go ahead in March as scheduled.
Tribunal officials insist that one of the reasons the list of indicted looks lopsided -- no Muslims are on it -- is that investigators have been denied access to Serbian witnesses of atrocities committed by Muslims.
"I cannot say that we have ever received or are we receiving the cooperation we are entitled to from the Government of Serbia and Montenegro," Mr. Goldstone said at NATO headquarters this month. "Nothing has changed since the Dayton agreement, even though it commits the signatories to help detain indicted war criminals and insure their speedy transfer to the international court in The Hague."
If Serbia does not cooperate, the Dayton agreement stipulates that international economic sanctions can be reimposed. Diplomats said that if Croatia did not cooperate it would be barred from the Western financial and political institutions it hopes to join.
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John Shalikashvili, has strongly opposed having American soldiers arrest General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic, an official close to the tribunal said.
Spooked by the deaths of 18 American soldiers who were killed while trying to capture a warlord during the American mission in Somalia, General Shalikashvili is reported by Washington officials to be adamant on the issue. The arrests of popular Bosnian Serb leaders or even rank-and-file officers could bring retaliation against NATO forces, Pentagon officials have said.
While in Washington, Mr. Goldstone was trying to clarify what the tribunal would be getting from Defense Secretary William J. Perry's offer to provide electronic intercepts made by intelligence agencies during the war. Such conversations, especially between Serbian commanders, could provide corroboration for witness testimony.
But a Washington official who has access to the Administration's intelligence on Bosnia and who visited The Hague this month said that promises by the C.I.A. in December to provide more satellite imagery and intercepts "still had a way to go to make it work."
To obtain evidence against Mr. Milosevic, the tribunal's prosecutor's office has suggested that the most likely route is through an associate "spilling the beans."
 
The Evidence Problem
Finding Witnesses Proves Difficult
"My impression is that the tribunal has not forgotten about Milosevic but I don't think he is the highest priority now," said a Western diplomat.
This was a polite way of saying that while the tribunal is independent, it also operates in an intense political atmosphere. Even human rights officials, who say the tribunal's job will not be complete unless Mr. Milosevic is fully investigated and then presumably indicted, say they are willing to allow for a grace period.
Mr. Milosevic's cooperation on sensitive issues like bringing Serbian-held Sarajevo suburbs under Bosnian Government control and insuring Bosnian Serb military compliance is needed in these early stages of the peace agreement, said Mr. Roth of Human Rights Watch.
Before concentrating on Mr. Milosevic and any role he may have had in directing and organizing war crimes, investigators are now beginning to focus on two notorious Serbian paramilitary leaders, Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan, and Vojislav Seselj. They believe that through these two the chain of command could reach Mr. Milosevic.
Lawyers familiar with the tribunal offer several explanations of why it has taken so long to pursue the trail of two men accused of being among of the most vicious proponents of "ethnic cleansing." First, they say, the tribunal spent enormous time and resources firming up the evidence for the indictments of General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic. Second, obtaining witnesses against these two paramilitary leaders has proved difficult.
"They are so notorious that witnesses would say, 'Arkan's people were here, Sesjil's people were there,' " said a lawyer familiar with the cases, explaining that while many acts of violence were attributed to the two, many accounts by witnesses were vague. "To get hard evidence is more difficult than seemed at first blush."
The reason that the indictments of General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic are so strong, the lawyer said, is that the two men could be clearly identified through their physical presence at and near the sites of killings at Srebrenica, a United Nations "safe area" that was captured by the Bosnian Serbs this summer. There is a view at the tribunal, the lawyer said, that to obtain an indictment and then a conviction it is necessary to tie a suspect to a particular incident.
If that view prevailed, indictments of Arkan, of Mr. Sesjil and, especially further up the line, of Mr. Milosevic, could prove very difficult, the lawyer suggested.

HEADLINE: WHITMAN'S BUDGET CALLS FOR A DROP IN STATE SPENDING

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
After two years of cutting taxes while increasing state spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will chart a different course in her third state budget, by reducing overall spending, if only slightly, through cuts in almost every state agency.
The Governor's $15.98 billion spending plan, outlined today by senior administration officials, is $124 million lower than the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. That amounts to a spending decrease of less than 1 percent. 
 Mrs. Whitman, who will formally present her budget proposal to the State Legislature on Monday, has cemented her reputation as a tax cutter by fulfilling her campaign promise to reduce income-tax rates by 30 percent, a year ahead of schedule. But she increased state spending by $700 million. In this budget, Mrs. Whitman moves forward on her other campaign pledge to help pay for the $1.2 billion tax cut with further reductions in government spending.
State colleges and universities would face cuts in some cases. Mrs. Whitman will try to save $26 million in the state's prescription program for the elderly by requiring higher co-payments and possibly removing from the program 30,000 senior citizens whose liquid assets exceed $50,000.
And she is seeking $11.7 million in new revenues by raising or introducing fees -- for instance, charging welfare recipients for services like day care. She also wants to extend the state sales tax to wrapping supplies and prewritten computer software.
As in previous years, the Governor's plan also calls for layoffs. The state work force of 62,740 would shrink by 1,220 -- 814 through layoffs and 406 through attrition.
However, school spending for poorer urban districts would rise a total of $60 million as part of the administration's effort to comply with court rulings requiring parity among school districts. But for 63 school districts with the highest administrative costs, school aid would be reduced by $6.6 million. And state aid for municipalities would remain at current levels.
Senior Whitman administration officials began dribbling out information about the new state budget on Thursday when they made public their revenue assumptions for the new fiscal year, and continued today when they presented broad outlines of the Governor's spending proposal without providing details such as the impact that the proposed cuts would have state programs and services.
Amid the second-worst joblessness of any big industrial state and growing concern about the uncertainty of the regional economy, the Governor's plan assumes lower unemployment and moderate economic growth.
Tax revenues are projected to increase $152 million even as state budget officials said only this week that revenues for the rest of the current fiscal year would be less than expected. Senior officials say they do not agree with the flurry of recent reports suggesting a sudden downturn in the state's economy and a rise in joblessness.
However, Mrs. Whitman, recognizing that the state's economy needs a boost, is recommending that the Legislature spend $100 million to stimulate economic development, most of it for worker retraining.
Peter Verniero, the Governor's chief of staff, said Mrs. Whitman sought to balance the needs of various constituency groups with the interests of taxpayers. "Under that standard," he said, "this budget is both prudent and fair."
Democrats, however, were quick to criticize the proposed budget, saying it failed to account for a recent downturn in employment and consumer spending. Since taking office, Mrs. Whitman has helped balance past budgets with such tactics as substantially reducing the state's contribution to public-employee pensions. In this budget, she relies less on nonrecurring revenues, although she proposes to pull a $250 million surplus from a temporary disability insurance fund. The budget proposal also includes a $550 million surplus, to cushion against tax revenue shortfalls and unexpected spending increases.
Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, the bond-rating agency, had praise for the budget, saying of Mrs. Whitman: "She is on her way. The new budget is flat, year to year. She is trimming, and homing in, and eliminating waste."
Details of what impact the proposed cuts would have on state programs and services were not available today and will not be made public until the Governor's budget address on Monday. For example, it was unclear which state agencies would lose workers.
But documents distributed today, when compared with similar budget reports from last year, do indicate that the largest spending reductions will be at the Departments of Human Services, Environmental Protection, Health, Community Affairs and the Judiciary. In addition, the Banking and Insurance Departments are to be combined. Meanwhile, spending will increase slightly in the Corrections Department to pay for part of the Governor's new juvenile justice programs, including a boot camp.
State Democrats, who are in the minority in both houses, said the Governor's budget was based on unrealistic revenue assumptions. "They might turn out to be negative as time goes on as indicated by sales and unemployment figures," said Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., the ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee. Federal labor statistics showed a New Jersey unemployment rate of 7.3 percent in December, but administration officials say that the joblessness rate in the coming fiscal year will be 6.2 percent.
Republican legislative leaders praised the proposal and pledged to work closely with the Governor to keep costs and spending down. "We will do all we can to assist her in this effort," said the new Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, a Salem County Republican.
Mr. Collins did not say, however, whether the Assembly supported the Governor's idea to increase co-payments or remove senior citizens from the state's prescription job program for the elderly and disabled. There was relief among some of the state's mayors that Governor Whitman did not cut state assistance to municipalities. It remains at $1.5 billion, with the administration continuing to phase out the Density Aid program, a formula created by Democrats to distribute more aid to suburban areas with high population density.
"I am very pleased that they are maintaining the same level of assistance as they did last year," said Mayor Robert L. Reiher of West Caldwell, who was working at Town Hall on his Essex County community's budget this morning. "This is what we have all been hoping for. We did not want to see state revenues decrease to local municipalities."
Despite dire warnings last year that Mrs. Whitman's decision to hold the line on state aid to cities and towns would lead to huge increases in property taxes, that did not happen last year. Senior aides said today that they did not expect their plan to lead to huge property tax rises this year.
Mrs. Whitman's spending plan does not include a new proposal to replenish an expired state fund that provides $400 million for hospital care for the poor. The Legislature did not go along with the Governor's recommendation in December to raise cigarette taxes by 25 cents a pack to help pay for the fund. The state's authority to continue drawing on the Unemployment and Compensation fund expired on Dec. 31.
 
HIGHLIGHTS: The Whitman Plan
 
Highlights of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's Budget
 
Total spending of $15.98 billion, down $124 million from fiscal 1996, a decrease of less than 1 percent.
 
Project growth in revenues of less than 1 percent, to $15.6 billion, in addition to a carryover of more than $500 million in 1996 money to make up the difference.
 
One-time savings or revenue items totalling $298 million, including $250 appropriated from the temporary disability insurance fund, and a $16 million savings through debt refinancing.
 
Highlights of the Spending Plan
 
State agency spending: $5.095 billion on departmental operations, down $138 million.
 
State work force: a reduction of 1,220 employees, to 60,477 by July 1997, with 814 layoffs -- about 200 from the Department of Environmental Protection and a loss of about 406 jobs through attrition.
 
State aid, including aid to schools, and municipalities and other recipients: $6.395 billion, down $51.8.
 
Increased school aid of $60 million, with poorest districts sharing distribution of $60 million.
 
Debt service: $466.3 million for debt service, down $3.2 million.
 
A $6.6 million cut in aid to 63 school districts that which spend more than 129 percent of the state average on administrative functions.
 
Prescription subsidies for 230,000 senior citizens: A $26 million reduction by possibly increasing co-payments or by cutting off eligibility to 30,000 elderly who have liquid assets of over $50,000.
 
Adding to the list of $3- to $5-fees that low-income families using such state social service programs as home health care, family counseling, and senior citizen services must pay.
 
State financing for state colleges and universities and county colleges will be frozen.
