HEADLINE: Henry Lewis, the Conductor Who Broke Orchestral Racial Barriers, Is Dead at 63

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Henry Lewis, who broke racial barriers in the music world as the first black conductor and music director of a major American orchestra, the New Jersey Symphony, and as the first black to conduct at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.
The cause was a heart attack, his former wife, the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne, said. 
 Though suffering from lung cancer in recent years, he continued to serve as music director of the Opera-Music Theater Institute of New Jersey and of the Netherlands Radio Orchestra, and was a frequent guest conductor for opera companies and symphony orchestras in Europe and America.
Musically brilliant and a commanding figure with the baton, Mr. Lewis since the 1960's had conducted nearly every major American orchestra -- the Chicago Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra, the Boston Symphony, the New York Philharmonic -- as well as orchestras and opera companies in Milan, London, Paris, Tokyo, Copenhagen and dozens of other musical capitals.
In a 47-year career filled with landmark events, Mr. Lewis, whom some critics likened to Jackie Robinson, became the first black instrumentalist with a major American orchestra as a youth in 1948, the first black to conduct a world-class orchestra, in 1960; the first black to become music director of a major orchestra, in 1968, and the first black to conduct at the Metropolian Opera, in 1972.
Mr. Lewis was only 16 when he joined the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Twelve years later, he made his conducting debut with that orchestra. He then founded the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, and was engaged as a guest conductor by top orchestras across the country.
On the strength of his rapidly growing reputation, Mr. Lewis was selected in 1968, over 160 other candidates and at the musically young age of 36, to become the conductor and music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. It was a landmark event in music, for few blacks had even made it into the orchestra pit, let alone onto the podium. It made national headlines.
Over the next eight years, Mr. Lewis built the orchestra from what critics called an ensemble of "avocational" musicians with a $75,000 budget and a season of 22 concerts, into a first-class orchestra with a $1.5 million budget, a 100-concert season and a glow of prestige that took it to Carnegie Hall, the Kennedy Center in Washington and other famed halls.
Based in Newark, a blighted city more concerned with survival than with symphonies, Mr. Lewis and his orchestra began the climb by acquiring 92 top-flight professional musicians, recruiting big-name soloists, including Misha Dichter and Itzhak Perlman, and vastly expanding the company's repertory, schedule and outreach into New Jersey's ghettos as well as middle-class communities.
While continuing to perform at Symphony Hall in Newark, often selling seats for $1, the orchestra undertook a grueling travel schedule to most of New Jersey's large communities, playing in town halls, high school gymnasiums, parks and other acoustically difficult arenas.
Mr. Lewis saw it as his goal to take good music to the doorstep of ordinary people, and in his first season he was not above drawing on the services of his wife to pull in the audiences. "I'll admit it," he said at the time. "We hid behind Marilyn's skirts that first season."
He also took the orchestra into ghettos and working-class neighborhoods for outdoor concerts. Many who attended were hearing classical music for the first time, and Mr. Lewis readily acknowledged that he changed the repertory to suit the audience.
"You can't play down to them," Mr. Lewis said. "But you can't give them an all-Brahams program at first. It's a question of building an audience. I'm not a believer in the old-fashioned attitude of a conductor and orchestra playing for themselves and letting the audience listen as a kind of favor. We do everything possible to make people feel they want to come."
Mr. Lewis was sometimes criticized for his relaxed style during a concert: he often talked to the audience, for example. "I'm always talking, exploring, consciously trying to break down the barrier between us," he explained. "I tell the people that if they want to break in with applause after an exciting movement, that's fine."
Mr. Lewis was also criticized by some blacks who said that symphonies and the repertories of Western European composers were not what impoverished black communities needed. Some more militant blacks were harsher, charging that he was trying to purvey "white" music to black people.
Mr. Lewis did not apologize for his music, though he noted that not everyone had the background or inclination to appreciate it. He said, however, that he was trying to fulfill the difficult, sometimes conflicting goals of building an internationally respected orchestra while taking music to the people.
During his colorful, often tumultuous tenure with the New Jersey Symphony, acclaim followed almost everywhere, and Mr. Lewis took on other high-profile appearances as a guest conductor.
In 1972, 17 years after the contralto Marian Anderson broke the color barrier at the Metropolitan Opera House, Mr. Lewis celebrated his 40th birthday on the podium there, conducting a performance of "La Boheme." In a review for The New York Times, Donal Henahan wrote: "Mr. Lewis proved after a rather stiff beginning that the Puccini style of broad lyricism was one he understood well and could command technically. Credit the Met with good sense in engaging him, and credit Mr. Lewis with a highly satisfactory debut."
While the New Jersey orchestra's reputation and his career as a conductor were soaring, an economic slump was hurting many of the nation's best musical ensembles, and Mr. Lewis's relationship with his members grew increasingly strained as he pressed hard to maintain a grueling schedule and high-level performances.
When Mr. Lewis resigned in 1976 after eight years as the symphony's leader, critics and insiders alike called it a case of irreconcilable differences. Mr. Lewis said he had imposed stern but reasonable demands, but members called him tyrannical. In a three-week strike that preceded his resignation, the orchestra's negotiating committee actually sought a contract clause stipulating that Mr. Lewis refrain from frowning at rehearsals and performances.
After leaving Newark, Mr. Lewis for many years was a guest conductor for major orchestras and opera companies in the United States and Europe. He conducted the Metropolitan Opera tour of Japan in 1975. In 1991, he was music director for the London production of "Carmen Jones." He also frequently conducted for recordings.
Henry Jay Lewis was born on Oct. 16, 1932, in Los Angeles, the only child of Henry J. Lewis, an automobile dealer, and Mary Josephine Lewis, a registered nurse. His musical gifts were recognized early. His mother put him at the piano when he was 5, and in parochial and later public schools he played with amateur orchestras.
But his father frowned on the prospect of his career in music, Mr. Lewis once recalled. "He wanted me to become what he called 'a respectable professional man,' not a musician," he said. "There were no Negroes in classical music then."
In junior high school, he leaped at a teacher's offer of lessons on the double bass. "Double-bass players were rare," Mr. Lewis said. "I decided to master it." He also studied other instruments and voice. His talent at the double bass won him a scholarship to the University of Southern California.
He did not graduate -- he took more than enough credits, but not in the right concentrations -- but made up for it with honorary degrees later in life. At 16, he joined the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, becoming not only the first black instrumentalist in a major American orchestra, but also the youngest.
He remained with the orchestra until 1954, when he was drafted into the Army. He then became conductor of the Seventh Army Symphony Orchestra, based in Stuttgart, Germany, where he remained until his discharge in 1957. He then returned to the Los Angeles Philharmonic and became assistant conductor under Zubin Mehta.
In 1960, after a long friendship, Mr. Lewis married Ms. Horne, by then a well-known opera star. In her autobiography, "Marilyn Horne: My Life," (Atheneum, 1983), Ms. Horne wrote that she received many warnings from friends and relatives about problems she would face as the white wife of a black man, including one from her mother: " 'What do you want to marry him for?' Mother said shortly. 'Why can't you just live with him? Be his mistress, for God's sake, not his wife!' "
The couple, who had a daughter, Angela, often appeared in musical performances together, and were the subject of magazine articles that portrayed them as happy in their music and their marriage. The marriage ended in divorce in 1979, but they remained close friends and colleagues, Ms. Horne said. Their daughter, of Hermosa Beach, Calif., survives.
"Henry Lewis was my prophet and my teacher and my right hand," Ms. Horne wrote in her book. "I certainly would have had a career without Henry, but it was he who really led me into the paths of bel canto. He labored and sweated and did everything he could to teach me the style."
In a 1970 Carnegie Hall appearance by the New Jersey Symphony, Mr. Lewis conducted and Ms. Horne sang an aria from Rossini's "Siege of Corinth." In a review for The Times, Harold C. Schonberg wrote: "There was an animal yell from the audience, then pandemonium, followed by a rising ovation. For almost five minutes, nothing could proceed."

HEADLINE: Tension Rises in Korean Stare-Down

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: YONGPYONG, South Korea

 BODY:
Lieut. Brad Harris kept his olive-colored gas mask ready for instant use beside him as he pointed to the gullies where he would expect North Korean tanks to be lying in wait for him.
An icy wind numbed his face as he commanded a 70-ton M1-A1 Abrams tank on field maneuvers, a bit south of the minefields and razor wire that mark the border between North and South Korea. 
 The mountains were majestic, but all in all, Lieutenant Harris allowed that he would rather be back home in Kansas City, Mo.
"My wife is supposed to be having our first baby right about now," he said, speaking through the tank's intercom system as it roared up a hill. "But this is our job, and for a soldier, this is as close to action as it's going to get."
Lieutenant Harris and 37,000 other American troops in South Korea are playing a waiting game, standing by in case of a North Korean attack, as Americans here have for decades. And this winter the border between the two Koreas, with its tank traps and minefields, with hundreds of thousands of enemy troops staring eyeball to eyeball, is more tense than usual.
The South Korean and North Korean Governments normally agree on nothing, but these days they both say there is a heightened danger of war breaking out. Most security experts say war is quite unlikely, but some are disquieted by recent military intelligence, like the discovery that North Korea has transferred 110 military aircraft to the border area.
They are also uneasy because of the virtual black hole of intelligence about North Korea. Americans and South Koreans are not even entirely sure about such basic questions as who is running the country, and they say such uncertainty makes it harder than usual to predict what the North will do.
The most common view among experts is that Kim Jong Il, the army chief, has been in effective control since the death of his father, President Kim Il Sung, in 1994. But the posts of President and Communist Party chief remain vacant, and some people voice doubt about who is really running the show.
"It's not clear whether Kim Jong Il is controlling the military elite, or whether the military elite is controlling Kim Jong Il," said Cha Young Koo, a South Korean Defense Ministry planner. "It's a little ambiguous."
The South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, has ordered his armed forces to be especially alert, and the South Korean Army has raised its readiness one notch on its "watch scale." South Korean fighter aircraft are flying more sorties, and intelligence analysts are scrutinizing more data for worrying signs.
"Are we concerned?" asked Jim Coles, a civilian spokesman for the American central command in South Korea. "Of course. We'd be fools not to be."
But Mr. Coles and others interviewed also emphasized that the indications were far from conclusive, and that there was no sign that a confrontation was imminent. Although tensions are rising, both sides have everything to lose by going to war, while they may each have a bit to gain politically by talking tough.
North Korea, for its part, denies any aggressive intentions. It warns that it is the "South Korean puppets and U.S. imperialist war-maniacs" who are creating an extremely dangerous situation.
"While trying to provoke the "second Korean war' with the backing of foreign forces, the Kim Young Sam group are claiming that the 'threat' to South Korea comes from the north of Korea," declared the official North Korean press agency. "The Kim Young Sam group, hand in glove with foreign forces, are bringing the situation to the brink of war."
Almost everyone agrees that there is one excellent reason to take the North Koreans at their word when they deny any intention of invading: by most accounts, a North Korean attack would be suicidal.
Still, South Korean and American military officers say North Korea has repeatedly behaved in unpredictable or irrational ways, and they cite several reasons for concern:
*Since last fall, North Korea has moved bombers and MIG-17 and IL-28 fighters to bases close to the border. North Korea has also moved long-range artillery, including 170-millimeter guns and 240-millimeter multiple rocket launchers, to the area near the border.
*Last fall, armed North Korean soldiers were caught infiltrating the South in two incidents, South Korean officials said. It was the first time in many years that the North was caught infiltrating soldiers, and it suggested that the North might be trying to test the South's surveillance of the border.
*North Korea has reshuffled its military leadership, retiring elderly leaders and promoting younger generals from field armies. The new commanders are regarded as hard-liners, and the army appears to have gained power in North Korea in the last couple of years.
Intelligence analysts are divided about the risks, in part because there is some counter-evidence: North Korea has cut back on winter training recently, its air sorties have dropped sharply and it has been trying to improve relations with Washington.
No one feels comfortable attaching a percentage to the risk of another war, but when pushed they give a wide range of assessments. Twenty percent risk, says one expert. Much lower, suggests another. Not at all, says a third.
A study published by the Rand Corporation last year concluded that there was a "medium likelihood" of North Korea launching an attack against the South out of desperation. If that were to happen, the study says, there would be a "high likelihood" of the use of chemical weapons by the North.
Some analysts emphasize that South Korea's explosive economic growth -- 9 percent last year -- means that North Korea's military is losing ground to the South's.
"It's got to be obvious that they aren't going to win economically," said Col. John W. Reitz, a public affairs officer for the American forces here. "So you've got to wonder if they're going to feel that they've got this great military machine and they've got to use it or lose it."
Some experts also worry that the North Korean leadership may even believe that armed clashes or a limited war might be in its own interest. These analysts say they fear that the North Korean Government might find it useful to have a crisis to blame its economic troubles on and divert domestic grumbling.
"Their actions may not be based on rational calculations, but on domestic political considerations," said Gen. Park Yong Ok, the Assistant Defense Minister for Policy. "That's why we're worrying about war."
Concerns about an attack are taken seriously, in part because North Korea has a huge army, one that could inflict far more damage than the Iraqi armed forces did.
For starters, North Korea has at least 1.25 million troops on active duty, according to analysis of population data by an American scholar, Nicholas Eberstadt. North Korea also has 3,800 tanks, 10,800 pieces of field artillery and a substantial air force of 1,620 aircraft.
As a result, North Korea's army has more soldiers and equipment than the 700,000 South Korean troops and 37,000 Americans stationed in Korea. Much of the North Korean weaponry is old and no match for the American equipment, but it is still an enormous military machine.
Aside from the fact that it may have a couple of nuclear weapons -- though perhaps no good way of delivering them -- North Korea is said to have 1,000 tons of chemical weapons, including nerve gas and blister agents. It has plenty of missiles and artillery shells that could carry chemical weapons to Seoul.
The American and South Korean troops keep their gas masks within arm's reach, but very few civilians have them.
"A nightmare scenario would be for North Korea to gas the population of Seoul," said an American military officer. "Politicians don't want to talk about it, because people can't accept that possibility."

HEADLINE: January 21-27;
Seeking Race-Blind Diversity

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
The University of California has a new admissions policy banning the consideration of applicants' gender and race in deciding which students to accept -- but still seeking "diversity" -- though it has proved difficult to explain. Last week the university president decided to postpone putting it into effect for a year, and it is now scheduled for students entering in 1998.
How to reach the goal? Here's a sample: 
 Between 50 percent and 75 percent of freshmen are to be selected on academic merit alone. The rest must meet academic standards and other "supplemental criteria." In other words, the university will be looking for "individuals who, despite having suffered disadvantage economically or in terms of their social environment (such as an abusive or otherwise dysfunctional home or a neighborhood of unwholesome or antisocial influences) have nonetheless demonstrated . . . character and determination in overcoming obstacles . . . ."
A task force has suggested that admissions offices could give special consideration to students who have had "disabilities, personal difficulties, low family income, need to work, disadvantaged social or educational environment, difficult family situations or circumstances, re-entry status, refugee status or veteran status." They may also seek students who have been "in special cross-cultural programs offered by the high school or community organizations, demonstrated outstanding individual effort to experience other cultures, or proficiency in other languages." SARAH KERSHAW

HEADLINE: Bronx Official in Spotlight Over School Fund Raising

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
Salsa blared from the Latin combo on the cavernous gymnasium's darkened stage. On the dance floor, through the crowd of principals and teachers stiff in their evening clothes, moved a stocky man with wiry gray hair and thick-rimmed spectacles.
Men threw their arms over his shoulder, and women bussed him on the cheek. Carmelo Saez Jr., president of Community School District 9, was the center of attention at this $35-a-head party for school employees late last year. The estimated $10,000 in proceeds would go, Mr. Saez said, to the Bronx Educational League, a private organization he founded and controls. 
 Many of the 300 partygoers were employees in the school district, which has the city's lowest test scores and a history of scandal. Some said they had paid the $35 ticket price for Mr. Saez's league event not just for fun, but to insure good will from the school board leadership, to gain support for promotions and extra teachers, to give money for after-school events, even furniture.
"What's wrong," a principal said, "is people feel if they don't, they won't get promoted, they won't get jobs." Like other critics of Mr. Saez, he spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "They feel there's a quid pro quo."
It is not clear what happens to the money brought in by the parties -- in addition to the estimated $10,000 from the December event, perhaps as much as $20,000 was raised at similar events in June and December 1994, based on tickets sold. More than a year after its founding, the Bronx Educational League, which sponsored the events, had yet to file an annual report with the state, as nonprofit organizations are required to do by law.
Edward F. Stancik, the Special Commissioner of Investigation for the New York City School District, this month began an investigation into Mr. Saez's fund-raising events, specifically to determine whether they violated a City Charter provision that prohibits public servants from compelling subordinates to make political contributions, Mr. Stancik said. The offense is a misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in jail. Mr. Stancik found evidence of irregularities in a similar investigation of several district boards two years ago.
In addition, a commission formed by Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, and headed by a former Bronx District Attorney, Paul Gentile, has been holding public hearings on questions of ethics surrounding school districts in the borough, with particular attention to District 9.
One of the questions, commission officials said, is how Mr. Saez uses the money he raises.
Critics say he has not had a salaried job in many years and note that he spends a great deal of time in his school district office, in a position paying a stipend of only $125 a month.
Mr. Gentile said Mr. Saez's "refusal to disclose what happens to the funds, combined with his apparent lack of means to make a living, raises a very strong suspicion that these funds are diverted for personal use."
Mr. Saez responded, "I bring in a few dollars here and there," adding that "as long as I don't do anything illegal, it's nobody's business."
He lives in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx, in a comfortable but hardly lavish two-story wood-shingle house with an assessed value of $85,800. He drives a 10-year-old car.
Mr. Saez, 54, was removed from the board by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez in 1992 after an allegation that he had improperly used district employees to make a fund-raising videotape for a private youth group he led. He was re-elected to his position on the school board the following year.
In a recent interview, he scoffed at the idea that there was anything improper about his fund-raising efforts. "You can't find a principal who says Saez called him and said, 'Sell those tickets.' " he said. "People were asking for tickets."
He acknowledged that some people think he holds the events "to pay my bills." But he described the December gathering as a "break-even affair." He paid $1,500 for the hall, a gymnasium of the New York City Mission Society, the city's oldest social services agency, society officials said. He estimated expenses for food, liquor, the band and other items at $3,500 and conceded that he had made liberal use of volunteers -- for cooking, setting up the hall and selling tickets. He refused to say how much money had been collected.
He said the event had had a financial purpose: to "establish the organization" that sponsored it, the Bronx Educational League, which he said has no funds and no employees. Mr. Saez said he had created the league to defend and advocate educational issues. But he had difficulty in citing its accomplishments.
Mr. Saez has his defenders in the district. Several principals said they felt no pressure to attend the fund-raising events, and one said Mr. Saez was genuinely dedicated to students. Yet the comments of other school officials place these events firmly within an old picture of the district, described as a "patronage mill" by Mr. Stancik in a report in 1993.
In the report, Mr. Stancik found that "numerous district employees" had been enlisted to organize and sell tickets to an event for Mr. Saez. But an investigator for the school system said Mr. Stancik had not pressed for prosecution because at the time the city's new conflict-of-interest provisions were still untested.
Other school board members in the city hold such events. But Mr. Saez holds more of them, said Mr. Gentile, the former prosecutor who is holding hearings in the Bronx. Mr. Saez has filed notice that he intends to sue Mr. Gentile's commission for libel, slander and harassment, and at a recent meeting, the District 9 board voted to do the same.
"They've pariah-cized me," Mr. Saez said. "It's affected me in my economic life. I've had difficulty finding a steady position. I can't just continue."
Born in Puerto Rico, Mr. Saez received his political schooling in the struggles to control antipoverty programs, the source of power in the South Bronx in the late 1960's and 1970's. He worked for Ramon Velez, the longtime baron of such programs, and still speaks warmly of him.
He has weathered a number of scandals over the years, personally or as a member of the District 9 board, including the suspension of all of the board members in 1988 after allegations of malfeasance.
"There are people who I've helped," Mr. Saez, a school board member for at least 20 years, said. "That's what this is about."
But one of the principals said Mr. Saez's assistance came at a price. "You're not going to go anywhere unless you're involved in any political activity he's involved in," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Worker Safety Net Isn't Too Much to Ask

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas Geoghegan's criticism of President Clinton's message to workers in his State of the Union Message (Op-Ed, Jan. 25) reflects a labor agenda that has held the Democratic Party captive. 
 As a Democrat who served in Congress for 12 years, I have seen too many in my party abandon the center on labor-related issues.
Democrats need to say to our union supporters that we no longer can ignore the workplace realities that face the 85 percent of American workers who don't belong to a union, especially when union interests run counter to the economic realities of the 21st century.
While Mr. Geoghegan and other union advocates speak of restoring worker dignity, organized labor would continue to deny nonunion workers the right to participate with management in decision-making.
The National Labor Relations Act makes employee involvement through decision-making with management illegal for nonunion workers. Corrective legislation has been introduced but faces a challenge in the Senate, where organized labor is urging a Democratic filibuster.
Democrats, while right to insist on a strong government role in assuring safeguards for workers, also need to recognize that the best labor policy is a strong economy. Democrats should be the party of the 21st century, embracing global markets, fiscal restraint and empowered employees. President Clinton had it right when he said: "When companies and workers work as a team, they do better. And so does America."
 
TIM PENNY
Waseca, Minn., Jan. 25, 1996

HEADLINE: Plan to Get 2 Pro Teams In Maryland Stirs Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 26

 BODY:
As the National Football League season draws to an end, football has become a hot topic in the Maryland Legislature. But while in other places the debate has focused on the relative merits of the two teams in the Super Bowl, the Pittsburgh Steelers and Dallas Cowboys, here the talk is of two stadiums.
Last fall, two owners of league franchises, Art Modell of the Cleveland Browns and Jack Kent Cooke of the Washington Redskins, negotiated deals with state officials to bring their teams to Maryland, which has been without an N.F.L. team since the Baltimore Colts left for Indianapolis in 1984. 
 The Browns would move to Baltimore and play in a new downtown stadium by 1998. The Redskins would move to Prince Georges County, outside Washington, and play in a new stadium by next year.
But with the state promising $200 million to build Mr. Modell's stadium and about $76 million for new roads and parking lots around the privately financed stadium Mr. Cooke intends to build, a growing number of lawmakers are challenging the deals, saying that the state has much more pressing needs.
"This has become intertwined with every other subject in the Legislature," said Jean Cryor, a Democratic member of the House of Delegates from Montgomery County, reflecting the impact the stadium deals have had on the current session.
And it is apparently not only lawmakers who have been caught up in the debate.
"A lot of people say, no matter what their issues are, that these are tough economic times," said Dana Lee Dembrow, a Democratic delegate from Montgomery County. "Yet we're able to find money to give away to millionaire owners of pro sports franchises."
Robert L. Flanagan, a Republican delegate from Howard County, said: "I can tell you, the Howard County Center Against Domestic Violence is very conscious of the fact that the Governor has cut their budget at a time he is proposing almost $300 million for new football stadiums."
The three lawmakers and more than two dozen other members of the House and Senate have formed a bipartisan group called Tackle to fight the deals negotiated by Gov. Parris N. Glendening.
They are particularly upset over the pact with Mr. Modell, which would not only provide him a new 70,000-seat rent-free stadium but would also give him all revenue from parking, concessions and the $1,000-per-seat license fees charged each season-ticket buyer for the right to purchase the seat. The stadium would be adjacent to the city's three-year-old baseball stadium, Oriole Park at Camden Yards.
While a lawsuit filed by the City of Cleveland is attempting to force the Browns to fulfill the last three years of their lease at Cleveland Stadium, the Maryland lawmakers are proceeding with their own efforts to thwart Mr. Glendening's initiative. They are urging the State Board of Public Works to delay the sale of bonds to construct the Baltimore stadium while opponents gather support for a budget amendment that would prohibit spending state money on any stadium that is privately owned. Various opponents also plan to introduce legislation that would terminate the stadium deals or force the state to renegotiate.
Mr. Glendening, a Democrat elected in 1994, remains steadfast in his support of both projects, as are the Legislature's leaders and the entire Baltimore delegation.
Their chief arguments are that the legislation to finance a new stadium in Baltimore with revenue from four new state-run sports lotteries was passed by the Legislature in 1987 and that the road improvements in Prince Georges County had been planned long before a stadium was contemplated. Mr. Glendening also calls the projects vital to the state and local economies.
The Governor's spokeswoman, Dianna Rosborough, said that the projected $9.2 million in state and local taxes each year from the Baltimore stadium would more than cover the $200 million investment, to be paid out over 30 years.
Objections to the Redskins' stadium are less vociferous because Mr. Cooke plans to build it himself, for $180 million, and most lawmakers agree that it is the kind of development the state needs. The new stadium would be less than 10 miles from the Redskins' current home.
But opponents say the Governor's economic projections of tax revenue and 1,400 full-time jobs are overly optimistic. They also say that the annual revenue from the sports lotteries have fallen short, which might result in the need for more money for the stadium project from the state's general fund.
And other costs could arise, including previous concessions to the Baltimore Orioles, whose owner, Peter G. Angelos, has already entered into arbitration with the state over a "parity clause" in the team's Camden Yards lease with the state. It was designed to give the Orioles, who pay an annual rent of $5.4 million, the same deal an N.F.L. team would receive in an adjacent stadium.
Opponents contend that the state can ill afford to invest in football teams when communities are clamoring for more schools, roads and social services.
"This is a different decade, a different legislature and different times," said Bruce D. Poole, a Democratic delegate from Washington County, who is opposing Mr. Glendening's efforts in Baltimore.
As for the state's authority to build the stadium, he said: "Our position is that the legislation represented the wants of the 1980's versus the needs of the 1990's. This money should be used for something else."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 1996, Thursday

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JASHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

SATELLITES
Jumping Into the Ring
MCI Communications and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation agreed to pay $682 million to the United States for the last unclaimed slot for a satellite that can beam programming directly to individual homes. The companies said they planned to invest an additional $1 billion to provide entertainment and communications services. Earlier in the week, AT&T said it would pay $137.5 million for a 2.5 percent stake in DirecTV, which beams 175 channels from satellites to home dishes.
 
COMPUTERDOM
Sliced, Pared, Cored?
Just what the future holds for Apple Computer is very much up in the air. Profits have evaporated, production and logistical problems abound, and among the various companies that have contemplated making an offer for Apple, only Sun Microsystems appears to be stepping forward -- and very much on its own terms. What Sun is prepared to offer, some insiders say, is $23 a share, which is considerably less than Apple wants and about $9 a share less than the market value.
 
THE FED
Campaigning for a Seat
Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker who dominates Lazard Freres, has made clear that he wants to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. A number of top business executives are lobbying on his behalf. Mr. Rohatyn would apply pressure for lower interest rates to stimulate growth, they believe. Neither Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, nor Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, who have known Mr. Rohatyn for years, have commented on his campaign. One potential obstacle: Mr. Rohatyn opposed the re-election of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, now chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, which must pass on nominations to the Fed.
 
TRADE
The Gap Narrows
Japan's enormous trade surplus with the United States fell 17 percent and its overall surplus 11.4 percent, reversing five years of broadening. As the surplus shrinks, trade tensions are likely to dissipate as well. Economists and trade experts expect the narrowing to continue, helped along by the strong yen, which makes imports less expensive for the Japanese.
 
BANKING A Top-Dollar Deal
Wells Fargo won the messy four-month battle for the First Interstate Bancorporation of Los Angeles, agreeing to pay $11.6 billion -- the most ever for an American bank. First Interstate had fiercely resisted the deal and had agreed to be acquired by First Bank System of Minneapolis for more than a billion dollars less. But if First Interstate shareholders make out well, as many as 10,000 of the combined banks' 48,000 employees are likely to lose their jobs, analysts said.
 
TOY STORIES
Barbie Meets G.I. Joe
Mattel, the largest toy company and the manufacturer of the perennial best-selling Barbie, wants to buy Hasbro, the No. 2, for $5.2 billion. Hasbro, whose brands include the G.I. Joe action figures and the Monopoly, Scrabble and Candy Land board games, publicly rejected the offer, saying the Government would block the deal on antitrust grounds. The combined companies would dwarf the competition with about 40 percent of the American toy market. Investors were betting that the deal would come off, and Hasbro stock soared.
OIL
The Markets Are Roiled
Iraq's stated willingness to negotiate with the United Nations over selling its oil to buy food holds the promise of relieving severe hunger in the country. But the prospect of unleashing that vast supply of oil worries other oil producers, most notably OPEC members, which are bickering over who will produce how much even without Iraqi participation.
 
BEEF
Ranchers Are Threatened
High beef prices in the early 90's encouraged ranchers to increase their herds, and now an oversupply has caused prices to plummet. That is good news for consumers but threatens to force many ranch owners into liquidation. An oversupply of pork and chicken compounds the problems of ranchers, who are now getting only 68 cents a pound for beef, compared with 93 cents in 1993.
 
HEMORRHAGES Applying the Tourniquet
Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest industrial company, said it would report a loss of at least $4.2 billion, one of the largest in business history, largely because it is abandoning its efforts to rescue Fokker, the Dutch airplane maker. The decision puts at risk thousands of jobs at Fokker, even though the Dutch Government quickly announced a rescue package.
 
WALL STREET
Half Full, Half Empty
Earnings from some of the big brokerages confirmed last year's rebound from 1994. Merrill Lynch's profits for the year were up 10 percent, to $1.11 billion; Salomon had a profit of $457 million after a loss in 1994 of $399 million. Fourth-quarter results outpaced the annual numbers -- but were less than impressive when compared with the third quarter, as the usual year-end slowdown took hold at both firms. From third quarter to fourth, Merrill earnings were up less than 1 percent, while at Salomon, earnings plunged 37 percent, sending its shares skidding.

GAMING (II)
Gulliver? Not!
 Associated Press
Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners is multi-cabled to a computer that tracks and records his movements, from home-run swing to home-run trot, the better to help Nintendo re-create them for a video baseball game. The technique, known as motion captures, involves putting sensors on the subject, then attaching the sensors to a computer.

HEADLINE: A Valuable Voice for the Fed

 BODY:
The White House is considering Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped save New York City from financial collapse in the 1970's, as a possible nominee to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He would be a worthy choice, a man of stature and experience whose views might help the Fed wring the most growth out of the economy.
Mr. Rohatyn, a managing director of Lazard Freres & Company, has an unusual blend of expertise that embraces the financial, business and political worlds. He is respected on Wall Street. In the political realm, he is hailed as the architect of the financial manipulations and tight controls that kept New York City out of bankruptcy in 1975. He is among the few highly successful figures on Wall Street who back progressive causes and activist government. Yet his quest for stronger economic growth and balanced budgets has won him endorsements from the heads of many major corporations. 
 Few will challenge Mr. Rohatyn's intellect or financial sagacity. But some economists will object that he, unlike the outgoing vice chairman, Alan Blinder, has no background in the Fed's primary mission -- setting the nation's money supply in order to control inflation and dampen temporary downturns. But by that standard, almost none of the Fed board members deserved appointment. Most were bankers whose careers gave them no more experience in determining monetary policy than did Mr. Rohatyn's career on Wall Street. The Fed has a highly qualified staff to guide members through the technical ins and outs of policy options.
Mr. Rohatyn has called for policies that would lead to faster growth than either the current Fed or many economists think feasible. His views are unlikely to square with those of the current chairman, Alan Greenspan. But good can come out of such tension. Indeed, Mr. Blinder challenged the chairman over the past few years, nudging policy in a direction that in hindsight has proved beneficial.
The Fed is supposed to keep the economy growing fast enough to keep the unemployment rate low. But most economists agree that there is some point at which, if unemployment is driven any lower, the Fed would ignite increases in wages and prices. Eventually, the Fed would be forced to crack down and, as in the early 1980's, drive the economy into a steep recession.
The problem is no one knows just how low unemployment can fall before inflation kicks in. Most would say around the current rate of 5.5 percent. Others think the Fed, by lowering interest rates, could drive unemployment as low as 5 percent. Everyone on the board agreed that interest rates needed to rise in 1994 and fall last year. But Mr. Blinder wanted less steep increases in 1994 and steeper reductions last year. Hindsight suggests he may have been right: the economy has slowed, with industrial production nearly stagnant, and this week the Fed is expected to drop interest rates one more time to give the economy another kick.
Mr. Blinder's voice, then, will be missed. Judging from his public writings, Mr. Rohatyn would be a valuable replacement. Mr. Greenspan gets very high marks for his stewardship of the Fed since 1987, steering the economy through uninterrupted growth and declining inflation. Growth has been slow, but that is the fault of sluggish productivity, over which the Fed has little if any control. Assuming Mr. Greenspan is appointed by Mr. Clinton to another four-year term, he will continue to control Fed policy. But that is all the more reason to add a shrewd counterweight to the chairman's instinctual conservatism. Mr. Rohatyn could serve that valuable role.

HEADLINE: America's Role in Russia

 BODY:
With Boris Yeltsin clumsily trying to distance himself from his reform record to placate voters as Russian presidential elections approach, President Clinton faces a delicate and difficult time in managing relations with Moscow. The days of bear hugs and political partnership with the Russian leader are over. Washington now owes Mr. Yeltsin a blunt condemnation of his drift away from economic reform, and a firm policy designed to discourage further erosion by Mr. Yeltsin or a successor.
The United States cannot determine the direction or outcome of Russia's perilous passage from tyranny, but it can use the influence it has to help Russia remain on a reform course. With Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin coming to Washington this week, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher scheduled to meet a week later with the new Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, the moment has come to apply some pressure. 
 Mr. Christopher made a good start in recent days by publicly reminding Moscow that its relations with the West, and its ability to attract foreign investments and loans, depend on a sustained commitment to reform. Mr. Yeltsin, while declaring that his administration's policies have not shifted, has made a series of cabinet appointments that belie his words. The latest was the selection last week of Vladimir Kadannikov, a Russian businessman, to manage Government economic policy as Deputy Prime Minister.
As head of Avtovaz, a troubled state-owned automobile company, Mr. Kadannikov seemed more interested in protecting his business by promoting tariff barriers than in refashioning the plodding industrial giant to operate more efficiently and produce better cars. He favors increasing Government subsidies to failing industries, a step that could lead the central bank to print more rubles, setting off a damaging new round of inflation.
The Clinton Administration must make clear to Mr. Chernomyrdin that a return to Soviet-era economic policy would be self-defeating. A relaxation now of the tough monetary and fiscal policies that have brought inflation down and maintained budget discipline would throw the economy back into a free fall that was only recently stopped by four years of painful reform.
Given Mr. Yeltsin's recent behavior, and the unsettled outlook for his management of the economy, Washington has no choice but to seek delay of a $9 billion, three-year loan agreement the International Monetary Fund has been negotiating with Moscow. For now, the I.M.F. should not proceed with a loan based on commitments by Moscow to economic policies that suddenly seem subject to modification or reversal. The loan agreement can be completed later this year if Mr. Yeltsin or another Russian president once again settles firmly behind reform policies. A rescheduling of Russia's debt should also be delayed.
Mr. Christopher must be equally firm in his meeting with Mr. Primakov in Helsinki. American and Russian troops are peacekeeping colleagues in Bosnia, and other areas of cooperation on international issues continue. But Mr. Primakov can be expected to advance a more assertive Kremlin agenda, particularly toward the newly independent states on Russia's border. America must stand behind their independence. Mr. Christopher should also register impatience with Moscow's failure to carry through on agreements reached earlier this year to exchange information with Washington on nuclear weapons and nuclear materials.
Some students of Russia have suggested that Washington make a clean break with Mr. Yeltsin and declare its sympathy for reform leaders like Yegor Gaidar and Grigory Yavlinsky. The Clinton Administration does not have that luxury. Mr. Yeltsin remains the elected President of Russia. His repositioning could still prove to be more a shift in posture than policy. But the measure of American policy in the days ahead will be whether Mr. Clinton does all he can to keep Mr. Yeltsin and Russia on the path to reform.

HEADLINE: Orders for U.S. Machine Tools Reached 16-Year High in 1995

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Orders for American industrial tools rose nearly 17 percent in December, capping a year in which orders reached their highest levels since 1979, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said yesterday.
For all of 1995, orders totaled $4.86 billion, up 3.6 percent from the previous year. "The industry also anticipates a good year in 1996," Albert Moore, president of the trade association, said. 
 Exports fueled much of last year's gain, surging 106 percent even as domestic orders slipped 4.3 percent.
In December, total orders rose to $377.5 million, a 16.8 percent increase from November, suggesting that American businesses ended the year by stepping up investment in plants and equipment. Domestic customers increased their orders by 23.6 percent from November, while demand from abroad fell 15 percent, the trade group said.
The report also showed that machine tool orders fell a revised 34.2 percent, to $323.1 million, in November. Previously, November orders were reported to have dropped by 35.4 percent.
Economists follow orders and shipments of machine tools -- used to shape and assemble metals in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers -- to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
Many companies have modernization programs under way, which is raising demand for machine tools, Charles Pollock, a spokesman for the association, said. With increased global competition, "a lot of the large companies invest all the time," he said.
By category, December orders for metal-cutting tools, like drills, rose 49.8 percent from the previous month, to $280.3 million, while orders for metal-forming tools, like stamp press machines, decreased 28.5 percent, to $97.2 million. For the year, metal-cutting orders rose 4 percent while metal-forming orders increased 2.9 percent.
Machine tool shipments fell 9 percent in December, to $474.3 million, but rose 21.3 percent for all of 1995. The backlog of orders, which tracks pent-up demand, fell 4.4 percent, to $2.081 billion, during December.
Though machine tool makers are predicting a good year, there are signs the rest of the manufacturing economy is slowing down.
"Manufacturing is sluggish," David Levy, director of forecasting at the Jerome Levy Economic Institute of Bard College, said before the release of the figures. "Investment is much weaker at this point, and there's a lot of capacity out there."
For instance, industrial production rose just one-tenth of 1 percent during December as capacity utilization fell to 82.8 percent, from 83 percent in November. Without the end of a strike at the Boeing Company, the aircraft manufacturer in Seattle, the month's production would have shown a decline.
Because of recent signs of sluggishness, many analysts expect the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee to cut the overnight bank lending rate at its policy meeting on Wednesday. The Fed last cut the rate, by a quarter of a percentage point, on Dec. 19.
Further rate cuts are good news for machine tool manufacturers because they allow companies to borrow more cheaply to make capital investments. "Lower interest rates always help," Mr. Pollock said.

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
THE elections in November notwithstanding, the Patent and Trademark Commissioner, Bruce A. Lehman, describes his present tenure as only his first term in office. Settling into a chair for an interview at his headquarters last week, a panoramic view of the Potomac River and the capital behind him, he responded to a question about his plans for the agency with a discussion of 1997 and beyond.
"We're moving toward a new paradigm of a 12-month patent-examining process," Mr. Lehman began. The Patent and Trademark Office has three packages of legislation pending in Congress. They complete the redesign he suggested in a working paper to the Clinton transition team before the inauguration. 
 So far, Mr. Lehman has accomplished much of that agenda, but not without bitter opposition from some agency customers, chief among them independent inventors. They accuse Mr. Lehman of "dumbing down" the patent system to conform with laws in Europe and Japan, and question how he can be so sure that his redesign of patent and trademark law will guarantee the American economic boom he predicts.
All the bills are still in committee -- meaning Mr. Lehman has no idea when there might be a vote. But he discounted the possibility of defeat.
"I'm working away, talking to people on the Hill, trying to educate them," said the Commissioner, who for a decade was a lawyer with the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Intellectual Property.
The most controversial bill, at least among independent inventors, is the one that would make it legal to publish patent applications 18 months after they are filed, even if no patent has been issued. Opponents say this would weaken the United States patent system.
Last year independent inventors vehemently but unsuccessfully opposed a law changing the life of a patent from 17 years after it was issued to 20 years from when an application was filed. They said that made the effective term shorter because it could often take several years to issue a patent. Mr. Lehman argues that there is no real difference, because the average processing time for patents is 19 months.
Now many of the same groups oppose the 18-month publication rule because it makes work public before most inventors have patent protection.
But the Japanese and the Europeans publish after 18 months, and Mr. Lehman is an advocate of "harmonizing" American patent law with that of the rest of the world. And in any case, aides of Mr. Lehman argue, once he trims examination to 12 months, early-publication risks will become moot.
"It's important so people will know what new technologies are coming down the pike," Mr. Lehman said. Now patent applications are secret. So most disputes over inventions arise only after the patent has been issued, and anyone wanting to fight a patent often has to go to court.
Another pending bill gives greater power to third parties -- someone other than the inventor and patent officials -- to appeal a patent's ownership or initiate a re-examination of a disputed patent.
The agency is also advocating legislation that would give copyright owners exclusive rights over the digital transmission of their work and extend the "fair use" privileges of libraries, archives and nonprofit groups for the visually handicapped to include certain numbers of copies in digital format. It also suggests making it an infringement to thwart copy-protection systems, like encryption, that copyright owners use to protect their work.
Members of the World Intellectual Property Organization, an agency of the United Nations, will attend a February conference to write a treaty replacing the Bern Convention, the international copyright agreement first adopted in 1886 and last modified in 1971.
The third set of legislative proposals turns the Patent and Trademark Office into a corporation wholly owned by the Government (as part of the Commerce Department). It would continue to pay for itself through user fees, and that money would still be channeled through Congress. Congress would continue siphoning off the money, too, though Mr. Lehman would like to get Congress's fingers out of the agency's till.
Mr. Lehman said he wanted to eliminate a surcharge tacked onto fees but frequently withheld from the agency by Congress. Instead, he said all money collected should remain with the agency. "But that has to wait for the next Clinton Administration," he said.
Nevertheless, the bill would turn the agency into something of a private business.
"We'll move completely to being a results-based agency," Mr. Lehman said. "We'll measure all our successes and activities based on whether they satisfy the needs of our customers rather than checking off a checklist the Office of Personnel Management or the General Services Administration has for us."
If the bill passes, the agency will take charge of buying its own supplies, hiring its own workers and negotiating and managing its own real estate deals (the patent office is now looking for a vast new space in Crystal City, Va.)
If those changes are enacted into law, Mr. Lehman said he would have nothing left undone. And he said he had only one regret.
"If one thing is distressing to me and I wish I could change," he said, "it would be the very negative reaction of independent inventors."

HEADLINE: Newsprint Price Increases Might Be Limited

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Faced with the near doubling of newsprint prices during the last two years, newspapers have compressed page widths, squeezed more content, including advertising, into smaller formats, and made their supplies stretch further by using lighter-weight paper.
Even as publishers introduced such economies to adjust to the costlier raw material, newsprint producers were reporting record profits and have even scheduled further price increases in coming weeks. 
 But the news might not be all that bad for publishers. Some analysts said the recent run-up in prices might have been too rapid and that newsprint prices could even start falling again, though not by as much as in the industry's last recession, in the early 1990's, when some producers were on the verge of bankruptcy.
Citing sluggish economic growth, weakness in the bellwether spot-newsprint market for isolated transactions and increasing production capacity outside of North America, Sherman Chao of Merrill Lynch and Chip Dillon of Salomon Brothers are among those analysts who see a broad downturn in the next couple of years.
Mr. Dillon said Salomon projected an annual rise in global capacity of 3.8 percent during the next two years, which the firm expected would outstrip both demand and the recent rate of capacity growth. "The tight supply will loosen some, and prices will come down some," he said, perhaps giving up as much as three-quarters of their recent increases.
"We're in a new cycle," Mr. Chao said. "It's fair to say that the producers who have announced their intention to raise prices by another $50 a ton will have a few hurdles to overcome."
Newsprint, which represents about a quarter of the cost of newspaper production, now costs around $750 a metric ton for large buyers in eastern North America and $765 for buyers in the West. The major producers, the biggest of which are in Canada, have scheduled increases to $796 in the East and $814 in the West, effective on March 1. As recently as December 1993, newsprint was about $390 a ton.
Large newspapers use hundreds of thousands of metric tons of newsprint annually. John Duncanson, an independent forestry analyst who advises pension funds from an office in Toronto, said he thought prices for large buyers this year could drop to $700 a ton. "Newsprint is stuck in the mud," he said.
But there is a wild card in the outlook this year -- the possibility of a strike by newsprint workers in eastern Canada, who are free to strike after May 1 as a result of a labor contract option to renegotiate wages between major newsprint producers and the Chemical, Electrical and Paper Workers Union. The sides are now far apart.
The sharp rise in prices since 1993 has prompted an investigation by the United States Justice Department's antitrust division. Bill Brooks, a spokesman, said the department was "looking at the possibility of anti-competitive practices in the newsprint industry" and that the investigation was "ongoing." He declined to be more specific.
The sharp rise in prices since 1993 followed the industry's most severe downswing since the Depression. Prices peaked in 1988 at $610 a ton, then fell for the next several years. Many of the biggest producers lost money throughout the period and shrank production capacity, closing down a number of higher-cost older mills. When demand rose in 1994, chiefly in booming offshore markets, prices shot up.
Because of faltering economic growth, which cuts demand for advertising space, and the conservation measures undertaken by newspaper publishers, consumption of newsprint actually fell last year in the United States, which accounts for more than a third of worldwide demand.
According to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, whose members, including some American companies, account for a third of global output, consumption by United States newspapers was off nearly 5 percent. Publishers' had a 47-day supply at the end of November, compared with 32 days in November 1994 and the more traditional level of 38 days.
Nonetheless, Fiona Cook, the association's economics director in Montreal, was not as bearish as American analysts. "Once consumers have worked down their inventories, we expect consumption to be flat or perhaps show slight growth in 1996," she said. She predicted a "positive impact" from the summer Olympic Games in Atlanta and the Presidential campaign, both of which could increase newspaper circulation and advertising.
Patricia Mohr, a vice president of economics at the Toronto headquarters of the Bank of Nova Scotia, gave the new price increases "about a 50-50 chance of sticking."
Despite the rise in inventories, supplies remain "quite tight," she said, noting that Canadian and American mills are operating at near capacity and that no new production is expected to come on line this year in North America. And recent price increases in Britain and Germany have stuck, she added, which the industry regarded as a good sign.
The reason for skepticism, she said, was that demand has weakened for other grades of paper. "You have a situation where different papers compete," she said. "It is difficult for newsprint to move up when other kinds of paper are moving down."
A key raw ingredient of paper -- bleached softwood kraft pulp -- fell in price last November for the first time in two years, to $925 a metric ton, down $75. This reflected soft economic conditions and a big inventory buildup in the fine-paper market, the principal user of this pulp.
Another Canadian analyst, Hamish Kerr of Goepel Shields & Partners of Vancouver, British Columbia, also saw brighter prospects than the American analysts. "Prices should be relatively stable in '96," he predicted, "because the capacity growth is not yet significantly above the trend line in consumption growth."
Mr. Kerr said demand in foreign markets, particularly in Asia and Latin America, would help to prop up prices. Industry figures showed that global demand rose 2.3 percent annually during the last 10 years and 1.6 percent during the last 5 years, despite virtually no growth in demand in North America in the last 10 years and an annual drop in demand of five-tenths of 1 percent during the last 5 years.
"Domestic suppliers in fast-growing markets will have difficulty keeping up with demand, insuring that North American exports will remain strong for several more years," he said.
In general, as economic conditions improve, so does demand for newspapers and the advertising they offer. Other factors affecting world demand are population growth, increased literacy rates and trends toward more democratic, consumer-oriented societies, especially in the Pacific Rim and Latin America.

HEADLINE: Spendthrift Priorities Delay Kenya's Bid for More Aid

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 28

 BODY:
When President Daniel arap Moi flew to Uganda last week for talks with other East African leaders, he traveled in luxury aboard a brand-new private jet that the taxpayers of this cash-strapped country bought last month for about $50 million.
As the jet lifted off from the airport, it banked over the rutted and potholed two-lane highway from Nairobi to Mombasa, Kenya's major port. A vital artery for business, the road is perhaps the most visible symbol of the dilapidated state of the country's infrastructure. On good days, the going is bumpy. On rainy days the road is impassable. 
 Some opposition leaders and diplomats here assert that the jet and the road illustrate what is wrong with the Government's economic priorities: a longstanding tendency among politicians to let personal prestige outweigh the public interest.
President Moi purchased the jet, a sleek Dutch-made Fokker, at the same time that his Government was seeking a $50 million low-interest loan from the World Bank to repair the road.
Since newspapers disclosed the purchase of the jet in November, Government officials have argued that the expense is justified because in the past the President has had to take one of Kenya Airway's two jets out of service every time he travels.
The airplane is one of several expenditures not listed in Kenya's budget that have jeopardized aid from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, as well as from other countries, diplomats and officials at international development banks said.
The officials and diplomats, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the jet and two other budget-busting projects of questionable worth have come up during talks this week between the Government and a joint mission from the Bank and the I.M.F. The two sides are trying to hammer out a plan for economic reform that would allow the I.M.F. to release hundreds of millions of dollars in blocked aid.
The stakes are high for Kenya, an economic engine for eastern Africa. Hanging in the balance are $200 million in direct aid from the I.M.F. and nearly $166 million in loans from the World Bank for roads and other infrastructure projects that are needed to attract foreign investment.
The talks are also being watched by Western countries, including the United States, and several have said the I.M.F.'s decision will be a bellwether for them. Only a fraction of the $800 million donor countries pledged to Kenya in November 1994 has been disbursed because of the stalled negotiations, diplomats said. Neither the I.M.F. nor the World Bank would comment on the talks.
But diplomats and people familiar with the talks say the main sticking points have been the Government's inability to stamp out official corruption and the kind of pork-barrel and prestige spending typified by the President's new airplane.
Besides the jet, the Government is spending about $85 million to build an international airport at Eldoret, the heart of the President's home state in eastern Kenya. Parliament never approved the project -- the money was tucked away in a special debt service fund in this year's spending plan. It was also hidden from World Bank auditors who scrutinized the budget until a newspaper reported its existence.
The Government has argued that the airport is needed because of an economic boom in the area. The growth there has been fueled in large part by flower merchants, who now truck their goods to Nairobi, over pitted roads, for air shipment to Europe.
In another deal done without competitive bidding or legislative approval, the Government recently awarded a multi-million-dollar contract to a French company to manufacture identification cards.
Paradoxically, the controversies over the airport and the jet come to light as Kenya has made big strides over the last three years toward improving its moribund economy.
Last week, the Government suspended a score of high-ranking port officials on corruption charges. Urged by the I.M.F., it has also eliminated import licenses, squeezed the money supply and liberalized trade.
As a result, interest rates are down, and the economy grew by 5 percent in 1995, after several years of stagnation. Inflation, which had hit 100 percent in 1993, stayed below 7 percent in 1995.
But the population continues to grow faster than the economy, local economists said. So Kenyans, with an average annual income of $1,200, are in reality getting poorer.
"It's a mixed bag," said one diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "They would not have achieved what they achieved last year if they hadn't been doing certain things right. But the question is, would they have had 8 percent growth without the corruption."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 566 words

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 28

 BODY:
Marie Sardella kept repeating the words like a mantra when the hours in her flower shop in Walpole, Mass., grew long and frantic during the holiday season.
"That's all she said, 'I can't wait to go to St. Thomas,' " said her daughter, Lisa Cotton, 33, a travel agent. "That is her haven, her place to relax."
But the trip was cut short on Wednesday night, when masked gunmen opened fire on Mrs. Sardella and a group of friends as they entered a restaurant and bar in the East End of St. Thomas, the main island in the United States Virgin Islands. The reason for the attack is not yet known.
A bullet grazed her skull and pierced one shoulder, critically injuring Mrs. Sardella, 53. Other shots wounded two of her friends, part of a group that had vacationed for many years in a nearby condominium development called Cowpet Bay.
The shootings have brought negative publicity to the island at a time when it is still recovering from a thrashing by Hurricane Marilyn in September. The island depends on tourism to generate 85 percent of its gross domestic product, officials said.
Police Commissioner Ramon S. Davila said Gov. Roy L. Schneider had ordered the police to be vigorous in enforcing a 10 P.M. curfew on youths under age 16 and had called in agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
While unable to provide details of the case, Mr. Davila said in a telephone interview today that the police had interrogated one person and expected to make an arrest shortly.
The police are investigating the possibility that the attack was related to a dispute over efforts to move housing project residents to the East End temporarily. Residents have obtained a Federal Court injunction against the relocation, which would allow the rebuilding of housing damaged by the hurricane.
Mr. Davila was able to speak briefly today to one of the victims, William Garrity, 52, a restaurateur from Sea Isle City, N.J. Mr. Garrity regained consciousness in the past 24 hours, Mr. Davila said. St. Thomas Hospital officials declined to disclose his condition at the family's request.
Mrs. Sardella and the third victim, Walter Schenk, 58, a construction company owner from Huntingdon Valley, Pa., were flown on Thursday to the Hospital Universitario in the Rio Piedras section of San Juan. Both patients were in critical condition and remained unconscious today, family members waiting outside the intensive care unit said.
Mr. Schenk has had surgery to remove a bullet in his brain and one leg. A bullet in his back will be removed after he regains strength, family members said.
The three victims were among a group of nine friends who vacationed regularly at Cowpet Bay Condominiums in the East End. They had gone to dinner together Wednesday night and decided to stop for a farewell drink at a stern-wheeler boat converted into a pub.
As the friends made their way from the parking lot to the restaurant, gunmen in white ski masks suddenly opened fire on them.
"I thought it was firecrackers," said Mr. Schenk's wife, Phyllis, as she waited to visit her husband. "But after the two shots, I knew I wasn't hearing firecrackers."
The Schenks bought a condominium at Cowpet Bay 12 years ago. Mrs. Sardella bought a condominium there 10 years ago.
"Ironically, they felt safe here," said the Schenks' oldest daughter, Diane Koerper, 34.

HEADLINE: Doing the Chores, With Relish and Regrets

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
When the building maintenance strike began 25 days ago, Michael M. Downey faced a daunting task: get the snow shoveled, carpets vacuumed, bathrooms cleaned and lobby floors waxed at 12 Manhattan office towers when his 1,100 maintenance workers were on the picket line.
To meet this challenge, Mr. Downey, who has worked seven days a week since the strike began, has relied on 150 supervisory personnel working 14-hour days, including weekends, and on a hastily assembled crew of about 700 temporary placement workers. 
 Mr. Downey, senior vice president in charge of building operations for the Mendik Company, one of New York's largest landlords, unmistakably regrets the strike, which has left many longtime, loyal workers shivering day after day on the picket line. Just as unmistakably, his proud, macho streak relishes the challenge of keeping his company's millions of square feet of office space, running smoothly despite a strike by porters, handymen, elevator operators and other maintenance workers.
For Mr. Downey, the hardest day of the strike was the Sunday of the Blizzard of '96, a day he now describes with a touch of elan. "We worked around the clock," he said. "I personally shoveled snow for 13 hours. We had guys sleeping in their offices, shoveling, taking catnaps and then shoveling again."
Just hours after the strike began, Mr. Downey began hiring replacement workers to maintain the Mendik Company's holdings, including 2 Penn Plaza, which towers over Pennsylvania Station, and 20 Broad Street, which houses many of the New York Stock Exchange's offices. Through his company's building maintenance subsidiary, he hired unemployed people, college students needing tuition money, new arrivals from Eastern Europe, and Latin American immigrants looking for a second job.
"We had to close the doors down twice because there were so many people who wanted to work," Mr. Downey said.
Even though he has deployed a small army of strikebreakers who are paid $350 a week, Mr. Downey maintains that he has a lot of sympathy for the strikers. "My father was a union man," he said, explaining that his father ran building boiler rooms as a member of the Operating Engineers Union.
Mr. Downey, who grew up at 67th Street and Columbus Avenue and now lives in Guttenberg, N.J., started in the real estate business, fresh out of the Navy, worked like his father in the boiler room as a lowly engineer's assistant. Now, after years of bounding up the corporate ladder, the 54-year-old Mr. Downey fits comfortably into management, with his tailored suits and Italian loafers and his sun-drenched 37th-floor office, which is filled with lithographs of 19th-century New York and pictures of his grandchildren.
He has an unmistakable resemblance to the actor Harvey Keitel. Like the actor, Mr. Downey is taut and intense with a throaty voice and fierce eyes, but his hair is lighter and his demeanor a lot less menacing.
"This strike is painful for everybody," he said. "It's hard for anybody to go without a paycheck for three weeks. I know a lot of these people for 10, 12, 18 years. I know their families. It's painful for me to see this."
But he was not going to let this sympathy stop him from employing people the strikers castigate as "scabs."
"Management has the responsibility to run their business to the best of their ability during a strike," he said.
As evidence of his sympathy, he mentions that he often gives $20 bills to strikers to buy lunch -- and to make sure the strike does not sunder longstanding ties.
"Do we want to hire permanent replacement workers?" he said. "No way. This is not a city or business that does that. A lot of these people are real assets."
Talking as if vandalism is an inconvenience of doing business, he said that at some buildings, strikers put glue in door locks, cut the tires of snow plows, stole building keys and used box cutters to tear open garbage bags.
"They're into the third week of the strike," he said. "They're getting desperate. A lot of this you have to accept. These are working people. They're not criminals."
Mr. Downey is especially close to the dispute since he is on the real estate industry's negotiating team, which is made up of representatives of building owners and managers. The two sides announced yesterday that they would resume talks on Wednesday after negotiations broke off Jan. 20.
According to Mr. Downey, building operations are more or less back to normal -- an assertion that many tenants dispute. He described a strategy in which management, during the first few days of the strike, concentrated on cleaning public spaces, like lobbies, elevators and bathrooms. Next, it moved onto emptying tenants' wastebaskets and vacuuming their carpets. Only afterward did the replacement workers move onto dusting the offices.
"We're now basically up to providing full service," Mr. Downey said.
Ellen Bisogno, who oversees the New York operations of BDO Seidman, an accounting firm and a Mendik tenant at 330 Madison Avenue, said, however, that things were still not back to normal.
"Mendik is trying their very best, but that doesn't mean we're not greatly affected by the strike," Ms. Bisogno said. "Whenever I need an engineer for heating or engineering problems, I have to wait longer than normal. Also, the cleaning services are not up to snuff. I end up emptying our garbage from the office kitchen."
Using a logic that many strikers would say is tortured, Mr. Downey insists that management's proposal, which includes cutting porters' $573-a-week starting salaries by 40 percent, would do more to preserve union jobs than the union's proposal of giving all workers three years of 3.5 percent wage increases. He said many building tenants are growing so fed up with the cost of unionized maintenance workers that they are hiring cheaper nonunion cleaning crews.
Mr. Downey insists that the industry needs to cut starting salaries and overall labor costs because building operating expenses are so high and the rental market so weak that many buildings are barely breaking even. But the strikers fear that a lower starting salary would encourage management to dismiss higher-paid veteran workers and replace them with lower-paid newcomers.
Saying that New York is teeming with real estate magnates earning millions of dollars each year, many strikers scoff at the real estate industry's assertion that it is hurting. Mr. Downey, who would not disclose his salary, said that typically a manager of operations for a large real estate firm earns from $125,000 to $275,000 a year.
Not flinching from being provocative, he suggested that the building workers have gone on strike in the wrong city.
"They should be striking Jersey City or Newark, where porters earn much less," and where some New York tenants have moved because of lower rents and operating costs, Mr. Downey said. "They shouldn't be striking in the city that has made them the highest-paid porters in the country."
