HEADLINE: FLIGHT TO NOWHERE: A SPECIAL REPORT;
AMBITIOUS UPDATE OF AIR NAVIGATION BECOMES A FIASCO

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Stymied by mismanagement, the Federal Aviation Administration has squandered 15 years and at least half a billion dollars on a new air traffic control system that is still years from completion and already obsolete.
In 1981, when President Ronald Reagan dismissed 11,000 striking air traffic controllers, the Government pledged to replace many of them by overhauling and modernizing the system that guides planes from takeoff to landing. 
 But today, in aging control centers across the country, overworked controllers direct tens of thousands of flights each day with the same screens that were out of date 15 years ago. So fragile is the equipment that technicians who open it for maintenance fear doing more harm than good. During breakdowns, which are more and more frequent, controllers carry slips of paper around darkened control rooms or read commands aloud, instead of sending computer messages or clicking on symbols on a screen. At such times, skill and luck substitute for technology.
Even when the system works, controllers are using screens so old that they "look like all the 'Victory at Sea' movies," as the head of the biggest pilots union, J. Randolph Babbitt, has put it.
Both the F.A.A. and the airlines say there have been no accidents they would attribute to system breakdowns. But about two dozen times in the last two years, the 25-year-old mainframes that drive the controllers' screens at five of the busiest centers have failed, delaying hundreds of planes each time, sometimes for hours. In Chicago, at the busiest center, there were seven failures last year alone, including three in mid-July.
The major airlines say that even when things run normally, there are about 20,000 delays a day due to air traffic control. Although most are short, the delays cost them up to $5 billion a year, the airlines say.
A study released last week by the National Transportation Safety Board also says that the system is safe but that its inefficiencies drive up the cost of airline operations and delay travelers.
The F.A.A.'s struggle to rebuild the air traffic control system illustrates how the Government's best intentions can be defeated when there is a constantly changing bureaucracy with a dearth of leaders who can manage complex projects.
Describing the agency's efforts, George R. Meinig Jr., a retired admiral who was part of an independent team brought in by the F.A.A. to evaluate what had gone wrong, said, "They needed some adult supervision along the way."
Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, who serves on the Committee on Governmental Affairs, said: "The F.A.A. is a victim of its own poor management. If the agency devoted more time to managing itself and less time to defending its deficiencies, the air traffic control system would have been replaced years ago."
Interviews with current and former agency officials and a review of Government documents show that the agency allocated billions of dollars to update the system and hired outside experts to help. Over the years officials labored hard on the project, which the F.A.A. regarded as the key to its future. But the records and interviews also portray an agency overwhelmed by technical problems, making ambitious and expensive plans in search of the perfect system, only to abandon them upon realizing they could not be pulled off.
 
The Vision
Hopes of Saving A Lot of Money
The F.A.A. initially planned to save money by consolidating controllers into about 20 large centers, from more than 250 smaller ones. But after four years of work and hundreds of millions of dollars, officials discarded the idea. Consolidation required different hardware and software, and the shift wasted thousands of hours of effort.
"By the time you build what they wanted, they changed it and they want something else," said Gerald W. Ebker, who headed the division of the International Business Machines Corporation -- since sold to the defense contractor Loral Federal Systems -- that was selected to write the software.
At other times, I.B.M. also had problems separating the practical from the impossible. The new system it promised to build was supposed to replay past events, like a videocassette player, at 10 times normal speed, as an aid in analyzing traffic patterns and controller errors. But I.B.M. later said that was impossible. The agency, however, stuck to its guns and insisted on the capability, driving up the project's costs. Only much later did the agency realize that such a playback speed was unnecessary.
F.A.A. officials "somehow or other don't seem to know how to do research and development and acquire things," said Charles A. Fowler, a software expert on the independent team, which was from the CNA Corporation, a consulting group.
F.A.A. officials counter that I.B.M., which won the $3.6 billion contract to replace the system and repeatedly failed to produce working software, shares in the blame, a position CNA endorses. In hindsight, everybody agrees that the F.A.A. should have recognized the problems sooner.
Thomas C. Richards, a retired Air Force general who was the F.A.A. Administrator in the last seven months of the Bush Administration, said, "Given the amount of money involved and the importance of modernization, it should have been the No. 1 priority." But he added, "People were clearly not focused." Mr. Richards said he was in office long enough to know the project was not working, but not long enough to fix it.
Finally, in 1994, David R. Hinson, the F.A.A. Administrator, pulled the plug on the original replacement project, called the Advanced Automation System, accepting that about $500 million had been spent on software that would never be used. He authorized a slimmed-down plan, an $898 million contract to deliver about 1,000 new screens and workstations for the 3,200 controllers in the 20 largest centers, beginning in 1998.
That plan, managers say, is on track. But agency officials acknowledge that the system makes no provision for incorporating new satellite-based technology that could shorten almost every flight.
Industry experts say the failure to set an achievable goal at the beginning and follow through has been a devastating setback.
"The failure of the Advanced Automation System is going to be with the F.A.A. for a long time," said Maurice F. Connor, who became director of safety and technology at the controllers union a year ago.
"They spent 10 years fooling around with it, and now in 1995, David Hinson said quite bravely that this thing is a turkey and we're finished with it," Mr. Connor said. "It's going to take another 10 years before we get to where we should have been in 1995."
 
The Vision
A Strike Fosters An Ambitious Plan
When President Reagan dismissed the 11,000 striking air traffic controllers in 1981, calling in substitutes, F.A.A. officials decided that they had to be able to run the system with fewer people and more sophisticated equipment. In addition, because of deregulation of the airlines and a healthy economy, air traffic was growing so fast that it was threatening to overwhelm the system. And so the Advanced Automation System was conceived.
A former F.A.A. official who served during the project's early stages said it was born about the same time as the Strategic Defense Initiative, the Reagan Administration's space-based missile-defense system.
"You've got a Government saying, 'Throw a ton of money at it, get a technofix, and have the biggest of the big do it,' " he said. "Then you have this bureaucracy at F.A.A. say to I.B.M., 'You do it; you figure it out.' "
Under the new plan, the overall method of directing air traffic would remain the same: controllers would tell pilots which way, how fast and at what altitude to fly by reading radar data, the flight plans filed by pilots before takeoff, information radioed from the planes, and weather information. But the new system would be so technologically advanced that it would allow controllers to "work smarter, not harder," said T. Allan McArtor, the F.A.A. Administrator in the beginning of the project. And, the agency promised, the new system would save $4.5 billion in labor costs over its life.
The Government solicited proposals, evaluated the results at great length and, in 1982, picked two companies, I.B.M. and Hughes Electronics, as possible contractors. It paid them a total of $450 million for a "fly-off," in which each would build a demonstration model of a proposed system. The F.A.A. set a target date of 1990 for beginning installation of the new system.
Early in 1988 I.B.M. won the contract, with its several hundred pages of specifications. The contract was the biggest from the Department of Transportation, of which the F.A.A. is a part. It was also the biggest that I.B.M. had ever received.
As is usual in such cases, Hughes appealed, and work had to stop until the appeal was resolved. The writing of the detailed software that would be the heart of the new system did not get started until October 1988. It had taken seven years to write the specifications and hire a contractor.
Writing the new software was an extremely complicated process requiring scores of programmers. But almost as soon as it began, it went awry, the CNA report said. I.B.M. let the programmers work independently, failing to coordinate their work, the report said, and the F.A.A. never noticed the problem until it was too late.
"Everybody was doing their own little bit, but no one was sewing it together," said William E. Smith, a member of the CNA team. The software factory resembled "a hobby shop," he said, with programmers wandering off on their own into whatever interested them.
But Mr. Ebker, the I.B.M. official, who has since retired, said the problem was not coordination within his organization, but a stream of changing orders from the F.A.A. "If people could have just left it alone, I think we would have delivered," he said.
By December 1990, 30 months into the project, it was 19 months behind schedule.
Not only were the programmers writing pieces of software that would not fit smoothly together, but they were also concocting a system that did not do all the things the agency said it had been promised, the CNA report said.
For example, the F.A.A. said the system had to be capable of "continuous operations," or updating the software while the software was running. But I.B.M. officials say they did not realize that was a requirement, even though the specifications referred to it.
"We were five years into the concept when continuous ops was sprung on us," Mr. Ebker said. "Even if it's obliquely in the specs, it was news to us." That misunderstanding added $350 million to the cost.
The independent report partly blamed I.B.M. for the failure to point out problems like that before they required expensive solutions, saying that the financial terms of the contract gave the company an incentive to stretch out the work.
"They had a key to the U.S. mint," said Robert S. Cooper, a participant in the study. "The cost of the program was going up at the same rate as expenditures, and no progress was being made. It was just a way of funneling money through I.B.M. Federal Systems and raking off whatever the percentage was."
Mr. Ebker said I.B.M. also lost money because of the delays. But he added, "Sure, I.B.M. should have stepped forward earlier and much more forcefully."
But Joseph W. Del Balzo, a 36-year veteran of the F.A.A. who was the Acting Administrator from January until August 1993, when he retired to become an aviation consultant, blames the F.A.A.'s structure, which he said did not reward people for coming forward early with pessimistic assessments. As a result, he said, problems became obvious only very late.
"Program managers are by nature very optimistic -- 'We're going to solve this problem by the end of the week,' " he said. " 'The last thing I want is my boss helping me, looking over my shoulder.' "
The F.A.A. has attributed much of its problems to complex Federal procurement and personnel procedures. Last fall Mr. Hinson told Congress that those procedures prevented the agency from hiring the experts it needed, because it could not pay salaries to compete with private industry. Congress has since exempted the F.A.A. from nearly all the procurement rules, but not everyone is convinced this will help.
"Regrettably, Congress bought the argument that Federal procurement and personnel policies have prevented the F.A.A. from modernizing the air traffic control systems," Senator Cohen said. "But Federal policies are not the problem." It was poor management, Mr. Cohen said.
By the early 1990's, with each month that passed, the completion date slipped three and a half weeks into the future, F.A.A. program managers say. Meanwhile, costs more than doubled, to $7.6 billion, as the project's goals expanded and each goal became tougher to achieve. The independent report said that by early 1994, the program was "schedule-driven, with little regard for the quality of the product."
 
The Problems
Colliding Opinions, Unrealistic Goals
A major problem, one that dogged the project from the start, was the agency's inability to decide what it wanted the new system to be, the independent report found.
For example, the agency reached for the sky with the plan to consolidate its 254 terminal radar approach controls -- installations known as tracons that take jurisdiction over planes when they leave the immediate vicinity of an airport -- into its 20 air traffic control centers, which handle high-altitude, long-distance flights.
But consolidation would have reduced the ability of the sites to pinch-hit for each other, and thus would have created much higher computing demands in a single installation. I.B.M. gamely set out to do the job, but most of its effort was wasted because in 1992, after four years of work, the F.A.A. dropped nearly all the consolidation plans. The reason was apparently nontechnical: closing anything the F.A.A. operates is about as easy politically as closing a post office or a military base.
"You can't hardly close anything we have," Mr. Hinson said in an interview.
The F.A.A. could also not decide how information about airplanes would be manipulated on the controllers' screens.
The contract specified that blocks of text on the controllers' screens be movable, but did not say how. For controllers, how the text blocks were to be moved was a point of major concern because it would affect their work routines, and it was a subject on which they had divergent views.
"You get 100 controllers, you're going to get 120 opinions on something," said Will Faville, who represented the controllers union in the development process.
I.B.M. designed a system with a block that could be moved only with several keystrokes on the keyboard. But most controllers preferred a system more like the current one -- in which they move the text block with a button they can feel near the screen, without having to look away from the screen -- and they pressured the F.A.A. to get I.B.M. to change the new software.
As more software was developed, the controllers had other complaints. Management, too, was dissatisfied with much of the emerging system. Over all, there were 290 changes that required modifications to the contract, and hundreds of smaller changes, each increasing the total cost.
Another problem that doomed the project was the F.A.A.'s inability to distinguish pipe dreams of the perfect system from affordable, achievable features.
For example, the agency insisted that the new system have a reliability of 99.99999 percent, called seven nines, which meant, in theory, that it would work all but three seconds a year. But some engineers doubt that such reliability is achievable.
"Whether or not it was realistic, I don't think anyone analyzed," Mr. Del Balzo said.
An engineer brought in by the F.A.A. to help with the project, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, "We were asking I.B.M. to do things in that A.A.S. system that actually violated the laws of physics."
Today the F.A.A. acknowledges that seven-nines reliability is not necessary. And by 1994, when Mr. Hinson scaled down the program, the agency had decided to state the reliability goal more flexibly.
But by initially insisting on such a high level of reliability, the F.A.A. missed the opportunity to put in place a system that would be vastly more trustworthy than the one in operation now.
"The F.A.A. is so risk averse, it is shod with this idea, 'We can't field anything until it's absolutely perfect,' " said Mr. Richards, the Administrator in 1992.
 
The Future
A Better System, But Still a Beat Behind
For top F.A.A. officials, the project was a long-term headache that was easy to overlook and pass on. J. Lynn Helms, who began the project in 1981, left office on Jan. 31, 1984, the end of the first Reagan term. Between his departure and Mr. Hinson's arrival on Aug. 10, 1993, there were three other administrators, and the office was vacant for 20 months.
Under the plan Mr. Hinson initiated in 1994, the new goal is to use hardware and software of the mid-1990's to do the same work as the existing equipment, which is from the early 1970's.
And although Loral Federal Systems, which bought the division of I.B.M. that was producing the software, continues to work on new equipment, the F.A.A. has decided to buy commercial off-the-shelf equipment to update other parts of the aging system. It has already purchased a control center for lower-altitude traffic in California.
But Mr. Hinson's efforts may not be enough to bring the F.A.A. into the 21st century. Experts say that even when the new system is finished, it will be very far from the cutting edge.
The most accurate way to determine an airplane's position now is through the Global Positioning System, in which a sensor on the plane uses satellite signals to calculate position precisely. Global positioning allows planes to fly straight from one airport to the next, rather than the way the F.A.A. directs them, from one imaginary point in the sky to the next, following a system of radio beacons that dates from 1941.
The F.A.A. has not based its new system on global positioning, which did not exist when the modernization project began.
But the agency knows it must eventually use such satellite technology. Global positioning will make it easy for planes to set their own direct courses, which would shave minutes and miles off nearly every flight.
The slimmed-down project initiated by Mr. Hinson is a step in the right direction, experts say, because even if it does not provide many new functions, it uses equipment that could eventually accommodate new features like global positioning.

HEADLINE: Tax Stock Trades to Close New York Budget Gap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "More Budget Woes for the City" (editorial, Jan. 23): 
 You call on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani "to rethink some of his basic assumptions" about how to close another budget gap of $2 billion. But the guidance you offer is to defer unnamed tax cuts, review real estate levies and pare the already mean levels of health care spending.
Surely the real alternative is to raise revenues from the sectors of the city economy that have brought unprecedented prosperity to the wealthy. In Manhattan in 1990, the richest one-fifth earned $174,486 a year and the poorest one-fifth $5,435. This gap has tripled since 1980, and no other city can match it.
The schools, welfare and infrastructure need $2 billion for urgent capital repairs, let alone bare-bone operating costs. And the city's human economy cannot afford further excise or sales taxes.
But a transfer tax on trading on the stock exchanges, after the sensational 1995 boom, could realize $1 billion or more. A tax on services would not drive the wealthiest lawyers, accountants, brokers and advertisers out of business. Or out of town.
Conventional wisdom holds that "tax and spend" liberals have ruined the economy. But Gov. George E. Pataki and the Mayor are planning to multiply social inequities with their priorities. The havoc they wreak will not be slowed until slashing is again linked to a progressive mode of taxation.
 
WALTER GOLDSTEIN
Albany, Jan. 4, 1996
The writer is a professor emeritus, SUNY Albany.

LENGTH: 176 words

HEADLINE: For Anxious Workers: Wage-Hour Reforms

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his Jan. 19 column, "Separation Anxiety," Bob Herbert is right about the cruelty of layoffs. But how empty is his solution in calling for a Presidential campaign that "would address the tyrannical power of the great corporations." 
 That would kill the technological progress that enables the economy to move our country toward a better life for all. Better to put teeth in our wage-hour laws in the manufacturing sector by specifying overtime pay of double time instead of the time and a half now required, and then demand the double time pay go into effect after 37 1/2 hours instead of 40.
In an economy in which more than twice as high a proportion of women are working than 35 years ago, shorter hours would give parents the "family time" so urgently needed by many of our youngsters who have drifted into drugs and crime. It would also decisively answer the "separation anxiety" Bob Herbert lightly cites.
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, Jan. 19, 1996
The writer was Senator from Wisconsin from 1957 to 1989.

HEADLINE: Even in Peace, a Family Is Balkanized

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BRCKO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 24

 BODY:
As children, Irena Tomic and her cousin Tanya Madjarevic played with Barbie dolls together. They were best friends by the time they were adolescents, enjoying summer weekends around the swimming pool at Miss Tomic's house in the wooded hills outside Tuzla.
But the two have been unable to see each other since the war divided them nearly four years ago. 
 Miss Tomic, 19, who dreams of becoming an elementary-school teacher, is a refugee living with her parents and teen-age brother in a one-bedroom apartment with electricity only every other day, and silt-thick water. The nine-story building has no heat, which is why other tenants were chopping firewood out front, surrounded by a war-ravaged neighborhood in this city on the Sava River.
Miss Madjarevic, 16, still lives in her family's modern two-story house in Tuzla, not far from the high-rise apartment building where her cousin lived before the war. Only 30 miles separate the families, but the war has created a chasm between people in this country.
"It is the United States Government's position that without returning the displaced people back to their homes, there will be war again," Terry Leary, an official with the United States Agency for International Development, said recently at a conference of international relief organizations in the city of Zenica.
It is a Sisyphean task. Assuming that foreign countries come up with the hundreds of millions of dollars needed for repairing houses so that the displaced have something to return to, the boulder of hatred generated by the war is poised to roll over the ideal.
There are about a million displaced people inside Bosnia, says the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and another million Bosnians are refugees in Europe. About 400,000 of the refugees in Bosnia are Serbs like the Tomics. If the Tomics cannot go home to Tuzla, which under the Dayton peace agreement is included in the territory controlled by the Muslim-Croat federation, it is difficult to envision an integrated Bosnia.
Tuzla has a proud history of being one of the most tolerant communities in the former Yugoslavia. Miss Tomic's lanky brother, Mladen, 15, remembers playing basketball with Croats and Muslims, and nobody cared, or even knew, who was what. In Tuzla even today, his uncle, Vlado Madjarevic, is a director of the Zrinski basketball club, named after a Croatian count, and half of the players are Muslims. Mr. Madjarevic, a Croat, is married to Miss Tomic's father's sister, who is a Serb.
The Tomics said they might go home if they had jobs and an apartment to go to. But there are few jobs in this country after nearly four years of war, which followed four decades of Communism. Miss Tomic's mother, Jelica, who was head nurse in the hospital in Tuzla for 20 years, works as an X-ray technician at the Brcko hospital for 20 German marks, about $13.50, a month.
Just this week, Miss Tomic's father, Miladin, deploying every bit of English he could muster, succeeded in getting a job as an interpreter with an American Army unit stationed nearby. Mr. Tomic, a research engineer before the war, is happy that he will be paid 200 German marks, or $135, a month.
As for the Tomics' finding a place to live in Tuzla, that raises the Gordian knot of the refugee return program. Mass movements and extensive destruction have created another obstacle.
The Tomics cannot return to their house outside the city, because it has been badly damaged by mortar shells. And their apartment was first occupied by Muslim refugees, and now by a Croat whom the local government gave it to.
In Tuzla there are some 60,000 refugees living in houses that will have to vacated before the owners can return. But many cannot go back to their own homes because those are destroyed.
Throughout Bosnia, 72,000 housing units were destroyed and 250,000 damaged during the war, says the International Management Group, a nonprofit organization working with the World Bank on the reconstruction program for Bosnia.
The Bosnian Government says it will cost $2 billion to repair war-damaged houses. The International Management Group estimates the cost at $1 billion; the World Bank has budgeted $600 million.
Regardless of the housing situation, 3,000 to 5,000 Serbs are ready to return to Tuzla, said Milos Bosic, president of the Serb Citizens Council there. "All they need is somebody to guarantee their security," he said.
At first, Mr. Bosic said, he thought the NATO peacekeeping forces were going to do that, but he has learned that providing security for returning refugees is not one of their missions. In any case, war-embittered anger is an obstacle to a refugee return program. Tuzla, for example, is no longer the tolerant city it once was.
Miss Tomic's aunt, Milojka Madjarevic, begins to cry when she asks a visitor what her brother looks like now, after having not seen him in four years.
Still, Mrs. Madjarevic said that even if her brother and his wife could find jobs and a place to live, "it wound not be very smart" for them to return to Tuzla, not because of physical danger, but because of the way they would be treated.
Her husband explained: "The demography of Tuzla has changed." Now there are many Muslims living there after being forced from their homes by the Serbs. "They are bitter," Mr. Madjarevic said. "They carry this bitterness with them."
Their daughter, Tanya, remembered that before the war she had many Muslim and Croatian girl friends, and no one talked about anyone's background.
Now, she said, "they are not looking at me as nicely as they did before -- they ignore me."
While her mother was packing a microwave oven and other items to be taken to the Tomic family in Brcko, Miss Madjarevic said she would like to send a message to her cousin Irena Tomic.
"Tell her that I miss her a lot," she said, "and I hope I will see her soon."
When she received the message, Miss Tomic cried. "I'd like to see my cousin Tanya," she said. "I love her so much."

HEADLINE: Budget Path For Whitman Is Independent

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
For a year now, Republicans have remarked happily about how the first-term Republican Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have seemed to be running their administrations from the same political playbook.
New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, first among the three to gain office, promised to cut taxes and to streamline state regulations to restrain the growth of government spending. Governors George E. Pataki of New York and John S. Rowland of Connecticut duly followed suit in each particular. Together, they have secured a place on the Republican Party's list of promising young leaders. 
 Yet, the outline of Mrs. Whitman's $16 billion budget for 1997, which she is to detail on Monday, shows one distinct area where the New Jerseyan parts company with her neighbors.
On social welfare issues, where Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland have redrawn the landscape according to their political vision, Mrs. Whitman has taken the approach of a preservationist.
Where her neighbors have used the budget to press broad ideological campaigns to revamp programs for the needy, Mrs. Whitman has been able to pick and choose from a broad range of Republican opinion, taking a more moderate approach that maintains and even enlarges some social programs.
Mr. Rowland has driven through the country's most restrictive welfare eligibility limits, and Mr. Pataki plans to cut welfare benefits and sharply curtail Home Relief for able-bodied childless adults. Mrs. Whitman, in contrast, has striven to protect benefit levels while improving medical care and educational opportunities for welfare mothers, and has even criticized her Democratic predecessor, Jim Florio, for denying additional stipends for children born to mothers on welfare.
While Mrs. Whitman proposes to reduce New Jersey's generous prescription drug program for the elderly, she would eliminate only those with assets over $50,000, not counting a house or car.
She wants to cut $54 million from the state colleges and universities but found an additional $24 million for scholarships that would help 2,600 low-income students.
She proposes to cut state school aid for some of the richest suburban districts and to freeze aid for most others, but proposes to increase funds for the state's 21 poorest school systems.
Peter Verniero, the Governor's chief of staff, explained this approach without ambiguity: "Our guiding principle in preparing the budget has been to balance the needs of various constituency groups with the needs of taxpayers," he said. "Under that standard, this budget is both prudent and fair."
One group of people who will feel the edge of Mrs. Whitman's budget knife will be the 814 state workers to be laid off, a cut the Governor needs to meet her goal of showing a net decrease in spending compared with the current year. It is a reduction of barely 1 percent in a work force of 62,740.
State worker union leaders point out that under the state's seniority bumping rights, the people most likely to lose their jobs would be mostly women and minorities, and the Governor has acknowledged this.
She justifies the layoffs, just as she justified diminishing the living standards of state workers whose departments were turned over to private management last year, with an argument that is more managerial than ideological: unnecessary or overexpensive state employees harm everyone -- particularly low-income taxpayers, she has often said, by forcing up state spending.
Perhaps in compensation, the Governor devotes the largest share of a proposed $100 million economic development program to a staple of Democratic Party economic thinking, the retraining of workers for the new information-based economy.
Mrs. Whitman's social moderation, when compared to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland, may be all the more noteworthy for the fact that she is the only one of the three Gpvernors whose party controls both houses of the legislature. In New York, the Assembly is heavily Democratic and a constant brake on Mr. Pataki's agenda, while the Democrats have a one-vote majority in the Connecticut State Senate, forcing Mr. Rowland at least to consult with the opposition in a way that Mrs. Whitman has not even considered doing.
By dominating the Legislature with her personal popularity, Mrs. Whitman has managed to pick and choose the ideas she likes from the wide range of Republican opinion and to discard the rest, said Stephan A. Salmore, a Republican campaign consultant and Rutgers professor of politics.
"She has managed a very politically astute marriage of two wings of the Republican Party -- the sort of noblesse oblige or Rockefeller wing that always argued that it was the role of government to pick up the slack, and the fiscal conservatives who focus on money and tax issues," Mr. Salmore said. "She has managed this much to the consternation of her liberal critics, who have been expecting her to fail for some time now."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the New Jersey budget misstated the political makeup of the Connecticut State Senate. Republicans, not Democrats, have a one-vote majority. Democrats have a 31-vote majority in the House.

HEADLINE: Sharp Regional Incongruity Found In Medical Costs and Treatments

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
A NEW study reports that medical care, adjusted for local costs of living, costs twice as much in some areas of the country as it does in others.
And the use of specific medical treatments, like surgery for breast cancer or prostate cancer, varies strikingly, depending on where a patient lives. For instance, in some parts of the country radical mastectomies were performed 33 times as often as breast-saving lumpectomies for women with breast cancer. 
 Previous reports have noted geographical differences in cost and in the kind of treatment provided. The new study, by Dr. John E. Wennberg of Dartmouth Medical School and his colleagues, is broader than previous studies. It is an analysis of Medicare data nationwide from 1993. These are records from people aged 65 and older who, for the most part, are not members of health maintenance organizations.
The researchers released their results yesterday in the form of a book, "The Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care." It will be distributed by the American Hospital Association, which represents 5,000 hospitals and health systems, after April 30; the number for orders is (800) 242-2626.
Dr. Jack Lord, a senior adviser for medical affairs at the association, said: "Within the health care field, people had some sense that there were differences, but I don't think that anyone had any idea that the rate of variation was so great. A thirty-threefold difference in the rates of lumpectomies as compared to mastectomies -- that's simply staggering."
Neither this, nor other differences were due to differences in Medigap insurance, said Dr. Lord, because researchers looked only at so-called core services, which Medicare covers in full.
Dr. Wennberg and his colleagues said that studies had found no evidence that people who had more medical care, or who paid more for it, were healthier. But they found that prices and procedures varied enormously.
For example, the researchers found, Medicare costs per person for fee-for-service medicine were at least twice as high in Miami as they were in Lincoln, Neb., Minneapolis and Honolulu. In Miami, the most expensive region, the costs were $5,966 per enrollee. In Lincoln, the cheapest area in the country, the cost was $2,729. Other high-priced regions included New Orleans, Pittsburgh, Nashville, Baltimore, Birmingham and Los Angeles. The inexpensive regions included Buffalo, Albany and Arlington, Va. New York City is higher than average but is not among the highest priced.
Regions with high medical costs were not substituting high priced hospitalizations for inexpensive home health care, the investigators found. Instead, they were spending more on all kinds of health care, both charging more for the services they provided and providing more services.
In Miami, for example, Medicare reimbursements for doctors and laboratory tests, but not hospitalization, were $2,380 per enrollee for the calendar year -- the highest in the nation. The lowest rate, of $585, was in Minneapolis.
In general, said Dr. Lord, areas with the highest costs had the largest numbers of doctors and hospitals. "One of the themes of the atlas is that supply seems to be a driver of demand," he said. "As we see increases in the number of physicians and of hospital beds, there seems to be an increase in the use of resources and the cost of resources. This defies the economic laws we've been trained to think about -- that demand is a driver of supply."
The investigators also found that when there was more than one option for treating a medical condition, the treatment of choice varied enormously from region to region of the country.
This happened, for example, in the decision to perform breast-sparing surgery -- a lumpectomy or partial mastectomy, followed by radiation or chemotherapy -- rather than a mastectomy for women with breast cancer. It happened in decisions to remove a man's prostate gland when he had signs of early stage cancer rather than treat the cancer with radiation or do nothing until it showed signs of rapid growth. It happened in decisions to treat heart disease aggressively, with bypass surgery or angioplasty rather than with medications. It happened in decisions to operate on people with chronic back pain rather than to prescribe rest, weight loss and specific exercises.
For example, Dr. Wennberg and his colleagues found that rates of breast-sparing surgery among women with breast cancer varied from a low of 1.4 percent of breast cancer surgery in Rapid City, S.D., to a high of 48 percent in Elyria, Ohio. Yet, said Amy S. Langer, who is executive director of the National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations, a nonprofit information resource center, 80 percent of women with early stage breast cancer are "excellent candidates for breast conserving treatment."
They also found that a man with early stage prostate cancer was four times as likely to have his prostate gland removed if he lived in Salt Lake City than if he lived in Manhattan. A person with a herniated disk is seven times as likely to have back surgery in Kingsport, Tenn., as one in Provo, Utah.
These treatment differences, the researchers noted, occur when there is uncertainty about which method is best. "For conditions that we know how to treat, like hip fracture, everyone goes to the hospital and everyone stays in the hospital," said Dr. Therese A. Stukel, the group's statistician.
The regional variations in medical costs and in treatments are so pronounced that they could not have occurred by chance, said Dr. Bradley Efron, a statistician at Stanford University who developed the standard method for looking for such chance associations and who is not associated with the project.
Dr. Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University, said the analysis raised real questions about what medical care should consist of and what it should cost. Doctors, he said, like to talk about the quality of care. But, he said, when you look at the price discrepancies you have to ask, "How can it be that 'the best medical care in the world' costs twice as much as the best medical care in the world?"
Medical care, Dr. Reinhardt said, "is driven by fads and the fads are regional." But, he added, "we don't call it fads -- we call it 'professional norms.' "
Dr. Wennberg said, and others agreed, that doctors rather than patients were calling the shots. "Patients are used to delegating decision making to physicians," he said. And, he said, when there is uncertainty about what procedure is best, "there are very few places where information is placed forward in an unbiased way to the patient."
One explanation of the results is that specialists tend to cluster in particular geographic regions -- orthopedic surgeons are found in the West, for example -- and the more specialists in an area, the more they might be expected to perform procedures. But that is not the entire explanation, doctors said. Dr. Robert Boyd, chief of orthopedic spine service at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said that his area had "many fine orthopedic surgeons" but, as a group, they were much less likely to operate on people with back pain than were orthopedic surgeons elsewhere.
"We are quite conservative," Dr. Boyd said. And, he added, "we are closer to the right number of operations per thousand than physicians in the West." In fact, he said, he thinks the number of operations in Boston can be even lower.
Dr. Boyd and others said that a central reason for the disparities was that different medical centers had different philosophies about treatments and that doctors tended to practice in regions where they were trained, perpetuating their medical school's treatment philosophy. When doctors do move to a new area, they often adapt themselves to the prevailing treatment there.
Dr. William Catalona, chief of urological surgery at Washington University in St. Louis, an area with a high rate of prostate surgery, said doctors in some other regions, like New England, "tend to be conservative."
But in St. Louis, he said, he and his colleagues trained young doctors to do the surgery and made sure they did enough operations to be proficient. In contrast, he said, "one of our young faculty members, who is just a wonderful surgeon, trained at Harvard in urology," adding, "When he finished his training not very long ago, he had never performed a radical prostatectomy." Now, Dr. Catalona said, the man has learned to do the operation and does it often.
Dr. Reinhardt said the move to health maintenance organizations might make practice variations fade away. H.M.O.'s insist on rigid treatment guidelines. But, Dr. Boyd said, the problem can be subtler than that.
"I don't think managed care has solved those problems," Dr. Boyd said. For example, he said, when he examines doctors for their orthopedic boards, he has found "people in practice a year who have done a couple of hundred spine fusions." Dr. Boyd, however, said, "I wouldn't do 200 of those things in the rest of my life." Yet when he asked the doctors why they did them, they listed accepted indications. It was a matter of interpretation and medical philosophy that drove them to do the operations -- not cold, hard facts, he said.
"It's hard to look at an individual procedure or doctor and be very critical," Dr. Boyd said. "But looking at the overall numbers, there's something funny here and we'd better find out what it is."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uncertainties Hurt Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, under pressure from uncertainty over economic conditions and this week's Federal Reserve meeting.
The market was also weighed down by a weaker dollar, higher commodity prices, an increase in the supply of new debt securities coming to market and a rush of new economic data this week. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 21/32, to 110 24/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.09 percent, from 6.04 percent on Friday.
Trading was moderate as the market consolidated ahead of the Fed meeting. The Fed's monetary policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, begins a two-day meeting today to set monetary policy for the months ahead. Half of the market believes the Fed will adjust short-term rates lower to stimulate a weak economy, analysts said, while the other half, still unconvinced that the economy is that weak, believes the central bank will leave interest rates as they are.
Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities (USA) Corporation, said he expected that the Fed would cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point. "It's the most prudent amount," he said, "since it would probably be the easiest to approve, with a half- point probably more appropriate and cleaner, but with more difficulty in getting the votes without clear-cut data about the weakness of the economy."
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, also said he expected a cut of a quarter- point.
The Fed meeting, Mr. Gamba added, is one of three significant factors dragging the market down, the others being continued selling by hedge funds, which are private investment funds for wealthy people, and the uncertainty over the Federal budget talks.
"All of these things will deminish in time," he said. " The budget will be resolved, the hedge funds will stop unwinding and Fed's meeting will end. Once those three obstacles are out of the way, there is no reason why the market can't be at 5.75 percent on the long end."
There are buyers, he said, as evidenced yesterday, when they came into the market to buy on the lows, and that generated a little short-covering rally. He also said that the market took notice of a sharp rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities, which gained 2.45 points, to 244.66.
Traders said early weakness in the dollar yesterday allowed Treasury prices to explore the bottom of the session's price range. Much of the activity, they said, was driven by position-squaring ahead of the meeting, the day's losses capped by traders looking for value and buying bonds on the lows.
The market was also bracing for a number of economic reports. The Government issues December retail sales today, and tomorrow the Treasury announces the size of its quarterly sales of new securities, including a 30-year bond.
At the weekly Treasury bill auction yesterday, rates were higher for the first time in five weeks. Analysts said the rise in rates suggested that investors thought the Fed might refrain from an immediate reduction in interest rates. The last rate cut came at the Dec. 19 meeting, when the Federal funds target rate, the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, was lowered by a quarter of a point, to 5.5 percent.
The average rate for a three-month bill at yesterday's auction was 5.01 percent, up from 4.99 percent last week, while the rate for a six-month maturity increased to 4.90 percent, from 4.88 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Mark On Doubt on Europe Money Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against the German mark, which was bolstered by growing uncertainty over the fate of plans to establish a single currency in Europe.
Traders were also hestitant to buy dollars ahead of the meetings today and tommorrow of the Federal Reserve committee that sets interest-rate policy. 
 Without any economic data for further guidance, traders shed their dollars for currencies, like the mark, that are perceived to be safer.
In late trading in New York yesterday, a dollar bought 1.4830 marks, compared with 1.4912 marks Friday. The dollar ended at 106.75 yen, up from 106.67 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5057, from $1.5020 on Friday.
Doubts about the timetable for a single European currency, to be called the Euro, helped the mark.
Recent economic reports from Europe indicate that even Germany, Europe's largest economy, is not assured of meeting the strict fiscal criteria for entering into a European economic union by 1999.
In recent months when economic union had seemed more clearly possible, traders had begun moving into the Swiss franc as a safe haven, replacing the mark as the primary European currency of safety.
Yesterday, that strategy went into reverse. Without a common European currency, the German mark would again be the safe currency to hold, traders said.
"We had expected money to flow out of Switzerland into Germany" if doubts grew about economic union, said Robert Prior, European economist at James Capel & Company's branch in Frankfurt.
The Italian lira, the French franc and the Spanish peseta all weakened against the mark yesterday. And the dollar weakened as a result, as traders sold the other currencies for dollars and then sold the dollars for marks.
Profit taking from gains made last week also hurt the dollar, said Chris Iggo, an international economist at Chase Manhattan Bank.
Analysts said the currency market was divided on whether the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates to aid the American economy during the meeting of its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee.
When a country cuts its rates, returns on new investments become less attractive to investors, along with that country's currency.
Dollar-yen trading stayed within a narrow range but fell to profit taking once the dollar hit 107 yen, Mr. Iggo said, noting that "there's been no news from the U.S. that would seriously impact the dollar."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Timely Cash Assistance Rescues 2 Households

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Two Manhattan households, separated by about two dozen blocks and very different circumstances, had one pressing need in common. Both had experienced financial hardship and were badly in need of emergency help.
Robbie and Marian Perry, high school sweethearts from nearby Harlem neighborhoods, were married 11 years ago. With two daughters, 6 and 11, they had always been able to make ends meet. Until last summer. 
 That summer was a tough time, too, for Bernard Williams, a 45-year-old traffic-enforcement agent. Having fallen victim to crack cocaine addiction, Mr. Williams was finally walking out of a rehabilitation program sober -- but facing a financial crisis.
Judith Milone, with the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, was able to help both Bernard Williams and the Perry family avoid eviction.
The federation, which provides grants to people in need, is one of the seven agencies supported by the Times Neediest Cases Fund, which pays its administrative costs so that donations go directly to the charities.
Early last year, Mrs. Perry lost her $32,000-a-year bookkeeping job. With the couple's third child due in September, Mr. Perry, then working nights for the Procall answering service in New Rochelle, took a second job as a customer service representative for Time Warner Cable but had to relinquish it after four months when Procall switched him to a daytime schedule.
Their financial situation began to worsen and, by midsummer, they fell behind in their rent.
"This is a family that needs two incomes," said Mrs. Perry, nursing 4-month-old Nia from a bottle. "It's expensive to have a child."
Ms. Milone, who arranged for an emergency grant of $675, a month's rent, to help the Perry family back on their feet, agreed that "with three children, their case was very compelling."
Mr. Perry said, "We just needed an opportunity to get out of this situation." He took the New York City Police Department test two years ago and is hoping to be selected soon. Behind him hangs a family photograph, and in the corner are two small bicycles and a Big Wheel children's tricycle, waiting for warmer weather.
"We just wanted to be able to get back on track," Mr. Perry said.
The Perrys worry about how to tell the girls, who are bright students, that they cannot afford some of their school's optional trips or special preparatory academic courses. "We tell them it's only temporary," Mr. Perry said.
While the Perry family is still living from one paycheck to the next, Mr. Williams tries to live one day at a time. Referred to the federation through a friend from the Canaan Baptist Church, he, too, was helped by Ms. Milone.
"He would come in his uniform," she said. "He was back to work and was in an outpatient program at St. Luke's Hospital but needed help with his rent."
Mr. Williams, a Department of Traffic enforcement agent for midtown, has found ways to enjoy a job he calls "the most stressful there is."
"I eat up double parkers and bus stops," he said, grinning. "You have to make the best of the job."
Mr. Williams said that the daily hassles from irate drivers did not bother him but conceded that painful events in his life, including growing up without a father and two failed marriages, did take their toll, causing him to seek refuge in drugs.
"I'd go out and try to medicate myself to try to run from the pain," he said. "Acid, speed, opium, cocaine. I tried them all."
Then his voice lowered and he looked toward the floor. "But my drug of choice was crack cocaine, the most addictive of all of them," he said softly. "Once I'd take the first hit, I couldn't stop until everything was gone. I remember once going through a $500 paycheck in 14 hours."
Last June, Mr. Williams checked himself into the Smithers Rehabilitation Center on East 93d Street for two weeks. "You get to the point where you're sick and tired of being sick and tired," he said.
Though his insurance covered the treatment costs, Mr. Williams received no paycheck for the two weeks out of work and could not afford to pay his overdue rent. The federation's grant of $590 in October helped him avoid eviction and resume a sober life style, which includes attending several Narcotics Anonymous meetings a week.
"Now I'm learning how to deal with life on life's terms," he said.

HEADLINE: Compaq Rank Again No. 1 In PC Sales

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation retained its top ranking as the world's leading marketer of personal computers last year, but I.B.M. edged past troubled Apple Computer for the No. 2 position.
The year-end tallies, reported yesterday by Dataquest, a computer market research firm in San Jose, Calif., showed that worldwide personal computer sales grew nearly 25 percent, to 59.7 million. In the United States, PC sales rose 21 percent, to 22.5 million. 
 The strong sales of personal computers last year were fueled by the switch to machines using Intel's Pentium microchip and the introduction of Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system in August.
But the company-by-company market numbers show that an industry consolidation, long predicted by industry analysts, does not seem to be occurring. The expectation had been that the market shares of the bigger companies would steadily increase, as they benefited from economies of scale in manufacturing and marketing.
Yet the market share of most leading PC makers held steady or declined last year, a trend that was particularly evident in the American market, often regarded as a forerunner of global market trends.
For the year, Compaq's American market share fell to 12.2 percent from 12.6 percent; Packard Bell's dropped to 11.3 from 11.4 percent; Apple's to 11.1 from 11.6 percent; I.B.M.'s to 8.3 from 9 percent, and Gateway 2000's to 5.1 from 5.2 percent.
"The PC manufacturers market is becoming more fragmented, not less, at least for the time being," said Kimball Brown, an analyst for Dataquest.
The industry, in a sense, has consolidated. But it has consolidated around the producers of the key PC technologies -- Intel's chip, and Microsoft's operating system -- rather than around the manufacturers, like Compaq and I.B.M., that assemble the technological components.
Intel has gone further by producing PC motherboards, which house not only the microchip but also the surrounding circuitry for a personal computer. Many PC makers buy the motherboards from Intel, so they have to do less assembly work themselves.
For Intel, the strategy can be risky, as it found out when it overestimated demand for motherboards and its fourth-quarter earnings were disappointing. Packard Bell, which analysts say misjudged demand for low-end PC's, is a large purchaser of Intel motherboards.
Yet purchasing motherboards from Intel makes design and manufacturing skills less crucial for PC makers. "That levels the playing field," Mr. Brown of Dataquest said.
As the PC market matures, some analysts say that the total size of a company's market share often means less than how it does in the market niches where it makes the most money -- and how efficiently it can make and sell computers.
For example, I.B.M.'s share slipped slightly in the world PC market and somewhat faster in the United States. But with its higher market share in 1994, I.B.M. lost an estimated $1 billion. Last year, by contrast, I.B.M.'s PC business probably made more than $100 million in operating profits, Daniel Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, estimated
For 1996, Dataquest is forecasting a slower pace of growth, with global shipments rising 19 percent and the American market ahead 13 percent. Still, some analysts regard the slowdown as a one-year transition, as the industry prepares for another round of new technology in 1997, when Intel's faster Pentium Pro chip becomes the industry standard and Microsoft is expected to bring out a major upgrade to its Windows program. M03,20,40,20> --------------------Digital Ending a PC Line
MAYNARD, Mass., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it would get out of the home computer market and focus on selling personal computers to businesses.
The company said it would discontinue development of its Starion line of PC's. It will instead expand and promote its Venturis desktop and Hinote notebook computers for businesses, although some Digital machines will remain in stores.

HEADLINE: Please Admit Poor, Pitiful Me

BYLINE: By Merrill Markoe; Merrill Markoe is the author of "How to Be Hap-Hap-Happy Like Me."

DATELINE: MALIBU, Calif.

 BODY:
As a graduate of University of California at Berkeley, I was fascinated by the Board of Regents's new affirmative action guidelines that consider social and economic disadvantage instead of the race and sex criteria of yesteryear. Admissions officers will give preference to students from "difficult family situations," which applicants can describe in personal essays.
This news made me regret all the energy I wasted in high school pursuing an acceptable grade- point average. If these guidelines had been in effect back then, I would have slept through my senior year and taken my chances with an essay that probably would have read like this: 
 Dear Board of Regents,
I realize that my grades are not all that great, but this is because I am a survivor of a difficult family situation (to say the least). If you talk to my parents (which I hope you do not), I bet they would say that my basic needs for food and shelter are being met.
Right. If I am willing to eat what they eat, which is impossible as I have been a lacto-vegetarian for more than six months -- a fact that both parents refuse to take seriously. They constantly tease and taunt me: "Care for more bean sprouts, Miss Vegetarian? Doesn't it bother you to kill an innocent potato? Isn't a vegetable a living thing, too?"
Many are the nights I run sobbing from the dinner table, only to lie alone, quaking with hunger and shame, in the dark, dark shadows of my cold and lonely room.
Oh, I guess you could say I have "shelter," if that's what you call such a soul-deadening environment. My mother sees dirt everywhere and constantly sends me in to perfectly clean rooms and demands that I clean them. So I move a few things around, but how can you clean something that is already totally clean?
I swear there is no way to please these people, especially when you take into account that my mother has horrible taste in clothes. One time she actually expected me to wear a navy blue wool-blend skirt gathered at the waist and trimmed in white piping that comes with a matching short-sleeved jacket with a SILHOUETTE OF A DUCK IN A RAIN HAT STITCHED ON THE POCKET!!!
Believe me, trying to talk to them about this stuff makes no difference, because no one cares about my feelings. For instance, I would rather not go to this one restaurant where a lot of the varsity football players work part time as busboys and waiters. But if we must, is it too much to ask that my father, just one time, NOT make horrible dumb jokes? For weeks afterward, whenever the guys see me they roll their eyes in a lizard-like expression that means "Oh, your DAD!!!"
Which brings me to the fact that I am not permitted to have a social life in any meaningful sense of the word. If a person gets her driver's license, then she should have full access to the car, even if she failed her test for a license the first three times, because she was very distracted due to personal matters that I cannot get into right now -- except to say that every single guy that I like has something wrong with him, according to my parents' twisted view of reality in which they refuse to comprehend that a shaved head or a tattoo is a way for a person to demonstrate his individuality and creativity. And if I suddenly want to shave my head and get a tattoo to express my individuality and creativity, I am not under his influence, and should not be grounded and treated like a criminal.
I do not intend to let this painful start in life keep me from striving fully for a brighter tomorrow. If you admit me, I will work hard to achieve my goal of becoming someone really important and famous. I am not absolutely sure what I want to do yet, but I will show the world I have overcome my pathetic, restrictive, boring childhood. Thank you.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Breaking Out of Japan's Orbit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 29

 BODY:
It has long been an article of faith in this industrially oriented society that, to borrow from an American saying, what's good for Toyota is good for Japan.
But as the Toyota Motor Corporation and other big companies move more operations and jobs out of Japan, that equation is becoming less true. And that is creating new stress in the vaunted relationship between government and big business. 
 Companies like Sony and Toyota might well continue as fearsome competitors on the world stage, but Japan will enjoy fewer benefits of their success. This break with the past, analysts say, will make Japan's Government less eager to help big business.
For their part, the increasingly global-minded companies have become more impatient with some strictures of the Japanese system and with the inability of the Government to address recent economic woes.
Big companies, trying to cut costs in areas like shipping and utilities, have been pressing for economic deregulation but have run into resistance from the Government and from some small businesses. Even as Japan faces a huge budget deficit, big companies are pushing for lower corporate taxes, saying the high tax rate puts them at a competitive disadvantage. And some big banks have been trying to shed the burden of rescuing weaker, smaller ones.
Without some changes, "all the competitive international companies will go out of the country," said Reijiro Kuromizu, executive vice president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, stressing that he was voicing a personal opinion, not his company's. "We have to survive."
Disputes between companies and the Government are, of course, nothing new. For example, the Honda Motor Company, originally a motorcycle manufacturer, entered the auto business against the wishes of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry about three decades ago.
Nor is the "iron triangle" -- the triad of big business, politicians and bureaucrats that is said to run Japan -- rapidly crumbling. Even as they internationalize, Japanese companies remain more wedded to their home country than American or European multinationals do.
One sign of rupture was that in 1993, Keidanren, the chief lobbying organization for big business, stopped funneling contributions on behalf of business to Japan's largest political party, the Liberal Democrats. But individual companies and some other business organizations are now resuming such donations, and Keidanren itself is making one more contribution.
Still, the issue is attracting attention now because the rise in the yen in the last three years has led to an acceleration of the shift of manufacturing offshore just as unemployment has risen to a postwar high of 3.4 percent. And Japanese companies are more openly espousing globalism. Toray, Japan's largest synthetic fiber maker, has adopted the slogan "Made in Toray" to suggest that it doesn't matter where its products are made.
Many American companies have long since become multinationals. And Washington has had to grapple with such questions as whether to give research and development incentives to an American company that is likely to manufacture the resulting product abroad.
But in Japan, globalization might have an even greater impact because the ties between business and government have been so close that their joint power has been dubbed Japan Inc.
"Japan's remarkable postwar economic development was due largely to a cooperative relationship between government and business," Jin Nakamura, business editor of Japan's leading newspaper, Yomiuri Shimbun, wrote in a column. But, he added, "conflicts have been emerging in recent years between the Government's 'national interests' and the private-sector 'corporate interests.' "
The shift of jobs overseas -- to lower costs, to calm trade tensions or to better exploit foreign markets -- has contributed to Japan's current slump, the longest since World War II, and it will mean any recovery will be tepid.
Company spending on plants and equipment, a prime driver of Japan's economy, has been weak. Nearly a quarter of the capital spending by the transportation equipment industry and almost a third by electrical machinery companies are now made outside Japan, according to the Japan Development Bank.
The shift has put big business under more pressure from politicians, who fear that companies will abandon Japan. Hiroshi Okuda, Toyota's president, said he constantly heard concerns from politicians that departing companies were "leaving high unemployment behind."
Partly in response to trade pressure from the United States, Toyota recently said it would build a fourth North American factory, in Indiana. Its production in Japan has already dropped by a million vehicles, or nearly 25 percent, between 1990 and 1994, with much of the decline offset by increases elsewhere.
One big concern is lifetime employment. Japan's big companies have avoided layoffs of full-time male employees. But if companies become less wedded to Japan, they might scrap such loyalty.
Asked recently whether his priority was jobs or profits, Hisashi Kaneko, president of the NEC Corporation, gave the politically correct answer: "Our responsibility is to maintain employment in Japan while maintaining a reasonable profit."
Big companies are, however, pressuring suppliers to cut prices, leading to layoffs at these companies.
The globalization has only just begun, and Japanese companies are in a state of "immature internationalization," said Hideki Yoshihara, a professor of international business at Kobe University.
The percentage of manufacturing done by Japanese companies outside Japan is still less than 10 percent, compared with more than 20 percent for American companies, the trade and industry ministry said, although some Japanese electronics and auto companies have far more than the average.
Moreover, the mind-set of Japanese executives remains centered on Japan. When a company reports how many employees it has, for example, it usually means only workers in Japan.
An example of this was the Daiwa Bank. When its New York branch suffered huge losses from unauthorized trading, it told Japan's Finance Ministry, but it did not tell American regulators for six weeks.
While American companies like Apple Computer, Compaq and Ford Motor are headed by people who are not from the United States, virtually no Japanese company, even seemingly global-minded ones like Honda and Toyota, has even a single foreigner on its board. An exception is Sony, which has two foreign directors after the resignation of a third, Mickey Schulhof.
Even foreign operations are managed mainly by Japanese sent from the home office. Only about 20 percent of overseas subsidiaries have non-Japanese chief executives, Professor Yoshihara said, while about 65 percent of the Japanese subsidiaries of American companies have Japanese chief executives.
Still, companies are beginning to globalize beyond merely moving manufacturing. Auto makers design some cars for the American market in the United States. Electronics companies have research labs in the United States and Europe. Sony is planning to move some administrative jobs to the United States.
As big companies become more globally oriented, disputes are arising with other segments of Japanese society, though they are often kept under the surface.
Big companies, through their lobbying organization, Keidanren, have been leaders in calling for deregulation, at least of businesses other than their own. Such deregulation would lower the cost of doing business in Japan. These companies also complain that protection of Japan's farmers contributes to trade tensions that raise the yen, making it harder to export cars and VCR's.
But the Government has been slow to deregulate, both to preserve its own power and because politically powerful interests, like small shopkeepers and farmers, object.
"The only ones that benefit are giant companies," said Katsuto Uchihashi, a noted business journalist and author. "Labor unions and small businesses would be hurt."
Mr. Uchihashi cited big business's push to weaken the law restricting large retail stores, which are putting thousands of mom-and-pop stores out of business.
In the financial sector, some big banks, which tend to be healthier, are becoming more resistant to Finance Ministry requests that they help rescue smaller, failing ones, as has been the practice in Japan.
Big banks also want to disassociate themselves from the smaller financial institutions. That is because right now all Japanese banks must pay higher interest to raise money internationally as a result of a perceived weakness in Japan's banking system.
"We have to cut the linkage between the major healthy banks and the troubled small banks," said Ryoji Miura of the international planning division of the Sakura Bank.
Still, Mr. Miura was not about to declare an outright revolt. "As one of the major banks," he said, "we have to offer any assistance we can to secure the financial system."
Strains can also be seen in trade talks. Last summer the United States threatened to impose steep tariffs on Japanese luxury cars unless Japanese auto makers agreed to voluntary plans to increase purchases of foreign auto parts.
The Ministry of International Trade and Industry resisted, but Toyota was more willing to concede to prevent a disruption of Lexus sales. So Washington began direct talks with the companies.
Still, Japan Inc. maintained its unified front. Toyota never publicly disagreed with the ministry. And all the big auto companies came forth with "voluntary" plans on cue, when the ministry told them to.

HEADLINE: War in the Caucasus?

BYLINE: By Fiona Hill; Fiona Hill is associate director of the Strengthening Democratic Institutions Project at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The civil war in Chechnya, once largely confined to the rebel republic, now threatens to spread through the Caucasus and even beyond. The seizure of hostages in neighboring Dagestan and the hijacking of a ferry in Turkish waters this month reflected this ominous turn in the conflict, which could easily draw in Georgia and Azerbaijan, and possibly Turkey and Iran.
A long history of invasions, settlement and mass migrations, combined with the isolation of mountain valleys, have made the Caucasus one of the world's most ethnically diverse and volatile regions. 
 The North Caucasus has often been torn by conflicts over territory and natural resources between Ossetians and Ingush, Ossetians and Georgians, Abkhazians and Georgians, Cossacks and Chechens, Chechens and Laks, Lezgins and Azeris.
With the Caucasian ethnic groups spread across so many borders, no conflict in the region can be considered the purely internal affair of one state, despite what Russia claims. Turkey and Iran, seeing their diplomatic protests ignored by the Russian Government, are covertly sending arms to the Chechens and other Muslim insurgents.
The recent civil wars in the region have their roots in high rural birth rates, ruined economies and, often, historical tensions between Islam and Eastern Orthodoxy. But they have been made worse by the geographic divisions and administrations inherited from the Soviet Union, many of which were intended by Stalin to divide ethnic groups across borders and impede the rise of local leadership.
In several regions Russia has negotiated bilateral treaties giving republics some control over profits from foreign investment, the management of state property, tax revenues, local judiciaries and other aspects of self-rule. Negotiations for such a pact were under way in Chechnya when the war began; if it is to have any hope of ending the conflict, Russia must make real concessions.
Otherwise, Dagestan will be drawn into the fighting. Dagestan is the North Caucasus writ small, with its own complex ethnic mosaic. If the Chechen war spreads there, the whole edifice of the Caucasus could come crashing down.
Lezgins, whose ancestral lands are divided between Dagestan and the independent republic of Azerbaijan to the south, would undoubtedly fight for independence, bringing Azerbaijan into the conflict. Widespread violence would also likely revive the rebellion of the Abkhazians in Georgia.
Turkey, with five million ethnic Caucasians, and Iran, which worries that any unrest in Azerbaijan might lead the 15 million Azeris in its northern provinces to secede, would feel forced to intervene in any full-fledged Caucasian war.
The fighting not only imperils the political stability of Russia and the Caucasian republics but their economic prospects as well. In October, Azerbaijan's international oil consortium announced it would ship Caspian oil from Baku to the Black Sea in pipelines to be built across Chechnya, Dagestan and Georgia. But no major investors will invest in pipelines that cross a war zone.
With the oil scheduled to start flowing from new Caspian fields later this year, Russia needs to offer the Chechens a treaty involving real concessions. The only alternative is war in the Caucasus.
