HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;
An Anti-PAC Fight Angers G.O.P.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 29

 BODY:
In control of Congress for the first time in 40 years, Republicans are proving to be as adept as Democrats in using their majority status to raise money for re-election.
But the windfall has attracted an old critic of Congress, the Texas billionaire Ross Perot, who has joined forces with a freshman Republican, Representative Linda Smith of Washington State, and a former Democratic Senator and Presidential candidate, Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, to form the Coalition to Clean Up Congress. 
 Starting with a town meeting on Jan. 20 in Concord, Mass., they plan to tour more than 100 Congressional districts, pounding home their message against a campaign finance system they say is little more than institutionalized vote-buying.
Judging by the reaction of fellow Republicans in Washington State, which had the biggest electoral swing from Democrats to Republicans in the 1994 election, the so-called clean Congress campaign is making new members somewhat squeamish.
Although Ms. Smith collected about $17,000 after being elected to Congress, she says she has stopped taking donations from political action committees. She paints the innumerable fund-raising events as cesspools of influence-peddling that would shock the average voter. And much to the anger of Speaker Newt Gingrich, she has joined with a handful of Democrats to push a bill that would ban all political action committee contributions.
"It's like our dirty little secret," said Ms. Smith, who represents the Third Congressional District, in southwestern Washington. "When I went back to Washington I had not a clue about how things really work. Every night, I found out, members go across the street to these fund-raisers. And this is where lobbyists buy access."
Privately, Republican party leaders in this state say they are furious with Ms. Smith. They note that she took PAC money to get elected -- about 25 percent of the $522,000 she raised in 1994 came from such groups -- and then suddenly found it to be the root of political evil.
But Ms. Smith said she had an epiphany about the connection between money and votes early on, when she offered an amendment to eliminate $23 million in tobacco subsidies from the budget. She expected the members from the tobacco states to vote against it, but was unprepared for the number of "no" votes by legislators from states with no economic interest in tobacco.
Ms. Smith's amendment lost by 24 votes, and the tobacco subsidy remained. To her, it was a clear case of money -- in the form of the contributions tobacco company PACs make to members -- buying votes. Why not have a Congress, she asks in speeches, that will decide issues on merits instead of influence?
"A lot of the American dream of our political system is in reality a few people in D.C. with big checkbooks controlling America's future," she said.
Such comments have not only won Ms. Smith the backing of Mr. Perot, they have also won the approval of editorial writers around the country, and support from groups like the League of Women Voters and Common Cause, both of which are providing volunteers for the clean Congress campaign.
But within her own party, Ms. Smith has been treated like an irritant at best. Mr. Gingrich said recently that American politics needed more money, not less, and that any effort at changing the system would have to come from a committee studying the issue this year.
Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, said voters do not really care about changing the system. He cited the Republican filibuster of a campaign finance overhaul bill in the Senate just before the 1994 Congressional races, a move that did not hurt his party at the polls.
The 73 freshman Republicans alone raised $4.4 million from PACs in their first six months in office -- much higher, proportionately, than previous freshman classes, according to Common Cause.
In this state, where the House delegation in 1994 shifted to seven Republicans and two Democrats from one Republican and eight Democrats, and the Democratic Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, was among the casualties, Ms. Smith's fellow freshman Republicans have been among the biggest PAC beneficiaries. That puts them in a difficult position when she gives speeches on why "we should shut down the fund-raisers that give us the tobacco subsidies and the military contracts that we don't need."
Representative Rick White, a freshman Republican from Washington's First Congressional District, raised $245,021 in the first six months in office, of which $113,741 came from PACs. Randy Tate, another freshman Republican whose Ninth District is just north of Ms. Smith's, raised $162,927, of which $105,251 came from PACs.
Mr. Tate says he will not "unilaterally disarm" by refusing to take PAC money, when his opponents will not do the same. Mr. White says he thought about declining PAC money, but decided against it for much the same reason.
"I think people spend altogether too much time time raising money," Mr. White said. "On the other hand, I don't think Congressmen are quite as venal as Linda portrays them. I don't think people buy your votes."
But Mr. Tate and Mr. White said voters kept bringing up campaign financing in town hall meetings. Particularly among swing voters or people who voted for Mr. Perot in the 1992 Presidential race, the issue is dear to their hearts, they said.
Both men said they would support an alternative to Ms. Smith's bill, which has attracted only 20 supporters in the House so far. Mr. White is offering his own proposal, in which an independent commission would come up with a plan to overhaul the campaign finance system.
Ms. Smith says the "old-timers in Congress, the ones that are brought out in wheelchairs" might never give up the current campaign system. But younger members are expected to do things differently.
In addition to banning PAC money, the bill would require that 60 percent of contributions come from a politician's home state, and it would restrict so-called soft money, which is funneled through the parties to avoid spending limits.
"These are extremely powerful issues in the country," said Ann McBride, president of Common Cause, which supports the bill. "The American people said in 1992 that they wanted Congress to change the way they did business. Tom Foley ignored that and look what happened to him. Mr. Gingrich should learn from history."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Linda Smith has won few friends, and little support, with her bill to ban contributions from political action committees. (Dan Lamont for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On TV, Showing Life as Lived

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The revolution, as they used to say, will not be televised. On the other hand there's always room in prime time for another sitcom.
Such are the north and south poles of Ralph Farquhar's professional existence. A tall, bearded 44-year-old partial to T-shirts and baseball hats, Mr. Farquhar is both a black activist and a successful network television writer, an agent of change and a well-connected industry insider. 
 "Throughout my entire career I've only had one goal, one motivation," he said over lunch recently at a Caribbean restaurant in a relatively untrendy neighborhood east of Hollywood. "To bring an honest portrayal to the life I live to the screen: to the small screen."
In 1994, "South Central," a gritty half-hour comedy set in inner-city Los Angeles, was praised by critics and received an award from Viewers for Quality Television, a group that uses viewer mail as leverage to petition the networks to save programs. But the show, which Mr. Farquhar created with Michael Whitehorn, had a low-rated run on the Fox Network and was dropped after only 13 weeks.
Mr. Farquhar's next television project, "Moesha" (pronounced moe-EESH-ah), is a more subtly, perhaps even sneakily, innovative sitcom that had its premiere on Jan. 23 on the one-year old United Paramount Network. (In New York the show is broadcast on Tuesdays on WWOR, Channel 9, at 8 P.M.)
The series, which he created with his co-executive producers, Sara Finney and Vida Spears, both of whom are veteran comedy writers, stars the 16-year-old Brandy Norwood, better known as the pop singer Brandy, in the title role.
Moesha Mitchell is a bright, attractive high school student with a smart-aleck younger brother (Marcus T. Paulk), a good-natured father (William Allen Young) and a disconcertingly vivacious stepmother (Sheryl Lee Ralph). Like most teen-age inhabitants of the sitcom world, she agonizes volubly over such issues as boys, household rules and the prevention of facial blemishes.
What sets "Moesha" apart from other black sitcoms is that the Mitchells live in a middle-class world that is demographically and culturally almost entirely made up of black and Hispanic residents. Their neighborhood, Leimert Park, is a real middle-class black neighborhood that while practically unknown to most white Los Angelenos is very familiar to Mr. Farquhar and his co-writers.
"Moesha is completely honest to the culture and the environment we're portraying," Mr. Farquhar said. "We make no nods toward making it seem white. You know, it just is what it is."
"But the good news," he added, "is that it's not that much different from anyone else's life in America. We just keep the flavor."
There were no white faces in the first episode of "Moesha." While it is obvious to the viewer that the Mitchells buy into many parts of the American dream -- Moesha's stepmother is a schoolteacher, her father sells Saturn automobiles -- the characters' ethnic sensibilities are neither muted nor, in most cases, underlined.
In the show, adults and teen-agers alike pepper their speech freely though not ostentatiously with black English, including black slang. Decor and dress show strong Afrocentric influences. Moesha's heartthrob is a boy named Ohagi (the character says it means "conquering warrior"), who recites rap-style poetry at a local teen-age hangout. A disparaging remark is made in passing about the O. J. Simpson trial prosecutor Christopher Darden, obliquely implying where the Mitchell family stands on the issue of Mr. Simpson's guilt or innocence.
These are clearly not the Huxtables from "The Cosby Show." But neither are they the Mosleys, the family on which "South Central" was centered. In that single-parent, female-headed household, just a paycheck or two away from welfare, plots were strongly tied to issues like unwed parenthood, gang warfare and racial discrimination. One son had been killed in a police shootout before the action of the series began. Another boy, a foster child, never spoke. Industry detractors labeled it too depressing.
"Did we go too far with 'South Central?' " Mr. Farquhar said. "No, because you can never go too far. If there's one thing I learned from TV, it's that if you know that something's going to work, if you're comfortable with it, you're wrong. When you go far enough so that you don't know whether something's going to work or not, then you're doing the right thing."
"Moesha" is about a family that is doing well, said Mr. Farquhar, who is divorced and remarried and has grown children, "so that we can focus on emotional issues without the barrier of economics."
"Still," he added, "there will always be serious moments. Moesha is not an idealized teen-ager. The real world is still out there."
Mr. Farquhar has always probed the limits of the system. He was born and reared in Chicago, then went on to the United States Military Academy. He said he soon realized that "my talents lay elsewhere" and left after "one year, eight months and eight days."
He later received a degree in advertising from the University of Illinois, but moved to Los Angeles in the hope of becoming an actor.
He worked as a receptionist at a travel agency run by the wives of powerful entertainment industry executives, one of whom was the producer of the long-running ABC sitcom "Happy Days." Soon he was a writer's assistant -- a secretary, in other words -- on that show.
"But you want to know something funny?" he said. "Being a 6-foot-2 black man, nobody asked me to type anything, so I just sat there and wrote my own scripts."
One day after a company baseball game, Garry Marshall, the creator and executive producer of "Happy Days, came over to him to talk, Mr. Farquhar said.
"He said: 'What do you want to do?' " Mr. Farquhar said. "I said, 'I want to be a writer.' So he said, 'O.K., you just pitch to me anytime you have an idea.'
"I did that for two years. He would give me some time once a month, and I would pitch story ideas to him. And one day he hired me. He said, 'O.K., you can be a famous writer."'
Mr. Farquhar was a staff writer on "Happy Days" for three years. In the early 1990's he worked on the sitcoms "Married . . . With Children" and "Drexell's Class," and then, along with Michael Weithorn, a white writer and producer, developed "South Central" for CBS.
When that network turned it down -- as it did "Moesha" last year -- the two men got a commitment from the upstart Fox network.
When "South Central" had its premiere in April 1994, John J. O'Connor of The New York Times wrote, "There are laughs in 'South Central,' but they are secondary to a permeating sense of danger and looming disintegration." He added that the show had a "steady ring of truth."
Fox canceled the show in August. A momentarily bitter Mr. Farquhar gave some angry interviews and organized a letter-writing campaign, to no avail.
He then moved on to "Moesha." After CBS passed on it, the show was in limbo for several months until UPN, with its two-night-a-week schedule aimed at younger viewers, picked it up.
"When I saw it I liked it right away," said UPN's head of entertainment, Mike Sullivan, a producer of such shows as ABC's "Growing Pains" and "Just the 10 of Us."
"I especially thought Brandy was terrific, even though as a middle-aged white guy I was only peripherally aware of her as a singer," Mr. Sullivan said. "I felt the same way seeing her as when Kirk Cameron came in to audition for 'Growing Pains.' Before she's back in her car, she's a teen idol."
In its Tuesday night time slot, Mr. Farquhar's show appears opposite "Roseanne" on ABC and "Wings" on NBC. "I think we've got a chance," he said. "Who can say?"
Mr. Farquhar glanced down at his pager. He excused himself, retrieved and dialed his portable phone and spoke softly into it for a few minutes.
He then relayed the urgent crisis at the studio to his co-writers: should Ms. Norwood be equipped with false eyelashes for a scene?
"I have absolutely no opinion on that," he said, laughing.

HEADLINE: Prudential Will Sell Mortgage Unit to Norwest

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The Norwest Corporation said today that it would buy the Prudential Insurance Company's mortgage-lending unit and half its mortgage-processing business to bolster its No. 1 rank in the American mortgage industry.
The companies would not comment on the financial terms, but a person familiar with the deal said that Norwest would pay $625 million to $650 million. 
 Norwest's purchase of the Prudential Home Mortgage Company adds the nation's fourth-largest mortgage lender, with $15.7 billion in loans last year, to the largest.
The Minneapolis-based banking and financial-services company, through its Norwest Mortgage Inc. unit, also agreed to buy 50 percent of Prudential's $80 billion servicing business, which handles billing and processing. In addition, Norwest will become a subservicer for the remaining $40 billion in the Prudential mortgage portfolio.
The transaction will increase Norwest's earnings per share in the first year, the company said. The Norwest parent company has $72 billion in assets and more than 3,000 offices in the United States, Canada, the Caribbean and Central America.
Prudential put its St. Louis-based mortgage-lending operation up for sale in March so it could focus on its insurance business. The company in 1994 had the worst year in its history, losing $1.2 billion from lower insurance sales, payouts on catastrophe policies and litigation costs from a brokerage scandal.
The sale of a major part of Newark-based Prudential's mortgage business is the latest in a consolidation of the slumping industry. Banks and mortgage lenders found increased value in servicing old loans when new loans declined in 1994 amid higher interest rates.
Prudential's servicing unit, the Residential Services Corporation, has about 3,200 employees, with almost 1,000 in Frederick, Md. Norwest agreed to buy that office, as well as one in Springfield, Ill.
A Norwest spokeswoman, Anita Liskey, said it was too early to say if the work force would be cut at the operations it was buying.

HEADLINE: Visa Lottery Is Given Credit For Neighborhood Revival

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
An annual visa lottery that strives to diversify immigration to this country has revitalized some New York City neighborhoods, attracting thousands of Irish and Polish immigrants to once-fading neighborhoods, according to city demographers.
The annual lottery, which this year will offer coveted green cards to 55,000 foreigners, has been responsible for bringing 95 percent of the city's Irish immigrants and 64 percent of Polish immigrants since 1992, replenishing neighborhoods like the historic Polish community in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and the old Irish neighborhoods in Sunnyside, Queens, and Norwood, the Bronx. 
 "That energy is palpable," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said during a news conference yesterday. "That energy drives the city." At the news conference, officials announced the lottery and rules for applying. Applications will be accepted from Feb. 12 to March 12.
From 1992 to 1994, 9,300 Polish and 9,000 Irish lottery winners moved to New York City, according to preliminary statistics from the city's Planning Department. The surge has meant that Ireland, which in the 1980's ranked 30th among countries sending immigrants to New York, today ranks 12th. In the 1980's, Poland ranked 18th; today it holds 6th place.
On Bainbridge Avenue in the Norwood section of the Bronx, for instance, Irish newcomers can buy Irish chocolates, Irish sausages, Irish brown bread and Irish beer. It is the neighborhood where Bridie O'Malley settled when she first moved from Ireland.
Two years ago, she won the lottery, guaranteeing permanent legal residence in the United States.
"It was, like, an unbelievable feeling," said Ms. O'Malley, 27, who now works as a paralegal.
For eight years, Ms. O'Malley lived here illegally, working as a waitress, with no hope of gaining legal status because she had no immediate family in the United States.
Since the 1960's, the largest waves of immigration have come from Asia and Latin America, areas of political and economical instability, while the more prosperous Europeans stayed home.
Under American law, these new immigrants could and did bring their spouses, children and close relatives with them. But as the years passed, Irish- and Polish-Americans in the United States found themselves generations away from their European-born relatives.
Immigration policymakers decided that groups like the Irish and Polish were underrepresented, so Congress created the visa lottery as part of the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1990 to create greater diversity among immigrants.
Since then, the pool of applicants has been expanded to include all but 11 countries, excluding, in the interest of diversity, those that have sent 50,000 or more immigrants to the United States during the last five years. The excluded countries are China (mainland and Taiwan), India, the Philippines, Vietnam, South Korea, Britain (except Northern Ireland), Canada, Mexico, Jamaica, El Salvador, Colombia and the Dominican Republic.
Immigrants from anywhere else, whether they live illegally in the United States or abroad, can apply as long as they have a high school education or have worked five years in a field that requires at least two years of training.
There is no application form. For years, the State Department, which directs the program, has asked that applicants simply write their names, the names of their spouses and children, their date of birth and country of origin on a plain piece of paper and mail it to one of several processing centers in the United States.
This year, in an effort to fight application fraud, the State Department will also require immigrants to sign the sheet of paper and to include a photograph. In previous years, some ineligible applicants have assumed the identities of other immigrants, hoping to win a green card.
Only 7 percent of New York's legal immigrants gain entrance to the United States through the lottery system. But for the Irish and the Polish, the two groups that have benefited the most from the system, it has been virtually their only way to get in.
"They simply wouldn't be here without the lottery," said Joseph Salvo, the city's chief demographer.

GRAPHIC: Graph/Map: "BY THE NUMBERS: Visas by the Draw" shows this year's lottery allotment, divided by geographic region. (Source: State Department)

HEADLINE: Microsoft and MCI Agree On an Internet Alliance

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
In the promiscuous world of digital technology, where most companies prefer playing the field to going steady, MCI Communications said yesterday that it had signed an Internet alliance with the Microsoft Corporation. This, even though it already has an on-line partnership with the News Corporation.
Under the terms of the deal, MCI and Microsoft will jointly develop and market an array of on-line and Internet services. Microsoft said it had chosen MCI as the primary distributor of its commercial on-line service, the Microsoft Network. And MCI said it would promote Microsoft's Internet software and browser throughout its network. 
 MCI is already developing an on-line service with News Corporation. But Bert C. Roberts, MCI's chairman and chief executive, said his company would reduce its 50 percent equity stake in the venture to a minority interest.
"We are pushing our boat into Microsoft's waters as we go forward," Mr. Roberts said in a telephone conference call.
William H. Gates 3d, the chairman of Microsoft, said MCI would help Microsoft as it tried to build the Microsoft Network into a on-line service rivaling America Online or Prodigy. Microsoft's service has 600,000 subscribers, while America Online has 4.5 million.
"MCI and Microsoft have a lot in common," Mr. Gates said. "We both see a lot of opportunities on the Internet." He added that no money was changing hands in the deal. But he said Microsoft would take in some revenue as MCI used its software and Internet browser.
Analysts said the deal would benefit MCI by relieving the long-distance carrier of the expense of designing its own on-line service. Since Microsoft will also promote MCI's regular telephone services, MCI will have access to the 80 million customers who use Windows software.
"If the name of the game is everybody competing with everybody else," said Jack Grubman, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, "then the more stuff you can sell to your customers, the better."
MCI's deal is a setback for the company's other venture with the News Corporation. MCI had originally promoted on-line services as the centerpiece of its $2 billion alliance with the News Corporation, which owned the struggling Delphi on-line service. Both companies planned to use Delphi as the base for a much larger service.
"It seems clear that MCI has been frustrated by the slow pace of development there," said Emily Green, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
Delphi still has fewer than 100,000 subscribers, and the company has said little about new marketing or technology initiatives.
Scott Kurnit, chief executive of the MCI/News venture, said MCI's priorities had changed since it struck an alliance with the News Corporation in May. He added, "We are pursuing several other companies about becoming partners with us."
Executives familiar with the venture said that tomorrow it would announce that the Oracle Corporation, the software developer, was taking a 40 percent equity stake in the venture. News Corporation will also own 40 percent, while MCI's interest will drop to 20 percent.
For his part, Mr. Roberts noted that the MCI/News Corporation partnership was expanding in other ways. The companies plan to collaborate in delivering satellite television, using a high-powered orbital slot that MCI won in a Government auction last week for $472 million.
Analysts said the News Corporation would provide entertainment programs to the satellite venture through its Fox television network.
In a sign of just how Byzantine the deal-making has become, MCI has a deal with the News Corporation and Microsoft, while Microsoft has a separate deal with another television network, NBC. Microsoft and NBC plan to start a 24-hour news network and on-line service, MSNBC.
Thomas S. Rogers, president of NBC Cable, said that Microsoft's deal with MCI did not pose a conflict with NBC's partnership. "NBC News is distributed on the Microsoft Network," he said, "so anything that expands the distribution of the Microsoft Network is good for us."

HEADLINE: Micron Offers No Insight On Chief's Exit and Return

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Hundreds of shareholders and employees packed the convention center here today, drawn by the corporate soap opera that has captivated both locals and Wall Street: Why did Steve Appleton, chief executive of Micron Technology Inc., return to his job on Friday, just a week after resigning?
Even the local paper, The Idaho Statesman, urged the company, which is the largest corporate taxpayer in the area, to give an explanation. But at the meeting, Mr. Appleton and the board were mum. 
 After explaining that his differences with the board had been resolved and he would say no more about them, Mr. Appleton told the crowd that "just for the record, I took vacation hours last week." Everyone laughed but Mr. Appleton later said he wasn't joking.
Only a single shareholder politely suggested during the question-and-answer session that management of Micron, a maker of computer memory chips, might owe its investors an explanation. But Mr. Appleton demurred again, saying it was destructive to hash over past differences.
And that was it. Back to business as usual.
Few attendees seemed to mind the stonewalling, and appeared more concerned to learn when the 35-year-old chairman and chief executive thought Micron's share price would again rise above the $90 peak it reached in September. (He said he didn't know.) Today the stock closed at $33.625, down 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. And several analysts cut their estimates for Micron's earnings next year.
Mr. Appleton is a local hero, having begun his career at Micron 13 years ago working in the plant for $4.46 an hour. "The fact is," Dan Niles, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said, "the company is in much better shape with Steve than without him."
The unusual episode was vintage Micron, whose world-beating technological prowess often bumps up against the fading legacy of the frontier spirit.
The latter is exemplified by Micron's board, which is controlled by wealthy farmers who dominate Idaho's economy. Having given Micron seed money in the 1970's and nursed it through heavy losses in the 1980's, they regard it as their company.
Their leader, and Micron's largest shareholder and a member of its board, is J. R. Simplot, a billionaire who pioneered the art of freezing potatoes and made his fortune selling frozen french fries to the McDonald's Corporation.
When Mr. Appleton resigned on Jan. 18, his departure was attributed to a dispute with Mr. Simplot, but an executive close to Micron who spoke on condition of anonymity said today that Mr. Appleton's clash had been with Allen Noble, another director from Boise who was one of the company's early investors.
Mr. Noble said that was not true. "It was a unanimous board decision when he left," Mr. Noble said last night. "It was a unanimous board decision when he came back."
Mr. Simplot, who is 87, also chose not to elaborate on the board's differences with Mr. Appleton, but in a rambling address today he did discuss the departure of Mr. Appleton's predecessor, Joseph Parkinson, who resigned in September 1994 after reportedly accusing Mr. Simplot of divulging inside information.
"He didn't want to tell anyone anything," Mr. Simplot said of Mr. Parkinson. "I want to tell people everything."
With that, Mr. Simplot proposed that shareholders receive 25 percent of Micron's earnings each quarter in a dividend. "When you clear $3 million a day after taxes," he said, referring to the company's recent profits, "I think you've got something awesome."
After a 2-for-1 stock split last May, the company now pays an annual dividend of 20 cents a share. Mr. Simplot has proposed a dividend increase at past meetings; the board did not approve any increase today.
Like many chip companies, Micron is in the midst of a substantial expansion, one it estimates will cost $4 billion; that includes the building of a $2.5 billion chip-making plant in Lehi, Utah, south of Salt Lake City.
But a decline in memory-chip prices, after three years of unusual stability, has spread fears that Micron's heady profit growth will slow. Since Micron has typically financed its expansion by reinvesting its profits, the company is not likely to increase its dividend at a time when it needs cash for growth. Indeed, the board met with bankers today about possibly borrowing money.
Mr. Appleton and his chief technology officer, Tyler Lowrey, face the challenge of completing the production transition to chips on 8-inch silicon wafers from 6-inch wafers, and to refine production of 16-megabit memory chips instead of the current 4-megabit chips that have been its biggest revenue producer.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Odds of Another Oil Crisis: Saudi Stability Plays a Large Role

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Oil Shock III. Could it happen again?
With supplies of oil plentiful and the price of gasoline, adjusted for inflation, as low as it was in the bountiful 1950's, the notion that the world will go through another spike in oil prices like those in 1973-74 and 1979 seems farfetched. And with Iraq apparently on the verge of re-entering the market, nothing is likely to change soon. Indeed, prices may fall for a while. 
 But some oil industry experts -- worried that Saudi Arabia, the linchpin of the world oil market, may be more vulnerable politically than is generally believed -- are raising the specter of an oil price surge for the first time in years.
The talk has intensified because of the possibility, remote as it may be, of a battle to succeed the ailing King Fahd between Crown Prince Abdullah, the King's half-brother, and Prince Sultan, a full brother. Both men control large armies.
On Jan. 1, the 74-year-old King handed over authority to Crown Prince Abdullah, 72, for an unspecified time while he recovered from exhaustion. The Crown Prince, long designated to succeed the King, is known as an Arab nationalist who may be less open than King Fahd to American policies.
Civil war between rivals for power or between the Sunni majority and the Shiite minority cannot be ruled out, says Donald P. Hodel, a Secretary of Energy under President Ronald Reagan. And any instability in Saudi Arabia, which sits on 25 percent of the world's proven oil reserves, or 260 billion barrels, would have wide repercussions. The tendency in the United States, he warns, has been to "go merrily on our way as if there is no potential problem to world oil supply until it is too late."
"Sadly," Mr. Hodel added, "the consequences can be devastating."
Political leaders and industry executives generally say that there is nothing to worry about. Another oil crisis is always possible, they concede, but highly unlikely. The United Nations World Economic and Social Survey 1995 predicts that the real price for oil will remain roughly constant for the next 20 years.
"Nobody can say it won't happen," said Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Texaco Inc. "But an earthquake on the San Andreas Fault is more apt to happen than a disruption in oil."
Is that confidence overdone?
Saudi Arabia is still vital to feed the world's growing appetite for oil, which now totals about 62 million barrels a day. The Saudis provide a little more than 8 million of the 17 million barrels of oil that flow from the Middle East. And even though output outside the region has been growing, there is not enough reserve capacity to fill the void if Saudi supplies are disrupted.
"The world needs Saudi Arabia," said John H. Lichtblau, the chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a private research group. In the event of upheaval, the question, Mr. Lichtblau said, is, "Will you be killed or just be hurt?"
Experts like Mr. Lichtblau offer the consoling thought that history shows that even the most disruptive political events are unlikely to prevent the pumping of crude oil for long.
Vahan Zanoyan, senior director of a private consulting firm in Washington, the Petroleum Finance Company, generally agrees. He recently argued in an article in Foreign Affairs magazine that Saudi Arabia's leaders were frozen in time and had shown little inclination to respond to the decade-old drop in oil prices by reining in spending by the royal family and its entourage of princes, households and hangers-on.
"If in the next three to four years the Saudi Government resists reforms," he said in an interview, "you will see more often the types of riots and civil unrest partly caused by economic concerns and the rise of more Islamic movements. The oil markets in the world will not watch this kind of thing with detachment."
Yet even in the most difficult case -- one in which a fundamentalist Islamic group seizes power in Saudi Arabia -- the new government would only hurt itself if it cut off the supply of oil for a sustained period, he said, adding, "Sooner or later, the new leaders would have to export oil."
The best protection against a temporary cutoff in supplies lies in the United States Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which holds about 600 million barrels, enough to meet American needs for 90 to 120 days. But growing complacency about the risk of another oil shock is leading some lawmakers to look at the reserve as a source of revenue today rather than an insurance policy for tomorrow. Senate Republicans have proposed selling 39 million barrels from the reserve to help reduce the budget deficit. And most companies have cut their own inventories of oil, leaving the nation with a smaller margin of protection.
Specialists also say that there is little will on the part of the public, political leaders or the oil industry to lessen the vulnerability by increasing conservation or supporting alternative energy sources.
"At the moment we're just letting things drift," said James R. Schlesinger, Energy Secretary under President Jimmy Carter, "when we should be alert to finding possible contingencies."
In the event of a crisis, the most likely outcome, many experts say, will not be a complete shutoff but the risk that any new leadership will decide to sacrifice maximum income for a while, cutting production over time in a bid to push up prices.
But not everybody is confident that the worst can be avoided. Milton Copulos, president of the National Defense Council Foundation, a conservative group in Washington, raised the possibility of an oil crisis at Congressional hearings last year. "The optimists assume that the Arabs are exclusively motivated by economics," Mr. Copulos said. "The Ayatollah Khomeini was not motivated by economics. Other militants are not motivated by economics."
Ultimately, of course, there is always the option of military force.
Walter E. Boomer, president of the Babcock & Wilcox Generation Group and a former Marine lieutenant general who was involved in the Persian Gulf war, said the United States had already shown its commitment in the war to defend Western interests in the Middle East. "If the country is threatened," he said, "we would make that commitment again."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1986 words

HEADLINE: Unions Try to Push Past Workers' Fears to Sign Up Poultry Plants in South

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: HAZLEHURST, Miss.

 BODY:
Cantrail Berry recalls the day Rossco Johnson showed up at the Sanderson Farms chicken processing plant, driving a shiny black, souped-up pickup truck with a throaty Floatmaster muffler, chrome-plated wheels and the Laborers' International Union of North America logo painted in gold on the doors.
Automobile envy soon gave way to talk of Mr. Berry's grueling job on the assembly line, picking chickens out of giant vats and hanging them from hooks on an overhead belt, reaching in and reaching up 10 to 12 chickens a minute. After 30 days of furtive, one-on-one organizing, Mr. Johnson had persuaded Mr. Berry, 24, and some of his friends to organize a labor union at the Sanderson plant in Collins, and then here in Hazlehurst. 
 "The idea of the union frightened me at first," Mr. Berry said. "But I knew it was time to make a change. The way the supervisors were harassing us and calling us 'boy,' I knew we had to get respect."
Increasingly, this courtship is being played out at poultry processing plants across Mississippi, Arkansas and Georgia as the nation's once-powerful industrial labor unions, struggling to bolster sagging membership and influence, go after a kind of worker they once ignored.
In the flush days of the American labor movement, workers like Mr. Berry made too little money and worked in states far too hostile to organized labor to attract its attention. Even as layoffs mounted in labor's traditional strongholds -- the North and Midwest -- unions focused on winning higher wages for existing members rather than seeking to expand.
Now, with the nation's economy being largely driven by nonunion businesses, many of them in the South and Southwest, the labor movement cannot be so choosy. In recent months, organizers have been fanning across the region into the plants of poultry giants like Tyson Foods and Perdue Farms.
"There is a quiet resurgence in organizing, and it is in the South and it is in the poultry industry," said Richard Bensinger, the executive director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Organizing Institute, which trains organizers for union campaigns. "This is a real opportunity for the labor movement, but I don't know whether we will be writing 10 years from now that we used it or that we blew it."
That opportunity brings with it a formidable challenge. Labor organizers are not only trying to make inroads in the South, hostile territory where union membership has historically been a rarity, but are also trying to work within an industry with a low level of union membership; only 20 percent of its 200,000 workers nationwide belong to unions. While it is too early to predict the ultimate outcome of organizers' efforts, labor's record is even so far: it has won over about as many poultry plants as it has lost.
While poultry companies are reacting to the onslaught by saying they are not concerned, they are vigorously opposing union campaigns.
 
Great Resistance To Labor Unions
What labor is greedily eyeing is an industry whose explosive growth has helped fuel the South's economic success. The poultry industry once consisted of many small companies and thousands of plants scattered across the country, but it is now dominated by a few giants whose plants are mostly concentrated in the South.
It is also an industry with jobs that are among the least attractive and lowest paid, along the chilled, wet "disassembly line," where chickens are halved and quartered, snipped and rended at an unrelenting pace.
For decades, trying to organize these workers was a Sisyphean task, the result of the region's right-to-work laws, which allow nonunion shops and give workers in unionized shops the option to stay out of unions and pay no dues. Unions' difficulties in the South reflect political and social bias against unions, the reliance of rural economies on local poultry plants and the intractability of race and sex discrimination among some locally important employers.
"But the whole country has become the South in terms of low wages," Mr. Bensinger said, making the region's poultry industry the perfect proving ground for a resurgence of labor organizing.
So great is the organizing potential of these factories that rival unions are competing. Mr. Johnson's Laborers' union and Unite, an offshoot of the Textile Workers of America United, are venturing into plants that had been the province of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union.
The July vote in Sanderson's Collins plant was breathtakingly close, with 17 votes spelling union victory. And only half the 1,300 employees joined. It was only in October, after the union successfully organized the Sanderson plant here in Hazlehurst, that management came to the bargaining table. Negotiations produced a new contract paying $6.90 an hour to one-year employees, making the Sanderson workers the highest-paid processing plant workers in Mississippi.
There have been some defeats for the unions as well, an indication that they sometimes face an uphill battle. A vote last December at Tyson's plant in Canton, Miss., went against the union by a 2-to-1 margin. A union was also rejected at a Perdue plant in Dothan, Ala., amid union accusations of management-inspired cross burnings aimed at intimidating black workers. Nonunion forces also triumphed at Perdue plants in Lewiston, N.C., and Robersonville, N.C.
Perhaps because there has been a rough parity between management and union victories in the last 18 months, industry representatives insist that they are not concerned about organizing efforts. Richard Lobb, a spokesman for the National Broiler Council, which represents the industry's 45 major companies, said that the council did not focus on union issues and did not help members defeat union campaigns.
"It's just not an issue that we really track," Mr. Lobb said.
Archie Schaffer, the spokesman for Tyson Foods, the nation's largest poultry company, said that only 11 of Tyson's 80 plants had unions and that even at the unionized plants, most workers had not joined.
 
Working Conditions Top List of Issues
In December, Tyson faced down its most recent union challenge at a newly bought plant in Canton. And Richard Auletta, a spokesman for Perdue Farms, the nation's third-largest chicken producer and processer, said there had been three attempts to organize Perdue plants in the last year. Although all were defeated, they represented the first such attempts by unions in almost 15 years, Mr. Auletta said.
Chicken production in the United States has grown about two-hundredfold in the last six decades, to 6.7 billion birds in 1993 from 34 million in 1934. In that same period, employment in processing plants has grown to 200,000 workers from 19,000, making it second only to automobile parts in manufacturing job growth, said Prof. Marc Linder, an expert at the University of Iowa Law School.
Turnover is high in poultry plants, Professor Linder said, making sustained organizing difficult. The issues for workers tend to be basic, like getting bathroom breaks and protecting employees in an atmosphere of ever-increasing assembly-line speeds. But because many workers are single mothers or recent immigrants who are afraid of losing their jobs, he said, they are reluctant to speak up, much less organize.
The problems of past, unsuccessful labor efforts in the South were recalled by Prof. Herbert Hill, who teaches African-American studies and industrial relations at the University of Wisconsin and who spent 30 years as the labor director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The unions depended on white organizers, generally from the North, Professor Hill said, and did not welcome black grass-roots leadership. The task is even more complicated now that Latin American immigrants form the bulk of the work force at scores of plants, he said.
"The need for outside organizers belonged to another era," Professor Hill said, "and now if you have an approach to the black community for organizing, you need an approach to the Latino community as well. Recognizing this will be decisive in labor's succeeding, and succeeding will be decisive in determining whether the labor movement will survive."
Officials of Sanderson Farms refused to comment on union efforts at their plants and refused to allow a reporter to visit the sites. But organizers and workers said in off-site interviews that the company had put up a ferocious fight. The company required workers, during their shifts, to attend meetings where managers recounted the disadvantages of unions, showed films of violent strikes and, Mr. Berry said, hinted that people would lose their jobs if the union was approved.
Mr. Johnson said the Sanderson company, with four processing plants in Mississippi, had been prepared to shift production if Collins workers had gone on strike. "That's why we needed the Hazlehurst plant organized," he said. "And the union's national officers gave us the resources that we needed."
 
A Union Defeat At a Modern Plant
 It was a different story 50 miles to the north, at the Tyson plant in Canton, where employees soundly defeated the union by a 2-to-1 margin. Workers like Dottie Spencer, who is 29, said they had tired of fighting the plant's previous owner, McCarty Farms, which had fought unionization through the courts.
So when Tyson bought the plant last year, just as a new union vote was scheduled, Ms. Spencer said, workers reasoned that it was perhaps time to give the new owner some maneuvering room and themselves another chance at higher pay.
A visitor recently found plant employees toiling at a seemingly leisurely pace along conveyor belts that carry chickens and chicken parts through the chilly room, kept at 50 degrees.
In the last 18 months, the plant has installed mechanized deboning machines that flay 82 thigh and breast pieces a minute. There is a year-old cutting machine that reduces whole birds to legs, wings, breasts and thighs. Next to it is the marinating machine, with 244 closely set needles that inject lemon pepper, lime herb seasoning or Tyson's spicy marinade into pieces before they are frozen.
The plant has none of the storied, Dickensian-feel of some other plants where workers with knives stand shoulder-to-shoulder at the assembly line, cutting, eviscerating, deboning and marinating chicken parts at breakneck speed. The repetitive motions often leave workers' hands swollen or even crippled.
But even automated plants need workers with scissors to trim fat at a hand-cramping eight pieces a minute. So the work remains hard.
"I wouldn't do that for $50 an hour with these hands," said Ms. Spencer, holding up manicured nails. She works in the packing area, where hands are subject to extreme cold, but comparatively little repetitive motion. "I need my hands. Plus, once you lose your hands, the company doesn't need you."
That same sense of self-preservation motivated Ms. Spencer and her co-workers to vote against the union in late November. She said she just would not trust anyone to speak for her because most labor activists of four years ago are gone -- dismissed or disabled. Anyway, she said, Tyson hinted at higher wages and, after the union's defeat, it delivered. Wages went up to $6.60 an hour, up from $6.25 an hour in August, just after Tyson bought the plant.
"And we are supposed to get a raise to $6.90 an hour in July," said Joyce Miggins, who works with Ms. Spencer. "The only thing that I could see that would make me vote for the union is if they didn't keep their promise to give us a raise."
Wayne B. Butler, who manages Tyson's Canton plant and three others, said: "People in the industry in times gone by who have unions have deserved them because they didn't know how to treat their people." By contrast, Mr. Butler said, "we're responsible for these people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Once-powerful industrial unions are trying to make inroads into a historically hostile segment of the economy: poultry processing plants in the South. One newly unionized site is the Tyson Foods plant in Hazlehurst, Miss., where workers along an assembly line cut up pieces of chicken. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Whitman Plans Welfare Limits And Incentives to Promote Work

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed an overhaul of the state welfare program today that would provide more help to ease the transition to work and would let beneficiaries earn more outside income.
Calling her proposal "tough love at its best," Governor Whitman said the state would match this generosity with sternness. Benefits would be limited to five years, recipients would have to stay current with child support payments, and teen-age recipients would have to stay in school and live with a parent or other adult. 
 The proposals, outlined in the Governor's annual budget message to the State Legislature, borrow from dozens of pilot programs in other states and from proposed changes in the Federal welfare rules agreed to on Capitol Hill. In drawing up her plan, Mrs. Whitman has remained on the moderate Republican course she has set for her administration in her first two years in office.
For example, she avoided many of the strictest proposals backed in other states, including a 21-month limit on beneficiaries put into effect by Gov. John S. Rowland of Connecticut. And her plan includes not just more money for child care and job training, but a call for state-provided job counseling and help negotiating conflicts between welfare beneficiaries and employers.
To put her proposals into action, Mrs. Whitman needs the approval of the State Legislature and the Federal Government. Although she made the proposal in her budget address, she put no overall dollar figure on her welfare plan. She only said that it would cost no more than the state now spends on welfare.
"President Clinton has challenged the states to come up with ways to reform welfare," Mrs. Whitman said. "Mr. President, I accept that challenge," she added, to thunderous applause in the chambers of the General Assembly. "Give us block grants or give us waivers. But give New Jersey the green light to end welfare as we've known it -- now."
Mrs. Whitman also announced that she would support a proposal by the State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, to enable New Jerseyans to deduct their property taxes from their state income tax returns, as they could before 1990. The measure would cost about $200 million and is not included in the Governor's proposed $16 billion spending plan for the new fiscal year.
Mrs. Whitman also did not say how she would come up with $400 million to replenish the expired fund that pays for hospital care for the poor. The Governor said in her budget message that she intended to reduce overall state spending slightly, by less than 1 percent, but did not offer many specifics.
Senior Whitman administration officials began last week to make public some details of the budget, but the actual document will not be available until late next month, officials said. However, officials said that cuts would be proposed for several state agencies, particularly in the Departments of Environmental Protection and Human Services. And they are proposing to trim $26 million from the state's prescription program for the elderly by making it off-limits to 33,000 seniors who have liquid assets of $50,000 and greater.
The Whitman administration's spending plan assumes moderate growth in the state's economy, even though some economists see recent signs that the state's economy is weakening. Federal unemployment figures were 7.3 percent in December, and 7,000 workers from AT&T will be laid off in the coming months. The administration, however, assumes that fewer jobs will be created this year as in the previous year, which raises questions about how easy it will be for welfare recipients to find work in a declining economy.
"Certainly, any of those welfare reforms are going to be much easier in an up economy rather than a slowing economy," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. "If we have vigorous job growth, the question of job availability would be answered."
In New Jersey, the state spends almost $1 billion on welfare. There are almost 117,000 families, mostly single-parent homes, receiving welfare benefits that average $424 a month. There are 35,021 single adults or childless couples receiving an average of $140 a month in general assistance. The Whitman administration's goal is reduce the welfare rolls by 15 percent within five years.
Democrats were generally supportive of the Whitman proposal, noting that the author of the state's most recent welfare changes, State Senator Wayne Bryant of Camden, had been pressing for a requirement that teenagers on welfare live at home, provided that they were not victims of abuse or incest. But the Democratic Senator said he is opposed to a five-year time limit. "When you start insisting that one size fits all," he said, "that's what the Federal Government had been doing for years and that is what we are trying to get away from at the state level."
Governor Whitman's welfare program, called Work First New Jersey, would shift focus from providing recipients with job training and education programs aimed at obtaining jobs with competitive salaries and benefits to training and placing recipients in lower-paying, entry-level positions that do not necessarily offer health benefits. "We are saying that people have to start somewhere," said William Waldman, Commissioner of Human Services.
To assist those who get jobs, Mr. Waldman said that the program envisions offering more intensive job-counseling services, training and home visits. And if a new worker has problems with a boss, the state would provide "coaches" to intervene and try to smooth things over.
Under the current system, welfare recipients who find jobs lose their benefits. Under the Whitman proposal, they would preserve most of their benefits on a sliding scale. The administration would seek a waiver from the Federal Government, allowing them to increase the level of earnings a recipient might collect before losing eligibility.
Currently, a mother of two could earn up to $750 a month before losing eligibility. The new proposal would allow her to earn $848 a month. After leaving the welfare rolls, she would be able to keep her child-care benefits for one year, and Medicaid for two -- just as she can now.
The plan allows participants to keep up to 100 percent of their earned income for the first month of employment and 50 percent of their income without losing benefits until they exceed income eligibility requirements.
The Whitman administration plan would double the investment the state now makes in supporting work activities and child care. The new plan also would expand available day-care services. At present, only 13,000 families have children in state-supported child-care programs. The Whitman proposal would also provide vouchers to participants to help them pay for transportation to their new jobs and to cover other work-related expenses.
Mrs. Whitman said that in exchange for this support, recipients would be required to show some "personal responsibility." Her plan would require mothers 18 or younger to live with a parent or a guardian and remain in school to remain eligible for benefits. The program also would require them to name their child's father and obtain a court order for child support.
After five years, recipients would be dropped from the welfare rolls.
Advocates for the poor called the time limit unfair. "The problem with time limits is that as long as we have unemployment there will be parents who can not find a job," said Mark Greenburg, senior staff attorney at the Center for Law and Justice in Washington.
Senior Whitman administration officials said that a limited number of hardship exemptions would be granted, but they would not exceed 15 percent and would be determined on a case-by-case basis.
 
WHITMAN'S PROPOSALS
Highlights of the Budget
 
Following are the main recommendations of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's 1997 budget proposal.
 
WELFARE
 
The centerpiece of Governor Whitman's 1997 budget proposal is her welfare program. It calls for these intiatives:
 
Reducing the number of people on welfare rolls to 109,000, from the current 117,000, in five years by forcing most recipients off the rolls after five years, while encouraging recipients to seek jobs.
 
Requiring teen-age parents on welfare to live at home or under adult supervision.
 
Allowing recipients to earn up to $848 a month without losing their grants, up from the current limit of $750. Grant levels would remain unchanged at $424 a month for a mother with two children.
 
Entitling recipients to have up to $2,000 in savings -- up from $1,000 -- and still qualify for welfare.
 
THE ELDERLY
 
Programs for the elderly covering prescription subsidies, counseling, transportation and nursing home information would be consolidated into a new Department of Health and Senior Services.
 
TAX CUTS
 
Property owners would be allowed to deduct their property taxes from state income tax, at a cost to the state of $200 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Again Set Records, Led by Drug Issues
The stock market rose, as the Dow industrials marched past 5,300 points for the first time, closing at 5,304.98, up 33.23, on strong corporate earnings and hopes for an interest rate cut.
Drug stocks and cyclical issues were particularly strong. Merck climbed 1, to 68 7/8, after announcing a study demonstrating that an experimental drug reduced the AIDS-causing virus to undetectable levels. [Page D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply, weighed down by a weaker dollar, an increase in the supply of new debt coming to market and a rush of new economic data. [D16.]
 
Norwest to Buy Prudential Unit
Norwest said it would buy Prudential Home Mortgage, the mortgage-lending unit of Prudential Insurance, and half its mortgage-processing business to bolster its No. 1 position in the mortgage industry. [D4.]
 
Loewen Settles Suit; Shares Surge
The Loewen Group, a Canadian funeral home chain, agreed to settle for $175 million a Mississippi lawsuit that it said would have pushed the company toward bankruptcy. Its shares rose $8.50, to $29, even though Loewen faces another suit in Philadelphia. [D5.]
 
A U.S. Battle Over Siberian Logging
A forestry project by American entrepreneurs and their Russian partners to use gamma-ray technology to kill pests in Siberian logs to be exported to the United States has stirred the ire of environmentalists. [A3.]
 
Micron Mum on Reconciliation
Steve Appleton, Micron Technology's chief executive, was back on board Friday just a week after resigning. But at a shareholders' meeting in Boise, Idaho, he declined to explain his actions. [D4.]
 
Compaq Tops List of PC Sellers
Compaq Computer retained its top ranking among the world's PC marketers last year, but I.B.M. edged past Apple as No. 2, Dataquest said. Worldwide personal computer sales grew nearly 25 percent, to 59.7 million. [D4.]
 
NEC Tops Japanese List
In Japan, local PC makers outsold American rivals last year, Dataquest Japan reported. NEC kept its No. 1 position, followed by Fujitsu. Apple Computer dropped to third place from second in 1994. [D4.]
 
Texaco Names Bijur Chairman
Texaco named Peter I. Bijur, a 53-year-old senior vice president with wide experience overseas, to succeed Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. as chairman and chief executive on July 1. [D5.]
 
Investors' Group Seeks Sassco
An investment group led by Three Cities Research is offering to buy Sassco, the most profitable division of the Leslie Fay Companies, the women's apparel maker, for $240 million in cash and stock. Neither the creditor committee to which the offer was sent nor the company has responded. [D2.]
 
MCI and Microsoft: Internet Allies
MCI Communications, which already has an on-line partnership with the News Corporation, announced an alliance with Microsoft to develop and market on-line and Internet services. Bert C. Roberts, MCI's chairman and chief executive, said, "We are pushing our boat into Microsoft's waters as we go forward." [D2.]

Wall Street Skeptical of Old Navy
As trendy shoppers picked through shelves of cheap overalls and sweatshirts at Gap's Old Navy clothing stores during the Christmas season, investors cast a more jaundiced eye on Gap stock, fearful Old Navy's profit margins were too skimpy. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Mayor Plans To Eliminate Five Agencies

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Redrawing the blueprint of New York City's municipal bureaucracy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to propose eliminating at least five city agencies -- including the Department of Transportation -- and consolidating their functions into other offices, senior aides said yesterday.
The proposals, part of the preliminary budget the Mayor is to unveil tomorrow, could save millions of dollars by consolidating administrative positions and functions. The aides said they would not result in any layoffs but would allow the city to reduce its payroll of more than 200,000 workers through attrition and streamline services. 
 First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani would model the proposals on the the merger of the city's three police forces last year. The merger has, by all accounts, freed many police officers from administrative duties. Now, for the first time, Mr. Giuliani has proposed reducing the total police force of 38,000 officers, by 1,000.
As a candidate and as Mayor, Mr. Giuliani has pledged to reinvent the city's sprawling bureaucracy. But in his first two years, he has accomplished little in that regard beyond the police merger and the consolidation of some smaller divisions, like moving the Parking Violations Bureau into the Department of Finance.
With the new proposals, Mr. Giuliani would significantly reshape government. They also come after his proposals earlier this month to create two new agencies -- one to oversee child protective services and another to handle emergency management.
"This is part of reinventing government," Mr. Powers said.
Under the proposals, the aides said, the Department of Transportation's functions would be parceled out to a variety of agencies. Its entire traffic-enforcement division would move to the Police Department and bridge construction to the city's new capital construction agency.
Mr. Powers said the department's maintenance and repair functions would be consolidated into a new agency tentatively called the Department of Infrastructure Maintenance, as would those of the Department of General Services, which maintains the city's 42 office buildings. The administrative and contract functions of general services, as well as those of the Department of Personnel, would merge into another agency called the Department of Citywide Administrative Services.
In the case of transportation, the plan would undo the consolidation of the department in 1977, under Mayor Abraham D. Beame, from a variety of other agencies that had overseen bridges and highways. Mr. Powers said it did not make sense to have one agency handle such diverse functions as traffic enforcement, collection of fines and construction.
Other senior aides, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the city's Community Development Agency would also absorb the Department of Youth Services and the Department of Employment. Both those agencies, like the development agency, award contracts to private or nonprofit organizations that provide recreational, educational or job-training services.
All of the consolidations would require the approval of the City Council as part of the Mayor's overall budget. Any or all could be blocked, as was the case with previous consolidation proposals floated by Mr. Giuliani and his predecessors. And even before the latest proposals became public, there were signs yesterday of potential opposition, both from advocacy groups and officials of the Council.
Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the Council would evaluate the proposals as part of the Mayor's overall plan to close a budget gap for the new fiscal year that has grown to at least $2 billion. His response, however, showed a degree of skepticism.
"We'll see if any of these proposals really make sense or if the administration is just rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic," he said.
Elliot G. Sander, Commissioner of the Department of Transportation, declined to comment on the proposal. It remained unclear of what would happen to the commissioners now heading the agencies once the consolidations took effect with the new fiscal year on July 1. Mr. Powers said that no decisions had been made.
The idea of disbanding the Department of Transportation, with its budget of $500 million and its payroll of 6,149 workers, is not new. Lucius J. Riccio, the Commissioner of Transportation under Mayor David N. Dinkins, proposed a consolidation of its functions twice before, in 1992 and 1993, with no success.
Mr. Riccio said yesterday that the idea made sense because the department had grown unwieldy since its inception two decades ago. "I think it was too large and diverse a department to be manageable," he said. "Each one of these functions makes more sense in other places."
Others disagreed. Two advocacy groups, Transportation Alternatives and the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, said dismantling the agency would fragment planning and relegate long-term planning to a secondary status within city government.
"Who's going to deal with the global transportation issues?" said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives.

HEADLINE: Logging in Siberia Sets Off a Battle in the U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
A team of American entrepreneurs and their Russian partners have devised a novel way to turn cold-war atomic expertise to peacetime profits: by sterilizing Russian logs with radiation to make them safe for export to the United States.
Backers call the plan a shining example of one nation helping another to beat bombs into buzz saws. But opponents see it as part of an environmentally reckless raid on the planet's greatest conifer forests. 
 Already, the proposal has received financial support from a little-known venture fund sponsored by the Pentagon, and condemnation from a conservation group that likewise gets Federal aid.
It is one of many joint forestry projects encouraged by the American timber industry and the Russian Federation, the kind of venture that Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia are striving to nurture at their latest economic consultations in Washington this week.
The idea is to bombard timber harvested in Siberia with gamma rays, emitted by radioactive cobalt, killing any pests that might accidentally infest American forests as the logs are shipped to American sawmills in the Pacific Northwest, where environmental laws have constrained logging.
Supporters say the project would employ thousands of Russians and earn millions of foreign-exchange dollars while preserving American sawmill jobs.
But environmentalists fear that unfettered logging could damage virgin forests and the habitat of rare species in the vast Siberian wilderness. They are also skeptical of the safety and effectiveness of the gamma-ray technology, a sterilization method that caused a stir in the United States a few years ago when companies proposed marketing similarly processed raw foods, and that is now permitted but not widespread.
Finally, the critics question the merit for Russia of building up a timber industry based primarily on exports of unfinished goods.
None of this has diminished the powerful lure of the Siberian forests for American investors, often operating with Government subsidies.
In September, the Defense Enterprise Fund, a private, nonprofit American venture capital company, agreed to invest $1 million in the wood irradiation project. The fund, which received its initial capital from the Defense Department, seeks to convert arms producers of the former Soviet Union into businesses serving nonmilitary markets.
The project's for-profit American investors, led by REM Capital Corporation of Arlington, Va., have promised that as many as 11 radiation plants in Russia would supply enough timber to sawmills in this country to preserve domestic sawmill jobs, lower wood prices and fill what they call a gap in domestic timber supplies. The investment could approach $100 million, said Ronald E. Muller, REM's chairman.
Leaders of 47 American and Russian environmental groups wrote to Vice President Gore last month to express "alarm" about several timber projects, saying Siberia and the Russian Far East could be transformed into "a massive whole-log export colony."
"Siberia and the Russian Far East offer some wonderful opportunities for both protecting biodiversity and creating a model of sustainable development, rather than promoting an economy based on the export of natural resources," said David Gordon, head of the Siberian forests protection project at the Pacific Environment and Resources Center, a nonprofit group in Sausalito, Calif.
At a White House meeting on Jan. 10, environmentalists called for assurances that all such projects comply with both long-standing American environmental regulations and untested new Russian rules.
In 1994, the two countries signed a memorandum of understanding to expand Russian forest products industries, calling for millions of dollars in trade of wood, pulp, paper products and related equipment.
A separate understanding pledges the two Governments to cooperate in environmental protection, and several agencies are carrying out projects in Russia to promote sustainable forestry, replanting, fire prevention and the like.
A report by the Pacific Environmental and Resources Center, which is critical of the broad timber initiative, cited these actions on various logging proposals:
*The Commerce Department's Trade and Development Administration has granted $500,000 to Global Forestry Management Group, a consortium of Pacific Northwest sawmills, for a feasibility study of logging millions of acres of old-growth forests in Khabarovsk, perhaps including areas where the rare Siberian tiger is sometimes found.
*The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which provides political-risk insurance and other subsidies, is considering several logging ventures, including the Global Forestry Management Group project.
*The Export-Import Bank, which provides lending assistance to promote trade, is working on an agreement that would ease Russian borrowing to buy logging equipment.
*Various privately managed, nonprofit enterprise corporations that receive their initial capital from Federal tax dollars are supporting forestry projects, including the Russian-American Ionized Energy Services' gamma-rays plan.
Russian-American Ionized Energy Services is a joint venture incorporated in the United States. Its founding shareholders are REM Capital Corporation; the V. G. Khlopini Radium Institute of St. Petersburg, Russia, and the institute's parent organization, the Russian Federation's Ministry for Atomic Radiation. Other investors include a Norwegian shipping concern, the Russian investment arm of Paine Webber, and the newly privatized Russian Forestry Industrial Company.
The plans, supporters say, would yield hundreds of millions of board feet of timber, directly employing 11,000 Russians in the radiation plants and indirectly many times more in the woods, while supplying American sawmills that employ 100,000 workers. In addition, they would earn hard currency for Russia and keep down wood prices in the United States, supporters say.
The opposition is led by the Pacific Environment and Resources Center, which has received environmental protection grants from the United States Agency for International Development.
Although environmentalists have questioned the safety and effectiveness of the nuclear treatments, their main objection is not to the use of radiation to sterilize the wood. They contend that the planned projects will seriously damage the forests and that exporting whole logs would do relatively little to create jobs and help the Russian economy.
Sponsors of the project say they expect Washington regulatory agencies to approve the technique for use in controlling pests in wood products.
They even claim a potential environmental benefit: radiation treatments could substitute for the fumigation of wood chips with methyl bromide, which is often used on chips exported to the United States from countries like Chile and New Zealand. Use of methyl bromide is being phased out because its emissions damage the atmosphere's protective ozone layer, a major environmental concern. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about proposed timber imports from Russia referred incorrectly to a Federal agency that issued a grant for a feasibility study of logging old-growth forests in Siberia. It is the U.S. Trade and Development Agency, not the Trade and Development Administration; it is an independent agency, not a part of the Commerce Department.
